title_text: Wedding necklace with flowers and case Wedding necklace with flowers
physical_appearance: The image shows a gold necklace that is placed inside an open container. The container is triangular but with curved sides instead. It has a blue padding at the top and dark blue cushion at the bottom to hold the necklace in place. The necklace is gold in colour. It is made up of several chains that link panels depicting flowery and foliage designs together. A pendant hangs from the necklace and there are three segments to it.
subject_terms_1: jewellery goldwork (visual works) neck ornaments cases (containers) filigree flower (motif) foliage (motif) costume accessories weddings (ceremonies)
subject_terms_2: Gold jewellery Goldwork Necklaces Containers Filigree Motifs Ethnic jewellery Dress accessories Marriage customs and rites
sgcool_label_text:
This gold wedding necklace is richly decorated with filigree panels that are embellished with flowers and leaves. Peonies are a symbol of love, affection, feminine beauty, and spring, making them auspicious flowers for weddings. The intricacy and refinement of the necklace indicate the importance of jewellery in Peranakan weddings.

Wedding necklaces such as this were worn by Peranakan Chinese brides throughout the Straits Settlements and the Dutch East Indies. The ornateness of this example appears to have originated from Jakarta (Batavia), although the exceptional quality of the necklace makes a precise geographical assignment difficult. Brides were draped with several necklaces to form an impressive assemblage and other jewelled ornamentation as a sign of the wealth and splendour of the occasion. Such necklaces became prized family heirlooms and were passed down the generations.

column51: This photo album contain various images of Singapore that were taken during Robert Arthur Polglaze's time in Singapore during the 1940s. Polglaze signed with the Judge Advocate General's section when was 16 years old, and was posted to Singapore about a year later. He was posted to Singapore during the latter stages of the Japanese Occupation, as he was present in the room of the Japanese Surrender as seen in some of the photographs of the surrender proceedings. Other photographs in the album also include scenes of the Singapore River, Katong and Collyer Quay.

sgcool_label_text:
Being Together, 2010 – 2012 
by John Clang (b. 1973) 

Artist Statement: 
In this series, webcam was used to do live recording of families in Singapore. The recording was then transmitted via skype to countries where the main sitters are located and projected onto their living space. This is how families, dis(membered) through time and space, can be re(membered) and made whole again through the use of a third space, a site that is able to reassemble them together within the photographic space that we call a family portrait.

Drawing upon my own experiences of being separated from my family as a New York-based Singaporean, this work documents and examines our condition of new-wave diaspora – Singaporean families of various races and ethnicities grappling with the same predicament of separation through time and space.

I also want this project to document and interpret a contemporary social-historical blueprint as it happens, allowing the future generations to reflect on it.

In addition, this is also an extension of one of the recurring theme of my works: the fascination with the expressions of time and space and how we negotiate our human existences within these two dimensions. this work specifically addresses the phenomenon of differing time zones, the different dimensions of our human representations, and how we can finally coexist, albeit in pixilated and two-dimensional forms.

About the artist-photographer:
John Clang is a photographer and visual artist. His fascination on time, displacement and existentialism influence his work. He held his first exhibition at 20 years old and has since participated in more than 20 solo & group exhibitions in China, France, Hong Kong, Italy, Malaysia, Singapore and the United States. In 2010, he became the first photographer in Singapore to receive the President's Designer of the Year award, which is the most prestigious design accolade in Singapore. Clang was also selected by a panel of jury from over 400 nominated entries, as one of the 30 finalists for the 2010 Sovereign Asian Art Prize.

A family is featured and they are all sitting down and looking towards the direction in which the photograph was captured. There is a total of four adults whose images are projected on a screen. Their images are juxtaposed with two ladies, who are both holding a soft toy in their arms. There is a toy vending machine at the extreme left hand side of the photograph.
subject_terms_1: group portraits colour photographs families (kinship groups)
subject_terms_2: Portraits, Group Portrait photography Colour photography Families Singaporeans
subject_terms_3: Portrait photography Clang, John Visual Arts
sgcool_label_text:
Being Together, 2010 – 2012 
by John Clang (b. 1973) 

Artist Statement: 
In this series, webcam was used to do live recording of families in Singapore. The recording was then transmitted via skype to countries where the main sitters are located and projected onto their living space. This is how families, dis(membered) through time and space, can be re(membered) and made whole again through the use of a third space, a site that is able to reassemble them together within the photographic space that we call a family portrait.

Drawing upon my own experiences of being separated from my family as a New York-based Singaporean, this work documents and examines our condition of new-wave diaspora – Singaporean families of various races and ethnicities grappling with the same predicament of separation through time and space.

I also want this project to document and interpret a contemporary social-historical blueprint as it happens, allowing the future generations to reflect on it.

In addition, this is also an extension of one of the recurring theme of my works: the fascination with the expressions of time and space and how we negotiate our human existences within these two dimensions. this work specifically addresses the phenomenon of differing time zones, the different dimensions of our human representations, and how we can finally coexist, albeit in pixilated and two-dimensional forms.

About the artist-photographer:
John Clang is a photographer and visual artist. His fascination on time, displacement and existentialism influence his work. He held his first exhibition at 20 years old and has since participated in more than 20 solo & group exhibitions in China, France, Hong Kong, Italy, Malaysia, Singapore and the United States. In 2010, he became the first photographer in Singapore to receive the President's Designer of the Year award, which is the most prestigious design accolade in Singapore. Clang was also selected by a panel of jury from over 400 nominated entries, as one of the 30 finalists for the 2010 Sovereign Asian Art Prize.

physical_appearance: The image displays a colour photograph printed on a piece of white paper. There is a white border around the perimeter of the photograph. There is a total of four children and six adults whose images are projected on a screen. A child on the left is holding a teddy bear. Their images are juxtaposed with a man, who is holding a teddy bear in his arms as well.

title_text: Erasure (1)
physical_appearance: The image displays a colour photograph printed on a piece of white paper. There is a white border around the perimeter of the photograph. A man is featured in the foreground, but with his face and back facing the direction in which the photograph was captured. He has grey hair and is wearing a short-sleeved shirt and pants. The image of the man has been rubbed out and blurred, leaving a greyish figure and outline amidst the background of a street and shop signs of different colours.
subject_terms_1: colour photographs portraits elderly
subject_terms_2: Portrait photography Colour photography Older people
subject_terms_3: Portrait photography Clang, John Visual Arts
sgcool_label_text:
Artist Statement:
Erasure revolves around my aged parents and parents-in-law in their seventies and their photographs taken during a family trip to Tokyo several years ago. The series title refers to my painstaking act of fading their images from the photographs with an ink eraser as a graphic portrayal of how life quietly empties itself from them. The resulting faint images becomes an urgent testimony of their slowly fading existence from this world, as well as from my life. Ironically, they are resurrected in my emotional space as reawakened memories by the very act of erasure - at once emotionally torment and intimate. Despite the joyous association of a holiday destination, this work speaks of my own uneasy anticipation of their final destination - death.

This dread extends even to the contemplation of my own death. Their fast aging faces become a reflection and questioning of my own mortality - a question I first asked myself many years ago as a child of four: what will happen to me when my parents die? This thought haunts me till this day.

About the artist-photographer:
John Clang is a photographer and visual artist. His fascination on time, displacement and existentialism influence his work. He held his first exhibition at 20 years old and has since participated in more than 20 solo & group exhibitions in China, France, Hong Kong, Italy, Malaysia, Singapore and the United States. In 2010, he became the first photographer in Singapore to receive the President's Designer of the Year award, which is the most prestigious design accolade in Singapore. Clang was also selected by a panel of jury from over 400 nominated entries, as one of the 30 finalists for the 2010 Sovereign Asian Art Prize.

Clang was also selected by a panel of jury from over 400 nominated entries, as one of the 30 finalists for the 2010 Sovereign Asian Art Prize.

title_text: Erasure (2)
physical_appearance: The image displays a colour photograph printed on a piece of white paper. There is a white border around the perimeter of the photograph. A woman is featured in the foreground, but with her face and back facing the direction in which the photograph was captured. She has grey hair and is wearing a blouse and carrying a handbag. The image of the woman has been rubbed out and blurred, leaving a greyish figure and outline amidst the dark background.
subject_terms_1: colour photographs portraits elderly
subject_terms_2: Portrait photography Colour photography Older people
subject_terms_3: Portrait photography Clang, John Visual Arts
sgcool_label_text:
Artist Statement:
Erasure revolves around my aged parents and parents-in-law in their seventies and their photographs taken during a family trip to Tokyo several years ago. The series title refers to my painstaking act of fading their images from the photographs with an ink eraser as a graphic portrayal of how life quietly empties itself from them. The resulting faint images becomes an urgent testimony of their slowly fading existence from this world, as well as from my life. Ironically, they are resurrected in my emotional space as reawakened memories by the very act of erasure - at once emotionally torment and intimate. Despite the joyous association of a holiday destination, this work speaks of my own uneasy anticipation of their final destination - death.

This dread extends even to the contemplation of my own death. Their fast aging faces become a reflection and questioning of my own mortality - a question I first asked myself many years ago as a child of four: what will happen to me when my parents die? This thought haunts me till this day.

About the artist-photographer:
John Clang is a photographer and visual artist. His fascination on time, displacement and existentialism influence his work. He held his first exhibition at 20 years old and has since participated in more than 20 solo & group exhibitions in China, France, Hong Kong, Italy, Malaysia, Singapore and the United States. In 2010, he became the first photographer in Singapore to receive the President's Designer of the Year award, which is the most prestigious design accolade in Singapore. Clang was also selected by a panel of jury from over 400 nominated entries, as one of the 30 finalists for the 2010 Sovereign Asian Art Prize.

sgcool_label_text:
This is an extremely rare book by G.W.A. Trimmer, Chairman and General manager of Harbour Boards, Straits Settlements. It was published in 1933. The book contains a beautifully coloured map of Singapore. 

Mr Trimmer came to Singapore in 1910 and was a significant figure in the development of Singapore's port facilities and trading activities.

sgcool_label_text: These two programmes were of Maurice Clare's violin recitals in Singapore in 1953 and 1954.The Scottish-born violinist had won critical acclaims for his performance, and had performed in Europe, New Zealand, Australia, Indonesia and Japan. When Clare came to Singapore, he held his recitals at the War Memorial Hall at St. Andrew's Cathedral in 1953, and the Victoria Memorial Hall the following year in 1954.

sgcool_label_text: This is a photograph of an unidentified Hindu family in Singapore taken in the early 1900s. Hinduism in Singapore can be traced back to the early 19th century when Indian immigrants arrived in Singapore to work for the British East India Company. The Sri Mariamman Temple in South Bridge Road is the oldest Hindu temple in Singapore, which was established by Narayana Pillay in 1827.

sgcool_label_text: Prior to the World War II period, Indians in Singapore and Malaya retained strong political, sentimental and economic ties with their home country. Anti-colonial thoughts and actions, inspired by the “call for freedom” in India, resonated in the region too. Radio broadcasts, newspaper reports and visits by nationalist leaders strengthened the nationalistic mood among the migrant Indian community. The Indian National Army and Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose brought to the fore this spirit of nationalism. This collection provides rare documentary evidence of the involvement of the region's Indian community in the Indian National Army and the Indian Independence League, the army's fund raising arm. This is a group of war time photographs, newspapers, magazines and ephemera collected by the sixth president of Singapore, Mr.S.R.Nathan.

sgcool_label_text:
fFurious was formed in 1999 by Little Ong and his friends. It is now a multi-disciplinary creative communications company with clients that include advertising agencies, publishing companies, small businesses to MNCs, non-profit organisations and government bodies.
Besides offering services in graphic/motion/interactive design, illustration and photography, fFurious also has non-commercial pursuits in the form of exhibitions and the development of personal art projects that has included short films, and even a comic series.

column51:
The poster marked the event – release of the DVD compilation of Royston Tan’s 13 short films.
 
The poster uses a combination of photographs and simple typography.  The photographs were shot at an old Laundromat in Potong Pasir whereby passer bys were asked to pose.

Royston Tan, (b 1976) is a well known Singaporean film maker.  Among his reputed films are 12 Lotus (2008), 881 (2007) 4.30 (2005) 15, The Movie (2003), and 15 (2002).  He is the recipient of numerous national and international awards

title_text: 0104, a compilation of Royston Tan's films Brochure, 0104, a compilation of Royston Tan's films
physical_appearance: \The image displays a rectangular brochure. \"\"0104 A Showcase of Royston Tan's Short Films\"\" is stated at the centre of the brochure. A man dressed in a white shirt and with white pants is crouching behind the sign that states \"\"0104\"\". He is wearing a headgear that contains bunny ears as well as a pair of shades. The background of the brochure shows greenery and trees.\""
subject_terms_1: film directors short subjects exhibitions (events)
subject_terms_2: Tan, Royston, 1976- Motion pictures, Singaporean Short films Brochures Exhibitions
subject_terms_3: Tan, Royston Short films Movie directors
sgcool_label_text:
0104 was a showcase of Royston Tan’s films at the Alliance Française de Singapour.  

Held in march 2005, 12 of Tan’s 15 short films produced between 2001 and 2004 were screened on two days and the proceeds were used to help another local film-maker, Bertrand Lee, who had his leg amputated as a result of an accident in Mumbai. Before Singapore, the screenings were also held in Chicago, London and Tokyo

The brochure features the photograph of film maker in disguise along with the text in red.

subject_terms_1: dresses (garments) womenswear birds (motifs) costumes (character dress)
subject_terms_2: Qipao Ethnic costume Women's clothing Motifs
sgcool_label_text:
This cheongsam designed for the theatre is quite significant - intended for the actress in the role of a night club owner, the garment in red velvet with an elaborate sequinned motif - seems appropriate for the setting.  The high mandarin collar, raglan shoulder, sleeveless and a highly cut skirt is indicative of the role of a cabaret owner in her 40s.
The costume was tailored for Dr Margaret Chan who played the role of the cabaret owner. 
Beauty World, 1988 is among the most well known Singapore musicals. Written by Michael Chiang, the play was first directed by Ong Keng Sen and presnted by Theatreworks. The songs were writteby Dick Lee.

sgcool_label_text: In the years preceding the Second World War Indian women in Singapore were essentially homemakers and contributed to community work, arts and crafts. This is a bedspread from the collection of the late Lakshmi Rangasamy Davar; she was a woman pioneer – she was an educationist, musician and philanthropist.

subject_terms_2: Ethnic costume Saris Women's clothing Motifs
sgcool_label_text: The sari is a traditional pan-Indian drape, woven in various parts of the sub-continent. Kanchipuram in Tamil Nadu, an illustrious weaving centre, is renowned for the “Kanchivaram Silk Sari”, worn during special occasions as well as by Tamil brides. This collection of saris were donated by Dr.R.D.Gangatharan in memory of his mother, the late Lakshmi Rangasamy Davar. Lakshmi Rangasamy Davar, was a woman pioneer – she was an educationist, musician and philanthropist.

sgcool_label_text: During the Second World War and the and the subsequent Japanese Occupation (1942 – 1945), Indians in Singapore had a diverse range of experiences; some left for India as refugees; some joined the Indian National Army; some were recruited for the Death Railway; and some strove to make ends meet and simply survive. This is a medal given by the Indian National Army to Indra Menon, in recognition of the dance performances she gave to entertain the INA troops stationed in Singapore, as part of the recreational activities organised for them.

sgcool_label_text:
G Sarangapany, titled Thamizhavel, arrived in Singapore in 1924. A believer of Periyar’s principles, he played a key role in extending the Self-Respect Movement to Singapore and Malaya and became the agent for distribution of the movement’s magazine Kudi Arasu in British Malaya. He later helped arrange Periyar’s visits to Singapore and Malaya. 

He was an active writer and publisher in his own right. In 1929 he set up the Tamil magazine Munnetram, and Tamil Murasu in 1935. Through his writings he promoted the principles of the Tamil reform movement. He encouraged Tamils to make Singapore their home, helped them gain citizenship and championed for the cause of the Tamil language to be recognised as one of the national languages in Singapore. This is a collection of archival photographs, documents donated by the family of Sarangapany’s close associate, Murugu Srinivasan.

G Sarangapany, titled Thamizhavel, arrived in Singapore in 1924. A believer of Periyar’s principles, he played a key role in extending the Self-Respect Movement to Singapore and Malaya and became the agent for distribution of the movement’s magazine Kudi Arasu in British Malaya. He later helped arrange Periyar’s visits to Singapore and Malaya. 

He was an active writer and publisher in his own right. In 1929 he set up the Tamil magazine Munnetram, and Tamil Murasu in 1935. Through his writings he promoted the principles of the Tamil reform movement. He encouraged Tamils to make Singapore their home, helped them gain citizenship and championed for the cause of the Tamil language to be recognised as one of the national languages in Singapore. This is a collection of archival photographs, documents donated by the family of Sarangapany’s close associate, Murugu Srinivasan.

title_text: Watercolour Batavia Portraits East Indie Natives
physical_appearance: This is set of watercolour paintings of natives in Batavia. There are six paintings, with every two sharing one frame. There are no inscriptions or signatures found on the paintings.
subject_terms_1: indigenous people ways of life ethnicity cultural diffusion colonialism
subject_terms_2: Watercolour painting Indigenous people Javanese (Indonesian people) Lifestyles Ethnicity Culture diffusion Racially mixed people
sgcool_label_text:
This set of 6 watercolour on paper drawings depict Dutch school observations of Natives in the East Indies. Each full-length portrait is a study of the various ethnic groups from Java as well the distinctive mestizo – persons of mixed European and Indonesian ethnic ancestry. It is likely that this set of watercolour drawings are from 17th century. Costumes worn by mestiza women in Dutch colonial towns indicate a clear 17th century style, characterised by a baju with a V-shaped opening for the head, a selendang, and a wrapped skirt of Indian cloth. 

Listed as an un-authored work of art, elements of the drawing bear strong resemblance to prominent 17th century Dutch artist, Andries Beeckman’s (active 1651-57 Dutch East Indies) watercolour drawings of “A Woman of Batavia”, mid-17th century. A blonde and barefoot mestiza for example, reveals the same composition and formal features as Beeckman’s drawings – Her hair is tied in a chignon and accompanied by curly tresses descending from the side and her body is angled sideways, with her right hand placed upon her head. It is plausible that these drawings are likely to be a copy of Andries Beeckman’s watercolour drawings of the same period.

These watercolour drawings depict a diverse community of ethnic groups from Java, as well the impact of Dutch colonialism in the form of mixed race populations and subsequent impact on social and cultural customs and practices. Such portrayals in watercolour are rare and seldom appear in the open market.

title_text: Watercolour Batavia Portraits East Indie Native: Man with spear
physical_appearance: This is a watercolour painting of a native man in Batavia. He is wearing a coiled scarf around his head, and a piece of cloth tied around his waist. There are a couple of hunting tools tied to his waist. He is holding a spear in his right hand, and a dart in his left hand. He is standing barefoot on the ground.

title_text: Morning Light
materials_name: gelatin  paper (fibre product)  silver sulfide  baryta paper
techniques_name: gelatin silver process photographic printing techniques black-and-white photography
physical_appearance: This is a gelatin silver print and the image captured show the sky and sea meeting in the horizon. A lone boat (sampan) traverses across the water body, and in it sits three individuals. The print is mounted on a white backing; spotting and yellowing can be seen along the ridges of the picture and on the white backing itself. A Royal Photographic Society (RPS) Associate 1957 symbol is embossed in the bottom right corner. The artist's photography studio stamp, along with the title of the work can be found on the verso.
subject_terms_1: sampans seascapes utility boats fishing vessels
subject_terms_2: fishing boats Photography, Artistic  Boats and boating
sgcool_label_text: Ho Koon Sang was a member of the Photographic Society of Singapore and an Associate of the Royal Photographic Society in London. This photograph was part of a set of 12 prints sent to the Royal Photographic Society in 1956.

title_text: keris Javanese keris and sheath
materials_name: wood (plant material) antler (material) gold (metal) steel (alloy) diamond (material)
physical_appearance: This is a keris with a gold-coated sheath. The keris has a narrow, wavy black blade with stylistic pamor patterns, and gold decoratives added near the handle. The handle is carved to resemble the head of a Hindu diety, Kala, and adorned with diamonds. The sheath is a wooden frame, coated in gold and carved with floral motifs.
subject_terms_1: ceremonial weapons daggers (weapons) flower (motif) fetishes
subject_terms_2: Daggers Javanese (Indonesian people) ceremonial objects Motifs
sgcool_label_text:
The extraordinary quality of this keris can be seen in both the valuable materials and high level of craftsmanship used to make it. Such keris were not for ordinary people but only for people of direct royal descent. 

Keris were an important dress accessory and status symbol, as well as a weapon and also were regarded as powerful objects of supernatural protection. The keris was thought to contain a spirit or isi which if properly cared for would ward off both physical and magical injury.

title_text: keris Javanese keris and sheath
physical_appearance: This is a keris with a gold-coated sheath. The keris has a narrow, straight black blade, with stylistic pamor patterns, and gold decoratives of a dragon added near the handle. A small part of the handle has added carvings. The sheath has a wooden frame, coated in gold, carved with floral motifs and adorned with diamonds.
subject_terms_1: ceremonial weapons daggers (weapons) flower (motif) fetishes
subject_terms_2: Daggers Javanese (Indonesian people) ceremonial objects Motifs
sgcool_label_text:
The extraordinary quality of this keris can be seen in both the valuable materials and high level of craftsmanship used to make it. Such keris were not for ordinary people but only for people of direct royal descent.

title_text: Ewer Brass ewer
physical_appearance: This is a brass ewer. It has a pear-shaped body with flat sides. It has a slender handle on the left, and an S-shaped spout on the right. There is a hinged lid, and a circular, flaring base. The body of the ewer is engraved with scrolling arabesque motifs.
subject_terms_1: ablutions ewers (vessels) palmette (motif) scrolls (motifs) Islamic (culture or style)
subject_terms_2: Ewers Ablutions (Islamic law) Motifs Islam
sgcool_label_text: Because the Quran states that “we made everything alive from water” (surah 21:30), ewers carry great significance. Usually paired with a matching basin, ewers are used by Muslims to wash their hands before prayer and many other acitivities. Because of their durability, brass and bronze were commonly used to make ewers and other vessels to hold liquids.

title_text: Pachisi 'bird' set Pachisi 'bird' board game
physical_appearance: This pachisi game set includes a cloth board, sixteen ivory bird-shaped gaming pieces, and three long die. The bird game pieces are stained and grouped into four colours - red, light green, black and yellow. Some design elements, such as the wings, are carved into each piece The board is made of green silk, lined with red cotton, and embroided with yellow thread.
subject_terms_1: board games (game sets) play (recreation)
subject_terms_2: Pachisi Board games Play
sgcool_label_text:
Pachisi is a one of the oldest games originating from the Indian subcontinent. It is often referred to as the national game of India and was played by all groups of society. A pachisi set comprises of a board, several gaming pieces and dice. Pachisi boards are fashioned in a wide variety of types and are often decorated with embroidery or beads. The gaming pieces were also made in various sizes and materials such as ivory, bone, glass, silver, although they were most commonly made of painted wood. 
Pieces that were made in the form of female musicians or birds are considered exotic.

title_text: Altar cloth Embroidered Peranakan Tokwi
physical_appearance: This is an altar cloth that is embroided with gold thread, and decorated with motifs. It is split into two panels. The top panel has the top folded down, with two cloth hooks by the side. The top panel features ritual vessels such as censors and incense burners, with a lion and a crane. The lower panel is decorated with phoenixes, quails, chickens, magpies, and peacocks, intersparsed with large peonies. The decorations are bordered by a black outline.
subject_terms_1: ceremonial objects flower (motif) birds (motifs) embroidery (visual works)
subject_terms_2: Altar-cloths Chinese New Year decorations Motifs Embroidery, Peranakan
sgcool_label_text:
The altar cloth is embroidered with gold and silk thread, possibly made in the Straits Settlements. The upper panel is decorated by embroidered ritual vessels and such as censors and incense burners, as well as a lion and crane. The lower panel is very crowded and decorated by phoenixes, quails, a cock and hen, magpies and peacocks. Large peonies also intersperse the animals.

 Altar cloths are Chinese textiles hung on the household altar during special occasions such as Chinese New Year. Known as tok wi in Hokkien meaning table cover, the term entered Baba Malay, the Malay dialect spoken by Peranakans.

title_text: Hanging banner Red Chinese hanging banner
physical_appearance: This is a red banner decorated with depictions of Chinese figures. There is a woman with a halo made of peacock feathers, sitting on top of a fawn. Beside her, there are two women attendants. Below her, there are two figures looking up at her, and one figure holding a flag and riding a horse. The group is surrounded by a floral scroll medallion.
subject_terms_1: depictions (visual works) Taoism floral (motif) putti (motifs) figures (representations) religious objects
subject_terms_2: Banners Taoism Motifs Taoist mythology Cherubs (Art) Religious articles
sgcool_label_text: The large red banner is decorated with images of Chinese figures. A goddess with a halo designed like peacock feathers sits astride a fawn, accompanied by two female figures. Her hands are lift up with fingernails that are almost talon-like. These symbols suggest that the banner is depicting Magu, a Daoist goddess known to symbolise beauty and longevity, therefore a popular motif for birthday banners like this. What makes this cloth particularly unusual are cherub angels that border the Chinese figures. Such cherubs are borrowed from Western Christian imagery, and it is highly unusual to find such designs on a textile that is often hung over a Chinese deity altar

title_text: Shrine with Sumatinatha, the Fifth Jain Tirthankara
physical_appearance: This is a shrine of Sumatinatha, the fifth Jain Tirthankara. There is a central figure in the middle of the shrine, seated in meditation on a throne supported by two lions. The canopy of the throne is supported by a pair of elephants. The deity is accompanied by 23 other figures surrounding it. There are open-worked star-shaped patterns along the base of the shrine.
subject_terms_1: Jainism worship deities
subject_terms_2: Shrines Jainism Ti?rthan?karas Worship Gods
sgcool_label_text:
Jains revere twenty-four Jinas, who have attained a state of bliss and transcendence. Jina means “liberator” or “conqueror”. They help all creatures to liberate their souls from the confines of the body. Jinas are also called “river crossers” or “forders” (tirthankaras), because they have been released from the eternal cycle of rebirth.

This shrine contains a central image of Sumatinatha, the fifth Jain Tirthankara, identified by geese on the throne. He is believed to possess miraculous powers to fulfil the wishes of pilgrims. He is surrounded by the other twenty-three Jinas. The naked Jina’s indicate that the patrons of the temple for which this shrine was made were devoted to the Digambara sect.

title_text: The Real Malay given
creator_2: Sir Frank Athelstane Swettenham The Bodley Head
creator_1: Swettenham, Frank Athelstane, Sir, 1850 - 1946 Bodley Head (Firm)
techniques_name: colour printing bookbinding (process) book cloth (textile material)
physical_appearance: The book is hardcover and its front cover is predominantly yellow in colour. There is a picture of a stalk and a single flower, a stream leading to an ocean, and mountains that illustrate the front cover. There are no visible tears and the book does not look worn out. The front cover contains the title and the name of the author.

subject_terms_3: Non-fiction Swettenham, Frank, Sir colonial administrators
sgcool_label_text: The Real Malay (1900) is Sir Frank Swettenham's follow up to his earlier work, Malay Sketches (1895). It contains his observations and perspectives on Malay life and culture. This is a presentation copy containing Swettenham's inscribed initials, dated 29 January 1900.

sgcool_label_text: \The Further Side of Silence is a collection of short stories by Hugh Clifford
column51: British Resident of Penang (1896-1900)
column52: Governor of North Borneo (1900-1901) and Governor of the Straits Settlements (1927-1930). The short stories in this collection
column53: while fictional
column54: are based on Clifford's personal experiences in the Malay Peninsula. In his preface
column55: Clifford claims that these stories \"\"faithfully reproduce the conditions of life as they existed in the Malayan Peninsula before the white man took a hand in the government of the native states"

title_text: ACMA refrigerator
physical_appearance: The image depicts a refrigerator that is rectangular in shape. It is predominantly white, except its top surface which is blue in colour. At the top of the refrigerator, there is a raised black rectangular platform where the number and words, '130 Extra Cold Deluxe', are displayed along with a rotary button and a red switch. There is a door handle to the left of the refrigerator's front surface, and the word 'Unico' is displayed on a metal tag to the right. The refrigerator does not look to have any dents and its paintwork does not appear to be chipped.
subject_terms_1: appliances brand name objects ways of life
subject_terms_2: Refrigerators Lifestyles Brand name products
sgcool_label_text: This is an ACMA brand refrigerator that was likely manufactured in the 1980s. Household products such as the refrigerator became common beginning from the 1960s due to rising affluence of families, widespread advertising and increased availability of electricity with more Singaporeans moving into HDB homes. The refrigerator was one of the first kitchen appliances that families would buy for the practical reason of prolonging the lifespan of food products in the tropical climate.

object_work_type: zoning maps historical maps topographic maps
title_text: A Map of the East Indies A Map of the East Indies by Herman Moll
physical_appearance: This map is rectangular in shape and its perimeter is demarcated by dotted lines. It depicts the colonized territories of the East Indies by the different European powers. The different colours used to divide the East Indies correspond to the type of European colonizer controlling the lands. The map has a brown frame. The longitudes of the map indicate how many degrees every point is from London. The map has a brown frame and the logo of the East India company is displayed on the upper right of the map.
subject_terms_1: colonial settlements former territories/colonies/dependent states
subject_terms_2: Topographic maps Zoning Maps Historical geography Maps Colonization East Indies East India Company Asia
sgcool_label_text: This map by Herman Moll, a Dutch geographer based on London, is dedicated to the Directors of the East India Company. It depicts the East Indies. with detailed captions explaining the territories belonging to England, Spain, France, Holland, Denmark and Portugal. It also features inset plans of the city of Bantam, Fort St. George, Madras and Batavia, as well as inset views of the cities of Goa and Surat.

sgcool_label_text: M.V.Gurusamy (b. 1920 in Seremban) was an accomplished percussionist and mridangam artiste as well as a renowned percussion teacher in Singapore. He arrived in Singapore and participated in the Indian classical music scene here. He was a member of the cultural contingent led by the then Minister for Culture, S. Rajaratnam, which visited and performed at various centres in Sarawak, Brunei and Sabah in 1965. He was the recipient of several titles including the Kala Ratna award given by the Singapore Indian Fine Arts Society in 1986.

column51:
This plaque is a token of appreciation for participating in the SEA Cultural Festival. It was given to Feng Huang Motion Picture Co. The plaque shows the façade of the old National Theatre, a public theatre built to commemorate Singapore's self government in 1959. The theatre closed down in 1984.
The South East Asia Cultural Festival was held in Singapore from 8 to 15 August 1963. It featured a series of performances involving about 1,500 artistes from 11 Asian countries. The old National Theatre (now torn down) and the Victoria Theatre.

title_text: Appavoo Kandiar  Photograph of Appavoo Kandiar
physical_appearance: The image shows a photograph that is in black-and-white. It is rectangular and it features a portrait of a man. He is wearing headgear and looking into the direction in which the photograph was captured. The background of the photograph suggests that this was taken in a studio.
subject_terms_1: studio portraits general contractors founders (originators)
subject_terms_2: Black-and-white photography Portrait photography Tamil (Indic people) Contractors
sgcool_label_text: A native of Karuvakurichi village, near Mannargudi town in Tamil Nadu, S. Appavoo Kandiar was a general contractor specializing in pipe and cable laying, handling of cargo and a concrete bricks supplier. Mr.Kandiar was a successful contractor; called a millionaire by the Straits Times in 1957, he owned properties in Bukit Timah and Coronation Road areas. He was a contemporary of Indian pioneers such as P.Govindasamy Pillai, Govindasamy Sarangapany, Pakkirisami Pillai, and had friendly associations with them.

title_text: Appavoo Kandiar’s residence A set of four photographs of Appavoo Kandiar’s residence
physical_appearance: This is a set of four rectangular photographs. All of them are in black-and-white. The photograph at the top left hand side shows two single-storey houses in a rural area. Kitchen utensils such as pots and pans can be seen from a window. The photograph at the top right hand side also shows two single-storey houses as well. However, there is a bicycle and several chairs situated outside one of the houses. At the bottom left hand side, the photograph shows four men standing outside a single storey building. Beside this photograph at the bottom right hand side, five people can be seen standing outside a single-storey house. context_18: Painting Charcoal drawing Singapore Blue collar workers Immigrants Derivative works
column70: This painting was first displayed by the artist May Oon at “Over/ Time” an exhibition organised by The Private Museum in 2015. It was created as part of a collection of primarily charcoal and oil works depicting the hardships of Chinese and Indian coolies in Singapore in the 1800s. The painting is inspired by archival photography available in the public domain, as a reminder to Singapore’s public of their migrant roots.

title_text: ‘Hob in the well’ dish \Porcelain dish with \"\"Hob in the Well\"\" motif\""
physical_appearance: This is white porcelain dish painted in Kakiemon Japanese style. The border is decorated with a floral motif. In the center, there are three figures. There is a man on the left. On the right, there is a woman attempting to rescue a person in a huge vase. There are no chipped edges or cracks seen on the dish.
subject_terms_1: tableware flower (motif) representation (form of expression) exports
subject_terms_2: Kakiemon porcelain Ceramic tableware Sima, Guang, 1019-1086 Motifs Exports
sgcool_label_text: Kakiemon porcelain from Japan was greatly admired in several European countries. The scene and design of this dish is known in Europe as the “Hob in the well”. Due to its popularity, Chinese and European kilns copied and reproduced dishes of this type from around the 18th century.

title_text: Spinning Wheel Sumbanese Spinning Wheel
physical_appearance: This is a spinning wheel carved from wood. There is a wheel on the left. In front of the wheel, there is a carved figure with a prominent phallus facing forward. On the right, there is a smaller carved figure facing left. The two figures and the wheel sits on a wooden plank. There are no inscriptions or decorative carvings on the spinning wheel.
subject_terms_1: symbolism (artistic concept) folk art (traditional art) customs (social concepts)
subject_terms_2: Spinning-wheel Sumba (Indonesian people) symbolism folk art manners and customs
sgcool_label_text: This spinning wheel once belonged to a weaver named Tamu Rambu Yuliana from Rindi, in eastern Sumba. It was used by women to spin cotton thread used to weave hinggi (a large mantle worn by men) and lau (a tube skirt worn by women) prior to their marriage. These would be given by her family to the prospective groom’s family during the marriage negotiations. The two figures are meant to represent the first couple who are the progenitors of all humans.

title_text: Spinning Wheel
Chinese junk at anchor
physical_appearance: This painting shows a ship at anchor. On the stern of the ship, there is an image of a large bird with the sun. There is another ship on the background on the left. On the right of the painting there is a structure on land. On the foreground of the image there are two boats with men rowing.
subject_terms_1: junks (vessels) harbors seaports Chinese (culture or style) trade (function)
subject_terms_2: Painting Junks Harbors China trade painting
sgcool_label_text:
This painting shows a Chinese junk at anchor, probably outside a trading port in China, perhaps Canton. The ships were used for trade with Southeast Asia and other areas, transporting rattan, bamboo, tea, tin, lead, sago, salt, porcelain, and other goods. The large bird near the sun on the stern is likely the mythical phoenix (feng huang). At right is a structure on land, possibly a fort. 

Produced largely for visiting tourists and foreign traders, these works were known as China trade paintings, and were popular in the 18th and 19th centuries. They were produced by local and foreign artists, working in a Western style, to appeal to the market.

title_text: Pair of ivory figures Figure of Virgin Mary and Saint Joseph holding Christ
materials_name: wood (plant material) ivory (material) hair (material) velvet (fabric weave) cotton (fiber) gold thread silver thread trimming (material) sequins (spangles) metal
physical_appearance: This is a pair of painted ivory figures. The figures are presented in identical wooden framed boxes. On the left is Saint Joseph, holding the Christ Child in his arms. On the right is Virgin Mary as Our Lady of Mount Carmel. Both figures are wearing long garments with minute detailings and gold trimmings. They are standing on a gold-and green platform within the frames.
subject_terms_1: worship Roman Catholicism devotional objects
subject_terms_2: Figurines Worship Jesus Christ Mount Carmel, Our Lady of Mary, Mother Joseph, Saint Devotional objects
sgcool_label_text:
This pair of painted ivory figures depict Saint Joseph holding the Christ Child, and the Virgin Mary as Our Lady of Mount Carmel. The heads, hands, and feet are made of ivory, but the bodies hidden under the clothing are made of wood. The hair and eyelashes are probably human hair. 
Images such as these were admired and made in Spain, as well as in the Asian territories under its influence. These were perhaps made for private devotion in the home

title_text: Crucified Christ
physical_appearance: This is a figuring of Christ crucified on a cross. The cross is dark brown, with a running lozenges geometric motif. At the top of the cross there is an ivory sign. The figure of Christ is wearing a loincloth around the waist. He is being crucifixed on the cross, with details of blood running down his arms and feet.
subject_terms_1: Roman Catholicism worship figurines lozenges exports
subject_terms_2: Figurines Jesus Christ Worship Crosses Crucifixion of the Christ Exports
sgcool_label_text:
The Crucified Christ is a central theme in Christian art around the world, and lustrous white ivory is an ideal material for representing the human figure. High-quality devotional Christian images made in Asia, like this one, were often exported to Europe as luxury goods or high-level gifts. 

The skill of the carver in convincingly rendering facial features, muscles, and even veins creates a figure with deep emotional impact. The arms and a part of the loin cloth were made from separate pieces of ivory, a technique common of European ivory figures.

sgcool_label_text: Elaborate and ornamental objects such as this rare ivory hand mirror were not meant for everyday use. They were created as luxury accessories, and were often included in dowries. While the handle is decorated with flowers and intertwining branches, the back of the mirror is carved with the Dashavatar or ten avatars of Vishnu; a standing Vishnu is placed within an oval frame, surrounded, in anti-clockwise direction are the ten avatars.  Elaborate and ornamental objects such as this rare ivory hand mirror were not meant for everyday use. They were created as luxury accessories, and were often included in dowries. While the handle is decorated with flowers and intertwining branches, the back of the mirror is carved with the Dashavatar or ten avatars of Vishnu; a standing Vishnu is placed within an oval frame, surrounded, in anti-clockwise direction are the ten avatars.

title_text: Gaming Pieces and Dice Collection of Gaming Pieces and Dice
physical_appearance: The image shows a collection of gaming pieces and dice. The gaming pieces are placed on the left hand side while the different types of dice are placed on the right hand side. The gaming pieces and dice come in numerous sizes. The different sizes of dice also come in a variety of colours and shapes. There are circular markings on almost all the gaming pieces as well.
subject_terms_1: pachisi board games (activities) dice games play (recreation)
subject_terms_2: Pachisi Board games Dice games Play
sgcool_label_text:
This is a large collection of gaming pieces and dice, relating to the traditional Indian games of chaupar and pacheesi. The collection consists of several sets of gaming pieces and dice. The games of chaupar and pacheesi can be traced back to ancient times, through archaeological and literary evidences. Although the gaming ‘board’ (traditionally cloth stitched into a ‘cross’ shape, with square segments where each player’s pawns would be placed and would move over) has seen changes, the pawns and dice have remained almost consistent through the centuries. The pawns in this collection are shaped as elongated domes, or squat columns, are fluted or turned, and stained with pigment in many pieces. The dice are of the typical Indian fashion, called pasa – oblong and four-sided.
Both games have been played in various ways across the Indian subcontinent, and can be dated back to at least the Vedic period. Chaupar was considered a suitable game for royalty, and was an extremely popular pastime under the Mughal Emperor Akbar. During the British period, the games were popularised in the west and are still known as ‘parcheesi’. The popularity of the games across class divides led to the creation of gaming pieces and dice that ranged from the simple turned and painted wood, to elaborate ivory and silver, as represented in this collection, and even gemstones, enamel (meena) and gold.

title_text: Ivory Fan Handle
physical_appearance: The image shows a fan handle that is cylindrical in shape. The mouth of the fan handle is shaped  like and designed to look like the head of a snake. The motifs of lozenges, scrolls, and foliage are displayed on both the handle and the mouth. The designs run around the object in concentric forms and are of a variety of colours.
subject_terms_1: ceremonial objects foliage (motif) decorative art (art genre) lozenges Buddhism carvings (visual works)
subject_terms_2: Ceremonial objects Aesthetics, Sri Lankan Buddhism Customs and practices Motifs Buddhist religious articles
sgcool_label_text:
This fan handle is made of two pieces of carved ivory that are screwed together. The handle itself is turned and decorated in red and black pigment with concentric forms; the mouth is densely carved with tightly scrolling leaf-work. 

The fan handle would have been a part of a vatapatha or semi-circular fan of the kind that are carried by Buddhist monks in Sri Lanka for processions and ceremonies. Large and beautifully ornamented fan handles such as this one would have been treasured and were also given to the monks as gifts.

title_text: Ivory Bible box
physical_appearance: The image shows a rectangular box. It is predominantly white in colour. There are golden designs, mounts, and hinges on the front and side of the box. The motifs of scrolls and foliage can be discerned. The left side of the box has a compartment that can be locked or pulled open. A keyhole can be seen at the middle of the compartment. The right side of the box is shaped like the spine of a book.
subject_terms_1: Christianity cases (containers) foliage (motif)
subject_terms_2: Book boxes Christianity Aesthetics, Sri Lankan Motifs
sgcool_label_text:
This is a rare ivory bible box, with silver-gilt mounts.  The bible box is in the shape of a book with a ribbed spine and shaped sides. The hinged lid is carved with a central motif and leaves with pierced and engraved brass mounts and spirally fluted studs. 
Dutch Colonial Bible boxes were usually made of calamander wood with silver mounts, but were also made out of ivory, tortoise shell and silver. They were used to hold a small personal bible, and were sometimes carried in the retinue of Dutch ladies who resided in south India, Sri Lanka or Southeast Asia.

title_text: Ivory comb depicting Lakshmi
physical_appearance: The image shows a comb that is light brown in colour. Teeths of the comb are present at its top and bottom. The ornamental portion of the comb is at its centre. This portion contains the image of the goddess Lakshmi in a seated pose and holding a leafy frond. Surrounding the image of the goddess are diamond-patterns which serve as the borders as well.
subject_terms_1: deities Hinduism ornaments (object genre) carvings (visual works) foliage (motif) lozenges
subject_terms_2: Motifs Lakshmi (Hindu deity) Hinduism Combs Ornamental combs Aesthetics, Sri Lankan
sgcool_label_text:
This ivory comb depicts a goddess, most likely Lakshmi, the goddess of wealth, seated and holding two leafy fronds. The diamond-patterned border and the additional beaded borders are typical of ivory combs from Sri Lanka from this time. This finely incised comb is rare for having all its teeth intact. Some of the original stained polychrome decoration remains on the comb. 
Several examples exist of such combs that were handcrafted and produced in multiples; they were sought after by the European market, particularly the Dutch and Portuguese.

Community donations for Sim family orphans Document related to community donations for Sim family orphans dated 1943
physical_appearance: The three documents look slightly worn out and there are numerous fold lines on all of them. The ink that is used to write the Chinese characters down is black in colour. The ink does not look smudged, although the handwriting is not neat. The characters are aligned in vertical columns that take up the majority of space in all three documents. The papers of the documents are light brown in colour.
subject_terms_1: world wars donations financial aid community development financial records assistance
subject_terms_2: World War, 1939 - 1945 Orphans War victims Records Fund raising
sgcool_label_text: The document, written on three scraps of paper, was dated to the second month of the Guimo year (1943). It is a record of how ordinary people in the community (comprising extended family members, former employer of the head of family, neighbours and friends) contributed financially to three children (one boy, aged 13 and two girls, aged 11 and 9) who were orphaned during the Japanese Occupation period. Their father, Sim Teow Kwang, was taken away in February 1942 by Japanese soldiers, who had gathered all residents from Tank Road, River Valley Road and Clarke Quay at River Valley Road, where Liang Court is situated today. A few months later, on 8th September 1942, Mrs Sim passed away due to an illness. Thanks to the pastor of the church which Mrs Sim attended, the funerary arrangements and the medical expenses that she incurred were taken care of. The Sim orphans went to live with their maternal uncle Tan Eng Seng after their parents' deaths. However, it was a tough struggle for Mr Tan to care for the children by himself, and an appeal to raise funds among the people in the community was thus made. It was also mentioned that OCBC Bank, Mr Sim's former employer, also contributed financially to the orphans. Mr Sim used to work at the Foreign Exchange Department of the local bank before the war.

title_text: Booklet related to community donations for Sim family orphans Booklet related to community donations for Sim family orphans dated 1943-45
physical_appearance: The booklet is predominantly green in colour, except for several designs of floral patterns that are brown in colour. At the centre of the booklet, three columns of Chinese characters in black ink are written inside an inner brown boundary. The booklet looks worn out at its edges. There are no visible tears and the colours are not smudged.
subject_terms_1: world wars donations financial aid community development financial records assistance
subject_terms_2: World War, 1939 - 1945 Orphans War victims Records Adopted children Fund raising
sgcool_label_text:
The title on the booklet states, ‘Funds raised in aid of Sim Teow Kwang’s children’ and is dated to the 2nd month of the Guimo year (1943). It contained two lists that track donations right up to 1945. The first list is a detailed account of the sums of cash from regular donor Tan Eng Seng and the second is a long list of names of the ordinary folk who contributed cash in various amounts to the three Sim children (one boy, aged 13 and two girls, aged 11 and 9) who were orphaned during the Japanese Occupation period. Before the war, the family was living along Tank Road. Their father, Sim Teow Kwang, was working with the Foreign Exchange Department of OCBC Bank. When Singapore fell, Mr Sim was taken away in February 1942 by Japanese soldiers, who had gathered all residents from Tank Road, River Valley Road and Clarke Quay at River Valley Road, where Liang Court is situated today. A few months later, on 8th September 1942, Mrs Sim passed away due to an illness. After their parents died, the children went to live with Tan Eng Seng, their maternal uncle. 
Many of those who contributed to the fundraising effort (comprising extended family members, neighbours and friends) had Sim as their family name. The record served as material proof of community self-help during this darkest chapter of Singapore’s history.

title_text: Community donations for Sim family orphans Document related to community donations for Sim family orphans dated 1945
physical_appearance: This document is made up of two pieces of red paper. There are numerous columns of Chinese characters written on it that run from the top to bottom. These characters are all aligned in a straight vertical line, closely alongside one another. For the smaller piece of paper, the columns of words vary in length, with some occupying just half of the paper while others take up the entire length. For the bigger piece of paper, all the columns take up approximately two third of the paper's length. Some of the Chinese characters look to be discoloured and have turned white.
subject_terms_1: world wars donations financial aid community development financial records assistance
subject_terms_2: World War, 1939 - 1945 Orphans War victims Records Adopted children Fund raising
sgcool_label_text:
The document, written on two pieces of red rice paper, was dated to the 23rd day, 6th month of the Yiyou year (1945). It is a list of 63 names of the ordinary folk who contributed in cash and kind (old clothes) to three children (one boy, aged 13 and two girls, aged 11 and 9) who were orphaned during the Japanese Occupation period. Before the war, the family was living along Tank Road. Their father, Sim Teow Kwang, was working with the Foreign Exchange Department of OCBC Bank. When Singapore fell, Mr Sim was taken away in February 1942 by Japanese soldiers, who had gathered all residents from Tank Road, River Valley Road and Clarke Quay at River Valley Road, where Liang Court is situated today. A few months later, on 8th September 1942, Mrs Sim passed away due to an illness. 
Many of those who contributed to the fundraising effort (comprising extended family members, neighbours and friends) had Sim as their family name. The record served as material proof of community self-help during this darkest chapter of Singapore’s history.

title_text: Jari or Zardozi-Embroidered Zoroastrian Hanging Large & Rare Jari or Zardozi-Embroidered Zoroastrian Hanging
materials_name: textile materials sequins (spangles) gold thread velvet (fabric weave)
physical_appearance: The image shows a rectangular wall hanging. Underneath the wall hanging, there is a red fabric. All the embroidery on the wall hanging is gold in colour. At the centre of the wall hanging between the images of columns, there are eight horizontal lines of cuneiform script. The images of the two columns on both sides of the cuneiform script are decorated with hieroglyphic-like emblems. The patterns of flora and scrolling foliage can be discerned along the images of the walls within the columns. Also on the images of the three rising steps near the bottom of the image, different types of scrollworks are present. Near the top of the image, a winged emblem is present.
subject_terms_1: backdrops applique embroidery scripts (writing) emblems (symbols) floral patterns scrolling foliage scrollwork Zoroastrianism
subject_terms_2: Wall hangings Emblems God (Zoroastrianism) Old Persian inscriptions Hieroglyphics Motifs Parsee art
sgcool_label_text:
This large wall hanging is from the Parsi community of West India, and most probably Bombay. It dates to the end of the nineteenth century and possibly a little later and seems to be an exceptionally rare wall hanging, either for a particularly wealthy family perhaps to be hung in a grand mansion, or perhaps to be used in conjunction with a Parsi theatre troupe, possibly as a back drop. 
It comprises gold thread embroidery and spangle applique work over thick purple velvet. Such work is known as jari work, which was centred on Surat, and is similar to the thick embroidery work in gold and silver thread on velvet known as zardozi work undertaken for the Mughal and Lucknow courts to decorate wall hangings, shoes, jackets and even umbrellas. Jari work is more typically seen on smaller articles for wear such as the caps and jackets commissioned for initiation (navjote) rituals.
Parsi theatre troupes were enormously popular and influential in the wider community in northern India, and the renewed interest in Persopolis and ancient history was reflected in the stage shows that the troupes staged. Realistically painted, magnificent palace interiors, mountainous landscapes, magnificent palace interiors or townscapes with streets and buildings were themes for backdrops commissioned. Generous amounts of money were spent commissioning these for use in plays. It is possible that the wall hanging here was produced for just this purpose. Singapore too has a history of Parsi theatre.

title_text: Nine Polychrome Wooden Sculptures of a Musical & Dance Troupe
physical_appearance: The image shows nine figurines, of which eight are males and one female. All of the male figurines are holding musical instruments. The lone female figurines is depicted on tiptoes and with a dancer's pose. The figurines come in a myriad of colours, but all of them are standing atop bases that are painted red with a yellow band. Some of the male figurines are rendered with dresses that comprise of breeches, stockings, and military jackets. All of the male figurines are rendered with a similar headgear.
subject_terms_1: carvings (visual works) ensembles (musical groups) dolls dancers personification instrumentalists performing artists
subject_terms_2: Wood-carved figurines Dolls Musical groups Dancers Personification in art Instrumentalists Entertainers Wood sculpture
sgcool_label_text:
India, during the Company period, produced paintings of typical Indian professions and trades. In similar fashion, highly naturalistic terracotta/clay figures of Indian tradesmen were produced in regions such as Kondapalli in Andhra Pradesh and more importantly in the Bengal region. Krishnagar, Hatwa, Datan, Muzzafarpur, Dacca, Burdwan, Lucknow and Patna (the latter two later on in time than the preceding) such life-like figures, predating photography, were produced. This rare set was produced in Chettinad, Tamil Nadu. 
This musical troupe accompanied by a single female dancer of painted carved wood is a highly decorative, superior example of south Indian dolls made in the 19th century. Every fold of cloth and each body movement and contour has been carefully captured by the wood carver. The faces of each performer are particularly sensitively rendered. The dancer has a metal girdle about her waist from which metal spheres are suspended but other than that, the set is entirely composed of painted and gilded wood. Each member of the set is also taller than is usual. The set has no religious function; it was made purely for decorative reasons for a local client. Other than the female dancer, the set comprises a bag pipe player, a drummer, a cymbals player and five other players of wind instruments. The troupe might well have been for a wedding or some other festivity. Certainly, the troupe with its (part) Western forms of dress such as breeches, stockings, and military jackets and Westernised musical instruments personify musicians who would have performed for wealthy, educated clients.

India, during the Company period, produced paintings of typical Indian professions and trades. In similar fashion, highly naturalistic terracotta/clay figures of Indian tradesmen were produced in regions such as Kondapalli in Andhra Pradesh and more importantly in the Bengal region. Krishnagar, Hatwa, Datan, Muzzafarpur, Dacca, Burdwan, Lucknow and Patna (the latter two later on in time than the preceding) such life-like figures, predating photography, were produced. This rare set was produced in Chettinad, Tamil Nadu. 
This musical troupe accompanied by a single female dancer of painted carved wood is a highly decorative, superior example of south Indian dolls made in the 19th century. Every fold of cloth and each body movement and contour has been carefully captured by the wood carver. The faces of each performer are particularly sensitively rendered. The dancer has a metal girdle about her waist from which metal spheres are suspended but other than that, the set is entirely composed of painted and gilded wood. Each member of the set is also taller than is usual. The set has no religious function; it was made purely for decorative reasons for a local client. Other than the female dancer, the set comprises a bag pipe player, a drummer, a cymbals player and five other players of wind instruments. The troupe might well have been for a wedding or some other festivity. Certainly, the troupe with its (part) Western forms of dress such as breeches, stockings, and military jackets and Westernised musical instruments personify musicians who would have performed for wealthy, educated clients.

title_text: Ganpa or Ganjifa Cards in a box A Set of Ganpa or Ganjifa Cards
physical_appearance: The image depicts a box with a top cover. The top cover is slightly slanted, revealing the interior of the box and its contents. A line of circular cards can be discerned inside. The sides of the exterior of the box are painted with different colours in horizontal lines, along with motifs of scrolls. The top cover is depicts an image of a male figure with long hair and a beard. The figure is standing on one leg, with the other folded across his knees. His right hand is shown to be holding a shiny circular object.
subject_terms_1: card games (game sets) recreation entertaining cultural diffusion figures (representations) scrolls (motifs)
subject_terms_2: Playing cards Boxes Card games Amusements Culture diffusion Motifs
sgcool_label_text: Ganjifa is pan-Indian, played in its various forms in Indian regions including Maharashtra, Rajasthan, Bengal, Orissa, Karnataka, among others. The ganjifa game of cards originated in Persia but it really flourished in India where the game developed in various forms. Meanwhile, in Persia, the game largely died out. Initially in India, the game was played by the Mughals of northern India, but it soon spread to most parts of the country. The proposed set underscore a rare aspect of Indian heritage – a craft tradition akin to miniature painting and a lesser known Indian game.

sgcool_label_text: Mr. Retnam (b. 1918) was a prominent musician and a bul-bul-tara (Indian Banjo or Nagoya Harp) player. Born in Penang in 1918, he arrived in Singapore in 1929 and pursued his interest in Indian music. He popularized the use of the bul-bul-tara in Indian classical music in Singapore. Mr Retnam formed the Rama Bhajana Mandali at Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple, and performed alongside veterans of Indian music such as Pandit M Ramalingam and MV Gurusamy. He was also a member of the Ramakrishna Sangeetha Sabha, and Singapore Carnatic Orchestra until 1984.

title_text: Aaberi Composition Music Notes for an Aaberi Composition
physical_appearance: The image shows a set of three handwritten notes. The writing is black in colour and the notes are composed entirely in Tamil script, along with a few numbers as pointers. subject_terms_1: composition (artistic arrangement) music (performing arts)
subject_terms_2: Carnatic music Raga Scores
sgcool_label_text:
Mr. Retnam (b. 1918) was a prominent musician and a bul-bul-tara (Indian Banjo or Nagoya Harp) player. Born in Penang in 1918, he arrived in Singapore in 1929 and pursued his interest in Indian music. He popularized the use of the bul-bul-tara in Indian classical music in Singapore. 

Mr Retnam formed the Rama Bhajana Mandali at Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple, and performed alongside veterans of Indian music such as Pandit M Ramalingam and MV Gurusamy. He was also a member of the Ramakrishna Sangeetha Sabha, and Singapore Carnatic Orchestra until 1984. 

Throughout his musical career, he performed with Bhaskar’s Academy of Dance and Gemini Music Band, and for Radio Television Singapore. He was also a keen theatre practitioner who composed music for and acted in several Tamil stage dramas and productions staged during the Tamil’s Festival or Thamizhar Thirunal. 

Mr Retnam was also the first music director for Krishna Our Guide and composed their bhajans or prayer songs. He was recognised for his talent by various organisations such as Indian Youth League (1941) and Tamils Representative Council (1958), and was awarded the “Golden Robe” award by Guru Gopinath in 1980.

These are notes/notations handwritten by Shri Retnam for a composition in the Raga Aberi.

Mr. Retnam (b. 1918) was a prominent musician and a bul-bul-tara (Indian Banjo or Nagoya Harp) player. Born in Penang in 1918, he arrived in Singapore in 1929 and pursued his interest in Indian music. He popularized the use of the bul-bul-tara in Indian classical music in Singapore. 

Mr Retnam formed the Rama Bhajana Mandali at Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple, and performed alongside veterans of Indian music such as Pandit M Ramalingam and MV Gurusamy. He was also a member of the Ramakrishna Sangeetha Sabha, and Singapore Carnatic Orchestra until 1984. 

Throughout his musical career, he performed with Bhaskar’s Academy of Dance and Gemini Music Band, and for Radio Television Singapore. He was also a keen theatre practitioner who composed music for and acted in several Tamil stage dramas and productions staged during the Tamil’s Festival or Thamizhar Thirunal. 

Mr Retnam was also the first music director for Krishna Our Guide and composed their bhajans or prayer songs. He was recognised for his talent by various organisations such as Indian Youth League (1941) and Tamils Representative Council (1958), and was awarded the “Golden Robe” award by Guru Gopinath in 1980.
Kedara Gowla.

These are notes/notations handwritten by Shri Retnam for a composition in the Raga Vijayanagari.

The Tamil scripts written on the paper are predominantly in straight horizontal lines from left to right. There are several tears on the sides of the handwritten notes.

sgcool_label_text: This is a cotton samfoo with green and yellow floral motifs and green piping. The samfoo is a traditional Chinese outfit which consists of a top (‘sam’) with side fastenings and a mandarin collar, worn over a pair of pants (‘foo’). Traditionally, the samfoo is loose fitting and its cut makes it convenient for the wearer to carry out everyday activities.

context_9: Awards Sound recordings Sound recordings Album covers Contests Television programmes
column61:
This group of 3 items are related to Talentime from 1968 which was under the Radio Television Singapore. The award shaped like the RTS logo and the vinyl record with cover are important souvenirs of this popular competition - now hailed as a precursor to the Singapore idol on television.
Radio Malaya started the competition called Talentime in the mid1950s.The competiion was meant as a platform to showcase musicians and this attracted many local groupos, several of whom went on to become famous.

sgcool_label_text: The region of Chettinad in Southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu is the region of origin of the Chettiar community of business or the Vaishya caste. The Nagarattar Chettiars are among the early Indian migrants to the Southeast Asian region with business establishments in Vietnam, Myanmar, Malaysia and Singapore. Their migration and establishment of money lending business in Singapore-Malaya in particular are of special significance to the Indian Heritage Centre (IHC). Their presence in the Straits Settlements can be traced to the early 18th century onwards. This is a collection of travel documents, photographs and horoscopes from the family of Ramasamy Chettiar.

title_text: Timurid tile with Kufic inscription Timurid tile fragment with Kufic inscription
physical_appearance: This is a terracotta tile. The face of the tile is glazed in turquoise. The tile bears an Arabic inscription amidst a scrolling foliated background. The edges of the tile is uneven and jagged. The turquoise glaze is slightly faded around the edges of the design, especially at the bottom of the tile.
subject_terms_1: foliage (motif) Kufic
subject_terms_2: Terra-cotta Paleography, Arabic (Cufic) Tiles Art, Timurid Motifs
sgcool_label_text:
Monumental, lavishly decorated architectural projects were a distinctive feature of the arts under the patronage of Timurid rulers whose territories encompassed present-day Iran, Central Asia and the Caucasus as well as parts of India, Syria and Anatolia between the 14th and 16th centuries. This carved and glazed calligraphic tile would have been part of a revetment for a mausoleum, such as those in the Shah-i Zinda necropolis in Samarkand, present-day Uzbekistan, which housed several members of its dynasty founder, Timur. 

Although a distinctive Timurid style was to emerge that influenced Safavid Iran and the Mughal emperors of India, carved and glazed terracotta was an existing, pre-conquest local technique that yielded highly attractive results and appeared to be employed only in the 14th century. Set against a scrolling floriated ground is an intricate, plaited Kufic inscription in Arabic which would have been repeated throughout the revetment. The inscription reads as “al-mulk [li’-llah]” meaning “Sovereignty is [for God]”, a phrase often seen on monuments, tiles, pottery, woodwork and metalwork.

title_text: Candelabra Qing dynasty candleholder
physical_appearance: This is a branched candleholder, decorated with bright enamel paint. The stem supports five candleholders, with the middle candleholder higher than the rest. The candleholders are shaped like lotuses. There are floral motifs around the base of the candleholder and around the stem. There are no chips seen.
subject_terms_1: lotus (motif) flower (motif) exports
subject_terms_2: Candelabra Qianlong, Emperor of China, 1711-1799 Enamel and enameling China History Ming-Qing dynasties, 1368-1912 Motifs Exports
sgcool_label_text:
This branched holder for candles (called a candelabrum or candelabra) is decorated with bright enamels. The double-baluster stem supports five candleholders shaped like lotuses. Candelabra were made for dining tables in Europe and America. However, much of the design and decoration of this object is distinctly Chinese.

The form of this candelabra was made in copper, which was then coated with pigments containing ground glass. The object was then fired to create a bright glassy coating. In the 18th century, this type was production for foreign export in Guangzhou (Canton), with the result that the type is often called Canton enamel.

title_text: Radha Folk-style sculpture of Radha
physical_appearance: This is a bronze sculpture of Radha in a poised standing position. The forms of the limbs in this sculpture takes on a geometric rather than realistic form. Her head is tilted to her left, with her right arm held up in a bent position. Her left arm is extended downwards. Her legs are placed slightly apart. The sculpture is standing on a patterned base. There are no chips or broken fragments seen on this sculpture.
subject_terms_1: folk art (traditional art) Jainism deities
subject_terms_2: Sculpture Radha Jainism Gods Folk art
sgcool_label_text:
The folk-style sculpture shows Radha standing in a pronounced triple flexion. The plastic forms of her body are articulated as geometric shapes. Her head is tilted to the left as her right hand is lifted up and her left extended downwards. She is beckoning to her lover, Krishna, who probably formed a companion piece to this sculpture. Her ears and nose are pierced and were possibly adorned with real jewellery.

Radha, whose name means ‘prosperity’, was chief among the milkmaids (gopis). She was the favourite consort of the young cowherd Krishna. She is often depicted standing next to him and together they represent love, passion, and devotion. Primarily Hindu deities they were also worshipped by Jains.
