title_text: Painting of Penang by Robert Smith Penang seascape
physical_appearance: This is an oil painting of the island of Penang along the sea. The coast line runs through the painting from the bottom-left to the center. On the right, there is a hill, with some trees and vegetation. Across the sea on the left, there are a few faint mountains on the horizon. There are no inscriptions on the painting.
subject_terms_1: scenery (landscapes) colonization
subject_terms_2: Painting Colonization George Town (Pulau Pinang, Malaysia)
sgcool_label_text:
This is one of the earliest oil paintings of Penang. It was made by Colonel Robert Smith around the time he was superintending engineer and executive officer of Penang in 1814–15 and 1817–19, at the time when the British organised a colony at Singapore. This painting is one of ten views made by Smith, who commissioned prints after them from William Daniell in 1821.

The idyllic image of the island of Penang shows George Town below along the sea. At the right, flags fly from Mount Erskine, which was the principal signalling station for the channel. Robert Smith was a sophisticated landscape painter adept at capturing weather, light, and the sweep of a scene.

title_text: Painting of William Henry Ker and Chinese attendant by Aaron Edwin Penley William Henry Ker with Chinese attendant
physical_appearance: This is an oil painting of William Henry Ker with his Chinese attendant. The painting depicts a boy on the left, wearing a brown coat and light-coloured trousers. He is holding a stick and a hoop. On the right is a Chinese man, wearing a loose blue attire with queue hair style. The background shows a countryside backdrop of the left, with a hanging red curtain on the right.
subject_terms_1: colonialism domestics (servants)
subject_terms_2: Portrait painting Imperialism Nannies
sgcool_label_text:
This studio portrait with countryside backdrop and red curtains hanging near a column (conflating indoor and outdoor) derives from European paintings of the period. The large scale of the attendant compared to the boy is noteworthy, and perhaps is intended to add an exotic appeal to the depiction of an English boy who grew up in a Southeast Asian colonial setting.  The child, playing with a stick and hoop, is William Henry Ker (1837-1864), son of William Wemyss Ker (1802–1874), a partner of Paterson, Simons and C, one of the earliest and largest trading firms in the Straits Settlements. 

The artist, Aaron Edwin Penley (1807–1870), was better known for watercolours, and exhibited regularly at the Royal Academy exhibitions in London.

title_text: Tamil family in Singapore  Photograph of a Tamil family in Singapore
physical_appearance: The image shows a photograph that is in black-and-white. It is situated at the centre of a brown paper board. The upper right side of the paper board is torn. The photograph features a lady and a young child sitting down, together with an adult male and three children who are standing behind. Only the lady is wearing her ethnic costume. They are looking towards the direction in which this photograph was taken. The photograph looks worn out and there are discolourations, especially at its sides. The background of the photograph suggests that this was taken in the interior of a building.
subject_terms_1: folk costume families (kinship groups) group portraits studio portraits
subject_terms_2: Black-and-white photography Ethnic costume Tamil (Indic people) Families Portraits, Group Portrait photography
sgcool_label_text:
In response to the appeal of the devotees of the Ramakrishna order, Swami Adyananda was sent to Singapore and with their help started a branch center of the Ramakrishna Mission on the 7th of August 1928. The mission occupied its first premises at Norris Road in 1932. The same year, the mission started the Vivekananda school, which taught both English and Tamil to children and a night school for adults from the poor sections of the community. A separate school for girls – ‘Sardamani girls’ School’ was subsequently opened in 1937 and it was quickly filled to capacity. The mission established one of the earliest Tamil schools in Singapore. 
Several Tamil Schools were established in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. These schools were located near the British bases in Seletar, Sembawang and Changi where Tamils found employment. Much later, these schools were discontinued because of the declining number of students due to Tamil families’ preference to send their children to English medium Schools. This is probably one of the earliest photographs available of the school.

title_text: Armlet
physical_appearance: The image shows an armlet. It is gold in colour. Its shape is symmetrical. At its vertical line of symmetry, three jewels can be discerned. The one at the top and the one hanging from a ring near the bottom are both grey in colour. In between these two grey jewels, a purple one is situated just below the mouth of the k?rttimukha. There are motifs of birds as well as animal art such as lions and horses all over the armlet.
subject_terms_1: birds (motif) animal art k?rttimukhas  jewellery ritual objects Hinduism ornaments (object genre) iconography allover patterns goldwork (visual works) decorative art (art genre)
subject_terms_2: Ethnic jewellery Motifs Idols and images Hinduism Gold jewellery Goldwork
sgcool_label_text: In the southern Indian region, jewellery is created keeping in mind several ritualistic needs of the various communities. The size and design of the ornament denoted the social background of the owner; some jewellery like the thali also declared the marital status of the wearer. This vanki or armlet is an elaborate example of repousse craftsmanship from Tamil Nadu. Stacked animal and bird motifs culminate in a central kirtimukha or face of glory. The kirtimukha is also placed centrally in the detail on the back.

title_text: Large gold bangle with birds
physical_appearance: The image shows a bangle. It is gold in colour. The inner circumference does not have any inscriptions or designs on it. The motif of peacocks can be discerned near the screw of the bangle. The outer surface of the bangle is ribbed. The screw that is lodged in the bangle can be separated from the latter.
subject_terms_1: commemorative jewellery birds (motif) decorations (personal artifacts) commemoratives gift giving goldwork (visual works)
subject_terms_2: Ethnic jewellery Motifs Gold jewelry Appreciation of a person’s creative works Goldwork
sgcool_label_text: This is an elaborately crafted gold bangle with a ribbed outer surface and smoothly finished inner circumference. A pair of finely sculpted peacocks flanks the screw which is seen in the form of a spire akin to the tower of a south Indian temple. Bangles such as these would have been made to be presented by royalty to scholars, artists, etc as a sign of imperial honour.

In Chinese culture, wedding lamps were placed at the bed side or vanity table and were intended to bless the couple in their marriage. The lamps have a symbolic meaning of fertility and wealth (????).

title_text: A palm-leaf fan with ivory handle and finial Palm-leaf fan with ivory handle and finial
physical_appearance: This is a palm leaf fan. It consists of a painted-turned handle, with scrolling and foliate red-and-black designs. The fan is held by the handle with a carved holder and finial ornament end.
subject_terms_1: scrolls (motifs) foliage (motif) Buddhism fans (costume accessories)
subject_terms_2: Ceremonial objects Aesthetics, Sri Lankan Buddhism Customs and practices Motifs fans
sgcool_label_text:
This fan consists of a painted turned handle, with scrolling and foliate designs in red and black. The palm-leaf fan is held in place by elaborately carved holder and finial. The style is characteristic of ivory objects from Sri Lanka, and this piece is exceptionally large.

It shows the high level of craftsmanship, especially in ivory carving, achieved during the Kandy period. The fan would have been used by a high profile monk during Buddhist ceremonies. Devotees presented ivory fans of this type to the monks they revered.

title_text: Box Chinese copper box
physical_appearance: This is a circular gilded copper box, decorated with Chinese motifs such as prunus trees, pagodas, birds, and mythical animals all around. The motifs are carved on, creating a raised appearanc, on the top of the lid and around the circumference. There are some light marks on the box where the material is slightly worn out.
subject_terms_1: birds (motifs) foliage (motif) exports
subject_terms_2: Boxes Copperwork Exports Motifs
sgcool_label_text: This circular box with a lid is decorated with figures in a landscape. Prunus trees, pagodas, birds and mythical animals, and a mounted scholar are set in a ring-punched ground. Made in gilded copper, it could have been used to hold cosmetics or tobacco snuff. Chinese metalsmiths in Canton and in provincial centres throughout Southeast Asia produced large amounts of such boxes as part of the lively export trade in decorative objects from the seventeeth century.

title_text: Syrian Christian House Doorway of Syrian Christian House
physical_appearance: The image shows a doorway. It is brown in colour. The doorway consists on a door and two steps which serves as the entrance platform. The motif of scrolls appears on the lintel, sides, stile, and sill of the doorway. A cross can be seen at the middle of the lintel, as well as at the centre of the door. A lock is located on the left hand side of the door, and it is accompanied with chains running across to the right hand side of the door.
subject_terms_1: residential structures doors Saint Thomas Christian (sect) crosses (visual works) scrolls (motifs) steps (stair units)
subject_terms_2: Doorways Stairs Doors Saint Thomas Christians Crosses Motifs
sgcool_label_text:
This is a very fine example of architecture from the Kerala region, and is rare because of its clear association with the Syrian Christian community.
The Syrian Christians, also known as Nasrani, are one of the oldest Christian communities in the world, tracing their conversion back to the arrival of St Thomas at Muziris in Kerala in 52 AD. The lintel of the doorway bears a carving of the St Thomas Cross or Mar Thoma Sliba, which is an important symbol of the faith for Syrian Christians. 
The Syrian Christian community is culturally Malayalee and follow many of the same traditions regarding clothing, food and architecture. The doorway is typical of domestic architecture from the region. Two high steps which would have led up from the entrance platform are part of the door, and an intact manichithrathazhu or ornate Kerala-style lock made of brass adorns the front of the door. 
The low height of the doors would have necessitated a bending, or bowing down before entering the household. This is a common feature in Kerala architecture, and can be linked to the similarities to temple architecture from the region, where the person seeking to enter has to bow respectfully before entering into the sacred space.

title_text: Elephant Caparison  Nettipattam
physical_appearance: The image shows an elephant caparison. The textile that can be seen on the sides of the caparison come in a myriad of colours. Some fringes of yarn can be seen to be attached to these textiles. The centre of the caparison consists of a metal plate that is gold in colour. Several spheres of different sizes are embedded within the metal plate, together with crescents forming a straight vertical line.
subject_terms_1: decorations (ornaments) festivals cultural ceremonies celebrations Hinduism Elephantidae (family) crescents (motifs) spheres (geometric figures) religious objects
subject_terms_2: Ceremonial objects Festivals Beliefs and cultures Hindu symbolism Ganesha (Hindu deity) Tr?s?s?u?r Pu?ram? Working elephants Motifs Religious articles
sgcool_label_text:
This ornate gold-plated nettipattam or caparison would have been part of the ornamentation of an elephant for a festival celebration in Kerala. This is a typical example of an elephant caparison, with a core of copper coated with gold, having five spherical fixtures and edged with a fringe of yarn, backed with textile.
The nettipattam is symbolic of the elephant-headed god Ganesha. Elephants are central to large festivals and celebrations in Kerala, with at least one decorated elephant being present at any large festival, regardless of religion or community. Caparisoned elephants are particularly associated with the Thrissur Pooram, an annual festival held at the Vadakkunnathan Temple in Thrissur, Kerala.

object_work_type: hanging lamps oil lamps bronzes (visual works)
title_text: Lamp Thookkuvilakku
physical_appearance: The image shows a lamp. It has the colour of bronze. It comes with a chain that is attached to a closed ring at the top of the lamp. The base of the lamp is wider than its middle and top. Also, the base is shaped like a plate, while the middle part is designed like the shape of a gear, with cut teeth.
subject_terms_1: ritual objects Hinduism cultural artifacts religious objects
subject_terms_2: Lamps Hindu temples Religious articles
sgcool_label_text: This hanging oil lamp or thookkuvilakku is a typical Kerala design, frequently seen at temples in the region. Made of bell metal, the lamp would be lit by multiple wicks and suspended from a low beam or rafter, to make it easy to light.

title_text: Puttu maker Puttu kudam
physical_appearance: The image displays a puttu maker. It comprises of a pot as its base, with five tubes at the top. These five tubes can be detached from its base. All of the five tubes are wrapped with cloth and have ropes tied around them.
subject_terms_1: kitchenware cooking utensils implements (object genre)
subject_terms_2: Food steamers Steaming (Cooking) Kitchen utensils
sgcool_label_text: This puttu maker is of highly unusual design, comprising of a brass pot, with five bamboo inserts. Puttu is a popular breakfast/snack in Kerala, made of a mix of steamed broken rice and grated coconut. The mix of rice and coconut would be stuffed into the bamboo tubes, and then steamed by heating the water in the pot.

title_text: Coconut Scraper
physical_appearance: The image displays a coconut scraper. It is grey in colour. There is a circular saw ascending above the circular depression in the base of the coconut scraper. The outer perimeter of this utensil has motifs of animals, birds, and mythical creatures. To the right of the circular depression, there are patterns ofsemicircles and a circle carved onto the surface of the coconut scraper.
subject_terms_1: kitchenware birds (motif) hand tools implements (object genre) cooking utensils
subject_terms_2: Kitchen utensils Motifs Tools
sgcool_label_text:
This is a typical coconut scraper from the Chettinad region of Tamil Nadu. The base is ornately carved wood, decorated with lions, parrots and mythical creatures. Many Chettiar domestic items are made of wood and profusely ornamented in similar fashion, a reflection of the wealth and prestige of the Chettiar traders in the 19th and 20th centuries.
The coconut would be grated by scraping the flesh of a halved coconut against the spiked metal head of the scraper, and collected in the circular depression in the base. The flat portion would be weighed down with the other hand or a knee to balance the scraper

title_text: Idli Steamer
physical_appearance: The image displays an idli steamer. It is yellow in colour. The lid of the steamer can be removed from its body. There are two rings attached to the sides of the lid, and two handles are present at its top. There is a silver mould plate present inside the steamer. It has numerous depressions of equal sizes. Two handles are present on the mould plate as well.
subject_terms_1: kitchenware cooking utensils implements (object genre)
subject_terms_2: Food steamers Steaming (Cooking) Kitchen utensils
sgcool_label_text: This large idli steamer belonged to a temple kitchen in the Kerala region. Idli (a steamed rice cake) is a popular south Indian snack, commonly served for breakfast. The steamer comprises of several mould-plates that are stacked on top of each other. The idli batter would be poured into the moulds and steamed in the large metal container.

title_text: Water Boiler
physical_appearance: The image displays a water boiler. The entire set-up is reddish brown in colour. The tank has a lid that can be detached from its body. Within the tank, there is the innter accessory as well as the shovel. The base of the water boiler comprises of a tripod stand. There are two handles on  the body of the tank as well as the lid.
subject_terms_1: kitchenware utensils implements (object genre)
subject_terms_2: Water heaters Kitchen utensils
sgcool_label_text:
This copper water boiler is typical of the type used to make “boiler tea” in south India and Sri Lanka from the 20th century, and would have been seen at tea shops, stalls and restaurants. The boiler would be used to heat a large quantity of water over a coal fire, or similar type of long-burning fuel. The tea maker would use hot water from the boiler to brew tea. 
It is an interesting artefact from the 20th century, and reflects the rise in popularity in beverages such as tea and coffee among Indians, during the Colonial era, and the paraphernalia that has since become associated with their consumption. This type of water boiler is becoming increasingly rare with the emergence of cheaper fuel, as well as changing methods of brewing tea.

title_text: Bedcover Chinese silk bedcover
physical_appearance: This is a bedcover embroided with decorative elements. The border of the bedcover is lined with red trimmings, with tassels attached to each corner. The bedcover features a scrolling foliage multicolored motif. The center of the bedcover has a double-headed eagle motif.
subject_terms_1: scrolling foliage birds (motifs) exports Roman Catholicism
subject_terms_2: Coverlets Exports Double-headed eagle (Emblem) Augustinians Catholic Church
sgcool_label_text:
The double-headed eagle motif in the centre of this bedcover derives from the emblem of the Augustinian Order. This Catholic order established missions in Asian port cities, including Manila and Macao. 

Chinese silks like this were commissioned for a wide range of purposes – furnishing, clothing, and liturgical vestments – and their designs combine Chinese techniques and decorative elements with European motifs, often copied from European engravings. These silks were primarily made for Portugal and the rest of Europe.

title_text: Rao Bakhat Singh of Bedla discussing documents with four British Officials
materials_name: pigment gilt paint ink paper (fiber product)
physical_appearance: This painting depicts the Rao Bakhat Singh of Bedla in discussion with four  British officials. The five men are sitting in decorated European-style chairs around a table. Documents are laid out on the table in their cases, along with quill pens and ink pots. The Rao is seated on the extreme left, with a servant assisting behind him. There are inscriptions by each figure in the painting. The painting is within decorative borders on a dark brown page.
subject_terms_1: colonization discussions (meetings) depictions (visual works)

title_text: Walking stick
materials_name: horn (animal material) ivory (material) silver (metal) mother of pearl
physical_appearance: This walking stick has small decorative inlays with carved stylized crosses along its body. At the top of the walking stick, there is a silver finial in the shape of a ball, with some ringed decorative elements. There are slight scratches along the body of the stick.
subject_terms_1: crosses (motifs) souvenirs
subject_terms_2: Staffs (Sticks, canes, etc.) Souvenirs (Keepsakes) Motifs
sgcool_label_text: This walking stick is inscribed with the name of the city of Vigan, a significant port in the North of the Phillippines. It is dated 1882, when the city was controlled by a Spanish colonial government.  It bears the name Francisco Carlos Corrales, a Spaniard who must have bought it or received it as a gift or momento. He probably brought it back with him to Spain where it remained for over a century. Given the fine materials and workmanship it clearly was meant for the use of a wealthy gentleman.

title_text: Painting of Lee Kuan Yew Lee Kuan Yew
physical_appearance: This is a portrait painting of Lee Kuan Yew. He is dressed in a suit and tie. He is sitting sideways, body facing towards the left. His gaze is towards the front. The painting uses muted colours of gray, beige, white and black. There is a signature on the bottom-right of the painting.

subject_terms_2: Portrait painting Lee, Kuan Yew, 1923-2015 Prime ministers Painting

sgcool_label_text: This posthumous oil painting of Lee Kuan Yew by Alvin Ong depicts the first Prime Minister of Singapore as a young man. It is based on a photograph of Mr Lee at Assembly House (now known as the Arts House or Old Parliament House), in December 1958.

title_text: South Indian Wedding Pendant
physical_appearance: An image of a wedding pendant is shown. The thread that holds the gold jewellery is red in colour. There are two rectangular blocks of gold jewellery attached around the thread. In the middle of these blocks, a purple stone is protruding outwards. The gold piece extends and diverges into five elongated segments. Floral patterns adorn the ornament.
subject_terms_1: jewellery ornaments (object genre) Hinduism customs (social) floral patterns goldwork (visual works) necklaces neck ornaments
subject_terms_2: Ethnic jewellery Gold jewelry Hindu marriage customs and rites Motifs Pendants (Jewellery) Goldwork Necklaces
sgcool_label_text: In southern Indian Hindu custom, the thali is the principal gold marriage ornament or auspicious amulet placed on the mangal sutram wedding necklace. Derived from the local term for palmyra palm (thala), this Sanskrit term thali makes reference to the ancient custom of tying strips of palm leaf around the neck of a married woman; in indication of her married status. This is an impressive and intricate wedding ornament; a component of the Chettiar wedding necklace or kazhuthuru, representative of the material heritage of the Tamil, Chettiar community; who are among the earliest Indians to settle in the Singapore-Malaya region.

title_text: Pillars A Pair of Pillars
subject_terms_1: structural elements houses residential structures columns (architectural elements) flower (motif)
subject_terms_2: Columns Architecture, Domestic Ethnic architecture Dwellings Motifs
sgcool_label_text: Among the early migrant Indian communities in Singapore and Malaya are the Malayalees from Kerala. This proposed acquisition highlights the built heritage of the community and illustrates their rich roots. The evolution of domestic architecture in the Kerala region followed the evolution of temple architecture very closely. In addition prescriptive texts such as the Manushyala Chandrika and Vastu Vidya laid out the theory and practice of domestic architecture. As such, the construction of domestic houses were standardised and adapted to suit the needs of different socio-economic groups. The traditional craftsmen such as carpenters followed the prescriptive rules of the texts and rigidly follow the proportions of the different elements till today. Such pillars were used as structural supports in the interior parts as well as inner courtyards of the traditional Kerala house.

title_text: Tray or pillow cover
physical_appearance: This cover is embroided with red and blue threads to create motif patterns. The border consists of multiple bands of floral and abstract designs. In the center, there is a hexagonal shape, decorated with vases of flowers, peacocks and butterflies.
subject_terms_1: drawn thread work birds (motifs) flower (motif) foliage (motif) geometric motifs embroidery (visual works)
subject_terms_2: Slip covers Embroidery, Peranakan Motifs
sgcool_label_text: This textile is probably a tray or pillow cover. An elaborately embroidered red and blue border, made up of multiple bands of floral and abstract designs, surrounds a hexagonal field. One recurring motif is a vase of flowers in full bloom. Peacocks perch on its branches, their feathers spread like a fan. This was produced using the technique known as drawn thread embroidery, whiich involves the extraction of warp and weft threads from a piece of cloth stretched upon a wooden frame. Not only does drawn thread embroidery demand expertise, it is also extremely labour intensive. Penang was especially known for the use of this technique in the early 20th century.

title_text: Comb Peineta tortoiseshell comb
physical_appearance: This is a decorative hair comb. The teeth of the comb is made of tortoiseshell, with dual shades of brown. The handle of the comb is made of gold, forged into decorative foliage motifs.
subject_terms_1: cultural diffusion foliage (motif) exports hair ornaments
subject_terms_2: Ornamental combs Culture diffusion Motifs Exports Hair ornaments
sgcool_label_text: Peineta are decorative hair combs which first became popular in the Philippines. Based on original Spanish as well as Chinese designs such combs were produced in Manila for local consumption as well as for export. Today old examples can be found all over Southeast Asia. Such combs went out of fashion when shorter hair styles came into vogue in the 20th century.

Garuda Garuda Sculpture
physical_appearance: This is a sculpture of Garuda. The sculpture has opened wings, with a featured head with horns. The sculpture's hands are outstretched, palm facing the front, with the tip of the middle finger and thumb touching. The legs of the sculpture are featured, with feet having three clawed toes. The sculpture is mounted on a stand. It has a slight orange tint around the surface of its head.
subject_terms_1: deities Hinduism Buddhism
subject_terms_2: Sculpture Garuda (Mythical bird) Hindu mythology Buddhist mythology Gods
sgcool_label_text:
Garuda is a figure who transcends specific religion, as he is worshipped in an independent cult. His image is also found in Buddhist as well as Hindu art. In Hinduism he is Vishnu's mount, while in Buddhism he is a guardian deity.

This sculpture emphasizes the connections between and makes an important addition to the Himalayan collection, which is envisioned to be a small, choice collection which covered different functions and types. The artistic qualities of this proposed work are strong: there is a clear sense of character and a Garuda is a figure who transcends specific religion, as he is worshipped in an independent cult. His image is also found in Buddhist as well as Hindu art. In Hinduism he is Vishnu's mount, while in Buddhism he is a guardian deity.

column51: Jayaram s/o Rengasamy was an amateur athlete who competed at the club level in Singapore and Malaya in the 1940s and 50s. He started his sporting career at the age of 14 as a boxer. In 1953, a friend and fellow athlete, MS Maniam, invited Mr Rengasamy to participate in the Tamil’s Festival or Tamilar Thirunnal. He then began training in athletics at Anglo-Chinese School Barker Road, the grounds of Victoria School off Jalan Besar and at Farrer Park. Mr Rengasamy also started participating in different races as a middle distance runner at the Tamil’s Festival (1954 – 57), Singapore Amateur Athletic Association meets (1955 – 57), as well as the Merdeka Games, Kuala Lumpur (1957). He was also a member of Swift Athletics Club.

One male is ahead the other and is about to reach the white finishing line. In the background, numerous people can be seen, either sitting down or standing up.

sgcool_label_text:
Xinyao is an abbreviated form of ????? (“Singapore songs” in Mandarin), a genre that emerged in the early 1980s in local schools and college campuses.
The first xinyao album, (Tomorrow 21), was released in 1984 to overwhelming success. This was followed by the first xinyao festival in 1985. Among the well-known personalities of Xinyao are Eric Moo Billy Koh Liang Wern Fook Roy Loi Thomas Teo Dawn Gan and Pan Ying.
The Young Songwriters Society was formed in May 1986. Comprising of members from several xinyao groups, the society aimed to promote their music. They also began to run the annual Xinyao festival that was organized by community centres.

column70:
Xinyao is an abbreviated form of ????? (“Singapore songs” in Mandarin), a genre that emerged in the early 1980s in local schools and college campuses.
The first xinyao album, (Tomorrow 21), was released in 1984 to overwhelming success. This was followed by the first xinyao festival in 1985. Among the well-known personalities of Xinyao are Eric Moo Billy Koh Liang Wern Fook Roy Loi Thomas Teo Dawn Gan and Pan Ying.
The Young Songwriters Society was formed in May 1986. Comprising of members from several xinyao groups, the society aimed to promote their music. They also began to run the annual Xinyao festival that was organized by community centres.

title_text: Young Songwriters Society poster Young Songwriters Society poster 1990
physical_appearance: The image shows a poster and it has a white background. A big treble clef musical symbol adorns the background of the poster as well. There are three Chinese characters in gold and the year 1990, displayed at the left hand side of the poster and on the treble clef symbol respectively. At the lower right side of the poster, there are several vertical columns of Chinese characters as well as several numbers denoting dates, a telephone number, and a postal code. At the top of the poster, there is a gold-coloured band where the logo of the Young Songwriters' Society is displayed.

column63: Setron was a household name in Singapore during the 1960s and 1970s. Granted pioneer status by the Singapore Government in 1964, Setron was the first local company to produce television sets. It was the only television assembly plant in Southeast Asia at the time when it began operations.

title_text: A fine wheel-cut flask Wheel-cut flask
physical_appearance: This flask is made of clear glass, and is pale blue in colour. It has a short cut foot. The body of the flask is globular, and is decorated with honeycomb indentations on its surface. The shoulder of the flask is stepped, leading to a tapered cylindrical neck. The mouth of the flask has a broad rim, with a hexagonal cut shape. It is slightly scratched on its surface.
subject_terms_1: exports honeycomb (motif) vessels glassware
subject_terms_2: Bottles Exports Islamic glassware Motifs
sgcool_label_text: Made of clear glass in a pale blue tone, this flask has a globular body and long tapering neck that opens up into a wide-rimmed hexagonal mouth. The decoration on the glass is created by a facet-cutting technique, where the curved surface of the glass has been ground to produce flat or slightly concave areas. The resulting honeycomb pattern references earlier Sassanian bowls, but the overall shape of the flask is regarded to be a distinctively Islamic form, and hallmark of Iranian glass production from the 8th to the 12th century.

title_text: A wheel-cut blue bowl   Wheel-cut blue bowl
physical_appearance: This cobalt blue bowl has flared walls, with a flat base, and slightly everted rim. The exterior features a scrolling palmette motif. The edge of the rim and base has added bands of wheel-cut facets. The  bowl has some cracks and scratches.
subject_terms_1: palmette (motif) scrolls (motif) glassware
subject_terms_2: Bowls (Tableware) Islamic glassware Motifs
sgcool_label_text: This cobalt blue bowl features flared walls and a slightly everted rim on a fairly flat base. It has been skilfully decorated with heart-shaped palmette motifs which feature scrolled ends curling inwards and a cross-hatched oval in the centre. This central pattern is bordered along the top and bottom by bands of successive wheel-cut facets, resulting in decoration that is bold and flamboyant. The precise execution of the cuts shows off the expertise and accomplished skills of its maker. This style of decoration is produced by bevelling the surface of the glass to the design, and has been termed as ‘slant-cut’ style.

title_text: A Painting from a Dasavatara Series: Matsya Avatara, or fish avatar of Vishnu Matsya Avatara, fish avatar of Vishnu
physical_appearance: This painting features the Matsya Avatara, or the fish avatar of Vishnu. There are two figures in the painting. On the right, a blue-skinned Vishnu is shown emerging from his fish avatar. He is holding a manuscript, a golden mace, a shell and a discus. There is a lotus flower tucked into his clothing. On the left, is the demon Hayagiva emerging from a shell. He is holding a golden mace and a shield. The painting is bordered by a floral pattern. There is no inscription on the painting.
subject_terms_1: representation (form of expression) Hinduism mythology (literary genre) avatara
subject_terms_2: Painting Vishnu (Hindu deity) Matsya (Hindu deity) Hindu mythology Hinduism
sgcool_label_text:
The blue-skinned Vishnu is shown emerging from his fish avatar and holding a manuscript page from the ancient sacred texts called the Vedas. He also holds a golden mace, a conch shell, a discus and the lotus flower he usually holds is tucked into his yellow dhoti. He is attacking the demon Hayagiva who emerges from a conch-shell, and holds up a golden mace and a shield to protect himself.

Matsya, which means fish in Sanskrit, is Vishnu’s first avatar, or incarnation. Hayagriva had stolen the ancient Vedas from Brahma, and hidden them in the ocean. Therefore Vishnu takes the form of a great fish to kill Hayagriva and retrieve the vedas, signified by the manuscript in his hand.

title_text: A Qur'an in three volumes Qur'an in three volumes
physical_appearance: This is a page from a Chinese-style Qur'an. The page presents a section of verses. The verses are printed in blank ink, with a gold and multicolored, floral motif patterned border around it. The edges of the page are slightly folded.
subject_terms_1: Islam calligraphy (visual works) flower (motif) cultural diffusion Arabic scripts Chinese (culture or style)
subject_terms_2: Qur'an Islam Motifs Culture diffusion
sgcool_label_text: Conventionally, Quranic manuscripts are presented as single volumes or as a thirty-part series where each volume is called a juz. However, this Quran copy has been unusually bound in three volumes. The main folios contain 11 lines of text in black. The script used is a distinctly Chinese script style inspired by the tapering brushstroke forms in traditional Chinese calligraphy, known as sini.  Each volume features different polychrome and gold illumination on the first and final bifolios. The illumination is predominantly composed of floral motifs and has been painted in a most refined and sophisticated manner. The richness of these motifs echo Chinese embroidery on silk.

title_text: Historical Relics of the Old East India Company
physical_appearance: This print depicts the historical artefacts relating to the East India Company. Four categories of images take up the entire space of the artwork. Under each set of images, there are texts that name the images. The print has a wooden frame and there are no visible tears or chips on them. The title of the print is displayed at the bottom, in capital letters. The colours on the print do not look smudged.

sgcool_label_text: This print was published in the Illustrated London News on 30 August 1890. It features, clockwise from top left, the mantelpiece formerly in the Directors’ court-room of the old East India House, the old East India House on Leadenhall Street (1648-1726), the old Crosby House at Bishopsgate occupied by the East India Company from 1621 to 1638, the re-faced East India House on Leadenhall Street in 1726, and obverse and reverse views of the Great Seal of the Commonwealth (1651) appended to a warrant of Oliver Cromwell.

sgcool_label_text: East India House on Leadenhall Street was formerly Craven House, when it was acquired by the East India Company in 1648 for use as its headquarters in London. This print shows the East India House after remodelling and extension of its frontage was completed by the end of the 18th century. The engraving was based on a drawing by Thomas Hosmer Shepherd (1792-1864), an English topographical artist.

subject_terms_2: East India Company Prints Engraving Steamboats China History Opium War, 1840 - 1842 Junks Nemesis (Steamer) Naval battles
sgcool_label_text: This print depicts the attack by the Nemesis on Chinese war junks at Anson’s Bay on 7 January 1841. Known as the Second Battle of Chuenpee, the attack was part of the First Opium War, and contributed to the eventual cession of Hong Kong island to the British. The Nemesis, captained by Edward Belcher, was the first steam powered warship used in action by Britain. This print, based on a painting by George W. Terry, was published in Lieutenant Colonel Williams’ England’s Battles by Sea and Land by the London Printing and Publishing Company.

sgcool_label_text: This print depicts the East India Company’s fleet of transport and warships at Bombay Harbour, before their sending off for the Persian Gulf in the Anglo-Persian War. This print was published in the 3 January 1857 issue of the Illustrated London News to complement an article titled “The Persian Expedition in the Gulf of Bombay”.

title_text: Chart of the Singapore Strait
creator_2:
Staff Commander John William Reed

Navy Lieutenant T.H. Tizard

F.J. Ray

J.H. Ellis Davies, Bryer & Co.
physical_appearance: This marine chart is rectangular in shape and its perimeter is marked by a pair of black lines. The navigation chart is not crumpled and the ink is not smudged. It is grey in colour. The geographical location of Singapore as well as the islands occupying the wider Malay Peninsula are displayed in the map. There are longitudes present on the map and also a section, near the centre at the top, which translates several key terms from the Malay language to the English language.
subject_terms_1: navies colonial settlements
subject_terms_2: Engraving Nautical charts Navigation Navies Malay Peninsula Singapore China Sea Colonization
sgcool_label_text: This British Admiralty sea chart of the Singapore Strait was based on a survey by Staff Commander John William Reed of the Royal Navy between 1865 and 1869. Reed was appointed to take charge of the China Sea survey for the Royal Navy in 1861 and had first arrived in Singapore in June 1862. Engraved by Davies, Bryer & Co., this chart depicts Singapore at the southern tip of the Malay Peninsula along with the islands south of it, and includes sounding details and sailing directions.

title_text: De Landvoogdy der Moluccos met de Aangrenzende Eylanden (The Landscape of the Moluccas and the Neighbouring Islands)
physical_appearance: This map depicts the islands of Moluccas, as well as its numerous neighbouring islands. Different colours are used on the different islands, ranging from pink to turquoise to yellow. The map is separated into a larger part and a smaller one. There are two different sets of scales used in this map. On the upper right hand corner of the map which is the smaller part, the scale of 1 : 45 is used. The larger part of the map utilizes the scale of 1 : 60. Straight black lines that run diagonal, vertical, and horizontal extend out from the two compasses that are located in both parts of the map.

sgcool_label_text: Francois Valentijn (1666–1727) was a minister, naturalist and writer who served the Dutch V.O.C. in the East Indies in the late 17th and early 18th centuries. His monumental work Oud en Nieuw Oost-Indien (Old and New East-India), published between 1724 and 1726, offers a comprehensive mapping of the East Indies with a large selection of scale maps and views. This chart of Maluku (or the Moluccas) and its neighbouring islands was published in that work.

Straight black lines that run diagonal, vertical, and horizontal extend out from the two compasses that are located in both parts of the map.Pictorial representations of mountains and hills are drawn in many of the islands.

His monumental work Oud en Nieuw Oost-Indien (Old and New East-India), published between 1724 and 1726, offers a comprehensive mapping of the East Indies with a large selection of scale maps and views. context_14: This is a skirt with pleated sides. The skirt has a brown waistband. It is made of pink patterned cloth. In the middle, there is a panel bordered by blue floral embroidery. In the center, there are two medallions bordered by a gold thread. In the medallions, there is a depiction of a woman with a child in her arms, and a man in official robes in a garden.
context_15: foliage (motif) flower (motif) embroidery (visual works) folk costume
column68: The skirt was worn with a loosely-fitted jacket. Taken together, the two-piece ensemble was known as aoqun, a popular form of Han Chinese dress during the Qing dynasty. The sides of the skirt are finely pleated.  Set against a gold thread background, two medallions depict a woman holding a child in her arms and a man in official robes strolling in a garden. Skirts with pleated sides became very popular during the Qing dynasty. The fact that some skirts had as many as 100 pleats earned this type of garment the name ‘fish-scale skirt of 100 pleats’.

title_text: Elephant head bangles
materials_name: gold (metal) enamel paint quartz crystal diamond (mineral)
physical_appearance: This is a pair of bangles that are closed by a clasp in the shape of elephant heads. It is decorated with gold and enamel paint. Small pieces of diamonds lined the outside of the bangle, while the inside is painted with floral motifs.
subject_terms_1: foliage (motif) flower (motif) jewelry
subject_terms_2: Bracelets Diamond jewelry, Mogul Empire Motifs
sgcool_label_text:
A pair of gold and enamelled elephant head bangles, decorated with precious stones, and exquisite pink enamelling on the inside of the shank.
This object shows the taste for luxury objects in Northern India in the 19th century. In Mughal India there was a great revival in the art of rock crystal carving, and Mughal craftsmen reached new heights of technical virtuosity especially during the reign of Shah Jahan (1628-1658). The motifs in the gem work and enamelling of flowers, plants, scrolling vines and animal forms allude to paradise gardens on earth. It would have been highly prized and made for a privileged few.

sgcool_label_text: The carved rock crystal eight-lobed cup and cover is inlaid with precious stones within a system of gold wire.  This object shows the taste for luxury objects in Northern India in the 19th century. In Mughal India there was a great revival in the art of rock crystal carving, and Mughal craftsmen reached new heights of technical virtuosity especially during the reign of Shah Jahan (1628-1658). The motifs in the gem work and enamelling of flowers, plants, scrolling vines and animal forms allude to paradise gardens on earth. It would have been highly prized and made for a privileged few.

title_text: Display stand Display stand
physical_appearance: The image shows a display stand. It  is brown in colour. The top of the display stand has a flat upper surface. It is of a lighter shade of brown as compared to its base. The base of the display stand is carved to resemble intertwining roots. The roots are gnarled in appearance. The root formation closest to the foreground of the image extends outwards, as compared to the others which tend to be clustered.
subject_terms_1: carvings (visual works) symbolism (artistic concept) cultural artefacts
subject_terms_2: Stands (Furniture) Symbolism
sgcool_label_text: This huangyangmu (boxwood) stand has been carved, at least partially, to appear like a natural root formation. It consists of a flat upper surface supported by gnarled, intertwining roots. The Chinese literati favoured furnishings that alluded to nature in form as well as materiality. Made of wood or stone, these items which included tables, stools and stands were also often depicted in Ming and Qing paintings.

title_text: Indian Pioneer, Gnanapragasam Pillai Portrait of Indian Pioneer, Gnanapragasam Pillai
physical_appearance: Gnanapragasam Pillai is painted in this portrait. He is dressed formally, with a formal green jacket with a flower attached to his left lapel. The jacket is not buttoned, revealing a white shirt with a buttoned collar. He sports a moustache as well. The portrait is bounded with a brown frame. The brown frame contains an inner and outer border.  Both of these borders are demarcated by a wood-coloured region.
subject_terms_1: founders (originators) businessmen merchants
subject_terms_2: Portrait painitng Businessmen Merchants Tamil (Indic people)
sgcool_label_text: Gnanapragasam Pillai (1872-1915), was born in India, in Muthialpet, the region of Pondicherry in south India; a French territory in colonial India. He migrated to Singapore/Malaya in search of a better fortune. He was an early Indian trader who owned a grocery business along Serangoon Road near Tekka Market in the early 1900s. He was a wealthy businessman who had two shop houses at number 44 and 46 Serangoon Road. His business was eventually taken over by P.Govindasamy Pillai after his demise. Having one’s portrait taken was common in early-mid 20th century Singapore among the upper middle class, well to do businessmen.

title_text: Brocade
physical_appearance: The image consists of a large brocde stole and a smaller one. Both are rectangular in shape and predominantly green and white in colour. It has diaper patterns that extend all over its surface. The sides of each lozenge is a fish, and in the centre there is a tortoise with red eyes. The big brocade stole has two holes, one at its lower right side and the other towards its left side at its horizontal mid-point.
subject_terms_1: textiles (visual works) avatara Hinduism symbolism (artistic concept) diaper patterns motifs allover patterns
subject_terms_2: Textiles Stoles (Clothing) Avatars (Religion) Shawls Hinduism Motifs Hindu symbolism Vishnu (Hindu deity)
sgcool_label_text:
This is a brocade from the Gujarat region of western India. Gujarat was a major centre of textile manufacture and trade, and Gujarati brocades were of fine design and craftsmanship. Although weaving has a long history in the region, many techniques and motifs were brought in from Persia during the reign of the Mughals. Traditional Indian patterns, such as flora and fauna were also integrated into the new approach, leading to the depictions of various symbols on textile.

This brocade symbolically represents Vishnu – the trellis pattern is formed by a very unusual fish pattern, while the central motif is a tortoise. The fish and tortoise are the first and second avatars of Vishnu.

title_text: Brocade Stole
physical_appearance: This brocade stole is predominantly light brown in colour. It is rectangular in shape. Along its sides are floral patterns that extend and follow the rectangular perimeter. Within the border of floral patterns, the figures of Hindu deities Krishna and Radha are present all over the brocade stole. Along Krishna and Radha are patterns of tree branches that are in green in colour and come with flowers and parakeets. There is a distinct stain line that runs vertically down the brocade stole at its mid-point.
subject_terms_1: textiles (visual works) deities Hinduism allover patterns plant-derived motifs birds (motifs)
subject_terms_2: Textiles Radha (Hindu deity) Krishna (Hindu deity) Stoles (Clothing) Shawls Motifs
sgcool_label_text:
This gold kimkhab brocade would have been woven in Benaras, which was the epicentre of fine brocade weaving during the 19th and 20th centuries. Benarasi brocades gained prominence during the Mughal period, and continued to be patronised by royalty and the British up to the 20th century. Over time, patterns and techniques evolved, and the export market provided new designs for weavers.

This stole shows a very unusual repeated pattern of Krishna and Radha sitting on a swing, which is hanging from the branch of a tree. A pair of parakeets is perched on the tree. Designs such as these can be seen from the 20th century onwards.

title_text: Brocade Stole
physical_appearance: This brocade stole is predominantly pink in colour, with a darker shade in the middle and a lighter hue at its sides. It is rectangular in shape. Along its breath, there are alternating patterns of elephants and birds. Along its length, there are also elephants and birds, but in a different form of design and arrangement. Within the borders, the figure of the Hindu deity Shiva is present all over the brocade stole. The pattern of Shiva is upside down from the top of the stole to its horizontal mid-point. He is in a lotus position and there are patterns of tree branches that come with flowers and parakeets.
subject_terms_1: textiles (visual works) Hinduism allover patterns plant-derived motifs birds (motifs) deities floral patterns motifs
subject_terms_2: Textiles Stoles (Clothing) Shawls Siva (Hindu deity) Motifs
sgcool_label_text: This Benarasi silk brocade carries the extremely unusual motif of Shiva as Yogeshwara, seated as an ascetic upon a tiger skin, holding a trident in one hand, damroo in the other, which a cobra around his shoulders. Each figure is separated by a flowering plant upon which are perched a magpie and a woodpecker. It is a superb example of the fine detail that Benarasi weavers could achieve using multi-coloured threads and a very tight weave.

title_text: Brocade Stole
physical_appearance: This brocade stole is predominantly brown in colour. Dark brown tassels are attached to the stole on the borders of its height. At the centre of the brocade stole, there is a vertical crease running down to the bottom. Alternating figures of Krishna and Radha, Hindu deities, are present at the borders of its height. The brocade stole does not appear to be torn or frayed.
subject_terms_1: textiles (visual works) Hinduism deities motifs
subject_terms_2: Textiles Stoles (Clothing) Shawls Radha (Hindu deity) Krishna (Hindu deity) Motifs
sgcool_label_text: This tinsel brocade would have been woven in Benaras. It is a silk-gauze popularised by women in the Mughal courts. The border of this brocade is highly unusual and rare for a Benarasi brocade. Alternating figures of Krishna and Radha appear on the wide border, without any of the usual accompaniments of floral scrollwork, background patterning, geometric edging or birds and animals.

title_text: Prayer Mat Janamaz
physical_appearance: The prayer rug is pink in colour. It is rectangular in shape. Near the bottom of the prayer rug, there is an outline design of a mihrab with minarets on the side. A border that is golden in colour can be seen. It contains a geometrical shape as its pattern.
subject_terms_1: textiles (visual works) geometric patterns Islam prayers (oral works) motifs religious objects
subject_terms_2: Textiles Rugs, Prayer Islam Islamic prayers and devotions Motifs
sgcool_label_text: This janamaz (Persian/Urdu: prayer mat) is a fine example of a zari-woven silk textile. The central motif appears to be a stylised, almost minimalistic, version of a mihrab with minarets on the side, surrounded by a geometric border. Prayer mats of this fine quality would have most likely been used by the upper classes or by royalty.

title_text: Dish cover Thaalposh
physical_appearance: The Thaalposh, or dish cover, is heptagonal in shape. An outline of a circle is situated within the heptagon. It has an inner and outer circumference and the border in between has numerous patterns of fruits in the colour of red. Within the inner circumference, A line of calligraphy is written in each of the four straight sections that extend from the inner circle of the circular dish to the outer circle. The sections facing the directions of East and West are dark red in colour, while the ones in the directions of North and South are light brown in colour. All four sections contain similar patterns of scrolls. At the centre of the heptagon, there is a single flower. This flower is surrounded by numerous smaller flowers, that are drawn together to form a smaller circle as well.
subject_terms_1: decorative art (art genre) Islam ritual objects textiles (visual works) floral patterns scrolls (motifs) allover patterns
subject_terms_2: Islam Calligraphy, Urdu Textiles Motifs
sgcool_label_text: This hand printed cotton thaalposh or large dish cover originates from the Deccan region. It would have been used to cover dishes during religious festivals by Deccani Muslims, both sunnis and shiyas. The kalamkari print shows not only the traditional floral designs and red-ochre colours, but also incorporates four sections of calligraphy, highlighting the textile’s use in ritual. The kalamkari printing can be attributed to the south Indian centre of Masulipatnam.

title_text: Military Uniform Herbie Lim's Military Uniform
physical_appearance: A Second World War Force 136 military jacket is displayed. The jacket contains a collar as well as a belt. The front of the jacket includes four pockets sewn on it. The colour of the jacket is khaki and it is long sleeved. There are four black buttons running down the center front of the apparel. There are no visible tears on the exterior of the jacket. Accompanying it are a military insignia on the right chest pocket and a badge on the left chest pocket. Both the epaulettes of the jacket contain three pips each.
subject_terms_1: world wars insignias (devices) badges military uniforms
subject_terms_2: World War, 1939 - 1945 Military uniforms Insignia Badges
sgcool_label_text:
The military jacket, which comes with a parachutist badge, a military insignia and a whistle, belongs to Herbert Lim Eng Kwan (1927 – 2002). 
He was the eldest son of Lim Chong Pang and Lee Poh Neo, and a third generation member of two famous pioneer families in Singapore. Mrs Lee Choon Guan, daughter of Tan Keong Saik and founder president of the Chinese Ladies’ Association, was his maternal grandmother and Lim Nee Soon, a Teochew millionaire who made his fortune in the rubber and pineapple industries, was his paternal grandfather. Herbert is also the eldest son of Lim Chong Pang.  
Nine days before the Fall of Singapore on 15 February 1942, Herbie (as he was affectionately known) and some of his family members were evacuated and eventually settled in Bangalore, South India for the duration of the war. Several women in the family, including his grandmother, Mrs Lee Choon Guan joined the Women’s Voluntary Service. In 1945, Herbie joined Z Force, an arm of the British Intelligence Force 136 after he completed his high school studies. He became a paratrooper who held the rank of Captain. However, three weeks before he was supposed to be parachuted into Malaya, the Japanese surrendered and he missed the chance to participate in the liberation of Malaya.

title_text: Nantang Red Lacquered Box
physical_appearance: A red lacquered box is depicted in the picture. The cover of the box is decorated with two peonies that are golden in colour. In between the two peonies, there are Chinese characters stating the name of the Cantonese restaurant, Nantang, the phone number of the restauranr, and its address and telephone number. These characters are written in a vertical alignment, running from the top to bottom. The circular cover has a golden circumference at its edges. The cover of the box looks to have several scratches on it.
subject_terms_1: lacquerware packing material gift giving customs (social) flower (motif) weddings (ceremonies)
subject_terms_2: Motifs Lacquer boxes Gifts Marriage customs and rites
sgcool_label_text:
The post-war period saw the establishment of several famous Chinese restaurants in Tua Po (Kreta Ayer area), including Nantang Restaurant at 8 Mosque Street and Da Dong Restaurant, which was just a few doors away on the same street. Judging from the five-digit telephone number on the box, it is possibly dated to the fifties and sixties. It was imported from Hong Kong, with the name of the import company or the lacquerware maker inscribed on its base.      
The box, made of bamboo and lacquered in an auspicious red, was traditionally used as a container for wedding pastries. The bride’s family would distribute boxes of these to relatives and friends ahead of the wedding, often together with the wedding invitation card.

The background of the painting comprises of trees and the sky. The painting has a wooden frame and a pink border. Hornsted's skin is painted as pale whereas Ali's skin is painted as dark brown. Hornsted is also dressed totally in a white colonial outfit while Ali only adorns a pair of brown shorts and is barefoot. There is a crocodile and a monkey standing on the ground alongside Hornstedt and Ali. There is one dead bird on the table and another in a transparent jar.Ali is holding an animal in his hands and Hornstedt is looking at it.

title_text: A View of Hong Kong Harbour Hong Kong Harbour
physical_appearance: This painting shows the Hong Kong harbour. The island of Hong Kong is in the background of the painting. In the foreground, there is a variety of vessels shown, including a coastal junk, Tanka boats, small boats, and three-mast ships. There is no inscription seen in the painting.
subject_terms_1: junks (vessels) harbors seaports Chinese (culture or style) trade (function) watercraft souvenirs seascape
subject_terms_2: Painting Junks Harbors China trade painting Boats and boating Hong Kong (China) Souvenirs (Keepsakes)
sgcool_label_text: The island of Hong Kong is visibly discernable and detailed in an accurate manner. The artist has included several well-known landmarks such as the tower of St. John’s Cathedral, seen above the smaller paddle steamer and the Government House, uphill to its right. A great variety of vessels are present in the harbour, including a coastal junk, Tanka boats operated by blue-robed “Boat Dwellers” (native ethnic minorities of Southern China), covered hulks (obsolete sailing ships converted for use as naval base), small side wheelers, and three-masted sailing ships flying the flags of Britain, France and the United States.   The first views of Hong Kong, such as this example, began to appear in the early 19th century. The British built their first city on the island of Hong Kong and called it Victoria city (presently Sheung Wan and Sai Wan districts). The name “Victoria” demonstrated the extent of rule and authority of the British government. As Hong Kong grew in stature as a British crown colony, such paintings became an important record of the development of the port and the increasing volume of international ships that called to port. Beyond the great number of vessels that visited the important Hong Kong harbour, lies a curiosity in the presence of a junk-rigged vessel with additional jib and topsails in Western fashion. The adapted design of the ship illustrates the pluralistic nature of interactions within cosmopolitan harbours. The port was a gate way of cross-cultural interaction between the East and the West, and demonstrates artistic and cultural exchange between China and the world. Such paintings were known as China trade paintings, and were popular in the 18th and 19th centuries. Produced largely for visiting tourists and foreign traders, the paintings were executed by local and foreign artists, working in a Western style in order to appeal to the market. Art studios were set up in Guangzhou and Hong Kong, where mass-produced genre scenes of treaty ports, portraits and still lifes were sold as souvenirs. While China trade paintings found a huge market at that time, the growing popularity of photography in the late 19th century shifted this demand pattern, eventually rendering such trade paintings obsolete.

title_text: Manila shawl
physical_appearance: This black silk is fringed around the edges. It is embroided with floral motifs and pattenrs in polychrome colours. There is a bordered embroidery around the edge, with larger flower embroidery at the top left and bottom right. At the bottom right, there is a bird amongst the flowers. There are no tears seen.
subject_terms_1: exports flower (motif) leaf scrolls birds (motifs)
subject_terms_2: Shawls exports Embroidery Motifs
sgcool_label_text: Shawls such as this object were often referred to as Manila shawl, or Mantones de Manila. Manila shawls were popular in Europe during the 19th and 20th centuries, especially in Spain. They are usually worn covering the shoulders or as a mantilla covering the heads of women. Made of silk and produced in China, they were brought to European shores through trade routes earlier established by the Manila-Acapulco galleon trade (1565–1815). Although the shawls were made in China, they were usually shipped to Europe via Manila on the galleons, hence the misnomer, “Manila shawls”.

subject_terms_2: Ethnic jewellery Gold jewellery Workmanship Dress accessories Necklaces Goldwork
sgcool_label_text: The m?nga m?lai (Tamil: Mango Garland or necklace) and the m?nikka Addigai (Tamil: Ruby Choker) are typical examples of Tamil necklaces, both worn for celebratory occasions such as weddings and/or as part of dance costumes by bharatanatyam dancers. Nature inspired jewellery, featuring flora and fauna were common in South India. The m?nga m?lai design can be traced as far back as the Chola period, as seen in bronzes produced at the time. This pair of necklaces are important in many ways – they bear testimony to the socio-cultural heritage of Tamils in Singapore; they are also superior examples of Indian gold craftsmanship and of the material culture of Tamils in the region in the 19th/20th centuries.

title_text: Chaur Sahib
physical_appearance: The image shows a set of two flywhisks. Both of them have a handle that is golden in colour. Long white woolly hair hangs out from the top of the handle. Some strands of hair end below the base of the handle of the flywhisks.
subject_terms_1: Sikhism ceremonial objects ritual objects implement (object genre)
subject_terms_2: Sikhism Customs and practices Ceremonial objects
sgcool_label_text: Chaur sahib and chauri are ceremonial flywhisks that are used to fan the Sikh holy scriptures, the Guru Granth Sahib (holy scripture of the Sikh faith), as an act of devotion and respect during religious observances. Legend has it that when the Guru Granth Sahib was first installed at the Golden Temple in Amritsar, Punjab, India, Guru Arjan Dev (the 5th Sikh Guru). The chaur sahib continue to be important ritual objects used in Sikh temples, as seen in Singapore's Sikh Gurudwaras as well.

It is painted with multicolored enamels in the form of repeating flower motifs. The pot is fitted with gold mounts, and sits on a four legged gold base. sgcool_label_text: This coffee pot has been decorated with European made gilded mounts. Japanese ceramics, such as Imari wares, were mainly introduced to Europe in the latter part of the 17th century through the trades of the Dutch East India Company. Imari porcelain was made in Arita, and is named after the port from which they are exported, and are known for their underglaze blue, iron-red and gold colours. Coffee became popular in Europe around the mid-17th century which increased the demand for coffee-specific wares.

title_text: An oratory Portable Namban shrine

physical_appearance: This is a portable altarpiece. It is composed of a rectangular wooden case.The sides of the case are decorated with Japanese lacquer techniques. There is a latch in the centre of the shrine. The doors of the shrine are painted with flower motifs, scrolling leaves and trees, with some images of birds. There are some small minor scratches and indents seen.
subject_terms_1: Japanese lacquer styles exports Roman Catholicism plant-derived motifs birds (motifs) lacquerware cultural diffusion oratories devotional objects
subject_terms_2: Altarpieces Triptychs Lacquer and lacquering Japan Namban art Exports Catholic Church Motifs cultural diffusion
sgcool_label_text: The decoration of this portable shrine, probably used for private devotion, combines Japanese lacquer craftsmanship, European Christian subject matter, and the late Mannerist painting style of Spain or Flanders. It is a striking example of interaction of cultures.  The crowned Virgin and sleeping Christ Child are flanked by St Joseph and the infant St John the Baptist. The inside and outside of the doors are decorated with Japanese lacquer techniques.  Lacquered furniture was one of the most prized Japanese products exported to Europe and Asia. Cabinets, chests, and other objects were decorated in the namban (literally, “foreigners from the south”) style. The term came to be associated with artefacts made for foreigners. The principal customers for namban lacquer were the Portuguese, who first arrived in Japan around 1542, followed by the Spanish and the Dutch.

title_text: Turban ornament in the form of a parrot
materials_name: enamel paint diamond (mineral) gold (metal) pearl (animal material) emerald (mineral)
physical_appearance: This turban ornament is in a shape of a parrot, decorated in gold, enamel, and gems. The parrot is perched on a curling leaf. It is decorated with red and green enamel, with added elements of white enamel and gold. The wings are decorated with tear-drop diamonds. On its head, there is a rosette attached by a stem. The bird holds in its beak a semi-spherical ornament with seed pearl and emerald tassels. The ornament is perched on a stand.
subject_terms_1: flower (motif) birds (motifs) worn costume accessories ornaments (object genre) jewelry
subject_terms_2: Jewelry Dress accessories Motifs Ethnic costume
sgcool_label_text: A gold, enamelled, and gem-set turban ornament (turra) in the form of a parrot perched on a curling leaf. It is decorated with translucent red and green enamel, with highlights of opaque white enamel. The wings are denoted by large, tear-drop diamonds. A rosette above is hinged at the stem and quivers when worn. The bird holds a semi-spherical ornament with seed pearl and emerald tassels (probably a later replacement) which also tremble when worn. This object shows the taste for luxury objects in Northern India in the 19th century. In Mughal India craftsmen reached new heights of technical virtuosity especially during the reign of Shah Jahan (1628-1658). The motifs in the gem work and enamelling of flowers, plants, and scrolling vines, and the parrot, allude to paradise gardens on earth. It would have been highly prized and made for a privileged few.

column51:
Rollei is a renowned German manufacturer of cameras and optics founded in 1920 by Paul Franke and Reinhold Heidecke. To remain competitive against Japanese manufacturers, Rollei shifted its production to Singapore in 1971, while retaining research and development work in Braunschweig, Germany. 
This slide projector is an example of the products manufactured by the Rollei production plants in Singapore.

column66: This Speedrite cheque writer (also termed ‘cheque protector’) by Hall-Welter Co Inc, one of the established American manufacturers of cheque writers, was manufactured in USA around the 1970s, and was used to produce inked figures on a cheque by pulling the lever on the side of the machine. Machines like this would have been used by banks, merchants and other financial institutions as they provided precise, clear and quality output, and prevented any fraudulent action such as alteration of the amount on the cheque.

sgcool_label_text: Made in USA, this Motorola cellular phone is one of the early cellular phones and has the typical 12-key telephone keypad and nine additional special keys, namely Rcl (recall), Clr (clear), Snd (send), Sto (store), Fcn (function), End, Pwr (power), Lock and Vol (volume). Limited information was shown on its LED display. The battery allowed for a call of up to 60 minutes, after which it was necessary to charge the phone up to 10 hours with a separate charger.

The marble top exhibits the same shape, but it is a bigger in size. There does not seem to be any visible cracks on the marble top. subject_terms_2: Tables Coffee shops Motifs
sgcool_label_text: In Singapore, the kopitiam or coffee shop is a place where people meet, socialise, chit-chat and gossip over a cup of freshly-brewed coffee, half-boiled eggs and kaya toast. From the 1950s to the 1980s, the kopitiam had its signature ubiquitous furniture set, comprising a wooden table with marble table top such as this table, and wooden chairs with round seats. The tables varied in terms of the table’s legs, and the different shaped marble table tops which were round, square or hexagonal. Such hardy tables have been mostly replaced by plastic tables which are lightweight, and can be moved around easily or sometimes collapsed to save space.

Each chair comprises of four legs with a circular spindle underneath the seat. There are no decorative motifs on the spindles, legs, and rails. Four of the chairs have geometric motifs visible on their seats, while the last one has floral patterns instead. The chairs also have rails that connect the lower rail to the round seat.

subject_terms_2: Coffee shops Chairs Motifs
sgcool_label_text: In Singapore, the kopitiam or coffee shop is a place where people meet, socialise, chit-chat and gossip over a cup of freshly-brewed coffee, half-boiled eggs and kaya toast. From the 1950s to the 1980s, the kopitiam had its signature ubiquitous furniture set, comprising a wooden table with marble table top and wooden chairs with round seats. The old chairs were, and are still made in Czechoslovakia. The first kopitiam chairs arrived in Singapore in the late 1930s. Made from pliable and hardy wood, the chair is characterised by a contoured spindle back and moulded plywood seat, using the bentwood technique that was invented by Michael Thonet in the 1830s. It is believed that the seats were knocked down and flat-packed before being shipped in bulk so as to lower freight costs. They were then assembled and varnished in workshops, locally branded and sold. Some of these chairs also have decorative motifs on the seats. These durable chairs have been mostly replaced by plastic chairs and stools which are lightweight, and can therefore be moved around easily and stacked to save space in the kopitiam.

sgcool_label_text: Made in Singapore and Malaysia, this round armchair with woven plastic cords and a white painted metal frame was iconic in the 1960s and 1970s. The true inspiration for this chair is not known, but could possibly be influenced by the Scandinavian chairs with plastic/polyurethane cords of the 1950s and 1960s. Users of such armchairs would have enjoyed its cooling effect under the warm climate of Singapore.

column55: This jacket was worn with the matching skirt. The scalloped edges of the jacket and skirt are trimmed with bugle beads, as are the faux cuffs and medallion details on both garments. Round buttons are here only used for decorative effect. Both jacket and skirt are secured by hooks and press studs. On the front is a flower stalk formed by bugle beads, echoing the floral pattern of the silk fabric. Garments like these were fashionable in China in the 1920s, especially among women in their late teens and early twenties.

title_text: Pink dress with purl fringe
physical_appearance: This pink dress has a scoop neckline, decorated waistline, and a scallop hem at the bottom. Its sleeves and front skirt is decorated with a bronze fringe. It is also decorated with bangle beads across the skirt, along the neckline, and along the sleeves. On the front of the dress, there are beads sewn to form the shape of winged creatures.
subject_terms_1: motifs Peranakan fashion (concept) beadwork (visual works) cultural diffusion
subject_terms_2: Dresses Motifs Peranakan (Asian people) Fashion Culture diffusion
sgcool_label_text: The pink dress is lavishly beaded along its scoop neckline, high waistline and scalloped hem. Purl fringe hangs from the sleeves as well as from the fabric that is draped asymmetrically across the body. Bugle beads embellish buttons and form a pair of winged creatures on the front of the dress.  By the early 20th century, Peranakan women were wearing European dress although many continued to wear the sarong kebaya and Chinese dress. The decoration of this garment may have been influenced by 1920s fashion in Europe and the United States of America which saw the popularity of heavy embellishment on tubular silhouettes.

title_text: Beaded Watch Case
physical_appearance: This is a beaded watch case. It is made from green velvet, and embroided with coloured beads. It is in a shape of a leaf, with embroided floral motifs bordering a depiction of a fruit in the center. The fruit resembles a pineapple or promegranate, and is surrounded by several leaves.
subject_terms_1: beadwork (visual works) plant-derived motifs Peranakan
subject_terms_2: Beadwork Motifs Watchcases Peranakan (Asian people)
sgcool_label_text: This watch case is embroidered with a mixture of glass seed beads and metallic beads. A pomegranate is beaded in a variety of colours, though when treated in such a way and given a set of spikey leaves, it was more likely to represent a pineapple, which symbolizes windfall in a not too distant future. Metallic beads were favoured for their shimmering quality. In comparison with glass seed beads, metallic beads were generally more expensive and produced in smaller quantities.

sgcool_label_text: This purse is embroidered with a figure of a dragon on one side and a phoenix on the other. As shown on this piece, the phoenix is a combination of the neck of a crane, feathers of a golden pheasant and tail of a peacock, which is effectively depicted here with both metal and glass seed beads. It was a symbol of honour and riches. It was said to appear only in times of peace.

sgcool_label_text: This dompet has a unique semi-circular shape quite unlike other envelope purses. Chain and bullion stiches are used to create the contours of a butterfly and two stalks of flowers. Unlike Chinese purses which were either square or circular in shape, the purses made for or by the Peranakan community show more variation.

physical_appearance: This is a beaded purse in a semicircular shape. It is made from red velvet, and decorated with embroided beads and stitching. sgcool_label_text: This dompet has a unique semi-circular shape quite unlike other envelope purses. The front flap is adorned with a fully beaded bouquet of flowers and what is possibly a pomegranate, a symbol of fertility. The flap opens to reveal a cluster of flowers and mango fruits. This dompet is also embroidered with gold thread in a style known as tekad timbol.  Tekad timbol was not only practised by the Peranakans but also by the Malays, for whom it was better known as tekat.

title_text: The End of History
subject_terms_1: aliases mixed media artists' materials
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Mixed media (Art) Artists' materials
sgcool_label_text: In 2009, the local art public found – to its surprise – that a Singaporean painter active in the Nanyang period had escaped recognition from history books despite leaving behind 76 notable paintings. It was later revealed that Huang Wei never existed – at least not in real life – but was a fiction created by artist-curator Alan Oei. Oei has an enduring fixation with history painting but is troubled that it possesses pale relevance to art-making in the present day. In Huang Wei, Oei entwined fiction with fact and created a character who stands as a metaphor for a vital but missing part of Singapore’s art history. In effect, Huang Wei may be regarded as a performance on several levels, and the relationship between creator and created echoes that of a two-way mirror. On one side, the character of Huang Wei is a conduit and device for Oei to unravel his conundrum about time and history. Yet to ‘use’ Huang Wei entails Oei becoming a medium himself and ‘channelling’ his creation so that the meta-artist can step through time’s portals and enter a realm where history painting still reigns. Still, even liminal spaces offer fleeting refuge and the stop-motion video Goliath unfolds to reveal the artist’s hand (Huang Wei, and/or Oei?) in a continuous cycle of creating-destroying his painting, time and again. Alan Oei (b. 1976, Singapore) is an artist-curator interested in the workings between art history, politics and community. He holds a Bachelor’s degree in Art History from Columbia University and a Diploma in Fine Arts from Lasalle College of the Arts. Huang Wei – a fictional post-war painter of maimed children – is the alter-ego Oei uses to present his paintings. His work has been shown in Malaysia, Hong Kong, Melbourne and New York. In addition, Oei’s curatorial projects include the ‘OH! Open House’, an annual art walkabout inside local neighbourhoods and residences. He was recently appointed the Artistic Director of Substation, Singapore.

He holds a Bachelor’s degree in Art History from Columbia University and a Diploma in Fine Arts from Lasalle College of the Arts. Huang Wei – a fictional post-war painter of maimed children – is the alter-ego Oei uses to present his paintings. His work has been shown in Malaysia, Hong Kong, Melbourne and New York. In addition, Oei’s curatorial projects include the ‘OH! Open House’, an annual art walkabout inside local neighbourhoods and residences. He was recently appointed the Artistic Director of Substation, Singapore.

Still, even liminal spaces offer fleeting refuge and the stop-motion video Goliath unfolds to reveal the artist’s hand (Huang Wei, and/or Oei?) in a continuous cycle of creating-destroying his painting, time and again. Alan Oei (b. 1976, Singapore) is an artist-curator interested in the workings between art history, politics and community. He holds a Bachelor’s degree in Art History from Columbia University and a Diploma in Fine Arts from Lasalle College of the Arts. Huang Wei – a fictional post-war painter of maimed children – is the alter-ego Oei uses to present his paintings. His work has been shown in Malaysia, Hong Kong, Melbourne and New York. In addition, Oei’s curatorial projects include the ‘OH! Open House’, an annual art walkabout inside local neighbourhoods and residences. He was recently appointed the Artistic Director of Substation, Singapore.
