On one side, the character of Huang Wei is a conduit and device for Oei to unravel his conundrum about time and history. Yet to ‘use’ Huang Wei entails Oei becoming a medium himself and ‘channelling’ his creation so that the meta-artist can step through time’s portals and enter a realm where history painting still reigns. Still, even liminal spaces offer fleeting refuge and the stop-motion video Goliath unfolds to reveal the artist’s hand (Huang Wei, and/or Oei?) in a continuous cycle of creating-destroying his painting, time and again. Alan Oei (b. 1976, Singapore) is an artist-curator interested in the workings between art history, politics and community. He holds a Bachelor’s degree in Art History from Columbia University and a Diploma in Fine Arts from Lasalle College of the Arts. Huang Wei – a fictional post-war painter of maimed children – is the alter-ego Oei uses to present his paintings. His work has been shown in Malaysia, Hong Kong, Melbourne and New York. In addition, Oei’s curatorial projects include the ‘OH! Open House’, an annual art walkabout inside local neighbourhoods and residences. He was recently appointed the Artistic Director of Substation, Singapore.

column57: This piece was specially created to celebrate SG50, Singapore's 50th year of independence, in 2015 and it was inspired by the William Farquhar collection of natural history drawings from the National Museum of Singapore. Farquhar was the first Resident and Commandant of Singapore, and the 477 watercolours from the collection were commissioned by him when he served as British Resident and Commandant of Melaka from 1803 to 1818. The drawings combine traditional Chinese painting methods with European, providing an insight into the local flora and fauna, as well as a glimpse into the history of British rule in the Malay Peninsula during the early 19th century.

title_text: Portrait of a Chinese merchant A Chinese Merchant
physical_appearance: This is a portrait of a Chinese merchant. He is dressed in official robes and accessories. He is a wearing a black hat, lue robes with long pearl necklaces. In the front of his robe, there is a picture of a bird amongst stylized clouds. His right hand is holding the pearl necklace. There are no inscriptions seen.
subject_terms_1: folk costume chiaroscuro merchants
subject_terms_2: Ethnic costume Painting Portrait China History Qing dynasty, 1644-1912 Chiaroscuro Merchants
sgcool_label_text: This half-length portrait of an unidentified Chinese merchant dressed in official robes is attributed to the painter Lamqua (1802–ca.1860) or his studio in Canton (modern-day Guangzhou), China. The realistic portrayal of the Chinese merchant is the result of the artist’s deft application of the Western painting technique of chiaroscuro---the use of light and shading to create a sense of three-dimensionality.  Lamqua was famous in mid-19th century Guangzhou for his outstanding painting skills, in particular, for executing European-style works with a realistic figurative composition. Lamqua owned a popular workshop that produced portraits, harbour views and paintings of other subjects that appealed to foreign customers. Several of Lamqua’s paintings were even exhibited in the West, including at the Royal Academy in London in the 1830s and 1840s.

title_text: Butterfly-shaped inkwell
physical_appearance: This is a copper inkwell made and painted to resemble a butterfly. The inkwell has detachable components. It has wings decorated with multi-colored enamel paint. The body of the butterfly is grey. The sizes of the inkwell is decorated with scrolling floral motifs.
subject_terms_1: flower (motif) exports
subject_terms_2: Inkwells Motifs Exports
sgcool_label_text: This copper inkwell is made and painted in vibrant colours to resemble a butterfly. The insect is an auspicious motif in Chinese culture and is often represented in paintings, textiles and other mediums. In addition to signifying joy, butterflies in pairs were also seen as symbols of marital bliss. The art of painting in enamels on copper was introduced from Europe into China during the late Kangxi period (1622-1722), probably by Jesuit missionaries, and came into vogue in the 18th century. The bustling city of Guangzhou, where this inkwell was likely made, was an important production centre of enamelled metalwares for both the domestic and export markets during the Qing dynasty (1644–1911).

title_text: A Pair of Filipino Mestizo Figures Filipino Mestizo Figures
materials_name: stone (worked rock) wood (plant material) ivory (material) resin (organic material) glass (material) lacquer (material)
physical_appearance: This pair of figurines resembles a Mestizo couple in Manila. On the left, the female figure is seated. She is wearing a beige embroided top, a shawl, and blue patterned long skirt with an overskirt wrap, and shoes. She is also wearing a pair of gold hoop earings. The male figure on the right is standing behind a miniature chair. He is wearing a beige embroided blouse, and pants, with a top hat. Both figures are wearing a gold cross around their necks.
subject_terms_1: cultural diffusion indigenous people ethnicity colonialism folk costume
subject_terms_2: Figurines Racially mixed people Indigenous people Ethnicity Culture diffusion Ethnic costume
sgcool_label_text: This pair of figures embodies a typical Mestizo couple in Manila during the early 19th century. Contributing to their impressive realism, both figures are carved and painted in refined wood and embellished with real human hair, glass eyes and clothes made from pineapple leaf fibres. The shoulders, elbows, hips and knees of both figures are separately attached, giving the figures a mobility that enhances their life-like quality. Two custom made gilt wood chairs allow for the figures to be displayed seated or standing. All materials are original and made exclusively in Manila.  The dressing of the couple exemplifies the style and fashion of the Manila wealthy class during the first half of the 19th century. The gold jewellery was specifically made for the figures as evident by the smallness of their size. Two crucifixes in gold adorn both figures. The female figure wears gold hoop earrings and a gold and tortoiseshell Pieneta (comb) in her hair. The jewels executed in precious and expensive materials, display excellent craftsmanship and reflect the elite status of its owners.  The male figure wears a beige delicately embroidered Baro (formal blouse) and pants of a colourful ikkat dyed textile, which is typical of Manila. European influence is evident by the gentleman's top hat and shape of trousers. Stylistic adaptations were made as seen by how the Baro is worn over the trousers, in consideration of the tropical heat. The female figure wears a similar beige embroidered Baro which is shorter in length and ends at the waist. She has over her shoulders an Alampay (shawl), a Saya (long skirt) and a Tapis (short overskirt wrapped around the Saya). Intricately sewn shoes complete the outfit. Crucifix pendants on both figures make a clear reference to the close relationship between Filipino Mestizos and the Catholic Church's missionary work in the Philippines, which dates back to the 17th century. This close affiliation was a result of the alleviated social standing Mestizos enjoyed under the colonial caste system. This led to the involvement of Mestizos in the subsequent translation of Sacred Scriptures for the Sangleys (Chinese people in the Philippines). For this reason, there are some royal decrees (since the early years of Spanish colonisation) which promoted foundations to accommodate orphan Mestizos, assisting and educating them for their future integration into society. \The remarkable quality of carving
column51: polychrome work and the value of the original textiles and accessories
column52: suggests that these \"\"dolls\"\" were never intended as a child's toy; but as faithful witnesses of their time.\""

title_text: Set of altar tables Altar tables
physical_appearance: This is a set of teak altar tables. It is carved with Chinese figural, mythical and plant motifs. The front features the carving of 'Shou Lou', the God of Longevity, perched on a crane and holding a staff. There are pairs of dragon heads at the corners. The larger table has a slighly curved front while the smaller table is rectangular in shape.

subject_terms_2: Tables Motifs Peranakan (Asian people) Worship Dragons Gods Buddhist altars
sgcool_label_text:
This imposing set of teakwood altar tables was used for the worship of Chinese deities by a Peranakan family of Singapore at home. It is intricately carved with auspicious Chinese figural, mythical and plant motifs, with an unusual curved frontal surface for the higher, rectangular table. The central motif on the rectangular table features Shou Lou, the God of Longevity perched on the crane and holding a staff. Pairs of stylized dragon heads decorate the table corners. The deity images, oil lamp and lamp screen were usually placed on the rectangular table while more elaborate offerings for festive occasions would have been presented on the lower square table. Such altar tables were usually positioned prominently in the front hall.

In particular, this set of altar tables belonged to the family of Mdm Chua Geok Choo and Tan Eng Wah (1923-2013). They were passed down Mdm Chua’s side of the family and were used for the worship of Guanyin, the Goddess of Mercy, in the family home on East Coast Avenue.

Tan Eng Wah was also the eldest son of Tan Lark Sye (1897-1972). Tan Lark Sye was a highly regarded Chinese businessman and philanthropist in Singapore.

title_text: Lamp screen
physical_appearance: This is a lamp screen. It is red, with two panels of glass. At the top and bottom of the glass on each panel, there is a gilded gold boards with carved foliage motifs. The gold gilding looks slightly faded.
subject_terms_1: foliage (motif) deities worship altar components Peranakan
subject_terms_2: Screens Worship Gods Buddhist altars Motifs Peranakan (Asian people)
sgcool_label_text:
This lamp screen is made of wood, painted red and gilded, with two panels of glass. The screen is placed on the higher altar altar to house an oil lamp, helping to keep the flame lit.

In particular, this lamp screen belonged to the family of Mdm Chua Geok Choo and Tan Eng Wah (1923-2013). It was passed down Mdm Chua’s side of the family and was used for the worship of Guanyin, the Goddess of Mercy; in the family home at East Coast Avenue.

Tan Eng Wah was also the eldest son of Tan Lark Sye (1897-1972). Tan Lark Sye was a highly regarded Chinese businessman and philanthropist in Singapore.

title_text: Oil lamp
physical_appearance: This is a brass oil lamp. It has two shallow dishes that is connected by a thin, long body. The body of the lamp has five pairs of decorative bands. The base of the lamp is a circular dish.
subject_terms_1: worship Peranakan ceremonial objects
subject_terms_2: Lamps Worship Buddhist altars Peranakan (Asian people) Ceremonial objects
sgcool_label_text:
This brass oil lamp was used by Peranakans for their altars and was placed within a red and gold lamp screen. Together, they were placed at a corner of the higher altar table. The key function of the oil lamp was to keep a constant fire burning, especially for the burning of joss sticks used for prayers.

In particular, this oil lamp belonged to the family of Mdm Chua Geok Choo and Tan Eng Wah (1923-2013). It was passed down Mdm Chua’s side of the family and was used for the worship of Guanyin, the Goddess of Mercy; in the family home at East Coast Avenue.

Tan Eng Wah was also the eldest son of Tan Lark Sye (1897-1972). Tan Lark Sye was a highly regarded Chinese businessman and philanthropist in Singapore.

title_text: Pair of portraits (Peter Lim Ah Pin and Florence Yeo) Peter Lim Ah Pin and Florence Yeo
physical_appearance: This is a pair of portrait photographs of Peter Lim Ah Pin and Florence Yeo. On the left, the portrait depicts a man in a cream-coloured shirt, with a mandarin collar. His hair is clipped back, and his head is slightly tilted to the left. On the right, the portrait depicts a woman wearing a kebaya adorned wit diamond brooch. Her hair is pulled back and secured with a pin.
subject_terms_1: Folk costume families (kinship groups) Peranakan Roman Catholicism companion portraits
subject_terms_2: Photographs Ethnic costume Family History Peranakan (Asian people) Catholics
sgcool_label_text: The portrait of Peter Lim Ah Pin depicts a man in a cream-coloured shirt with a simple mandarin collar. The other portrait shows Florence Yeo in a floral kebaya with a set of diamond kerosang made in the Melaka style. Both portraits are coloured photographs, bear the signature of the same artist and were probably made as a pair. Peter Lim owned a successful bee hoon manufacturing business and was known as the ‘Bee Hoon King’. He also built several markets, schools and houses. Lim Ah Pin Road and Florence Road were named after the couple, who owned and rented out several properties in the area.

title_text: Box of Gold Thread Boxes of Gold Thread
physical_appearance: These two boxes contain spools of gold thread held by red wool. The cover of the box shows the address of the company. There is also a picture of a vessel surrounded by a wreath, above a scroll bearing jawi script. The side of the box is also stamped with the address. The box also contains two pieces of paper. One of the paper has printed chinese characters.
subject_terms_1: exports gold thread
subject_terms_2: Gold thread Exports Sewing Equipment and supplies
sgcool_label_text: This box contains 2 spools of gold thread held by fine red wool. The lid of the box is stamped ‘Yong Nam Say 40,41,42 Circular Road Singapore”, “???”, together with a depiction of a floating vessel surrounded by a wreath, and above a scroll bearing jawi script. Gold and silver threads were imported into Singapore in the second half of the 19th century through Hong Kong, France and Germany. It was then from Singapore that metallic thread stocks were transported to the Netherlands Indies.

physical_appearance: The image shows a photograph in black-and-white. It has a black frame and its border is white in colour. sgcool_label_text:
The Swimming Beaver is an example of the low value added toys manufactured by Tomy Singapore.The toy would have been designed in Tokyo and sophisticated parts would have been imported to Singapore in putting it together. Most of its metallic parts would have been produced in Singapore. 

Tomy Singapore is perhaps most remembered for its (supposedly) annual donation of toys (valued at $100,000) to Singapore’s poor children every Christmas.

subject_terms_2: Brand name products Miniature objects Amusements Slot cars Brand name products Miniature objects Amusements Slot cars
sgcool_label_text:
The American Plastics corporation, Aurora Products Corporation Asia Pte Ltd, produced slot cars from 1974-1983 such as the ones features in this box. Its main factory opened on 31 March 1977 and manufactured a wide range of quality electric toy-racing cars for the world market (primarily USA, Europe and Australia). 

These electric toy cars, also known as slot cars, ran on a track with grooves or slots that guided the cars. Primarily slot cars were used in the competitive hobby of slot car racing. Typically modelled on actual racing automobiles, slot cars share a relationship with popular interest in racing and have been featured at F1 events since 2010 in Singapore. subject_terms_3: Description and travel Singapore Tourist Promotion Board Cultural development Description and travel Singapore Tourist Promotion Board Cultural development
sgcool_label_text:
This “Welcome to Singapore” visitor guide was published in 1978 by the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board (STPB). Catered to tourists, this free publication provides an overview of Singapore’s cultural heritage and introduces the main attractions of Singapore. 

The cover of the visitor guide features a tropical scene of ladies dressed in sarong wear and contains a foreword by the Chairman of the Tourist Promotion Board.
STPB was created in 1964 as a statutory board by the government to develop and promote Singapore as a tourist destination. 

STPB’s efforts in marketing Singapore as a holiday destination paid off, with tourist arrivals increasing from 100,000 in 1964 to over 2 million by 1978. sgcool_label_text:
The Singapore Changi Airport Magazine provides a guide to tourists on the various sightseeing landmarks in Singapore. Published in August 1990, this particular edition commemorates Singapore’s Silver Jubilee as an independent nation. 

This magazine features an article on how Singapore has become an international business centre and air hub, while retaining its historic charm. It sheds light on the various redevelopment projects in the Civic and Cultural District during that period, such as the restoration of the 19th century Empress Place Building and Raffles Hotel, which is featured on the magazine’s cover page. sgcool_label_text:
The inaugural issue of Open Space, a bi-monthly bilingual magazine with events and reviews which ran till December 1992. This important issue documents the launch of the Substation, perhaps the definitive independent art space in Singapore. 

With a forward by its founder Kuo Pao Kun and featuring images and events of its different functioned spaces, the issue also features a rare full-colour centrefold collage by Joe Ng, a local music archivist of a gig in what was then the Substation’s open air garden. Open Space was distributed for free at the Substation’s Box Office. The inaugural issue of Open Space, a bi-monthly bilingual magazine with events and reviews which ran till December 1992. Open Space was distributed for free at the Substation’s Box Office.

Consisting of 697 items, the publication was an introductory effort to provide the Mandarin equivalents for common food items which had been known primarily by their dialect names. 

The publication was part of the Speak Mandarin Campaign launched on 7 September 1979 that sought to simplify the language environment, improve communication among Chinese Singaporeans from the various dialect groups, and create a Mandarin-speaking environment in support of the national bilingual education policy. subject_terms_2: Informational pamphlets Public health Hygiene Promotional materials Informational pamphlets Public health Hygiene Promotional materials
sgcool_label_text:
In 1958 as part of an Anti-Spitting Campaign, about 100 workers in the Singapore City Council’s health and water departments, volunteered and went door-to-door to distribute pamphlets, such as this, and anti-spitting emblems. 

Volunteers wore blue and red badges when going house to house to warn the people against the dangers of spitting in public.

This was part of what was then termed a “Mass Health Movement” – three campaigns on “Anti-Spitting”, “Anti-Litter” and “Anti-Pests” organised by the Singapore City Council in 1958. In 1971, mass promotional campaigns such as the Keep Singapore Clean Campaign were continued with an added emphasis on pollution and the raising of the standards of personal hygiene. As part of such efforts, the Ministry of Education re-introduced the teaching pf hygiene in primary schools. Pamphlets such as this and a Travelling Health Exhibition that opened at the Teachers Training College were possibly used in such efforts.

This personal hygiene pamphlet in Chinese advises good hygiene practices such a no spitting.

sgcool_label_text:
Nanyang University was the first university outside of China catering to high school graduates from the Chinese stream. It was open from 1956 to 1980.

The University Tribune was published by the Nanyang University student union, a union that all students that joined the university had to pay to be a part of. The issue is largely devoted to a protest on May 15 1961, where a minority of students demonstrated against their mandatory inclusion in the student union. 

The issue also includes a centrefold feature by Dr Han Suyin on Rabindranath Tagore

sgcool_label_text:
The Singapore Education Publishing Bureau (EPB) was set up by the Singapore Ministry of Education (MOE) in 1967.  EPB worked with the MOE to develop syllabus for Civic and moral education and mother tongue languages. 

This included song books such as this assembly songs book for young Singaporeans which includes “Singapura” written in 1962 and the national anthem written in 1958. The dress cap and khaki shirt belonged to Major W.J.F. Sutton, a British veteran of the Malayan Emergency. The daggers and sheaths, jungle scarf and Communist peaked cap were retrieved from the body of a Communist whom he killed.

Formed in 1930, the Malayan Communist Party (MCP) was allowed to operate openly during the post-war British Military Administration period as it had been Britain’s ally during the war. However, when the MCP attempted to infiltrate trade unions to exploit popular grievances, the British clamped down on its activities. By May 1948, most Communists had left Singapore for the Federation of Malaya to prepare for armed struggle in the jungles. The dress cap and khaki shirt belonged to Major W.J.F. This was a performance put up by the Singapore Federation of Chinese Drama Association. The performance was about the Singapore River, which was held in conjunction with the celebrations of Singapore’s 25th year of independence. The performance was held at the Victoria Theatre and Concert Hall, one of the oldest performances spaces in Singapore whose origins can be traced to 1909 when it first opened. It was originally known as the Victoria Memorial Hall – in memory of Queen Victoria – being being renamed Victoria Concert Hall after renovations in 1979.

sgcool_label_text: This instructional booklet provides basic lessons on common Malay words that are used in everyday conversations. These lessons were printed in The Daily Mail and Radio Weekly, and aired on Radio Malaysia and Radio Singapura as well. This booklet was published by the Dewan Bahasa Dan Kebudayaan Kebangsaan (DBKK), or Institute of National Language and Culture, which was established in 1960. This was part of the government’s larger initiative to promote Malay as the national language, as well as a Malayan culture. Besides publications, the DBKK also organised a National Language week, conferences for writers, competitions, exhibitions and cultural shows among other events to promote the national language. sgcool_label_text: This instructional booklet teaches Chinese speakers the basics of the Malay language. It was published by the Dewan Bahasa Dan Kebudayaan Kebangsaan (DBKK), or Institute of National Language and Culture, which was established in 1960. This was part of the government’s larger initiative to promote Malay as the national language, as well as a Malayan culture. Besides publications, the DBKK also organised a National Language week, conferences for writers, competitions, exhibitions and cultural shows among other events to promote the national language. sgcool_label_text: This booklet was published by the Ministry of Culture to communicate the new government’s messages and larger concerns regarding the state of the nation. The budget that Minister for Finance Dr Goh Keng Swee presented to the Legislative Assembly in 1960 is reproduced in Mandarin here. Topics that were brought up centred round the government’s economic policy, the review of the year’s expenditure and various revenue proposals such as property tax and business registration tax. This booklet was the third of the Towards Socialism series by the Ministry of Culture. sgcool_label_text:
The Tiger balm brand remains today an important local brand and traces its history back to the Aw brothers—Au Boon Haw and Aw Boon Par. Their father, Au Chu Kin was an herbalist who started Eng Aun Tong (the Hall of Everlasting Peace) and passed the product formula to his sons in the early 1900s.  The Aw brothers perfected the formula in oil and balm form.  The oil form was the original form and was popular in Singapore households from the 1930s onwards.
The photograph depicts three visitors to the Tiger Balm gardens (also known as the Haw Par Villa). This villa garden was an entertainment park to teach and preserve traditional Chinese values (such as filial piety) through the exposition of folklore, legends and historical events in the form of tableaux and figurines.

sgcool_label_text: This was a product of Singapore Frozen Food Co. Ltd. marketed under the Sea Horse brand, which was a Singapore brand that imported and exported poultry, fresh eggs and fish meal during the 1960s and 1970s. As part of the government’s early industrialisation efforts, swamp lands in Singapore were often converted into prawn ponds to provide more food and jobs in land-scarce Singapore. Attempt were also made to expand exports of seafood including fish and prawns by using freeze drying, which was the latest food processing method in the mid 1960s. By increasing the shelf life of food, new export markets such as those in the United States could be opened up. Typically, a fish factory in Jurong, which was the symbol of Singapore’s industrialisation progress, would export fresh prawns to Japan and the United States. title_text: Tools used for picking up rice sacks
physical_appearance: A set of four hand tools are displayed in the image. Two of them are long while the other two are short. The long pair of hand tools contains a wooden L-shaped handle, while the short pair contains a wooden curved handle. On one of the short pair of hand tools, there is a hfinger-sized hole in its handle. All four hand tools have a metal shaft that curves inwards to form hooks.
subject_terms_1: tools hooks (object genres) implements (object genre)
subject_terms_2: Tools Hooks
sgcool_label_text: These tools belonged to Mr Neo Kim Teah, who had worked as a coolie in Singapore from the 1950s to the 1970s. Part of his job was to unload sackfuls of rice from boats docked at the Singapore River, and to transport them to the godowns. Such tools were essential during this process. Mr Neo had arrived in Singapore as a young child in the late 1930s and he had stayed in the Sungei Kadut area.

title_text: Pestle Chinese stoneware pestle
physical_appearance: This stoneware pestle has a long neck, that has been incised with a spiraling line. The neck is covered with an olive-green glaze.  It has a globular body, that is unglazed and smooth at the bottom. The neck of the vessel is hollow. The pestle is slightly scratched with some black marks on its body.
subject_terms_1: ceramics (object genre) kitchenware
subject_terms_2: Pestles Ceramics Kitchen utensils China History Jin dynasty, 1115-1234
sgcool_label_text:
The long neck of this vessel is incised with a spiralling line and covered with an olive-green glaze. In contrast, its globular body is unglazed and smooth on the bottom, which indicates the use of this stoneware as a pestle. The hollow neck of the vessel could also have been used to contain liquids. This allowed the user of the pestle to add small amounts of water, wine or other liquids to the herbs or other substances that he/she was grinding.
Stone pestles and mortars have been used to prepare food and medicines in China since the Neolithic period (around 8,000 BC - 2,000 BC). Over time, wooden, ceramic and metallic pestles were also made and used in China. This pestle is a rare find as very few Chinese ceramic examples have survived from the pre-Qing period.

title_text: Mortar Chinese stoneware mortar
physical_appearance: This stoneware mortar has a circular shape, with a hollow center. The exterior of the mortar is carved with ribs, resembling a cog. It is covered with a dark-brown glaze. The glaze is uneven, especially along the bottom. The edges of the mortar, especially along the exterior ridges, are faded.
subject_terms_1: ceramics (object genre) kitchenware
subject_terms_2: Mortars Ceramics Kitchen utensils China History Song dynasty, 960-1279
sgcool_label_text: This heavily-potted stoneware mortar is carved with ribs around the exterior, resembling a cog. It is covered with a dense, darkly-brown glaze that thins at the extremities of the ribs to reveal a buff body beneath. At the same time, the glaze pools to thick drops around the base. Vessels of such form were sometimes thought to have been used as a bowl for offerings. However, the heaviness of this example indicates it was most probably used as a mortar, possibly for the preparation of food or medicinal ingredients.

sgcool_label_text: Mr. S Gopalakrishnan (b. in 1920 in Tanjavur) was a prominent violinist, and Carnatic singer. He arrived in Singapore in 1939 and actively participated in the Indian classical music scene here. Mr Gopalakrishnan performed alongside veterans of classical performers such as Pandit M Ramalingam and MV Gurusamy at temple and other music festivals. He also taught violin lessons at the Singapore Malayalee Association from the 1970s to 2000s. He was a member of the Tamils Reform Association and performed his wedding according to the principles of the Self-Respect Movement. He was also employed as a compositor at the Far East Air Force from 1954 to 1970.

sgcool_label_text: Mr. S Gopalakrishnan (b. in 1920 in Tanjavur) was a prominent violinist, and Carnatic singer. He arrived in Singapore in 1939 and actively participated in the Indian classical music scene here. Mr Gopalakrishnan performed alongside veterans of classical performers such as Pandit M Ramalingam and MV Gurusamy at temple and other music festivals. He also taught violin lessons at the Singapore Malayalee Association from the 1970s to 2000s. He was a member of the Tamils Reform Association and performed his wedding according to the principles of the Self-Respect Movement. He was also employed as a compositor at the Far East Air Force from 1954 to 1970.

title_text: Silk baju panjang with peony motifs
physical_appearance: This is a pink baju panjang. It is embellished with large peony motifs. It is knee-lengthed, with a v-shaped opening down the front, and mid-length sleeves.
subject_terms_1: flower (motif) Peranakan cultural diffusion tops (garments, general) blouses (main garments) ceremonial costume
subject_terms_2: Ethnic costume Motifs Peranakan (Asian people) Culture diffusion Blouses
sgcool_label_text: This pink baju panjang is embellished with large peony motifs. Baju panjangs are hip or knee length long tunics with v-shaped openings. Silk baju panjangs were worn by Peranakan brides on the twelfth day of the traditional Peranakan wedding ceremony. In the late nineteenth century, Peranakan women wore batik baju panjang in subdued shades. In the 1920s, chemical dyes introduced a range of colours, producing colourful baju panjangs. The baju panjang remained fashionable for young girls in Penang and Malacca up until the first decade of the twentieth century, when the far more form-fitting kebaya overtook it in popularity.

title_text: Chitty Melaka Necklace
physical_appearance: This necklace features a thick chain with a large central pendant that is inset with several gemstones. At the bottom of the pendant, there are several beads attached. The main chain of the necklace where the pendant is attached to has a butterfly link chain, that is also inset with gemstones.
subject_terms_1: cultural diffusion Peranakan
subject_terms_2: Necklaces Jewelry Culture diffusion Intermarriage Peranakan (Asian people)
sgcool_label_text: The necklace is made of gilded silver and features a large central pendant inset with gemstones, with beads at the bottom of the pendant. The pendant is attached to the main chain of the necklace with a butterfly decoration similarly set with gemstones. They were often crafted by Indian goldsmiths. The intricacy of the patterns and designs were closely associated with the financial and social status of the wearer.  Although commonly used in China to prevent tarnishing, the practice of gilding silver did not become popular in India.  Peranakan Indians were descended from marriages between South Indian Hindu merchants and local inhabitants.

title_text: Coinafon – Orange Public Phone
creator_1: Telecommunication Authority of Singapore (LC) Telecommunication Authority of Singapore (TTE)
physical_appearance: \The image shows a telephone. It is predominantly orange in colour. The handset is connected to the telephone body through black wires. There is an opening at the top of the telephone body and \"\"10¢\"\" is displayed beside the opening slot. The number pad of the telephone is also visible and to the left of the image is a series of eight images. The images depict symbols and words for instructions on how to use the telephone.\""
subject_terms_1: technology (general associated concept) brand name objects
subject_terms_2: Telephone Brand name products Technology
sgcool_label_text: A common sight in Singapore during the 1970s and 1980s, this orange public phone was introduced by the Singapore Telephone Board in 1971. Users would have to insert 10 cents to operate the pay phone. The rise of mobile phone technology in the late 1990s led to the decline in usage of such public phone services.

title_text: Motorola Jazz pager
physical_appearance: \The image shows a pager. It is black in colour. There is a transparent casing over it. A metal chain is attached to the the right hand side of the pager as well. \"\"Motorola\"\" is stated at the front surface of the pager. There are three buttons below the screen. The screen at the centre of the pager is blank.\""
subject_terms_1: brand name objects technology (general associated concept)
subject_terms_2: Beepers (Pagers) Brand name products Technology
sgcool_label_text:
A pager is a wireless telecommunications device that transmits and receives short alphanumeric messages. In the 1980s and 1990s, pagers were widely used as a communication device in Singapore before the rise of mobile phone technology. At the height of its popularity in June 1998, there were 1.36 million users in Singapore, or nearly 40% of the population. 
 
This Motorola Jazz pager is made in Singapore. The pager had the latest paging technology of its time, the FLEX technology, which extends the battery life up to four times compared to ordinary pagers and improves the pager’s ability to receive messages. In the 1990s, Motorola was one of the dominant pager manufacturers in Singapore. Motorola’s operations in Singapore also included a regional Research & Design center for paging products.

title_text: A pair of hangings Embroided hangings
physical_appearance: This is a pair of embroided hangings. Each consists of three sections. In the large section at the bottom, there is a large embroided flowering tree motif against a red background. At the bottom of the tree, there are two lions. Amongst the leaves of the tree, there are motifs of phoenixes. On the top two sections, there are also depictions of phoenxies, decorated with sequins.
subject_terms_1: cultural diffusion Peranakan plant-derived motifs birds (motifs) embroidery (visual works) ceremonial objects
subject_terms_2: Draperies Culture diffusion Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs Embroidery Ceremonial objects
sgcool_label_text: This pair of embroidered hangings probably functioned as door curtains at the entrance to the bridal chamber, and consist of two sections.  The flowering tree motif in the large section of the panel tells us that this hanging is vertically oriented.  A pair of lions in profile flanks the bot-tom of the tree, each playing with a brocade ball, while phoenixes inter-sperse between the leaves and flowers.  These motifs were constructed using a technique known as surface couching, where gold, red and black threads are laid on the surface of the silk cloth and couched (or fastened) with thread.  On the top panel which is divided into two sec-tions, sequins are fastened with metal purl onto the gold couchings of phoenix and peony blossom motifs.  The hanging is replete with auspi-cious symbols, reflecting how they were used during festive occasions such as Chinese weddings.

title_text: Altar cloth: Dewi Cina Bian Cai Tian goddess Altar cloth with Dewi Cina Bian Cai Tian goddess motif
physical_appearance: This is an altar cloth. It has three horizontal panels. The lowest panel features the goddess Dewi Cina Bian Cai Tian, seated playing the pipa, a Chinese string instrument. Surrounding her are motifs of animals and figures. The middle panel features more stylized animals amongst foliage. The panels are bordered by fretwork.
subject_terms_1: deities Peranakan cultural diffusion Cantonese motifs
subject_terms_2: Altar-cloths Gods Peranakan (Asian people) Culture diffusion Batik Motifs
sgcool_label_text: The goddess Dewi Cina Bian Cai Tian is shown on the lower panel of this tok wi or altar cloth.  This deity is adapted from Fujianese or Cantonese Buddhist folklore, and is shown seated playing the pipa, a Chinese string instrument.  Surrounding her are Chinese auspicious symbols, aquatic animals and dancing celestial beings rendered in European style.  The two panels are bordered by fretwork, possibly a variant of the banji pattern, believed by the Chinese to contain talismanic properties.  This tok wi was likely produced in Cirebon, a northern Javanese coastal town comprising a large population of Chinese.  The ‘cloud’ motif (megamendung) in particular, is commonly associated with Cirebon.  It is derived from the Chinese auspicious ruyi cloud motif.  These cloths decorated the front of altar tables in homes and in some temples.  Instead of coloured silks or gold thread couchwork in imported Chinese examples, batik altar cloths were more common in Java.

title_text: Kain panjang (hip wrapper)
physical_appearance: This is a kain panjang, a long hip wrapper cloth. It has a light brown background, with patterns of black ad brown. It is decorated with figures of winged-men, horned villains, and other reptiles, amongst foliage patterns.
subject_terms_1: comic strips motifs foliage (motif) Peranakan
subject_terms_2: Ethnic costume Batik Flash Gordon (comic strip) Motifs Comics (Graphic works) Peranakan (Asian people)
sgcool_label_text: The comic strip, the Flash Gordon was the inspiration for the design on this kain panjang.  First published in 1934, the comic strip was celebrated for its exotic storyline and science fiction theme.  Winged-men, horned villains and ferocious reptiles are rendered in a background of densely packed small curls (ukel).  Although the comic contains aggressive action and scantily-clad women, these are not reproduced on cloth.  Instead, the artist tames these characters and creatures by clothing them in textile patterns, and setting them in a benign floral setting.  The combination of natural soga brown and indigo dyes are favoured in central Java batik.  Both the batik's subject matter and laborious patterning are indicative of the owner's and artist's high economic status.  Unlike a sarong, a kain panjang is not sewn into a tube.  It is wrapped around the lower body, and then fastened by tucking in the folded ends of the kain at the waist.

title_text: Sarong kecil (young girl’s skirt cloth)
physical_appearance: This is a small batik sarong. It has a light beige background, with a blue panel in the center. The cloth is decorated with floral motifs, butterflies and birds.
subject_terms_1: Peranakan foliage (motif) birds (motifs) cultural diffusion folk costume
subject_terms_2: Ethnic costume Batik Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs Culture diffusion
sgcool_label_text: This is a rare sarong kecil or young girl’s tube-like skirt cloth.  A typical sarong however, is around 2.25 metres long, with both ends sewn together to form a tube.  The flowering tendrils and butterflies on the white background occupy the main body of the cloth (or badan).  A large bouquet, a motif known as buketan or ‘bouquet’ is the cloth’s characteristic design feature or head of the cloth (kepala).   The buketan motif is depicted on a dark blue background on this piece.  It is typically accompanied by butterflies and birds as seen in this example.  Although this motif was made popular by the Europeans in the pasisir, it was later identified with Peranakan Chinese women, (the nonya) and was a key design for ‘Batik Nonya’.  Other Batik Nonya designs include characters from European children’s fairy tales and other Western motifs. The buketan motif remains popular today and is seen in contemporary batik.

title_text: Celanda batik tulis (man’s pyjama pants)
physical_appearance: This is a pair of batik pants. It has a symmetrical pattern of tendril-like blue flowering stems, against a background of diagonal rows of black wavy lines. The rows of black lines are alternated with blue borders of white diamond-shaped motifs. The bottom of the pants are bordered my floral patterns on a blue background.
subject_terms_1: flowers (motifs) lozenges cultural diffusion Peranakan
subject_terms_2: Culture diffusion Motifs Pajamas Batik Peranakan (Asian people)
sgcool_label_text: This pair of batik pants contains a symmetrical pattern of tendril-like blue flowering stems.  They are set against a background of diagonal rows of black wavy lines that are framed by blue borders of white diamond-shaped motifs.  The batik cloth is carefully cut and joined in the middle to produce the symmetry of pattern.  Beginning in the 19th century, batik was used to produce tailored garments.  For European men, batik pyjama (celanda) trousers and sarong (for informal wear) became common as the Europeans adapted to the weather and lifestyle in Southeast Asia.  Children’s celanda were often tailored from used adult batik.

title_text: Sarong batik tulis gerus (woman’s skirt cloth)
physical_appearance: This is a batik sarong. One vertical section is decorated in diagonal olive and cream bands of flowers and birds. The panel on the left of the cloth features garden motifs on cream ground, with bonsai plans, ceramics, peacocks and birds amongst flowering trees.
subject_terms_1: flowers (motifs) birds (motifs) foliage (motif) cultural diffusion folk costume Peranakan
subject_terms_2: Ethnic costume Motifs Culture diffusion Batik Peranakan (Asian people)
sgcool_label_text: The kepala (head) section of this sarong (tubular skirt cloth) is decorated in diagonal olive and cream bands of flowers and birds.  The sarong is sewn along its width and worn by wrapping it around the waist.  The badan or body of the cloth features Chinese and Japanese inspired garden motifs on a cream ground.  Bonsai or cherry blossom plants, garden ceramics that echo the shape of Chinese ceramic wares and bronze vessels, elegantly rendered peacocks and pairs of birds on a flowering tree are depicted.  Japanese inspired batik motifs may have a response to the increased popularity of Japanese artwork in the second half the 19th century.  This piece is signed by Oey Tjoeng Kwee PK.

title_text: Dutch colonial settee
physical_appearance: The image depicts a settee. The frames of the settee are made of a wooden material and it is brown in colour. The cushions on the seat and back have tiny holes arranged in straight lines. The design on the frame of the sette, at the centre, is of the shape of a scallop. On either side of the scalloped shape, there are symmetrical wave patterns and a scroll motif. The legs of the settee are designed to be paw feet. There are no visible tears or cracks in the paintwork of the settee.
subject_terms_1: chairs (furniture forms) Dutch Colonial wave pattern scroll (motifs) paw feet
subject_terms_2: Chairs Furniture, Dutch colonial Motifs
sgcool_label_text: \This settee belonged to Paul Victor Emanuel Warnars (1876-1940) and his wife Maria Warnars-Krol (1885-1930). Warnars was involved in the tin mining industry
column51: living an working in Muntok
column52: which was at that time the capital of the Dutch Indies Bangka-Belitung Residency. The settee is made of Amboyna wood
column53: and was of a style popular across Dutch and British colonies in the 19th century. It bears the influence of the early 19th century \"\"Grecian\"\" sofas designed by Thomas Sheraton.\""

title_text: Kebaya with Red Peonies
physical_appearance: This is a beige kebaya top. It has elongated tapered ends, and is embroided with peony and foliage motifs concentrated towards the bottom. The ends of the sleeves are also embroided with peony and foliage motifs.
subject_terms_1: folk costume flowers (motifs) foliage (motif) Peranakan tops (garments, general) blouses (main garments)
subject_terms_2: Ethnic costume Motifs Peranakan (Asian people) Blouses
sgcool_label_text: This kebaya is embroidered with peony and foliage motifs against a gingham fabric with white flecks. Kebayas with elongated tapered ends were popular in the 1930s and many were commissioned by Peranakan women. It is part of a donation which contains a mixture of garments worn by Peranakan men and women.

subject_terms_1: foliage (motif) scrolls (motifs) cultural diffusion textile materials
subject_terms_2: Textiles Motifs Culture diffusion
sgcool_label_text: These examples provide insight into the making of kebayas and raw material used. There are numerous pieces of bobbin lace in this donation, the making of which was an established tradition in port cities like Malacca and Palembang by the early 20th century. European printed cotton was popular in the late 19th century and was often used to make baju panjangs, though some pieces in this donation show that the material was used for the making of kebayas too.

sgcool_label_text: The baju panjang is made of silk fabric with curving foliate patterns. It is thickly lined and padded on the inside. Family lore has it that the nyonya bride wore this when visiting relatives in the cold months of China after her Penang wedding. In late 19th century Penang, there was a large selection of materials to choose from for the making of baju panjang, including silk, European cotton and velvet. It is part of a donation which contains a mixture of garments worn by Peranakan men and women.

subject_terms_1: clubs (associations) relocating

subject_terms_3: Lim, Chong Pang Lim, Nee Soon
sgcool_label_text: This uniform was worn by Herbert Lim Eng Kwan (1927-2002) when he was a was a King’s Scout and leader of Clarence High School’s 4th Bangalore Troop. Son of Lim Chong Pang and grandson of the Peranakan pineapple and rubber planter and prominent philanthropist Lim Nee Soon, Herbert was evacuated with his family to Bangalore Cantonment before Singapore fell to the Japanese in 1945. A small piece of fabric with the words ‘Bangalore Troop’ is attached to the right sleeve. The uniform is part of a donation which contains a mixture of garments worn by Peranakan men and women.

title_text: Postcard from Herbert Lim Eng Kwan

subject_terms_3: Portrait photography Lim, Chong Pang Lim, Nee Soon
sgcool_label_text: This postcard shows Herbert Lim Eng Kwan (1927-2002) in his scout uniform. Son of Lim Chong Pang and grandson of the Peranakan pineapple and rubber planter and prominent philanthropist Lim Nee Soon, Herbert was evacuated with his family to Bangalore Cantonment before Singapore fell to the Japanese in 1945. He was a was a King’s Scout and leader of Clarence High School’s 4th Bangalore Troop. On the reverse is written ‘Patience is a golden virtue’. The postcard is part of a donation which contains a mixture of garments worn by Peranakan men and women.

Yellow lilies are embroidered on the end of sleeves and bottom left portion of the kebaya while drawings in black give a glimpse of the intended design. Kebayas with elongated tapered ends were popular in the 1930s and many were commissioned by Peranakan women. It is part of a donation which contains a mixture of garments worn by Peranakan men and women.

sgcool_label_text: The body of this wooden walking stick has a brown grain with black patterns. It is topped by a gold knob, its facets decorated with foliate designs and crowned with an eight-pointed star. Walking sticks with a golden attachment were popular in 19th century Europe and often completed a gentleman’s ensemble. It is part of a donation which contains a mixture of garments worn by Peranakan men and women.

title_text: Top Hat with Box
physical_appearance: This is a top hat with a red box. The top hat is foldable, It is covered with black silk fabric and adorned with a single black grosgrain ribbon.
subject_terms_1: top hats cultural diffusion boxes (containers)
subject_terms_2: Hats Culture diffusion
sgcool_label_text:
This is an example of a Gibus hat, a top hat fitted with an internal spring mechanism which could be used to collapse and fold the hat. Covered with a black silk fabric, it is adorned with a single black grosgrain ribbon. The mark of its maker is vaguely visible. A red box seemingly custom made to hold the hat accompanies it. A shopmark can be made out on the underside, including the word ‘England’. 

The Gibus hat was named after the man who patented it in 1837, Antoine Gibus. It was held under the arm and paired with an opera clock. Top hats were staple to an European gentleman’s wardrobe for much of the 19th century. It is part of a donation which contains a mixture of garments worn by Peranakan men and women.

It is part of a donation which contains a mixture of garments worn by Peranakan men and women.

sgcool_label_text: Known as a baju peiki or baju shanghai, this long-sleeved jacket with a mandarin collar and frog buttons is made from a richly patterned cream silk fabric and thickly lined on the inside. The cotton baju peiki could have been paired with batik sarong in less formal occasions.It is part of a donation which contains a mixture of garments worn by Peranakan men and women.

title_text: Wedding Gown
physical_appearance: \The image depicts a wedding gown. It is totally white in colour. It is also long-sleeved and there are laces running in a criss-cross pattern at the lower portion of the sleeve towards the hands.There is a collar which is made in the form of the scalloping pattern. The sleeve cuffs are also constructed in similar fashion. The label tag is still intact at the back collar of the gown. The tag states
subject_terms_1: \"\"Harrods\"\". There are no visible tears and stains on the exterior of the wedding gown. The sleeves are transparent but not the rest of the gown. \""
subject_terms_2: dresses (garments) scalloping
subject_terms_3: Wedding costume Dress accessories patterns Harrod's Stores, Ltd
column51: This is a wedding gown designed by Singapore-born Benny Ong. Ong was well-known for his designer cocktail and evening wear from the 1970s to 1990s. The early collections of Ong were sold at Harrods and Selfridges, two of London’s most reputable departmental stores. Ong is one of the pioneer Singapore-born designers known for dressing royalty such as the late Princess Diana and for establishing his brand in London. This dress was bought from Harrods in 1977 and wore by the donor, Claire Buske for her wedding in Canada in the same year.

title_text: Working in Unity
physical_appearance: The image shows a square photograph in black-and-white that is enclosed by a white frame. One of them has lifted the bale of rubber over his head. The two workers on the lorry are attempting to take the load from him to place it on the lorry. There are already several bales of rubber stacked on the lorry. Low-level buildings are present at the background.
subject_terms_1: trucks blue collar workers bales (object genres) trade (function) transporting
subject_terms_2: Black-and-white photography Street photography Clarke Quay (Singapore) Blue collar workers Trucks Rubber Business
sgcool_label_text: Loke Hong Seng (b. 1943) was working as a radio announcer with Radio Television Singapore in the 1960s when he picked up photography and subsequently grew to specialize in street photography. His images of 1960s and 1970s Singapore offer a candid view of everyday life in the early days of the nation’s development. This photograph is one of Loke’s earliest photographs, taken using a Rolleicord camera borrowed from a colleague. It depicts some workers loading bales of rubber onto a lorry at Clarke Quay.

title_text: Foundation of the Spanish colony in the Philippines
creation_date: Second half of 17th century - early 18th century
physical_appearance: This painting depicts three European men. The man on the most left is dressed in Augustinian friar robes, with quills and pots of ink beside him. The man in the center is dressed in a white coat and a hat with feathers, holding a stick, with a sword at his side. The man on the right is in black and brown attire, with a red sash around his hip. He is also holding a stick and has a sword at his side. The names of the men in the painting are inscribed below the figures. At the bottom of the painting, the creator has inscribed a passage in Spanish. There is no creator's signature inscribed.
subject_terms_1: colonization trade routes colonists
subject_terms_2: Painting Imperialism Colonists Philippines History 1521 - 1898 Manila galleon. Spanish Urdaneta, Andrés de, 1498-1568 Legazpi, Miguel López de, 1510?-1572 Magellan, Ferdinand, -1521
context_1: Foundation of the Spanish colony in the Philippines
sgcool_label_text:
The three men in this painting were crucial to the establishment of the Spanish colony in the Philippines, and the Manila Galleon trade. From left, they are Friar Andrés de Urdaneta (1498–1568), Miguel López de Legazpi (1502–1572), and Ferdinand Magellan (1480–1521). 
Magellan was a Portuguese-born explorer best known for captaining on behalf of the Spanish Crown the first fleet of ships that circumnavigated the world. Lopez de Legazpi and Urdaneta formed the first European settlement in the Philippines on Cebu in 1565. Friar Urdaneta’s documentation of his voyage was the basis for the Manila-Acapulco Galleon trade route. Spanish ships sailed this route across the Pacific for around 250 years, carrying luxury goods that created riches for Spain.

title_text: Altar Sideboard
physical_appearance: This is a large carved altar sideboard. It has a marble tabletop. In the centre sits a portrait of a couple. The man is wearing a traditional Chinese dress and hat. The woman is seated on the left, wearing a green, floral long garment fasted with three large diamond brooches, over a sarong, with a pair of beaded slippers. Above them hangs a rectangular photograph of three people. The table is carved with intricate designs and patterns, with dragons and phoenixes along the sides.
subject_terms_1: portraits paintings (visual works) motifs Peranakan folk costume businessmen worship carvings (visual works)
subject_terms_2: Altars Portraits Painting Motifs Peranakan (Asian people) ethnic costume Businessmen Worship
subject_terms_3: Religious life and practices Peranakan clans and associations Ong, Sam Leong
sgcool_label_text:
This is a large carved altar sideboard with a marble tabletop and a portrait of Mr and Mrs Ong Sam Leong in the centre. Mr Ong is depicted wearing traditional Chinese garb while his wife, seated on the left is painted wearing a green, floral baju panjang fastened with three large diamond brooches (kerosang in Baba Malay) over a sarong with a pair of beaded slippers. A rectangular photograph of their eldest son Ong Boon Tat in between his two wives is affixed at the centre above them. Dragons and phoenixes run along the sides of the altar, and a pair of phoenixes is carved in openwork as a crown. 

This item is donated by the family of prominent Peranakan, Ong Sam Leong (b. 1857, Singapore – d. 7 February 1918, Singapore). It comes from his ancestral home of Bukit Rose, formerly at 259 Bukit Timah Road. Ong was a well-known successful businessman who made is money in the mining of phosphate on Christmas island, which was historically a territory of colonial Singapore.

subject_terms_1: flower (motif) foliage (motif) lion's head (motif) birds (motif) Peranakan Chinese export porcelain
subject_terms_2: Vases Porcelain, Chinese Ming-Qing dynasties, 1368-1912 Motifs Peranakan (Asian people) Exports
sgcool_label_text:
This is a large baluster vase dated to the Qing period in China. Such vases were often used on altars in Peranakan homes as decorative objects containing flowers. This vase is considered an early example of export porcelain used in Peranakan homes before the later tradition of porcelain commissioned to the specific tastes of Peranakans, known as nyonyaware.

 This item is donated by the family of prominent Peranakan, Ong Sam Leong (b. 1857, Singapore – d. 7 February 1918, Singapore). sgcool_label_text:
This small brass spittoon is an unusual item to be found on an altar in a Peranakan home. It is a simple spittoon with a wide trumpet-shaped mouth and a bulbous body. Spittoons were used by Peranakan women for daily hygienic disposal of spittle from chewing betel leaves with areca nut.

title_text: Turtle shaped censer
physical_appearance: This is a small censer. It is engraved decoratively with carvings. The lid is depicted as a turtle. There is a small handle on the right of the lid in the shape of a turtle head.
subject_terms_1: altar components Peranakan religious ceremonies ceremonial objects
subject_terms_2: Censers Altars Peranakan (Asian people) Rites and ceremonies Ceremonial objects
sgcool_label_text:
This small censer is engraved decoratively with carvings which depict the lid as a turtle. In Chinese symbolism, turtles signify long life and would be an appropriate motif for the ancestral altar. Incense and ashes would be placed within the body of the turtle and a small hole at the top would allow the smoke of incense to escape.

This item is donated by the family of prominent Peranakan, Ong Sam Leong (b. 1857, Singapore – d. 7 February 1918, Singapore). title_text: Patchwork quilt made by Samsui woman Mdm Wong Swee Keng
physical_appearance: The image shows a patchwork quilt. It is rectangular in shape and it has a pink background. There is a ten by seven grid pattern of hexagonal motifs. They come in an assortment of colours.
subject_terms_1: geometric motifs  geometric patterns
subject_terms_2: Patchwork Motifs
sgcool_label_text: This patchwork quilt was made by Mdm Wong Swee Keng, a Samsui Woman. Mdm Wong was born in Singapore in 1914, but was taken to China when she was 5. At the age of 15, she returned to Singapore, working at a rubber factory until she was 21 when she returned again to China to get married. At the age of about 27, she joined her husband in Singapore, where she worked at construction sites as a Samsui Woman, a job she held until she was 70. She spent eight hours a day for one month to make this quilt, and offered it for sale at a charity event.

title_text: Shou Lau on Crane Ornament
physical_appearance: This is a gold ornament of Shou Lau, the God of Longevity, riding a crane. He is depicted smiling, in an intricately designed robe, facing forward. The crane's wings are outstretched on either side. Small clouds and birds are attached to the main structure by coiled springs.
subject_terms_1: birds (motifs) deities depictions (visual works) commissions (orders for works)
subject_terms_2: Decoration and ornament Motifs Gods
sgcool_label_text:
This is an ornament of Shou Lau riding a crane. He is the God of Longevity and is often depicted with a crane, also a potent symbol of longevity. It is likely that this ornament was originally sewn onto a textile such as a ceremonial handkerchief or a wedding headband. Based on the shopmark on the reverse of the ornament, this was made by Da Xing (??), one of the popular goldsmiths commissioned by Peranakans in the Straits to produce their jewellery and silverware.

This ornament is part of a group donation from descendants of Tan Kim Seng and Tan Jiak Kim. Both were wealthy merchants, philanthropists and leaders of the local Hokkien community.

title_text: Large Dish with Reign Mark
physical_appearance: These are two porcelain dishes. They is white ground, with enamel painted design. The plates are decorated with painted flowers and flowering branches, and two pheasants.
subject_terms_1: exports flower (motif) birds (motifs) tableware
subject_terms_2: Porcelain Tableware Exports Motifs
subject_terms_3: Decorative arts Ceramics Tan, Kim Seng
sgcool_label_text:
This white ground enameled plate with a pair of pheasants is dated to the Daoguang (1821-1850) period. It is therefore a predecessor to “nyonyaware”, the porcelain that is more often associated with Peranakan taste by the turn of the 20th century. According to descendents, the white pieces were used as part of a larger dining set and on the altar in the house of Tan Kim Seng.

This dish is part of a group of porcelain and jewellery from Panglima Prang, the ancestral home of prominent businessmen and philanthropists, Tan Kim Seng (1805-1864) and Tan Jiak Kim (1859-1917).

title_text: Running Stream
materials_name: Chinese ink coloured ink  paper (fibre product)
physical_appearance: This image is a landscape painting that depicts a running stream that cuts across the composition. Several tall trees line this stream. There are two seals; one on the top right hand corner, whilst the other is on the bottom left. Accompanying the latter, is the artist's signature, followed by the year of creation, and lastly a description of the painting in Chinese.
subject_terms_1: landscapes (representations) streams
subject_terms_2: Landscapes Rivers  Ink painting, Chinese
subject_terms_3: Chinese ink painting Chinese landscape painting visual arts
sgcool_label_text: Wu Guanzhong (1919 - 2010) is one of the most significant artists of 20th century China. He belonged to a generation of Chinese painters who went to France to study art in the 1940s. His distinctive style integrates Western and Chinese art traditions, setting a new direction for modern Chinese art. Running Stream us a representative work of Wu's from the 1980s. Wu painted bold black strokes for the trees, quick washes for the running stream and included his iconic dots of colours for flowers and plants. From his inscription, it is also indicated that this was a scene from the bottom of the Jade Dragon Mountain, a subject that Wu revisits often in his artistic practice.

sgcool_label_text: Lee Lim was one of the most important modern photographers in Singapore, influencing a generation of photographers in the pictorial photography circles. Between 1952 and 1979, Lee took part in more than 100 photographic competitions and won numerous awards and honours. He received the Fellowship of the Royal Photographic Society (UK) in 1959 and the Artist Distinction by the International Federation of Photographic Art (FIAP) in 1977. He was also conferred an honorary fellowship by the Photographic Society of Singapore and won the Cultural Medallion in 1987.

title_text: Do Not Prevent The Fertility Of The Mind
materials_name: paper (fiber product) wood (plant material) glass (material) liquid
physical_appearance: This installation depicts a wall, decorated with women's sanitary napkins, and bordered by fluorescent lights. In the center, there is a framed photograph of a woman. She is dressed in a red top, wearing a headpiece with a red cross, and holding wire tools in both her hands. In front of the wall, there is a stool. On the stool, there is a red vial filled with red liquid placed on a plastic sheet.
subject_terms_1: political art government policy reproduction (biological event) avant-garde
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Art Political aspects Government policy Birth control Pro-life movement Women's rights
sgcool_label_text: Central to Arahmaiani’s work is the theme of the position of women, particularly in Indonesian society. Do Not Prevent The Fertility of the Mind draws on the artist’s personal experience of being arrested in her student years for her performance art, and conflates ideas of artistic creativity with female fertility, commenting on how both these impulses are curtailed by watchful authorities. Making reference to the Suharto government’s birth control policies of the 1990s, which the artist views as a “coloniz(ation) by the state even to the innermost part of (women’s) bodies”, Do Not Prevent The Fertility of the Mind expresses the narrow confines within which avant-garde artists had to work, even as it confronts the viewer with the (often taboo) bodily realities of a woman’s reproductive capabilities – and, by extension, her artistic creativity.

title_text: SIA sarong kebaya uniform
physical_appearance: This is the Singapore Airline's sarong kebaya uniform for ladies. The blouse has a scoop neckline, three-quarter sleeves, and a front zip opening. A sawtooth design runs through the centre panel and bottom edge of the blouse and skirt, neckline and sleeves.
subject_terms_1: batik  corporate image identity  flower (motifs)
subject_terms_2: Pierre Balmain (Firm)  Corporate image Identity  Floral decorations  Uniforms  Malaysia-Singapore Airlines  Batik  Singapore Airlines
sgcool_label_text: The iconic SIA sarong kebaya uniform is central to SIA’s branding, particularly when the “Singapore Girl” emerged as a marketing initiative.  The blouse has a scoop neckline, three-quarter length sleeves and a front zip opening.  A colourful border resembling the sawtooth motif runs throughout the edges of the blouse and the pleated centre panel of the skirt.  This uniform was designed by renowned French couturier Pierre Balmain, and was first unveiled in 1968 when Singapore Airlines was still part of Malaysia-Singapore Airlines (MSA).  Balmain’s choice of batik print for the uniforms of both cabin crew and ground staff was a means for SIA to assert Malayan identity and hospitality.  Although the batik print design has been updated over the years, the use of batik and the colours blue, red, brown, brown and green for the batik motif persists.  Today, this uniform is seen in four colours, with each colour denoting the rank of the flight stewardess.

title_text: SIA ground staff uniform
physical_appearance: This is a three-piece uniform consisting of a turquoise A-line skirt, jacket, and a batik-print blouse. The latter is short-sleeved, and collared; ending with a narrow bow where the top button usually is. Pocketed, the jacket has the Singapore Airlines logo minted on it.
subject_terms_1: batik  corporate image identity  flower (motifs)
subject_terms_2: Pierre Balmain (Firm)  Corporate image Identity  Floral decorations  Uniforms  Malaysia-Singapore Airlines  Batik
sgcool_label_text: This three-piece uniform belonged to a former Singapore Airlines ground hostess.  It consists of a turquoise A-line skirt that was coordinated with a short-sleeve collared blouse with a narrow bow in batik print design.  The uniform was designed by French couturier Pierre Balmain, and was first unveiled in 1968 when Singapore Airlines was still part of Malaysia-Singapore Airlines (MSA).  Balmain’s choice of batik print for the uniforms of both cabin crew and ground staff was a means for SIA to assert Malayan identity and hospitality. The batik print design consists of brightly-coloured floral motifs and a colourful border resembling the sawtooth motif that runs along the edges of these uniforms.  A label stating the name of the tailor for this uniform, “Lilian’s 108-A Orchard Road, Tel: 377626” in on the jacket and blouse.

title_text: Dish Dishes with Eight Immortals
physical_appearance: This is a set of two ceramic dishes. The interior of these dishes feture a variety of birds flying amongst several flowers against a lime green background. On the exterior, the Eight Immortals are depicted riding the waves amidst clouds. There are no cracks seen on the dishes.
subject_terms_1: tableware flower (motif) birds (motifs) deities depictions (visual works) Taoism
subject_terms_2: Ceramics Tableware Motifs Gods Ba Xian (Taoist mythology)
sgcool_label_text:
A beautiful and lively medley of auspicious Chinese birds and flowers are painted on the broad base of the interior of this pair of famille rose dishes. The phoenix, pheasant, cranes, magpies and swallows fly and wonder amidst luscious blooms of the flowers of the four seasons; the peony, lotus, chrysanthemum and prunus. Set against a vibrant lime green ground, the birds, foliage and plumage are skillfully rendered, with realistic veining, and subtle colour gradations in the enamels. The lack of proportion of the motifs and dense decoration also create a romantic and whimsical charm to the overall composition. On the exterior of the slightly flaring shallow sides of the dishes, the Eight Immortals are depicted riding the waves amidst auspicious ruyi clouds, a reference to a key mythical story of crossing the ocean. Together, the auspicious decoration convey wishes of longevity, prosperity and good fortune. 

The lime-green bases of both dishes carry the six-character, “Da Qing Daoguang Nian Zhi” (Made in the Daoguang reign of the great Qing dynasty) in iron-red. The technical mastery evident in the brushwork reflects how high-quality production continued in the late Qing period, especially the Daoguang and Guangxu periods.

title_text: Mother-of-pearl inlaid stand
physical_appearance: This is a wooden stand with mother of pearl inlays. It consists of three platforms, with the centre one being taller than the other two flanking it. Abstract vegetal motifs in mother of pearl decorate the frames and beams of the piece.
subject_terms_1: altar components Peranakan  plant-derived motifs  censer stands
subject_terms_2: Altarpieces Peranakan (Asian people)   Censers
subject_terms_3: Furniture design Religious life and practices
sgcool_label_text: This wooden stand was likely to have been used as a stand for a censor, and placed in a prominent position on an altar. It consists of three platforms, each framed by borders decorated with abstract vegetal designs in mother-of-pearl. Despite the adoption of numerous Malay cultural practices, such as language and dress, the religion practiced by the Peranakans was essentially a traditional Chinese form, which was polytheistic in nature and incorporated elements of ancestor worship, Buddhism and Taoism. Blackwood furniture with mother-of-pearl inlays was extremely popular with wealthy Peranakans in the 19th century.

title_text: A talismanic youth’s jama
physical_appearance: This is a shirt with a lattice of rectangles filled with red, blue, and gold concentric circles. Words have been inscribed all over the shirt. In particular, there are two blue roundels on the breast of the shirt that have been inscribed with the shahada.
subject_terms_1: Qur'ans  Islam Mughal textile styles  healing  religious objects
subject_terms_2: Talismans Qur'an  Islam  Healing  Shahada
sgcool_label_text:
This cotton shirt is inscribed with all the sura of the Quran in black and red ghubari script within a lattice of rectangles linked with red, blue and gold concentric roundels. The ghubari script produces fine, delicate words which is suited to miniaturising text, compressed into the smallest possible space. Each rectangular panel contains a single verse, with sura headings in blue on gold panel. Two large roundels on the front of the jama are inscribed wih the shahada in elongated gold bihari script on a red and blue ground while the border is filled with the 99 names of ‘Allah reserved against a hatched ground bearing polychrome dots. 

Talismanic shirts are considered to be related to large paper and parchment talismanic charts, that is, they can be viewed more as manuscripts than wearable garments. The use of these shirts are not always well defined, although it is commonly understood that such shirts are worn by warriors underneath their armour to protect them during battles. However, it has also been suggested that these shirts could be worn for other objectives such as healing garments, much like how large talismanic charts have been used to cover the body of a sick person like a blanket.

sgcool_label_text: This bowl, which appears plain at first glance but reveals its subtle patterns on closer inspection, features an anhua ?? (‘hidden decoration’) design of a three-clawed dragon chasing a pearl. This is paired with a sketchy blue scroll painted around the narrow foot rim. The use of anhua decoration on porcelain is thought to have begun in the Ming dynasty during the reign of the Yongle emperor (1403–1424), and refers to delicately-incised designs that almost seem to vanish when covered with a glaze. sgcool_label_text: Lee Lim was one of the most important modern photographers in Singapore, influencing a generation of photographers in the pictorial photography circles. Between 1952 and 1979, Lee took part in more than 100 photographic competitions and won numerous awards and honours. He received the Fellowship of the Royal Photographic Society (UK) in 1959 and the Artist Distinction by the International Federation of Photographic Art (FIAP) in 1977. He was also conferred an honorary fellowship by the Photographic Society of Singapore and won the Cultural Medallion in 1987.

title_text: Bible box Tortoiseshell bible box
physical_appearance: This is a dark brown bible box. It has a thick spine on the left, and opens by two clasps on the right. It has chased and engraved silver mounts along the peripheries and the spine. The silver mounts are decorated with foliate arabesques and floral motifs.
subject_terms_1: colonialism flower (motif) scrolls (motif) cultural diffusion Christianity cases (containers)
subject_terms_2: Book boxes Tortoiseshell Imperialism Motifs Culture diffusion Bible Christianity
sgcool_label_text:
This is a rare dutch colonial bible box made in Batavia or Sri Lanka for the colonial market. It is conventional in design with a hinged lid and is thicker at the front than at the back to emulate a leather-bound book. It has chased and engraved silver mounts along the peripheries and along the 'spine', and the box itself is made of tortoiseshell. The hinged lid is kept closed by two silver clasps, engraved with floral motifs, while the remaining silver mounts are decorated with foliate arabesques.

Bible boxes such as this were made by local artisans for wives of the dutch colonial officials living in Sri Lanka or Batavia. These boxes would have traditionally held a small personal bible.
