subject_terms_1: flower (motif) scrolls (motif) Roman Catholic Christianity
subject_terms_2: Crosses Motifs Catholic Church Christianity
sgcool_label_text: This is a rare example of a nineteenth century silver crucifix typical of the Kandyan region in Sri Lanka. The surface is embellished with decorative floral motifs accompanied by foliage, front and back. A moveable silver loop is attached to the top, to allow for suspension by a chain.

title_text: An Icosahedron Silver icosahedron
physical_appearance: This is a silver icosahedron. It has 20 triangular sides. On all 20 faces of the dice, there are engravings of repeated scrolls. There is a hinge on one edge. The silver is slightly faded around the edges.
subject_terms_1: exports scrolls (motif) filigree polyhedra
subject_terms_2: Boxes Silver Exports Motifs Filigree Icosahedra
sgcool_label_text: This extraordinary and rare box is hollow and has twenty triangular sides. Each side is made of particularly fine, solid silver filigree. One of the triangular sides is hinged and opens, permitting access to the interior. The form fits into the oeuvre of scientific and mathematical devices in the Islamic world, perhaps tempered with mysticism and notions of magic. It is also known in gaming and has been used as a rare type of dice based on the Platonic solid known as an icosahedron consisting of 20 equilateral triangle faces that meet five to a corner. Each side of such a dice is numbered from one to twenty. With so many faces, such a dice is easy to roll, being almost spherical. Such dice appear to be more prevalent in the Islamic world, and generally are shaped from solid stone. This example might have been made in India, but the filigree is more in keeping with filigree that is associated with 18th century Batavia or the West Coast of  Sumatra in the Dutch East Indies.  It is possible, perhaps likely, that it was made there for export for the Islamic market in India, perhaps as a diplomatic gift. It also has a small Dutch import mark for foreign silver which bolsters the case that it was made in the Dutch East Indies, and perhaps was never sent to India. Most probably it was made in the Dutch East Indies at the behest of the Dutch East India Company (VOC) for the India market.

title_text: Chess Set and Table
materials_name: sandalwood (wood) ivory (material) horn (animal material) stone (worked rock) resin (organic material) glass (material) lacquer (material)
physical_appearance: This is a miniature chess set and table. The top of the table is octagonal in shape, with carved decoratives and ivory embellishment. There are four medallion disks engraved with Hindu deities. The feet of the table is embellished with animal feet. The chess pieces are plain and red stained.
subject_terms_1: exports cultural diffusion deities chess tables
subject_terms_2: Chess sets Exports Culture diffusion Gods
sgcool_label_text:
Between the 15th and 20th centuries, distinct schools of Indo-European furniture evolved in India. Embodying the fusion of the Western form with Indian material and technique, Indo-European furniture were an important derivative of the spice trade that the European Companies were engaged in South (India and Ceylon) and Southeast Asia (Batavia). 
The Coromandel Coast, a region of early textile production, lined with international ports, received traders from the East and the West, and emerged as an early centre of production of Western-style furniture. For instance, the craftsmanship of these artisans suggests their exposure to Western examples and Western-style Asian creations; a familiarity which grew with the establishment of the European powers in India.  Other centres of European trade and settlement such as the Malabar and Gujarat Coasts and Bengal also became centres of production; while trading centres such as Goa, Surat and Cambay also functioned as sourcing points for readymade furniture. 

This is a very fine example of a miniature chess set and table from the Vizag region. The octagonal top with sandalwood is overlaid with ivory, with a central chess board created ivory and horn insets. The ivory embellishment around the table top has four medallion disks engraved with Hindu deities, the feet of the table embellished with zoomorphic ivory feet. Miniature plain ivory and red stained ivory chessmen complete the set.

title_text: Silver Cheroot Case
physical_appearance: This is a silver cheroot case. It opens by a lid. The body of the case features dense foliage that also incorporates deity figures, animals and mythical creatures. The case appears to be in good condition, with no scratches.
subject_terms_1: foliage (motif) deities cultural diffusion colonialism
subject_terms_2: Cigarette cases Motifs Gods Culture diffusion Imperialism
sgcool_label_text: This high quality silver cheroot case would have been manufactured in Trichinopoly (currently, Tirichirapalli), as a luxury item made for Colonial consumption. The case is made of heavy silver, utilising deep, almost 3-dimensional repousse. The decoration comprises of dense acanthus-leaf foliage, within which appear mounted figures and animals. The lid of the case opens to reveal a segmented interior, which would have held twelve cheroots in such a way as to minimise damage. The object is typical of silver manufactured in Trichinopoly, which was known for the manufacture of small, highly prized, luxury items such as this cheroot case. Stylistically, the figures are also reminiscent of “swami silver” that was manufactured in the Madras region, and was so termed by the British, for the liberal use of deity or mythological imagery on the surface of silver objects.

title_text: Singapore from Cairn Hill
physical_appearance: This painting depicts the landscape of Singapore from Cairn Hill. Almost three quarters of the painting consists of the sky and clouds, with the remaining space depicting the natural landscape of Singapore. There are three human figures drawn in the painting. Two of them are standing alongside one another, dressed in white colonial garb. The other figure is a gardener dressed in blue and tending to the vegetation. Nearer to the horizon line on the painting, colonial buildings atop hills can be seen as well as the coastline. The colours of the painting do not look smudged. There is a signature of the artist and the date of the creation of the artwork on the bottom right, in a single row.
subject_terms_1: landscapes (representations) colonials (people) colonial settlements
subject_terms_2: Watercolour painting Singapore Colonization Landscapes
sgcool_label_text: This view of Singapore was painted by Percy Carpenter (1820-1895), an English artist who resided in Singapore from 1855 until he moved to Calcutta by 1859. The foreground of this watercolour work depicts John James Greenshields, a partner of Guthrie & Co. and a member of the Singapore Municipal Committee, together with his wife, looking outwards from the vantage point of their residence at Cairn Hill. Government Hill is visible at the centre of this landscape, flanked by Mount Sophia on the left and Institution Hill on the right. This idyllic, picturesque view nonetheless shows hints of Singapore's busy trade, with glimpses of shipping scenes in the background.

object_work_type: aquatints (prints) engravings (prints) paperwork (visual works)  aerial views aquatints
title_text: A View of the East India Docks A View of the East India Docks
physical_appearance: This artwork depicts a landscape view of the East India Docks. The top half of the aquatint consists of the sky and clouds, while the bottom half depicts the ships, docks, and rivers. The artwork has a wooden frame and it has a white border with a brown perimeter in between. At the bottom of the artwork, its title is displayed in capital letters. Under its title, there are four rows of paragraphs describing aspects of the East India docks. The colours on the aquatint do not look smudged.  This is an aerial view of a dock. The meandering river is filled with ships of various sizes, and the land across seems vast and expansive with sparse settlement.
subject_terms_1: landscapes (representations) marines (visual works) dockyards docks (waterfront spaces) shipping  landscapes (representations) ships
subject_terms_2: Landscapes Aquatint Engraving Docks England East India Company prints Thames River (England) Blackwall (London, England) East India Company  Thames River (England) Greenwich (London, England)  Daniell, Thomas, 1749-1840? Aerial views  Docks  Indiamen Landscapes  Aquatint
subject_terms_3: Visual arts East India Company East India Company  Visual Arts
sgcool_label_text: The East India Docks were opened in 1806 in Blackwall, London, to accommodate the shipping needs of the East India Company. This aquatint presents an aerial view of the docks, with the Thames in the middle ground, and Greenwich in the distance to the right. It was drawn, engraved and published by William Daniell, an English landscape and marine artist who together with his uncle Thomas Daniell  travelled extensively in India. The East India Docks were opened in 1806 in Blackwall, London, to accommodate the shipping needs of the East India Company. This aquatint presents an aerial view of the docks, with the Thames in the middle ground, and Greenwich in the distance to the right. It was drawn, engraved and published by William Daniell, an English landscape and marine artist who together with his uncle Thomas Daniell  travelled extensively in India.

context_1: Dutch East India Company's first embassy to China
sgcool_label_text: This book contains the account of the first embassy sent by the Dutch East India Company (VOC) from 1655 to 1657 to the Emperor of China, as chronicled by Johan Nieuhof. It is one of the earliest European accounts of Chinese culture, society, geography, botany and zoology, and includes a detailed description of the East Indies. The text, based on Nieuhof's eyewitness account, is supplemented with numerous illustrations.

sgcool_label_text: Henricus Hondius's 1636 map of Southeast Asia was based on Willem Blaeu's map from the previous year. Both maps were vast improvements from earlier maps of the region, and present the extent of the trading influence of the Dutch East India Company. This map features a dedication in Latin to the wealthy Dutch merchant Christophoro Thisio.

sgcool_label_text: Francois Valentijn was a minister, naturalist and writer who devoted much of his life in serving the Dutch V.O.C., having spent a significant tenure from 1685 to 1714 in the East Indies. His monumental work Oud en Nieuw Oost-Indien (Old and New East-India), published between 1724 and 1726, offered a comprehensive mapping of Southeast Asia, and a large selection of scale maps and views of the East Indies.

title_text: Jain Siddhapratima yantra

sgcool_label_text: The Siddhapratima Yantra, meaning magical diagram depicting a perfected being, shows the silhouette of a Jina from the Digambara sect of Jainism. It is cut out of a copper plaque which is stele-shaped with a stepped base, the usual style of a sculpture, except there is a space where the figure would be. This type of image is a way of showing a formless form. It denotes the ultimate transcendence of the perfected being.

title_text: Buddhist artist's manual
physical_appearance: This is an artist's manual written with black ink on yellow dyed paper and folded in an accordian format. The instructions are written in Nepali.
subject_terms_1: Buddhism Buddhas (visual works)  stupas
subject_terms_2: Buddhist literature, Newari  Art, Newari  Nepali Buddhism and art Stupas
sgcool_label_text:
This artist’s manual consists of 24 pages of hand-made paper folded accordion-style (Nepali: thyasaphu). Annotated diagrams indicating the standard proportions for reliquary stupas and for Buddha images are drawn in ink. Buddhist and Hindu craftsmen use this system, called iconometry, to invest sacred images with divine power.

Artists in the Kathmandu Valley are usually of the Newari ethnic group. The skill of Newari craftsmen in the metallurgical arts was recorded by pilgrims from China as early as the seventh century Newari craftsmen passed down their skills down generations of apprentices through manuals such as this one, supplemented by oral teachings.

title_text: Man's sash
physical_appearance: This is a long sash. The sash is blue, with the ends featuring embroidery work comprised of brightly-coloured, geometric patterns. The ends of the panels are bordered by stitched triangles. There are several tears in the middle of the sash.
subject_terms_1: folk costume embroidery (visual works) geometric motifs ceremonial costume
subject_terms_2: Sashes (Clothing) Ethnic costume Embroidery Motifs
sgcool_label_text: The form of this sash is similar to Chinese men’s sashes.  Both ends of the sash are embroidered in drawn work technique.  The embroidery panels comprise brightly-coloured, geometric patterns.  They are segmented by flattened and couched metallic thread work.  The pointed end of the panels are bordered by triangles in darning stitches.  The style of this drawn work is typical of West Sumatran examples, which features angular animal motifs as well.  Gold bobbin lace and the sawtooth motif worked in a variant of buttonhole stitch bind the edges of the sash.  Given its labour intensive production and choice of silk, this sash may have been worn as part of a ceremony, such as a wedding.

title_text: Ceremonial handkerchief or dowry tray cover
physical_appearance: This is a square handkerchief. It features a multicolored dense embroidery depicting several animal and floral motifs. The center of the handkerchief shows a circular medallion with a peony and a phoenix. It is framed by more floral motifs, with a figure of an elephant, tiger, lion, and gilin on the four corders. The square handkerchief has three borders of decorative bands that contain Daoist symbolisms and sylised animals.
subject_terms_1: embroidery (visual works) ceremonial objects flower (motif) geometric motifs birds (motifs) Taoism trousseaux
subject_terms_2: Handkerchiefs Embroidery Ceremonial objects Motifs Taoism Dowry
sgcool_label_text: This handkerchief (sapu tangan) was probably used as a decorative tray cover that was placed over items presented on trays as part of a ceremony.  A peony in bloom and a phoenix dominates the central circular medallion.  It is surrounded by floral sprays, and framed by an elephant, tiger, lion and qilin on the four corners.  Following the edges of this main square decoration are three borders of distinct decorative bands.  The innermost and outermost borders, like the main square silk fabric, are worked with silk floss in satin and voided satin stitches.  They contain auspicious Daoist symbols such as the double knot of happiness, conch and a pair of castanets.  The middle border consists of a polychrome border of drawn thread embroidery, consisting of stylised animals, human figures and floral motifs.  The handkerchief could have been part of the bridal trousseau prepared for the groom and his family.

title_text: Ceremonial handkerchief or dowry tray cover
physical_appearance: This is a square handkerchief. It features a multicolored embroidery depicting several animal and floral motifs. The center circular medallion contains phoenixes and a peony bloom. It is outlined by lotuses, and framed by an elephant, a tiger, a lion, and a gillan on the four corners. The handkerchief is decorated with two borders of repeated geometric shapes and stylised animals.
subject_terms_1: embroidery (visual works) ceremonial objects flower (motif) geometric motifs birds (motifs) Taoism trousseaux
subject_terms_2: Handkerchiefs Embroidery Ceremonial objects Motifs Taoism Dowry
sgcool_label_text: This handkerchief (sapu tangan) was probably used as a decorative tray cover that was placed over items presented on trays as part of a ceremony.  A circular medallion comprising a pair of confronting phoenixes and a peony bloom occupy the centre of the cloth.  It is outlined by a band of lotuses.  The medallion is further framed by four qilins, each demarcated by Chinese cloud scroll patterns in silver thread.  Two borders comprising silk floss in satin and voided stitches, and drawn work embroidery enclose the main square decoration.  The drawn work embroidery consists of repeated geometric shapes and stylised animals.  Given the auspicious motifs on this piece, this handkerchief could have been part of the bridal trousseau prepared for the groom and his family.  The phoenix is symbolic of martial harmony while the qilin represents fertility and longevity.

title_text: Ceremonial handkerchief or dowry tray cover
physical_appearance: This is a square handkerchief. It features a multicoloured embroidery around the border, and a drawn batik design in the center. The batik drawings encompasses of several animals and sea creatures. The edges of the handkerchief is bound by a stitching of gold bobbin lace.
subject_terms_1: embroidery (visual works) ceremonial objects geometric motifs batik art
subject_terms_2: Handkerchiefs Embroidery Ceremonial objects Motifs Dowry Batik
sgcool_label_text: This handkerchief (sapu tangan) was probably used as a decorative tray cover that was placed over items presented on trays as part of a ceremony.  The main square panel comprises hand-drawn batik design of animals and sea creatures in navy blue.  It is enclosed by a border of drawn work embroidery made up of repeated geometric patterns, animals and sea creatures.  The combination of batik tulis and drawn work embroidery is unusual.  Its layout of the square decorative panel is comparable to the silk batik lokcan squares that were imported from Java to Sumatra.  The edges of the cloth is bound by sawtooth borders worked in a variant of buttonhold stitch.  The fridge of this handkerchief is decorated with gold bobbin lace.

title_text: Ceremonial handkerchief or dowry tray cover
physical_appearance: This is a square handkerchief. It features a multicoloured embroidery decorated with motifs including stylised flowers, birds, animals and insects. The central square decoration features butterflies and phoenixes. Four peony blooms surround the corners of the central motif.
subject_terms_1: embroidery (visual works) ceremonial objects flower (motif) geometric motifs birds (motifs) cultural diffusion
subject_terms_2: Handkerchiefs Embroidery Ceremonial objects Motifs Dowry Culture diffusion
sgcool_label_text: This handkerchief (sapu tangan) was probably used as a decorative tray cover that was placed over items presented on trays as part of a ceremony.  The choice of auspicious decorative motifs (stylised motifs of flowers, birds, animals and insects) suggests that this handkerchief was part of the bridal trousseau prepared for the groom and his family.  Pairs of butterflies in the central square decoration and phoenixes enclosed in squares at the four corners of the cloth symbolise martial harmony, while the fretwork border, possibly a variant of the banji pattern, is believed by the Chinese to contain talismanic properties.  It is plausible that European influence is present in this piece given the choice of European flowers such as the rose in the embroidery, and the similarity to European cross-stich designs.

title_text: Robe Silk robe
physical_appearance: This is a silk robe. It has a V-shaped opening. The collar is enclosed by a quatrefoil of scrolling chrysanthemums and hibiscus. The floral motif is repeated on the edges of the sleeves.  Peacocks interspersed amongst flowers are printed along the bottom on the front of the robe.
subject_terms_1: tops (garments, general) flower (motif) birds (motifs) symbolism (artistic concept) folk costume
subject_terms_2: Robes Motifs Symbolism Ethnic costume
sgcool_label_text: This silk robe has a v-shaped opening for the head.  Its collar is enclosed by a quatrefoil of scrolling chrysanthemums and hibiscus motif.  This cloud cover design, also known as the auspicious ruiyi fungus motif, resembles 18th century Qing dynasty robe designs.  The floral motif is repeated on the edges of the sleeves.  Peacocks interspersed among flowers are printed on both the front and back of the robe.  The peacock is a symbol of beauty of dignity in Chinese culture.

title_text: Panel
physical_appearance: This is a costume panel. It is long and bronze in colour, featuring nine medallions in the center. The center medallion features a dragon motif, while the other medallions feature other symbols such as a whisk, a fan and a drum.
subject_terms_1: dragons folk costume symbolism (artistic concept) Taoism
subject_terms_2: Clothing and dress Ethnic costume Symbolism Motifs Taoism Dragons
sgcool_label_text: A dragon motif occupies the central lobed medallion, and is flanked by auspicious Daoist symbols--the fly whisk, fan, pair of castanets, and bamboo drum—similarly enclosed in lobed medallions.  The front- facing dragon was possibly inspired by Ming dynasty imperial court robes, with the dragon symbolising the emperor’s centrality in the universe.  Pencil outlines of the designs in the cartouches are evident where some beads have fallen off.

title_text: Panel
physical_appearance: This is a textile panel. It comprises of three main horizontal decorative sections. The topmost section features stitched Chinese scrolls. The middle section features vases of flowers amidst scrolls and butterflies, with brown lobed medallions enclosing birds and flowers. The bottom panel feature two horizontal rows of black-bordered sections. Each section alternates flowers, birds and animal motifs. The edges of the panel is slightly frayed, especially at the bottom-right.
subject_terms_1: embroidery (visual works) birds (motifs) scrolls (motifs) flower (motif) symbolism (artistic concept) Buddhism
subject_terms_2: Textiles Embroidery Motifs Symbolism Buddhism
sgcool_label_text: This textile panel comprises three main horizontal decorative sections.  Satin-stitched Chinese scrolls occupy the uppermost section.  In the middle section, vases of flowers, also one of the eight Buddhist auspicious symbols, are shown amidst the scrolls and butterflies while birds and flowers are enclosed within brown lobed medallions and black diaper patterns.  At the bottom of the panel are two horizontal rows of black diaper borders.  They feature alternating vase of flowers, bird and animal motifs.  It is plausible that the stylized motifs represent the phoenix and qilin, both of which are commonly depicted on nyonya embroidery.  The phoenix is symbolic of martial harmony while the qilin represents fertility and longevity.

title_text: Trade Catalogue of Kashmiri Copperware
physical_appearance: This is a catalogue book. It has a red cover, with a label on it. There is an inscription written on the label in Kashmiri script. The cover is indented with floral decorative patterns. The book looks worn, with frayed and torn edges especially along the spine.
subject_terms_1: industries (organizations) copperwork (visual works) trade (function)
subject_terms_2: Catalogs Indian copperwork Commerce
sgcool_label_text: Coppersmithing and the production of copper utensils is a traditional craft of the Kashmir region of India. Fine-quality utensils were manufactured in the region using hammered, repousse techniques and tinning. Kashmiri copperware was traditionally given as bride gifts, and used for ritual purposes. During the 18th and 19th centuries, Kashmiri copperware was also collected by Europeans in India as evidenced from the collections of Kashmiri copperware that are part of the collections of the Victoria & Albert Museum and the British Museum, donated by collectors who had purchased them in the 19th century. This catalogue is a very interesting and rare artefact, as it contains drawings of the various types of utensils being manufactured, possibly for customers to choose and place orders with the coppersmiths. This type of document, dating to the 19th century, is a record of the breadth of manufacturing and industry in Colonial India as well as of the type of designs that were in vogue at the time.

title_text: The Medieval Encyclopedia Tirukkural Medieval Encyclopedia Tirukkural
physical_appearance: This is a classical Tamil text called Tirukkural. It is a collection of inscriptions on thin panels, held together by a string through two holds in the middle of each segment.
subject_terms_1: Tamil (culture or style) ethics (philosophy) inscriptions religious texts
subject_terms_2: Classical texts Tiruvalluvar Ethics Palm-leaf inscriptions Tamil language
sgcool_label_text: Tirukkural, authored by the sage Tiruvalluvar and dating to the 5th-6th century, is considered one of the greatest works of Tamil writing. The text, divided into 133 chapters of 10 couplets each, covers a wide range of topics pertaining to morality, behaviour and the human condition. From the 12th century, in the tradition of Indian literary discourse, various commentaries have been written on Tirukurral, more so than for any other Tamil text. This is a 19th century copy of Tirukkural with annotated commentary, further highlighting how important the text continued to be even up to the modern period.

title_text: Manual for Ten Rituals - On Marriage Dashakarmapaddhati
physical_appearance: This is a compiled palm leaf manuscript. The manuscript is compiled within two rounded palm leaf cases. It is bound by a red and orange band. There is a hole through the center of the palm leaf manuscript.
subject_terms_1: Hinduism weddings (ceremonies) inscriptions religious texts
subject_terms_2: Classical texts Hinduism Rites and ceremonies Handbooks and manuals Marriage service Palm-leaf inscriptions Tamil language
sgcool_label_text: The dashakarma or “ten rites” of Hindu tradition, encompass all aspects of a Hindu’s life from conception to death. The methods or paddhati of these ten rites have been described, to enable correct observance of each rite. This manuscript is the manual of marriage, thus describing the steps to be taken for a marriage ceremony. The text originates from the Bengal region of eastern India, and as it dates to the 19th century, would serve as an important record of the rites observed at the time.

title_text: A Sanskrit Lexicon Amarakosa Sanskrit Lexicon
physical_appearance: This is a Sanskrit Lexicon. It is compiled on inscribed palm leaf pieces. Each piece is rectangular in shape, and has two holes in the center. There is a string by the compiled manuscript.
subject_terms_1: Sanskrit (language) inscriptions
subject_terms_2: Dictionaries Sanskrit language Palm-leaf inscriptions
sgcool_label_text: The Amarakosa (“immortal treasure”) is a lexicon of the Sanskrit language, authored sometime between the 5th and 8th centuries, and has had over 40 commentaries written to it. This palm-leaf manuscript of the Amarakosa originates from Sri Lanka, dating to the early 19th century, indicating the spread of the usage and study of Sanskrit, and its continued prevalence even in the 19th century.

title_text: Bridal tunic
physical_appearance: This is a red tunic with elaborate embroidery done with gold thread. It is T-shaped, and has broad, straight sleeves. Central to the tunic is a large red lotus motif surrounded by phoenixes and peonies. It is paired with a skirt which has a frontal and back panel joined together at the waist; each panel has either a dragon or a phoenix motif that is framed by floral borders.
subject_terms_1: Peranakan  plant-derived motifs  phoenixes  dragons lotus (motif)  weddings (ceremonies)
subject_terms_2: Peranakan (Asian people)  Floral decorations  Lotus in art  Wedding costume
sgcool_label_text: This skirt is made up of two pieces, a frontal panel and a back panel joined together at the waist.  Each panel comprises either an auspicious dragon or phoenix motif.  Framed by brightly coloured floral borders, the dragon and phoenix are worked in gold thread couchings.  The front-facing coiled dragon motif was possibly inspired by Ming dynasty imperial court robes, with the dragon symbolising the emperor’s centrality in the universe.  Dragons are seldom seen in Peranakan embroidery, whereas the phoenix, signifying loyalty and good fortune, is more common.  Here, the dragon represents the yang or male principle while the phoenix represents the complementary yin or female principle. The bride wore this skirt together with a tunic as part of her twelve-day Peranakan wedding.

title_text: Figur Dasar Bulat-Bulat
physical_appearance: This colourful silkscreen features a female nude lying on her back on a cushion with her legs lifted up in the air. Interspersing the image and peppered throughout the print are geometric patterns. The bottom half of the print is predominantly yellow, while the top half is white.
subject_terms_1: nudes (representations)  geometric patterns
subject_terms_2: Female nude in art Geometry in art
sgcool_label_text:
This work is an interesting study of Apin’s steadfastness in searching for new visual languages. Often called the ‘Father of Graphic Art’ in Indonesia this work features the female nude, a series that he would go on to develop in his last paintings between 1990-1993 titled ‘Provocative Bodies’. 

This work is also an important reference for the Bandung art scene in the 1970s where there were many artists pushing the boundaries of this art medium. Most of these artists came from ITB where Apin was teaching at that time. Their names include Kaboel Suadi, T. Sutanto, A.D. Pirous, Priyanto S. and others.

object_work_type: canvas paintings  oil paintings (visual works) religious art
title_text: Hanuman
physical_appearance: This central focus of this painting is Hanuman, a monkey deity featured in the Ramayana. His jaw is ajar, revealing a set of sharp teeth. Depicted to be on all fours with the exception of his raised right palm, he tilts his head backwards and stares at the top right corner where a red circle is. Duchanee's paint strokes are strong, decisive and swift. Outlining only certain areas, he uses a combination of shading techniques to give the body of Hanuman its form. His head is fully coloured, and his palms have been realistically portrayed.
subject_terms_1: Hinduism gods (deities)  religious characters folk tales outlines (linear forms)
subject_terms_2: Hinduism and culture Hindu gods Hanuman Folklore Faith in art
subject_terms_3: Hinduism Religious life and practices visual arts
context_1: This painting was part of a solo exhibition held at the British Council in 1973 showing art that depicted characters from the Thai epic Ramakian.
sgcool_label_text:
Thawan Duchanee is one of Thailand’s foremost artists and whose vivid and visceral interpretations of Buddhist teachings and visual motifs have won him international acclaim. 
Despite being an avowed Buddhist, Thawan has invoked the importance Hinduism has within Thai folk culture with his depiction of Hanuman, a central figure of the Ramayanan or Ramakien (in Thai). Popularly known as the Monkey God, Hanuman is in Hindu accounts, the incarnation or avatar of Shiva and represents divine strength, power and agility. Here in this painting, Thawan captures a chapter in the chronicles of Hanuman in which the monkey deity is ravenous with hunger and mistakes the sun for a ripened mango. As he chases the sun, the god Indra intervenes by striking Hanuman in the jaw, triggering a saga of retaliation from Hanuman’s father.
Hanuman was part of a renowned series of 14 paintings shown at his solo exhibition at the British Council in Bangkok in 1973. This work comes from a period just after Thawan’s paintings were slashed by students in 1971 for supposedly desecrating Buddhism as he had juxtaposed erotic, monstrous forms with the Buddha, and he was at the time residing at the Student Christian Centre which led to a misconception that Thawan was a sacrilegious Christian railing against Buddhist beliefs. The Ramayana series however did not cause the same controversy of his earlier works because the depicted subjects were monkeys and demons rather than Buddhism.

title_text: WWII – The Ambitious Trio of the Axis  ????
physical_appearance: This is a coloured drawing depicting three military leaders. On the left is a portrait of Benito Mussolini in uniform and headgear. On his right is the Japanese emperor Hirohito in a suit. On the most right, is Adolf Hitler, dressed in uniform with a swastika arm band. The three individuals are drawn as overlapping portraits. There is a vertical signature at the top left of the drawing.

subject_terms_2: Drawing World War, 1939-1945 Great Britain. Army. Force 136 Force 136 (Guerilla movement) Chen, Chongzhi, 1916- Mussolini, Benito, 1883-1945 Hirohito, Emperor of Japan, 1901-1989 Hitler, Adolf, 1889-1945
subject_terms_3: Drawing War personalities Force 136 (Guerilla movement) Tan, Chong Tee 1942-1945 Japanese occupation
sgcool_label_text:
This drawing belongs to part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from mid 1990s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

This drawing is Tan’s rendition of the three leaders (from right) Adolf Hitler, the Japanese emperor, Hirohito and Benito Mussolini.

title_text: Fate in God's Hands???: a scroll depicting Chua Koon Eng's Confession, Li Ah Ching Pretending to Surrender and Tan Tien Soong (alias Tan Chong Tee) Under Death Sentence Fate in God's Hands

sgcool_label_text:
This painting belongs to part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from mid 1990s to early 2000s.

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerrillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya. 

This painting is painted from the memory of Tan Chong Tee and depicts the trials underwent by war hero, Lim Bo Seng.

title_text: 50th Anniversary of the Death of Martyr Lim Bo Seng ???????50????
physical_appearance: This oil painting is a commemoration of the 50th Anniversary of the Death of Lim Bo Seng. It features a montage of media coverage and attendees at the memorial event. The foreground shows a collage of media materials including newspapers and books. The background of the painting features a pagoda in the center, against the cityscape. The center of the painting is filled with a depiction of the crowd at the event, blending into portraits of significant figures who attended the memorial. There is a signature at the top-right of the painting.

The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

sgcool_label_text:
These documents and photographs belong to a larger part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

title_text: Reflections of Tan Chong Tee: Letters, Notes, and Photographs Reflections of Tan Chong Tee: Memoir
physical_appearance: This text, written in Chinese in blue ink, records the author's experience after leaving the prison where he was held captive for 18 months. The author was unwell and on his return journey to the hotel, had fainted in the car. He was rushed back to his accomodation, where he could then take medication and rest. Despite the 18 months of torture, he felt comforted knowing that he was alive. The top half of the paper is torn, and insertions and markings were made in blue and red ink. It was written on Chinese foolscap paper.

sgcool_label_text:
These documents and photographs belong to a larger part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

physical_appearance: This text documents the author's desire to leak the information regarding Lim's death and their transfer to the police lockup in Tapah. The document is composed of text written on a piece of Chinese foolscap which has a another piece of writing pasted on it. The words are written in two shades of blue ink and red ink. It has numerous corrections, and is marked 32 (??/ second part.5) on the top left corner. The paper is folded inwards on both the left and right length. There is a tick on the bottom right corner.

title_text: Lung Chui Ying Collection: Force 136 badge ????? Lung Chiu Ying Collection: Force 136 badge
physical_appearance: This is a set of two badges from Force 136. The top one is rectangular shaped, and striped in the colours blue, yellow, red and light blue. The badge below it is in the shape of a circle. Within it, there is a bird with outstretched wings against a beige background. Underneath the bird, there is a red flame pattern. The thread on the right of the badge is slightly frayed.

title_text: Lung Chui Ying Collection: Scarf of Force 136  ????? Lung Chiu Ying Collection: Scarf of Force 136
physical_appearance: This is a scarf of Force 136. It has a white base, with fraying ends. Embroidered on the scarf is a portrait image of a man in a collared uniform in blue. There are initials on the bottom-right of the man's portrait. On the underside of the scarf, there is a embroidered image of a coast, with a name, date and place embroidered underneath it. The scarf is slightly stained.
subject_terms_1: world wars resistance movements embroidery (visual works) portraits
subject_terms_2: World War, 1939-1945 Great Britain. Army. Force 136 Force 136 (Guerilla movement) Scarves Embroidery Portraits
subject_terms_3: Force 136 (Guerilla movement) 1942-1945 Japanese occupation Lung, Chiu Ying
sgcool_label_text:
This scarf belongs to Lung Chui Ying and forms part of a larger collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was amassed by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the mid-1990s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

Lung Chui Ying was a Hainanese born in Johor and recruited as a Force 136 member to fight against the Japanese in Malaya.

physical_appearance: This is a map featuring Malaya and Sumatra. On the bottom-left of the map, there is a wider view of the region in a rectangular boxed section. The map utilises shades of brown and orange to indicate altitude. The map is deeply creased along the folds.

title_text: Lung Chui Ying Collection: commemorative booklet on unveiling of Lim Bo Seng Memorial  ????? Lung Chiu Ying Collection: commemorative booklet on unveiling of Lim Bo Seng Memorial
physical_appearance: This is a commemorative booklet on the unveiling of Lim Bo Seng Memorial. It is printed in black and white. The cover of the booklet includes a title and date at the top-center, with a Chinese title at the bottom. In the center of the booklet, there is a photograph of an octagonal pagoda, with lions at the base and a roof cap. The booklet is stapled together at three points on the left. The edges of the booklet is slightly folded and torn, especially along the spine and at the bottom right corner.

title_text: Lung Chui Ying Collection: Image and interior plan of an Allied submarine  ????? Lung Chiu Ying Collection: Image and interior plan of an Allied submarine
physical_appearance: This is a set of black-and-white documents featuring photographs of an Allied submarine and its interior plan. The first document at the top shows the interior plan through four different sections, with labels for each room and compartment. The second document below it shows two photographs of the submarine above water. The photographs are accompanied with Chinese captions underneath them. There are no tears seen on either documents.

These photographs, printed images, pamphlets and clippings belong to Lung Chui Ying and is part of a larger collection related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the mid-1990s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

Lung Chui Ying was a Hainanese born in Johor and recruited as a Force 136 member to fight against the Japanese in Malaya.

The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the mid-1990s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

Lung Chui Ying was a Hainanese born in Johor and recruited as a Force 136 member to fight against the Japanese in Malaya.

title_text: Report on Demobilisation of Force 136
physical_appearance: This is a report on demobilisation of Force 136. It consists of six pages, written in vertical columns. There are several holes on the document, especially on the first page on the right.
subject_terms_1: world wars resistance movements documents (object genre) handwriting Chinese scripts
subject_terms_2: World War, 1939-1945 Great Britain. Army. Force 136 Force 136 (Guerilla movement) Demobilization Chen, Chongzhi, 1916- Writing
subject_terms_3: Force 136 (Guerilla movement) 1942-1945 Japanese occupation Tan, Chong Tee
sgcool_label_text:
This report belongs to part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the mid-1990s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

This report outlines the work revolving the demobilisation of Force 136 at the end of the war.

There is a caption printed at the bottom of the photograph.

The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the mid-1990s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

This photograph featuring Force 136 members with general Chuan Hui Quan ???? in Perak. Chuan worked alongside Lim Bo Seng as a commanding general in leading Force 136 against the Japanese.

subject_terms_3: Force 136 (Guerilla movement) 1942-1945 Japanese occupation war personalities
sgcool_label_text:
This certificate belongs to part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

title_text: Lim Hong Pei Collection: Reproduction of a discharge document  ?????
physical_appearance: This is a reproduced document certifying honourable discharge from Force 136. The title is printed at the top-center of the document. The date and signature is marked at the bottom of the document, with several added handwritten inscriptions. The document is slightly folded around the corners.

These photographs belong to part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

The notes contain information on the nature of explosives and how to proceed with a guerrilla mission.

sgcool_label_text:
These materials belong to Chan Phui Kong and consist of items which he used in guerrilla warfare as a member of the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136.  They form part of a larger collection of materials gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s.

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

title_text: Chan Phui Kong Collection: Japanese Flag, Parachute Cloth, Photographs, Maps, Documents and Scarfs  Chan Phui Kong Collection: Reproduction of a discharge document
physical_appearance: This is a reproduced letter of military discharge. The name of the officer is printed at the top center of the letter. Below it, there is a signature on the left, with an identity photograph on the right. There is a Force 136 stamp by the photograph. Underneath the text, there is a signature on the bottom right, and a date on the bottom left. The folds and marks of the original document is slightly visible. The reproduced document has no tears or folds seen.
subject_terms_1: world wars resistance movements discharges reproduction (copying)

The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

title_text: Pocket sized French-Dutch-Malay Dictionary LONG, G. and HOCHREUTINER, Bénédict Pierre Georges.  Petit dictionnaire Français-Hollandais-Malais dans l'ordre alphabétique des trois langues... Kleine alfabetische woordenlijst in het Fransch-Hollandsch-Maleisch... Kitab lograt dari bahasa Melajoe, Wolanda dan Prantjis.  Batavia, Kolff & Co, 1906.
creator_2: Benedict Pierre Goerges Hochreutiner  G. Long
creator_role: compilers (people in literature) compilers (people in literature) publishers
physical_appearance: This is a French-Dutch-Malay dictionary. It is worn along its edges, and has some scribbling along the top right corner. The spine appears to be weak and tattered.
subject_terms_1: French (language)  Dutch (language)  Malay (language)
subject_terms_2: Dictionary  Malay language  French  Dutch  Dutch East Indies  s Lands Plantentuin (this is oddly, the name of Botanic Gardens of Buitenzorg)  Java (Indonesia)
sgcool_label_text: This pocket-sized French-Dutch-Malay dictionary, published in Java in 1906, is extremely rare, being the first and only edition. It was compiled by G. Long and Bénédict Pierre Georges Hochreutiner, respectively assistant and temporary assistant at the Botanic Gardens of Buitenzorg (Bogor), in the Dutch East Indies. The fact that botany officers were involved in the production of this tri-language dictionary underscores the importance that European technocrats placed on learning Malay so that they could operate in the field

title_text: English-Malay bi-directional Dictionary  BOWREY, Thomas.  A dictionary English and Malayo, Malayo and English. To which is added some short grammar rules and directions for the better observation of the propriety and elegancy of this language.  London, Sam. Bridge for the author, 1701.
physical_appearance: This is an English-Malay dictionary. It is hardback, and the cover is reddish-brown. Noticeably, the edges of the papers are red.
subject_terms_1: Malay (language)  English (language)
subject_terms_2: Dictionary  Malay language  English
sgcool_label_text: This is a first edition copy of an English-Malay dictionary, compiled by Thomas Bowrey and published in London in 1701. Bowrey (ca. 1650-1713), was an East India Company (EIC) sea captain who spent nineteen years from 1669 sailing about the islands, seas and coastlines of the Malay Archipelago. He endured many perils during his voyages, including attacks by pirates, hidden shipwrecks and local warfare. Bowrey explains in the Preface (p. 6) the reasons for such a publication: ‘I finding so very few English Men that have attained any tollerable knowledge of the Malayo tongue, so absolutely necessary to trade in those Southern Seas, and that there is no book of this kind published in English, to help the attaining of that Language; these considerations, I say, has imboldened me to publish the insuing Dictionary…”. That such a dictionary existed so early in the 18th century, suggests that international trade in the area was significant enough for the English to learn the language of business there, i.e. Malay.

sgcool_label_text: These photographs were taken by Egbert Sheaf, the Australian Trade Commissioner in Singapore, several taken before and some of which were most likely taken when he was posted here between 1922-25. Sheaf conscientiously studied South-East Asia's ethnography and his scholarship was coupled with a passion for travel and adventure. His photographs cover various aspects of daily and cultural life such as weaving, the rice agriculture and other rituals of Javanese and Malayan communities, as explained and illustrated in the portfolios and albums.

title_text: The Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere by Utsunomiya Ken
physical_appearance: On the cover of the book, the title, substitle, and publisher's name can be found. It is also underlined in blue.  Along the right edge of the book are white strings that reveal how the book has been bound. Beneath the title is an illustration of palm trees and aeroplanes in flight.
subject_terms_1: propaganda world wars colonialism
subject_terms_2: Southeast Asia  Photographic surveying  Propaganda, Japanese  Colonies  World War, 1939-1945 Books Greater East Asia Co-prosperity Sphere  Utsunomiya Ken  Nihon Rekishi Kenky?kai
sgcool_label_text: Published in 1942, this book is an extensive photographic survey of the regions of Southeast Asia under Japanese colonial rule during the Pacific War, including the Philippines, French Indochina, Thailand, Burma, Malaya, Borneo and Singapore. It was edited by Utsunomiya Ken, and published by Nihon Rekishi Kenky?kai (Japanese History Research Group). As a propagandistic publication, it intended to promote the concept of ‘brotherhood’ amongst Southeast Asian people under the Japanese Empire.

title_text: Perfect Man's Model (Quanren Juyue) by Karl Friedrich August Gützlaff
physical_appearance: The book is bound by white strings that have been threaded through small holes along the edges of the paper. The papers are torn along the top right of the book, and shows wear along the ridges of the paper. Browning has also occurred throughout the book, though particularly evident along the edges of the papers.

title_text: Compilation of bugle calls for the Ceylon Rifle Regiment
physical_appearance: This is a compilation of bugle calls for the Ceylon Rifle Regiment. The cover of the book is brown, with strips of red along its spine as well as on the top and bottom right corners.
subject_terms_1: military officers bugles (valveless aerophones)
subject_terms_2: Bugle calls  East India Company  Musical notation  Ensign William Guy
sgcool_label_text: The Ceylon Rifle Regiment (CRR) was a regular native regiment formed by the British in Ceylon in 1795, when five independent companies of Malays were transferred from the Dutch to the British East India Company service. This manuscript, dated 1856, compiles the bugle calls for 113 military commands, each with musical notation and explanatory remarks in English, Malay and Tamil. It was compiled by Ensign William Guy of the CRR, and was directed to native and non-commissioned officers of the Regiment. The bugle calls were divided into ‘regulation sounds’, daily barrack sounds’ and ‘miscellaneous sounds’.

title_text: Title unknown
materials_name: paper (fibre product)  rice paper (paper)  acrylic paint glass (material)
physical_appearance: This is an illuminated collage consisting of acrylic-dyed coloured rice paper pressed together. Abstract and non-representational, its layering shines through when the light is turned on. Bulbs are arranged within the glass panel (behind the most exterior surface) and has a power cord that leads to an adaptor which when plugged in, lights up the entire work.

subject_terms_2: Art, Abstract Experiments  Lighting  Ideology in art

sgcool_label_text: Rodolfo Paras-Perez (1934-2011) or Rod. Paras-Perez, as he frequently used in texts he authored, is a respected Philippine artist and art historian. In the 1960s, Paras-Perez created illuminated collages, made of acrylic-dyed rice paper pressed between glass and lighted from behind. They were seen as quite experimental for its time, using static light to expose and highlight the layers composing the collage. The works combine the growing influence of collage with an early experimentation with using lighting as a medium. As collages of various layers of coloured paper, the works are also abstract, in line with the vogue of abstract art at that time. The abstract form and the effort to expose the collage process through lighting provides visual intrigue and elicits more thinking on the part of the viewer on composition and method. Paras-Perez has said, “an image should be ambiguous enough to slide into several meanings. In a collage, one can use several layers of forms to sustain interest.”

title_text: Meditative Series IV
materials_name: paper (fibre product)  rice paper (paper)  acrylic paint glass (material)
physical_appearance: This is an illuminated collage consisting of acrylic-dyed coloured rice paper pressed together. Abstract and non-representational, its layering shines through when the light is turned on. Bulbs are arranged within the glass panel (behind the most exterior surface) and has a power cord that leads to an adaptor which when plugged in, lights up the entire work. Composition wise, particularly striking are two hemispherical blotches of blue along the right edge of the work, the yellow, red, and orange dyed paper presses.

title_text: Untitled
physical_appearance: This oil painting depicts a serene scene of a rural community set amidst lush greenery. Tall trees with dense foliage occupy more than half of the composition, while the back center piece features a bamboo house with a high attap-roof. Emphasis is paid to the hut as it is framed under the arch of a rainbow that cuts across the sky. Filled with fluffy white clouds, the sky features a lone star that can be seen on the top right corner. To the hut's right, one notices another hut in a distance.
subject_terms_1: identity  landscapes (representations)  rural areas  thatched roofs rural life  rural houses
subject_terms_2: Identity  Rural  National identity  Cross/cultures Painting
sgcool_label_text:
Born in 1932, Patrick Ng received his early education at Oxford English School in Singapore and his secondary education at St John's Institution and Victoria Institution (VI) in Kuala Lumpur. As a mentee of Peter Harris, Ng was one of the earliest members of the Wednesday Art Group, founded in 1952 and was secretary to the group who met at the Selangor Education Department office. Ng left for London under a British Council-administered scholarship known as the Sino-British fellow trust, now defunct, to study at the Hammersmith College of Art and Building (later Chelsea College of Art) from 1964-66. He continued his studies at Southlands Teacher Training College (majoring in fine art and textiles) from 1966-68. In his work, Ng incorporates a range of local Malaysian iconography and his distinctive style has positioned him as one of the most highly acclaimed artists in the history of modern Malaysian art.  

Upon comparing his painting styles across other works, this proposed work was likely to have been painted around the time of Ng’s most well-known painting Spirit of earth, water and air (1958/59), which is gazetted in the Malaysian National Heritage Register List and listed by Redza Piyadasa as one of the masterpieces in the collection of the National Art Gallery Malaysia. Spirit was used as front cover image for SAM’s catalogue Modernity and Beyond (1996). Ng’s Self-Portrait from 1958 is also rendered with similar motifs and in a similar colour scheme.  The proposed painting also looks to be a probable precursor to both those paintings, where Ng is working out the landscape composition and patterns from natural elements before the inclusion of human figures.

title_text: Irian Man with Bird of Paradise  Orang Irian dengan Burung Tjenderawasih
physical_appearance: The painting depicts an Irian shaman with a stern, piercing look. In his arms are several birds; one of which appears to be about to take flight. The colour scheme gravitates towards earthly hues of dark green and brown, with the exception of the bright red and yellow strokes on the birds. The contrast of hues enhances the mysticism of the piece; especially with respect to the positioning of the foot as an arm on the right of the painting.
subject_terms_1: magic  shamans contrast indigenous people  religious characters
subject_terms_2: Shamans  Indigenous men  Papua (Indonesia)  Shamanism  Painting
subject_terms_3: visual arts  oil painting  Religious life and practices
sgcool_label_text: As a sole female participant in PERSAGI (Persatuan Ahli Gambar Indonesia or Association of Indonesian Draftsmen) , Emiria Soenassa is a pioneering modern artist from Indonesia.  An Irian shaman with a mask-like face and piercing gaze is shown embracing the magical birds, with one of them abou to take flight.  The dreamy imaginative qualities of the work is emphasised through the stark contrast between dark and bright hues and the magical transformation of the man's hand to an earthy foot.  As a self-proclaimed princess from the island Sultanate of Tidore, Emiria advocated for Papuan independence from the Dutch.  Painted one year before the UN Roundtable Conference to discuss the handover of sovereignty over Papuan region from the Dutch to Indonesian government, this work may be associated with her political inclination.

title_text: Danger lurking behind the lotus Bahaya Belakang Kembang Terate
physical_appearance: Decked in a loin cloth and a head gear, this archer stands with his feet apart whilst drawing his bow. Dense foliage envelop him, and its dark green hue juxtaposes the bright pink of these blossoming lotus flowers, which are symbols of purity.
subject_terms_1: archers loincloth headdresses  bows (tools)  flower (plant material)  indigenous people  lotus (plant, general)
subject_terms_2: Archers  Headgear Headdresses Indigenous men  Papua (Indonesia)  Lotus in art Painting
sgcool_label_text:
Being the sole female participant in PERSAGI (Persatuan Ahli Gambar Indonesia or Association of Indonesian Draftsmen) , Emiria Soenassa is a pioneering modern artist from Indonesia.   
As a self-proclaimed princess from the island Sultanate of Tidore, Emiria advocated for Papuan independence from the Dutch.  An archer has bow drawn, but his aim or the source of his threat remain unknown in this work.  This, added with the stark contrast between the dark jungle and the bright flowers in various proportion conjure up a sense of mysteriousness and unsettling quality to the work.  The ethnic origin of the subject remains ambiguous, with certain elements of Dayak (loincloth) and Papuan (headdress and archery hunting) appear to have been combined together.

title_text: Chrysanthemum Bunga Crisant
physical_appearance: This is a still life of a vase of chrysanthemums in bloom with a hint of browning to perhaps indicate wilting as evidenced by the bend in stalks of the flowers. This is contrasted with the bulbous curves of the vase, and the black emptiness of the background.
subject_terms_1: chrysanthemum (genus)  still lifes  flower vases
subject_terms_2: Still-life in art Chrysanthemums in art  Flower vases
sgcool_label_text: As a sole female participant in PERSAGI (Persatuan Ahli Gambar Indonesia or Association of Indonesian Draftsmen) , Emiria Soenassa is a pioneering modern artist from Indonesia.  Her flowers, rather than being an idealised represntation of dainty flowers, are depicted boldly with forceful strokes and a sense of tention is created through the stark contrast of bright and dark hues.

title_text: Sri, the Goddess of Rice Sri Padi
physical_appearance: The painting is rather flat and has its depth implied with the utilisation of blocks of colour; pink for the sky, and green for the ground. The application of colour appears to be swift, as evidenced by the visible strokes of the brush and its lack of uniformity in direction. Central to the painting is a thin lady with elongated limbs sporting a headdress; the rice stalks found on the ground behind her suggests that she is the goddess of rice, Shridevi (whose lakshana is a rice). The presence of meru as well as the Balinese mask harkens to Balinese aesthetic traditions.
subject_terms_1: Oryza (genus)  religious characters  goddesses dance masks  ceremonial masks
subject_terms_2: Rice  Balinese mythology  Ceremonial objects
subject_terms_3: visual arts  oil painting  Religious life and practices
sgcool_label_text: As a sole female participant in PERSAGI (Persatuan Ahli Gambar Indonesia or Association of Indonesian Draftsmen) , Emiria Soenassa is a pioneering modern artist from Indonesia.  Whilst most of her contemporaries tended towrads mainstreatm nationalist interests, her works expressed a concern for the marginalised in society--the ethnic communities across the archipelago and women. The presence of meru, the Balinese mask and the goddess of rice suggest the work's reference to Bali.  The bold emphasis in flatness, playful use of bright colour and almost caricature like rendition of her motifs note the stylistic characteristics of her later period works.

title_text: Bathing in the River Mandi di Sungai
physical_appearance: This painting depicts a scene of a mother bathing her children in the river. Adopting a triangular composition, the mother strategically occupies the central position and is of a larger size than the other figures (albeit logically so). Baring her breasts, she hunches over slightly to wash the baby in her arms, whilst the other two children are left to care for themselves. A bucket of linen is placed in front of the mother. The branches of a tree cut diagonally on the upper left towards the centre, skillfully shaping the outline of the river. The backing which the painting has been mounted on and framed within shows signs of browning.

An attap hut can be seen in the shaded areas of the right, while human figures can be seen harvesting rosin from the trees.

title_text: 20 cards of strings of beads
physical_appearance: This is a set of 20 cards each containing strings of seed beads. There are four carrying green beads of various shades, two with blue beads of various shades, and the rest bearing beads of various colours.

subject_terms_3: Vanishing trade Textile art and design
sgcool_label_text: Strings of seed beads used in nyonya needlework are hung on these 20 cardboard pieces. The presence of shop marks on the backs of some of the cards is also important in identifying the provenance of these materials. Handwritten labels indicating the sizes of strings of beads also useful show how beads were categorised by size. These beads show the variety of bead types available to embroiderers in Malacca and Singapore. The original owner of these items made a living fashioning beaded slippers and dresses, working from home as she did not have a shop.

sgcool_label_text: This case of needles was used to store needles used in nyonya needlework. The brand ‘Mitrailleuse’ is inscribed on the case.. Needles used for beadwork are nearly identical to those utilised in embroidery. Since needles are made of iron and vulnerable to rust in the region’s humidity, they were packed in silver foils in bundles of ten, before being placed into small, cylindrical metal containers. The original owner of these items made a living fashioning beaded slippers and dresses, working from home as she did not have a shop.

Strings of beads could be unstrung before being categorised and placed into small bottles for use. Needles used for beadwork are nearly identical to those utilised in embroidery. The original owner of these items made a living fashioning beaded slippers and dresses, working from home as she did not have a shop.

title_text: Relief panel depicting St Francis Xavier
techniques_name: gilding (technique)  panel painting (image-making) carving (proceses)  relief (sculpture technique)
physical_appearance: This painted carved panel  in high relief depicts the moment when a crab returns Saint Francis his crucifix which had fallen into the sea during a storm. The carving is clean and the forms are vividly articulated. Varying colours of the paint as well as the gilding further enhances its dimensionality.  This panel may have been a part of a larger ensemble.
subject_terms_1: reliefs (sculptures)  religious art Roman Catholicism  religious characters  missionaries Jesuit (Christian order)  parables religious visual works religious symbolism
subject_terms_2: Religious art Christian art and symbolism Jesuit Missions Saints  Ceram Island (Indonesia)  Ambon Island (Indonesia)
subject_terms_3: churches Religious life and practices  visual arts
sgcool_label_text:
This carved panel shows one of the most famous miracles related to the Catholic missionary Saint Francis Xavier. When Francis Xavier was travelling between the islands of Ambon and Seram on his evangelizing mission, his ship encountered a storm, and Francis lost his crucifix in the rough waters. The ship managed to dock safely. Just then a crab appeared holding the crucifix in its claws, returning it to Francis Xavier. 
This is one of the most popular episodes from the life of the saint, and served as inspiration for many artworks after his death. From the panel’s size and high quality of carving, it was likely commissioned for a church.

title_text: Dish with the Arms of the de Muinck family
physical_appearance: This is a lacquered dish with gold decoration. Its broad flat rim is decorated with peonies and foliage. Featured in the centre of the dish is the de Muinck coat of arms. Some browning can be found across the dish.
subject_terms_1: maki-e exports commissions (orders for works)  flower (motif)  foliage (motif)
subject_terms_2: Relief (Art)  Art commissions  Peonies in art Foliage plants  Middelburg (Netherlands)
subject_terms_3: Decorative arts  Industrial and Product Design?
sgcool_label_text:
This dish bears the coat of arms of the de Muinck family from the city of Middelburg, Netherlands. Japanese lacquered objects were very popular in Europe between the 16th and 18th centuries. Many westerners commissioned pieces from Japan. 

This armorial dish was probably privately commissioned by a member of the de Muinck family, and the form is likely modelled after a Dutch pewter dish.

title_text: The Goddess emanates from the essence of all the gods
physical_appearance: This watercolour painting depicts a scene from the Devi Mahatmya (Glory of the Goddess). Surrounding the central goddess figure are various gods. They are adorned with crowns and are of different skin colours. Swift strokes of differing thickness emanate from the circle of gods towards the central figure, contributing to the culmination of her bodily form.
subject_terms_1: religious art religious characters religious concepts  religious texts religious visual works religious symbolism  deities
subject_terms_2: Puranas. Markandeyapurana. Devimahatmya Religious art Hindu gods Hindu goddesses Hindu symbolism  Indra (Hindu deity)  Gods
subject_terms_3: Hinduism Religious life and practices  visual arts  watercolour painting
sgcool_label_text:
The painting depicts a scene from the Devi Mahatmya (Glory of the Goddess), written between fifth and sixth century as part of the Markandeya Purana. The text indicates that all goddesses are in fact different aspects of one, ultimate goddess. She is said to have emerged from the combined energy of all the gods. 

The story states that Indra and the other gods had been expelled from their heaven by the buffalo-headed demon Mahishasura, and they appealed to Vishnu and Shiva for help. The anger of all the gods is channelled into pure energy that unites into a female form, thus creating the Great Goddess. She goes on to kill the buffalo demon Mahishasura, and the gods are restored to Indra’s heaven. 

The main Hindu gods are recognisable, ash-white Shiva, Indra covered in eyes, and blue Vishnu on the left, with four-headed Brahma on the right. The blank background indicates that the event happens outside of space and time.

title_text: Street Scene in Bombay
materials_name: paper (fibre product)  watercolour (paint) watercolour paper pencils (marking material)
physical_appearance: This is a watercolour painting that depicts a bustling street in Bombay in the 19th century. Horse carriages are seen to be passing amidst a throng of people, evidencing the busy nature of the streets. The plethora of costumes worn by the figures in the image also points to the cosmopolitan nature of the city.
subject_terms_1: perspective views (images)  colonialism  carriages (vehicles)  merchants street vendors street scenes
subject_terms_2: Cosmopolitanism  Imperialism  Perspective  Merchants Street vendors  Mumbai (India)
sgcool_label_text:
The watercolour shows a bustling street in Bombay in the 19th century. A European gentleman in a top hat rides in a carriage between merchants and street sellers. It shows the cosmopolitan nature of port cities at the time, with everyone jostling for space on the busy streets. 

William Simpson (1823-1899) was a successful topographical artist who after a series of acclaimed images of the Crimean War, was commissioned in 1859 by the publishers Day and Son, to produce images of India for publication. On his return he produced the book India: Ancient and Modern London, 1867, a series of illustrations with a descriptive text by John William Kaye. He made several later trips to India as well.

physical_appearance: This is a Ming dynasty blue-and-white dish. The centre of this large dish depicts a carp leaping out of the waves into the sky; implied by the cloud motifs. The flat rim is decorated with peonies that alternate between a variety of auspicious symbols  common to the Chinese tradition. Its outer body is painted with jasmine flowers. Its lower outer rim has sprawling vine motifs.

subject_terms_2: Carp Peonies Faith in art Fortune  Taoism and the arts Buddhism and art  Buddhism and culture Blue and white ware China Porcelain, Chjnese Ming- Qing dynasties, 1368-1912

context_1: It was exhibited at the Exhibition of Chinese Blue-and-White Ceramics held at the National Museum of Singapore in 1978.
sgcool_label_text: The centre of this large dish is painted with a carp leaping from waves, while the flattened rim is decorated with the various auspicious emblems and peony sprays. In Chinese art and culture, the leaping carp represents determination and accomplishment as it is associated with the passing of the civil service examinations. The imagery stems from a traditional Chinese belief that carps which swim upstream in the Yellow River and leap successfully across the rapids at Dragon’s Gate are transformed into dragons.

physical_appearance: This is a Ming dynasty Zhangzhou ware, evidenced by the grit on the base of the dish. The upper and lower rim of its exterior surface is decorated with simple blue lines, while its interior decorative scheme is composed of floral motifs and sprays segmented in three concentric bands.
subject_terms_1: porcelain paintings (visual works)  symbolism  floral patterns  freehand drawings (drawings)  Chinese export porcelain
subject_terms_2: Porcelain, Chinese Ming- Qing dynasties, 1368-1912 Blue and white ware China China trade porcelain  China painting
sgcool_label_text: This dish is decorated with floral sprays arranged in three concentric bands. The thick potting, sketchily-rendered decoration and gritty base of this dish indicates that it was produced at the Zhangzhou kilns in Fujian province. Grit often adhered to the foot of Zhangzhou wares as the pieces were placed directly on the coarse sand (spread on the bottom of the saggar) while they were still wet with glaze. Zhangzhou wares, which are distinguished by their free and vigorous style of painted decoration, were a popular type of ceramics made for export during the late Ming dynasty.

context_1: The dish was exhibited in the Exhibition of Chinese Blue-and-White Ceramics exhibition held at the National Museum of Singapore in April 1978. It is featured as number 157 in the exhibition catalogue.
sgcool_label_text:
The central medallion of the dish features five deer amid a rocky landscape. This is a representative example of Kraak porcelain which is distinguished by a thinly potted body and a decorative scheme divided into rectangular panels containing freely drawn figures and scenes. 

The term ‘Kraak’ was probably derived from the word ‘carrack’ referring to a type of Portuguese trading vessel. It might have also come from the Dutch word kraken which means ‘to break’ or the name for a style of shelves used for porcelain display in Dutch homes.

Similar to its exterior, its interior's central medallion shows the side profile of a spotted deer amongst vertical shrubs.
