context_1: The dish was exhibited in the Exhibition of Chinese Blue-and-White Ceramics exhibition held at the National Museum of Singapore in April 1978. It is featured as number 156 in the exhibition catalogue.
sgcool_label_text:
This bowl is painted on the exterior with eight panels of deer amid flowering shrubs, while the interior features a deer at the centre as well as panels decorated with peaches and flowers. The deer and peach were frequently used to decorate Chinese porcelain as they were associated with immortality. The panelled ornamentation and thin walls of the porcelain bowl are characteristic features of Kraak porcelain, a major type of Chinese export ware during the late Ming dynasty.  

The term ‘Kraak’ was probably derived from the word ‘carrack’ referring to a type of Portuguese trading vessel. It might have also come from the Dutch word kraken which means ‘to break’ or the name for a style of shelves used for porcelain display in Dutch homes.

sgcool_label_text: The creature depicted in the centre is typically identified as a qilin, a mythological beast believed to embody attributes such as benevolence, longevity and the bearing of illustrious offspring. Such dishes with a sketchily-rendered qilin motif have been recovered in large quantities in the Malay Archipelago. The thick potting and quality of glaze and decoration of this dish suggests that it was probably a product of the Zhangzhou kilns in Fujian province. Zhangzhou wares, which were distinguished by their spontaneous and often exuberant painted decoration, were a popular type of ceramics made for export during the late Ming dynasty.

sgcool_label_text: This small bowl is painted with a robed figure reclining against a rock. On the other side of the bowl, a young attendant seems to be preparing a drink for his master by a stove. Many similarly-sized bowls with designs sketchily-executed in underglaze blue were recovered from the Hatcher shipwreck, an Asian ship that sank in the South China Sea around 1643. While many bowls of this less refined quality were exported overseas, they have also been excavated in China and were probably used for drinking tea.

sgcool_label_text: This vessel which takes the form of a bronze gui censer is painted with a band of stylised decoration around the neck, and ruyi-heads and ring handles on the body. The decoration around the neck makes reference to taotie masks and other motifs used on ancient Chinese bronzes. The nod to antiquity highlights the prevalence of archaism as a key theme in the production of Chinese porcelain during the Qing dynasty (1644–1911).

context_1: The dish was exhibited in the Exhibition of Chinese Blue-and-White Ceramics exhibition held at the National Museum of Singapore in April 1978. It is featured as number 156 in the exhibition catalogue. They are featured as number 131 and 132 in the exhibition catalogue.
sgcool_label_text:
The pair of circular boxes have covers which are decorated with a peony blossom at the centre, surrounded by flowering shrubs in four bracketed panels. Covered ceramic boxes from China have been found in large quantities in Southeast Asia, and were most probably used to store incense, cosmetics or medicines. 
Although the decorative style of arranging designs into panels is generally associated with Kraak porcelain produced at Jingdezhen, it was also adopted by the Fujian potters at Zhangzhou. The relatively thick bodies, off-white glaze colour and more spontaneously-rendered decoration, suggests that the boxes were probably made at the Zhangzhou kilns. Boxes are unusual among extant examples of Zhangzhou wares, making this pair an important addition to the museum’s collection of Zhangzhou ceramics.

title_text: Blue and white box with floral decoration

physical_appearance: This is a small blue white porcelain lidded box. Painted atop the lid are flowering plants that blossom from the bottom left across to the top right. The strokes in underglazed blue is clear and refined; a testament to its quality. Lining the exterior of its base are also flowering decorations. There is strip of brown that lines the rim of both parts that indicates its wear.
subject_terms_1: floral patterns porcelain paintings (visual works)  symbolism  freehand drawings (drawings)  Wen ren  scholars
subject_terms_2: Porcelain, Chinese Ming- Qing dynasties, 1368-1912 Blue and white ware China China painting  Floral decorations
sgcool_label_text: The domed cover of this circular box is elegantly painted with flowering plants. The refined decoration executed in underglaze cobalt blue and the small size of the box suggest that it may have been used to contain seal paste. While seal-paste boxes are not identified as one of the ‘Four Treasures’ of a scholar’s studio, they were an important part of a gentleman’s writing desk as they stored the red paste with which he affixed his seal on a painting or calligraphy. Conversely, such small porcelain boxes may have been used by women for keeping ointments and cosmetics. These boxes were apparently popular overseas as well, as over a thousand small, circular porcelain boxes were found in the Hatcher shipwreck, an Asian ship that sank in the South China Sea around 1643.

context_1: The dish was exhibited in the Exhibition of Chinese Blue-and-White Ceramics exhibition held at the National Museum of Singapore in April 1978. It is featured as number 156 in the exhibition catalogue. They are featured as number 252 in the exhibition catalogue.
sgcool_label_text: This vase is painted with birds, bamboo and flowering plants in varying washes of cobalt blue. It belongs to a type of Chinese ceramics described as ‘Transitional porcelain’, which was produced at the Jingdezhen kilns in the period of transition spanning the late Ming to early Qing dynasties. More specifically, this period stretched from the death of the Ming emperor Wanli in 1620 until the reorganisation of the imperial kilns in 1683. ‘Transitional’ porcelains often featured more naturalistic depictions of flora and fauna, as well as narrative scenes drawn on fine-quality white body.

sgcool_label_text: This cup is decorated with plum blossoms on a blue, cracked ice pattern (???) ground. The cracked-ice pattern gained popularity as a decorative motif in seventeenth-century China and was appreciated for its beautiful asymmetry. On porcelain vessels, the pattern is often coupled with the plum blossom, which was regarded as a symbol of strength and endurance since the flower blooms in late winter or early spring.

Though painted with simple clean strokes with a fine brush, its features such as the bushy tail and hooves are distinctively visible.  The cobalt blue ink wash however, spills out of the figure's outlines. The potting is thin; testament to its refined quality. Encrustation can be found at the base of 001.
subject_terms_1: legendary beings  qilin porcelain paintings (visual works)  freehand drawings (drawings)  symbolism
subject_terms_2: Mythical beasts Porcelain, Chinese Ming- Qing dynasties, 1368-1912 Blue and white ware China China painting  Qilin
sgcool_label_text: This delicately-potted pair of teacups are painted with mythical creatures that appear to be the qilin. The imaginary beast, which was thought to possess the physical attributes of various animals, was highly popular in Chinese art and culture. Although the qilin on this pair of teacups are rather sketchily painted, some of these features can still be discerned, such as the hooves and bushy tail. The qilin was very auspicious as it is believed to embody attributes such as benevolence, longevity and the bearing of illustrious offspring.

physical_appearance: This is a polychrome jar with an elaborately decorated exterior. A swirl pattern lines the neck of the jar, while its body is filled with flowering blossoms of red and blue that surround the figure of a lion.  The underglazed blue appeared to have smeared and is therefore less defined than the overglazed green and blue.
subject_terms_1: enamels (visual works)  porcelain paintings (visual works)  freehand drawings (drawings)  symbolism
subject_terms_2: Floral decorations  Polychrome Lion Mythology  China painting
sgcool_label_text: The jar is decorated with lions and floral scrolls in the wucai style, which sees elements of the design painted in underglaze blue and combined with patterns executed in overglaze polychrome enamels. Although the term wucai literally means ‘five colours’, it actually denotes the use of a multitude of colours and does not always necessarily mean five. Wucai porcelain emerged during the sixteenth century and grew in popularity from the Jiajing period (1522–1566).

subject_terms_2: Monochrome art  Porcelain, Chinese Ming- Qing dynasties, 1368-1912 Brush stands
sgcool_label_text: This blue-glazed porcelain elephant was probably an item made for the scholar’s desk. Apart from serving as a holder to rest a scholar’s brush or inkstick, this elephant is also a delightful example of a “scholar’s plaything”. The potter has imbued the elephant with life by modelling the animal’s trunk in an upturned and trumpet-like manner. The outline of the animal also takes the form of a double-gourd. The gourd was a popular motif in Chinese art as it was associated with longevity as well as protective and magical properties.

physical_appearance: This is a blue white covered box. In the central medallion of the top surface is a large chrysanthemum. Bordering its sides are panels of plant motifs alternating with geometric patterns. The latter is repeated on the bottom as well. It is to note that the colour is faded and appears porous.
subject_terms_1: cultural diffusion geometric shape  porcelain paintings (visual works)  exports freehand drawings (drawings)  symbolism  flower (motif)
subject_terms_2: Porcelain, Chinese Ming- Qing dynasties, 1368-1912 Blue and white ware China China painting  Floral decorations  Geometry in art Porcelain, Vietnamese
sgcool_label_text: The top surface of this box is decorated with a chrysanthemum spray while the sides are painted with panels of stylised plants alternating with geometric patterns. This panelled style of decoration is widely seen on Vietnamese ceramic boxes produced in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. The development of Vietnamese blue and white ceramics was spurred by the Chinese occupation of north Vietnam from 1407 to 1428 and the decline of Chinese porcelain exports during the fifteenth century.  Vietnamese potters were quick to capitalise on the gap and became prolific producers of blue and white wares, which they exported to overseas consumers in Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines.

sgcool_label_text: This globular jarlet features three bands of decoration executed in underglaze cobalt blue around its body, with stylised lotus scrolls occupying the middle register. The development of Vietnamese blue and white ceramics was spurred by the Chinese occupation of north Vietnam from 1407 to 1428 and the decline of Chinese porcelain exports during the fifteenth century.  Vietnamese potters were quick to capitalise on the gap and became prolific producers of blue and white wares, which they exported to overseas consumers in Indonesia, Malaysia and the Phillipines. Small ceramic jars or jarlets were a popular commodity among the local communities and were probably used to contain medicines, oils and even magic potions.

title_text: The Supreme Goddess as a pouring vessel symbol
physical_appearance: This is a pair of tear-shaped vessel. Both have a bulbous bottom, but while 001 tapers to a tip, 002 tapers to a spout. The hammered indentation at the centre of both however, are both hollow. Oxidisation appears to have occurred on 002.
subject_terms_1: religious objects  Hinduism religious symbolism
subject_terms_2: Hindu bronzes  Religious articles  Hinduism Hindu gods
subject_terms_3: Religious life and practices  visual arts
sgcool_label_text:
This object is a ceremonial vessel possibly used for holy water.  It is tear-shaped with a small, hammered indentation at the centre. It is thought to be a symbol of the Great Goddess, the yoni (or vulva), and the indentation is thought to indicate the male counterpart, the god Shiva in the form of a linga (phallus). 

The goddess is the energy of the god, or his shakti. Her presence galvanises him into action. Therefore the combination of the male and female principal brings all things into being.

sgcool_label_text: This Malay-English dictionary written in pencil in old exercise book is an artefact that represents how P.O.Ws adapted to their language environment and gives an insight into everyday life for a P.O.W at Changi. This artefact is part of the archive of James Steele, Royal Artillery (Field) who served in Malaya from January 1941-February 1942, when interned as a P.O.W at Changi until his release in October 1945.

physical_appearance: This is a drawn pencil diagram. It is drawn on two pieces of paper that were originally blank naval message forms. The second page is split into two vertical sections, each showing a different burial ground in a different camp.
subject_terms_1: world wars prisoners of war documents (object genre) handwriting burial sites site plans
subject_terms_2: World War, 1939-1945 Prisoners of war Writing Cemetries
context_7: Great Britain. Army. Royal Field Artillery
sgcool_label_text: Once the Malaya Command Battle Headquarters, the fall of Singapore in 1942 saw the Sime Road Camp being converted into temporary quarters for POWs working within the vicinity, as well as a staging post for prisoners who were sent up-country to work on the infamous ‘death railway’, the Thailand-Burma railway. Life at the Sime Road Camp was deplorable - characterised by hunger, disease and death. This artefact which speaks to life at Sime Road camp is part of the archive of James Steele, Royal Artillery (Field) who served in Malaya from January 1941-February 1942, when interned as a P.O.W at Changi until his release in October 1945.

title_text: A bound journal with bible cover and information on the Malayan Campaign from Lt. Gen. Sir Lewis Heath
physical_appearance: This is a bound journal. It has a bible cover. The cover is brown and worn out, especially along the spines. There are quite a number of scratches on the cover. In the center of the cover, the words 'HOLY BIBLE' is inscribed with a slight indent.
subject_terms_1: world wars documents (object genre) letters (correspondence)
subject_terms_2: World War, 1939-1945 Letters
subject_terms_3: 1942-1945 Japanese occupation Letters Surrender of Singapore, 1942 Malayan Campaign, British Malaya, 1941-1942 war personalities
context_7: Great Britain. Army. Royal Field Artillery
sgcool_label_text: The journal includes various paper scraps containing information related to the “Selarang incident”, namely Selarang Special Orders issued by the Colonel and Commander of British and Australian troops which direct troops to sign the Japanese order promising that they will not try to escape. Most interesting of these orders is the assurance that pensions will be ensured upon the P.O.Ws’ release. The journal also includes a message from Major General Beckwith-smith on the unconditional surrender of Singapore as well as Lt. Gen. Sir Lewis Heath’s account of the Malayan campaign. This artefact is part of the archive of James Steele, Royal Artillery (Field) who served in Malaya from January 1941-February 1942, when interned as a P.O.W at Changi until his release in October 1945.

title_text: A pen and coloured ink Christmas card for 1944, depicting a Changi inmate at a camp fire
physical_appearance: This is a christmas card. It is drawn on a gray pain paper in multicolored ink. The flap at the top features drawn mistletoe and written greetings. The picture at the bottom is ofa man, dressed in shorts, cooking over a fire. There is a small fold at the top right of the card. There are no tears seen.

context_7: Great Britain. Army. Royal Field Artillery
sgcool_label_text: This pen and coloured ink Christmas card is from 1944. It depicts a Changi inmate at a camp fire. The card illustrates P.O.Ws’ efforts in maintaining their spirits and traditions in spite of the conditions they lived in. This artefact is part of the archive of James Steele, Royal Artillery (Field) who served in Malaya from January 1941-February 1942, when interned as a P.O.W at Changi until his release in October 1945.

title_text: \King George's \"\"warm welcome home\"\" circular letter sent to returnees from Japan.\""

There is date at the bottom-left of the letter. There is a signature in black ink on the bottom-right of the letter. The letter has a small fold on the lower-left corner. There are no tears seen.
subject_terms_1: world wars prisoners of war
subject_terms_2: World War, 1939-1945 Prisoners of war Letters George VI, King of Great Britain, 1895-1952
context_7: Great Britain. Army. Royal Field Artillery
sgcool_label_text: A letter issued to ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese, in which George VI welcomes them home, expressing sympathy for their “heavy… suffering” at the hands of the Japanese and wishes them and their families “a full measure of happiness”. This artefact is part of the archive of James Steele, Royal Artillery (Field) who served in Malaya from January 1941-February 1942, when interned as a P.O.W at Changi until his release in October 1945.

title_text: 122 Field Regiment Royal Artillery’s involvement in the Malayan Campaign Drawing memorializing 122 Field Regiment Royal Artillery’s involvement in the Malayan Campaign
physical_appearance: The drawing is made on a piece of paper that has been torn on its bottom right side and the upper left corner. The drawing depicts the military insignia of the 122 Field Regiment Royal Artillery. It also includes the names of places where the Regiment fought at during the Malayan Campaign in World War II. The paper does not look creased. The location where the drawing is created is also stated at the bottom centre.
subject_terms_1: world wars prisoners of war prisoner-of-war camps commemoratives
subject_terms_2: World War, 1939 - 1945 Great Britain. Army Prisoner of war Prisoner-of-war camps Drawing Changi POW Camp (Changi, Singapore)
sgcool_label_text: \A drawing that memorializes the involvement of the 122 Field Regiment Royal Artillery in the Malayan Campaign
column51: this diagram includes all the areas in which they fought during the campaign and their motto” Quo Fas Et Gloria Ducunt” (\"\"Where Right And Glory Lead\"\"; in Latin fas implies \"\"sacred duty\"\"). This is a particularly important historical document. Effectively"

title_text: Drawing memorializing places by P.O.W
physical_appearance: This is a graphic drawing. It is a graphic work listing the names of places in capital letters in black, in various sizes and alignments. Each place name has two faint margin lines at the top and bottom of the word.There are no tears or folds seen on the drawing.

sgcool_label_text: A graphic drawing listing names of places such as Kuala Lumpur, Luang, Sembawang, Sungi best, Malaya etc by P.O.W R H Bailey of the Royal Air Force. This artefact is part of the archive of James Steele, Royal Artillery (Field) who served in Malaya from January 1941-February 1942, when interned as a P.O.W at Changi until his release in October 1945.

The sheet of paper has several tears and holes in it, especially along the left, and top sides.

title_text: Orchids under Bamboo Shade
physical_appearance: This is a chinese ink painting of bamboos and orchids. The strokes are clean and measured, and comprise of both wet and dry brush strokes. Cutting across the paper in a zig-zag fashion, the leaves provide a visual rhythm that works in harmony with the void. An inscription has been written on the top left in a semi-cursive script. Two seals can be found at the end of the last two lines of the inscription, as well as the bottom  right corner.
subject_terms_1: Orchidaceae (family)
subject_terms_2: Bamboo in art
sgcool_label_text: \As one of the most influential pioneer artists in local art scene
column51: Fan Chang Tien(1907-1987) was significant in shaping the direction for the modern development of ink painting in Singapore. During the 1920s
column52: Fan studied in Shanghai Xin Hua Art Academy and then Shanghai Changming Academy of Art. He was taught by renowned Shanghai school artists such as Wang Geyi
column53: Wang Yiting
column54: Zhu Wenyun and Pan Tianshou. Fan arrived in Singapore in 1956 and began teaching art in Chung Cheng High School and Whampoa Secondary School respectively. Over decades
column55: the artist nurtured a group of ink painters
column56: and some of them become the leading figures of modern ink innovation in Singapore such Chua Ek Kay
column57: Tan Oe Pang and Chen Kezhan.

accession_no_csv: Fan is specialised in the\"\" xieyi\"\" style (an expressive and sketchy style of Chinese ink painting) Chinese painting and competent both in the traditional genres of mountain-and-water and flower-and-bird."

title_text: Yong Bamboo and Rock  ????
physical_appearance: \This chinese ink painting of a bamboo and a rock has been executed in a one-colour (yi se biao) style. While the leaves of the bamboo were painted with a wet brush
subject_terms_1: its stalk and the rock were done with both wet and dry brushes.  In particular
subject_terms_2: the outline of the rock was drawn in a \"\"flying white\"\" technique where pressure has been applied such that the hairs of the brush separate to reveal streaks of white spaces in the stroke itself. Strokes are then added to produce a less defined effect by utilizing a \"\"bands dragged in mud\"\" technique. \""
subject_terms_3: bamboo (plant)  Wen ren  inscriptions rock (inorganic material)  running script
subject_terms_4: Bamboo in art Inscriptions, Chinese  Ink painting, Chinese rocks  Chinese language Writing Xing style
column52: \As one of the most influential pioneer artists in local art scene
column53: Fan Chang Tien(1907-1987) was significant in shaping the direction for the modern development of ink painting in Singapore. During the 1920s
column54: Fan studied in Shanghai Xin Hua Art Academy and then Shanghai Changming Academy of Art. He was taught by renowned Shanghai school artists such as Wang Geyi
column55: Wang Yiting
column56: Zhu Wenyun and Pan Tianshou. Fan arrived in Singapore in 1956 and began teaching art in Chung Cheng High School and Whampoa Secondary School respectively. Over decades
column57: the artist nurtured a group of ink painters
column58: and some of them become the leading figures of modern ink innovation in Singapore such Chua Ek Kay
column59: Tan Oe Pang and Chen Kezhan.

accession_no_csv: Fan is specialised in the \"\"xiey\"\"i style (an expressive and sketchy style of Chinese ink painting) Chinese painting.  This is one of his best works representing the subjects of bamboo and rock. The compositional emphasis on the rock in front and the seasoned brushstrokes convey the strong spirit of a literati mind.   \""

title_text: Swallows Passing by the Willows  ????
physical_appearance: This is a chinese ink and colour on paper work depicting a flight of swallows flying past a willow tree. Executed in a mixture of dry and wet brush of varying ink hues, the scene is dynamic and alive with movement.
subject_terms_1: running script  Aves (class)  Salix (genus) inscriptions

title_text: Lanna Buddha Head
physical_appearance: This is a bronze Buddha head. He is depicted with highly arched brows that meet at the bridge of his nose, downcast eyes, a tall nose, relatively thin lips that curve slightly upwards at its edges, a defined chin, and long ear lobes. He also sports an ushnisha, snail-shell coils as hair, and has three lines on his neck; lakshanas that define him as a mahapurusha (Great Being). He is missing his top finial.
subject_terms_1: buddhas (people) attributes (symbols)  nirvana  religious art religious visual works religious symbolism
subject_terms_2: Buddha Nirvana  Introspection Religious art
sgcool_label_text:
This Buddha, when it was complete, would have looked down serenely upon those who worshipped it. It was produced in Lan Na (northern Thailand), a major bronze-casting centre. Its prominent cranial bump (ushnisha) was originally topped by a flame finial (now missing) similar to those on the two Sukhothai Buddha images on display in this gallery. 

As with Sukhothai, Lan Na was heavily influenced by Sri Lankan Buddhism. Styles flowed between the various kingdoms, and Buddha images from Lan Na and Sukhothai share many similarities. Influence also moved by less peaceful means: in the 15th century, Sawankhalok captured by Tiloka, the Lan Na king, who then repulsed a number of attempts by Sukhothai to regain the city.

title_text: A Scroll Painting Of A Muharram Procession
physical_appearance: This is a scroll painting depicting the Muharram procession. Unfolding in a horizontal fashion, the figures are depicted in orderly rows.  They don various garb in a plethora of colours, and the scene is set against a plain background.

context_13: Rows of opposing and interlocking triangles, known as tumpal or pucuk rebung, occupy the broad vertical panel (kepala) of this sarong.  Together with the two panels flanking the kepala, known as papan, they divide the main design field (badan) into two equal parts.  A profusion of lotus flowers, tendrils and stylised birds and animals is harmoniously executed on this piece.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942), the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her batiks feature the classic layout typical of her time, and are embellished with Chinese traditional motifs.  These motifs include lotus flowers, centipedes and cloud motifs, which are rendered sensitively and imaginatively.  The combination of natural red and blue dyes on a cream ground is also characteristic of batiks made during this period in the north coast of Java, before the invention and widespread popularity of chemical dyes in batik sarongs by the late 19th century.  Oey Soen King’s pieces were all unsigned as signatures were not yet fashionable.

title_text: Kain panjang
physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. On the left, there is a vertical panel featuring rows of opposing triangles with stylised birds and rosettes. The main design of the batik features birds perched on flowering trees and butterflies. The batik designs are set against a cream background. There are no signatures on this batik kain panjang.

sgcool_label_text: The main design or “body” (badan) of this kain panjang is replete with swirling tendrils, birds perched on flowering trees and butterflies set against a plain, cream background.  On the kepala (vertical panel at the end of the batik), rows of opposing triangles, enlivened with birds and tiny star-shaped rosettes occupy the broad vertical panel (kepala) of this piece.  Natural dyes were used to create this palette of cream, maroon, indigo blue and black colours.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942), the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her batiks feature the classic layout typical of her time, and are embellished with Chinese traditional motifs.  These motifs include lotus flowers, centipedes and cloud motifs, which are rendered sensitively and imaginatively.  The combination of natural red and blue dyes on a cream ground is also characteristic of batiks made during this period in the north coast of Java, before the invention and widespread popularity of chemical dyes in batik sarongs by the late 19th century.  Oey Soen King’s pieces were all unsigned as signatures were not yet fashionable.

title_text: Sarong

sgcool_label_text: The main design field (on the body or badan) of this batik is replete with swirling tendrils, floral blooms and birds.  The exuberance of this design is enhanced by tiny, creamy filler motifs, known as tanahan, which echo the main design thereby creating visual harmony.  The broad vertical panel (kepala) of this sarong comprises two large floral bouquets or the buketan design, and minutely decorated diagonal bands of motifs.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942), the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her batiks feature the classic layout typical of her time, and are embellished with Chinese traditional motifs. This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942), the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan. title_text: Kain panjang
physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It features both Chinese and Javanese motifs. The panel on the right consists of a verticle square diamonds in between rows of triangles. The right panel  is densely decorated with floral and bird motifs. The left side of the kain panjang consists of zigzag bands, containing motifs such as qilins, phoenixes and swastikas. There are no signatures seen on the batik kain panjang.

sgcool_label_text: This exquisite batik combines design elements of both Chinese and Javanese inspiration.  Auspicious Chinese motifs such as mythical qilins, phoenixes and banji (or swastika) are enclosed within the zigzag bands on the main design field of this batik (or badan).  Javanese elements are also present, such as the ancient kawung and parang motifs, both of which were initially reserved for the exclusive use by the Central Javanese courts.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942), the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her batiks feature the classic layout typical of her time, and are embellished with Chinese traditional motifs.  These motifs include lotus flowers, centipedes and cloud motifs, which are rendered sensitively and imaginatively.  The combination of natural red and blue dyes on a cream ground is also characteristic of batiks made during this period in the north coast of Java, before the invention and widespread popularity of chemical dyes in batik sarongs by the late 19th century.  Oey Soen King’s pieces were all unsigned as signatures were not yet fashionable.

sgcool_label_text: A row of elongated triangles (or tumpals) decorated with tiny rosettes occupy the broad vertical panel (kepala) of this sarong.  The tumpal motif was probably inspired by the Indian patola cloths that were traded widely in Southeast Asia by the 13th century.  The rest of the sarong is set against a cream ground and embellished with finely drawn motifs of birds, insects and floral tendrils.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942), the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her batiks feature the classic layout typical of her time, and are embellished with Chinese traditional motifs.  These motifs include lotus flowers, centipedes and cloud motifs, which are rendered sensitively and imaginatively.  The combination of natural red and blue dyes on a cream ground is also characteristic of batiks made during this period in the north coast of Java, before the invention and widespread popularity of chemical dyes in batik sarongs by the late 19th century. sgcool_label_text: The batik cloth is carefully cut and joined in the middle to produce the symmetry of pattern on this pair of batik pants (celanda).  The Chinese influence is evident on this piece, particularly the mythical qilin and phoenix motifs, and fretwork border which is a variant of the auspicious Chinese banji pattern.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942), the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her batiks feature the classic layout typical of her time, and are embellished with Chinese traditional motifs.  These motifs include lotus flowers, centipedes and cloud motifs which are rendered sensitively and imaginatively.  The combination of natural red and blue dyes on a cream ground is also characteristic of batiks made during this period in the north coast of Java, before the invention and widespread popularity of chemical dyes in batik sarongs by the late 19th century.  Oey Soen King’s pieces were all unsigned as signatures were not yet fashionable.

The artist, Oey Soen King also used filler motifs on the birds’ plummage leaf veins and flower petals, creating depth to the overall design.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942), the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her batiks feature the classic layout typical of her time, and are embellished with Chinese traditional motifs. sgcool_label_text: The design structure of this kain panjang is typical of north coast batik from the same period, in particular the split kepalas (or elongated triangles) on both ends of the batik.  Bouquets of flowers embellish the main design field (badan) of the cloth, creating a wallpaper effect.  They are reminiscent of the “wallpaper” patterns that are stamped on wallpaper with the wooden blocks.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942), the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her batiks feature the classic layout typical of her time, and are embellished with Chinese traditional motifs.  These motifs include lotus flowers, centipedes and cloud motifs, which are rendered sensitively and imaginatively.  The combination of natural red and blue dyes on a cream ground is also characteristic of batiks made during this period in the north coast of Java, before the invention and widespread popularity of chemical dyes in batik sarongs by the late 19th century.  Oey Soen King’s pieces were all unsigned as signatures were not yet fashionable.

Javanese elements, such as the sawat motif, are attached to plant forms on this piece.   The sawat design, consisting of a pair of garuda wings and tail feathers, was exclusively reserved for the Javanese courts.  A row of opposing triangles known as tumpal, appear on the vertical band (kepala) on one end of this piece.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942), the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan. title_text: Sarong
physical_appearance: This is a batik sarong. The middle of the sarong features a maroon panel, with large bouquets of flowers and butterflies. The panels are segmented by borders of floral bouquet motifs. The other panels have lime green with white dots as a background. There is a signature on the top left of the batik sarong.
subject_terms_1: Peranakan folk costume flower (motif) foliage (motif)
subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs
sgcool_label_text: Butterflies flutter amidst the large bouquet of flowers on the maroon, broad vertical panel (kepala) of this sarong.  The fluid expression of the buketan (or ‘bouquet’) motif is echoed in the borders that separate the kepala from the lime green “body” (badan) of the sarong.  The lime green background is filled with white dots known as tanahan motifs.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966), the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her later batik designs attest to her virtuosity in technique and inventive colour palette.  Her repertoire of tiny isen-isen motifs (filler motifs within the outlines of the key motifs) in particular, exudes a strong sense of artistic individuality, possibly informed by modernist designs on European printed cloths.  Her treatment of floral bouquets is also charactertistic of the undulating and curving lines of the Art Noveau style that was introduced in the northern coast of Java by the Europeans.  This piece is signed “Nj Oey Kok Sing”.

title_text: Kain panjang
physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. The left of the kain panjang features a panel with a lighter background, bordered by repeated florals on scrolling tendrils. The main body of the kain panjang has green with starburst rosettes. The floral bouquet motif is repeated across the kain panjang, with birds and butterflies flying over them. There is a signature on the top left of the kain panjang.
subject_terms_1: Peranakan flower (motif) birds (motifs)
subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs
sgcool_label_text: The buketan (or ‘bouquet’) motif is repeated on the main design field (badan) and broad vertical panel (kepala) of this batik.  A variety of intricate motifs are used to fill in the main buketan motif and background, creating a lively and harmonious design.  Starburst rosettes enhance the buketan on the badan.  On the kepala, swirling tendrils echo the elegant twists in the floral branches.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966), the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her later batik designs attest to her virtuosity in technique and inventive colour palette.  Her repertoire of tiny isen-isen motifs (filler motifs within the outlines of the key motifs) in particular, exudes a strong sense of artistic individuality, possibly informed by modernist designs on European printed cloths.  Her treatment of floral bouquets is also charactertistic of the undulating and curving lines of the Art Noveau style that was introduced in the northern coast of Java by the Europeans.  This piece is signed “Nj Oey Kok Sing”.

title_text: Kain panjang
physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It features a broad vertical panel on the left, with a darker green background filled with fern-like leaves and a flower petal. The main body of the kain panjang has a lighter green background filled with vegetation patterns. Repeated floral bouquets with flying birds. There is a signature on the bottom left of the kain panjang.
subject_terms_1: Peranakan flower (motif) birds (motifs) foliage (motif)
subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs
sgcool_label_text: The batik is the work of a strong hand, exhibiting both technical mastery and artistic flair.  Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966) elevates the buketan design (large bouquets of European flowers) with her sensitive treatment of filler motifs.  On the dark green kepala (broad vertical panel of the batik), each filler motif combines a fern-like design with a minutely detailed flower petal.  The light green ground of the badan (main design field of the batik) in contrast, is filled with dense vegetation.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing, the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her later batik designs attest to her virtuosity in technique and inventive colour palette.  Her repertoire of tiny isen-isen motifs (filler motifs within the outlines of the key motifs) in particular, exudes a strong sense of artistic individuality, possibly informed by modernist designs on European printed cloths.  Her treatment of floral bouquets is also charactertistic of the undulating and curving lines of the Art Noveau style that was introduced in the northern coast of Java by the Europeans.  This piece is signed “Nj Oey Kok Sing”.

title_text: Sarong
physical_appearance: This is a batik sarong. It features alternating bands of motifs. The center panel is composed of diagonal bands of dark red, blue and green backgrounds. The backgrounds are filled with small, dense secondary motifs of foliage patterns. The main pattern decorating the batik features large floral blooms. There is a signature on the top-left of the batik sarong.
subject_terms_1: Peranakan folk costume flower (motif) foliage (motif) cultural diffusion

sgcool_label_text: Alternating bands of motifs decorate this sarong in its entirety.  Diagonal bands are shown on the kepala (broad vertical panel of the batik), and are filled with two alternating floral designs that are also arranged diagonally.  In contrast, vertical bands are depicted on the badan (main design feature or ‘body’ of the batik).  Alternating swirling tendrils and starburst motifs form the background for pairs of phoenixes and floral motifs.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966), the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her later batik designs attest to her virtuosity in technique and inventive colour palette. This piece is signed “Njonjah Oey Kok Sing”.

sgcool_label_text: The buketan design, comprising large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies and birds, is shown on this sarong.  On the kepala (broad vertical panel) of this batik, diagonal bands of floral motifs set against fern-like fillers.  The buketan is repeated on the badan (main design feature of the batik or ‘body’).  Curving, fluid floral branches are juxtaposed to the geometric design, an ancient Javanese ceplok motif in the background.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966), the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan. This piece is stamped “Oeij Kok Sing 18 April 1955”.

title_text: Kain panjang
physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It is blue, with lighter blue and white designs. The kain panjang features large bouquets interspersed with birds and butterflies. On the left side of the batik, the bouquet motifs are set against a dense patterned background, with repeated floral blooms. The right side of the batik features a more sparse design, with the bouquets set against a plain blue background.
subject_terms_1: Peranakan flower (motif) birds (motifs) cultural diffusion
subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs Culture diffusion
sgcool_label_text: This batik is structured in the pagi-sore format, comprising two different but related designs on each half of the kain panjang.  One side comprises large bouquets of carnations interspersed with butterflies and birds.  This buketan design is also applied to the other side although the large rose bouquets are surrounded by densely packed background patterns.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966), the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her later batik designs attest to her virtuosity in technique and inventive colour palette.  Her repertoire of tiny isen-isen motifs (filler motifs within the outlines of the key motifs) in particular, exudes a strong sense of artistic individuality, possibly informed by modernist designs on European printed cloths.  Her treatment of floral bouquets is also charactertistic of the undulating and curving lines of the Art Noveau style that was introduced in the northern coast of Java by the Europeans.

title_text: Kain panjang
physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It features a repeated motif pattern of a large bouquet of flowers on both the main design of the batik and the broad vertical panel. The floral blooms and tendrils on the panel on the right are set against a brown background. On the main body, the motif is set against diagonal rows of parang design. There is a signature on the bottom right of the batik.
subject_terms_1: Peranakan flower (motif) geometric motif cultural diffusion
subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs Culture diffusion
sgcool_label_text: The buketan motif or a large bouquet of flowers is depicted on both the main design field (on the body or badan) and broad vertical panel (kepala) of this batik.  The curving tendrils and exuberant blooms are set against a plain traditional soga brown ground in the kepala.  While the buketan is set against diagonal rows of the parang design, an ancient Javanese motif that was traditionally associated with the Javanese royalty.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Liem Giok Hwa Kedungwuni”.

She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This kain panjang is signed “Batik Kesenian Liem Siok Hien Kudus”.  Kudus was added to indicate that her design was executed in the Kudus style although she lived and worked in Pekalongan.

title_text: Sarong
physical_appearance: This is a batik sarong. It features a repeated motif of large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies and birds. subject_terms_1: Peranakan folk costume foliage (motif) cultural diffusion

sgcool_label_text: The buketan design, comprising large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies and birds, is repeated on this sarong.  Bouquets of calla lily are shown on both the brown kepala (broad vertical panel of the sarong) and badan (‘body’ or main design feature).  The artist, Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987) used a variety of intricate filler motifs (isen-isen) on the calla lily petals, giving depth to the overall design.  Interesting background motifs, such as the tiny castles on the cream badan are also depicted.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio, the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan. sgcool_label_text: Rows of opposing and interlocking triangles, known as tumpal occupy the broad vertical panel (kepala) of this sarong.  On the main design field or badan of this sarong, flowers interspersed with bats (symbolising good fortune for the Chinese) and birds are repeated.  Although the buketan motif (large bouquets flowers) is a common design theme for batiks, this sarong additionally features exotic rock formations and bird varieties.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan. physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang.  It features red circular cloud motifs, interspersed with birds and plant forms. The bottom of the batik is lined with the design of a rocky landscape, above a pink wavy border.

sgcool_label_text: This kain panjang features motifs commonly seen on Cirebon batik designs.  Set against a black background, the Cirebon cloud motif (megamendung), is depicted in trios with attached plant forms, and as a rocky landscape surrounded by birds.  A flame-like motif is also shown above the rock formations, and on the pink wavy border near the bottom of the cloth.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s © Batik Art “Unique” Pekalongan Java Indonesia”.

title_text: Kain panjang
physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. The main body of the kain panjang features zigzag bands of mythical animals and birds. Filler motifs are also used to decorate each band and segment, creating an intricate and dense design. On the left, there is a vertical panel featuring opposing triangles. In the center of the rows of triangles, there is a vertical row of upright diamonds. The triangles and diamonds are filled with similar mythical stylised animals. There is a signature at the top-left of the batik kain panjang.
subject_terms_1: Peranakan foliage (motif) birds (motifs) legendary beings
subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs
sgcool_label_text: The main design feature or ‘body’ (badan) of this kain panjang is decorated with zigzag bands of mythical and fantastical animals and birds.  A variety of filler motifs are used in each decorative band.  On the broad vertical panel (kepala) of this cloth, interlocking triangles (or tumpal) sandwich a row of upright diamonds.  Like the zigzag bands, they are filled with curious animals and plant forms.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan. title_text: Hanging
physical_appearance: This is a batik hanging. It features a phoenix with an exuberant feather plumage, perched on a flowering branch. Its feathers extend upwards across the height of the hanging. sgcool_label_text: On the centre of this kain panjang, a phoenix with exuberant plumage is perched on a knobbly branch.  A variant of the parang design, an ancient motif that was reserved for the exclusive use by the Central Javanese courts, frames this central design.  At the four corners of this batik, a pair of wings resembling the sawat motif, possibly symbolising the mythical garuda, is depicted.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece contains the initials ‘JH’ which stands for Jane Hendromartono.

title_text: Kain panjang
physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang.  It features pairs of phoenixes with outstretched wings, set against a background of flowering tendrils and rock forms. The background is further embellished with filler motifs to create an intricate and dense design. There is a signature on the bottom-right of the batik kain panjang.
subject_terms_1: Peranakan phoenixes foliage (motif) scrolls (motif)
subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs
sgcool_label_text: Pairs of phonexies with outstretched wings are set against a blue background of flowering tendrils and rock forms.  Intricate filler motifs known as isen-isen enliven the overall design.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s Batik Art” Unique Pekalongan 100% Tulis”.

title_text: Kain panjang
physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It features garuda wings and tail feathers amidst spiralling cloud formations  and flowering tendrils. The motifs are set against a purple background, decorated with starburst speckles to create a dense design. There is a signature on the bottom-left of the batik kain panjang.
subject_terms_1: Peranakan birds (motifs) foliage (motif)
subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs
sgcool_label_text: Spiralling cloud formations, an ancient megamendung motif, are shown amidst flowering tendrils. Interspersed among them are the double wings and tail feathers of the garuda, yet another ancient motif known as sawat.  Both of these motifs were commonly associated with the Cirebon and Javanese courts respectively.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s Batik Art” Unique Pekalongan Ind”.

title_text: Altar cloth
physical_appearance: This is a batik altar cloth. It consists of two panels. The lower panel features a pair of phoenixes and three mythical qilins amidst cloud forms. Surrounding them are emblems such as a scroll and a vase. The top panel features eight figures amongst cloud forms. The panels are bordered by a floral scrolling pattern. There is a signature on the bottom-right of the altar cloth.
subject_terms_1: Peranakan phoenixes legendary beings symbolism depictions (visual works) Taoism flower (motif)
subject_terms_2: Altar-cloths Batik Peranakan (Asian people) Symbolism Taoism Motifs
sgcool_label_text: A pair of phoenixes and three mythical qilins are shown on the lower panel of this tok wi or altar cloth.  On the upper panel are eight figures, possibly depicting semi-divine Daoist Eight Immortals.  Surrouding the qilins and phoenixes on the lower panel are emblems of the Eight Immortals, symbolising happiness and transmutation.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Jane Hendromartono ‘77”.

title_text: Altar cloth
physical_appearance: This is a batik altar cloth. It consists of two panels. The lower panel features a Chinese character painted in the middle as a medallion, bordered by foliage designs. It is accompanied by a pair of birds perched on a tree on the right, and a pair of fishes swimming amongst plants on the left. The upper panel features four Chinese characters in scallop medallions. There is a signature on the bottom-left of the batik altar cloth.
subject_terms_1: Peranakan symbolism depictions (visual works) foliage (motif) ceremonial objects
subject_terms_2: Altar-cloths Batik Peranakan (Asian people) Symbolism Motifs
sgcool_label_text: The Chinese character denoting ‘double happiness’ is shown on the lower panel of this tok wi or altar cloth.  It is flanked by a pair of birds on the one side, and a pair of fishes on the other.  On the upper panel are four Chinese characters denoting wishes of loyalty and faith.  This altar cloth was probably used as part of a wedding ceremony given the pictorial symbolism of martial bliss and harmony.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Jane Hendromartono Pekalongan Java”.

object_work_type: silks (costume by material)  folk costume  womenswear
title_text: Informal robe and skirt in kesi fabric
physical_appearance: This is a set of informal robe and skirt. The robe is purple, and buttons on the right; as per Chinese tradition of ???? (men on the left, women on the right). The skirt is of an A-line cut, and  has blue floral designs woven along the hems and the central flap of fabric. Both are decorated with intricate designs of animals, flowers, plants, and human figures.
subject_terms_1: prestige scholars gift giving  Song (Chinese culture, style, and period)  flower (motif)
subject_terms_2: China History Qing dynasty, 1644-1912 China History Song Dynasty, 960-1279  Prestige  Floral decorations  Diplomatic gifts  Ethnic costume
sgcool_label_text:
Informal robes and skirts like this were intended for everyday use. They were typically worn by the wives of officials and merchants in China during the Qing dynasty. Made of silk, they are decorated with intricate designs of animals, flowers, plants, and human figures. 
The woven silk fabric used to make these outfits is called kesi. Kesi tapestry was one of the main Song dynasty achievements and the extremely fine silk tapestry came to symbolise cultural prestige. This is evident through the use of kesi tapestries as diplomatic gifts by rulers and its idealisation among Chinese scholar-officials. It remains a living art form today in China and the Himalayan region.

title_text: British military uniform components: coat, pants, sash, hat
physical_appearance: This is the British Army uniform that consists of a coat, pants, sash, and hat. The coat has gold accents; the cuffs and collar are embroidered with gold bullion in oak leaf motif, whilst brass buttons have been sewn on.  On the other hand, the trousers are black with a gold braid stripe running down the side of each leg.  The gold braid can also be found on the hat which has an accompanying elastic sweatband. Also in a matching colour tone is the red and gold sash with tussles.
subject_terms_1: insignia (devices)  coats (garments) trousers sashes (costume accessories)  hats rank
subject_terms_2: Great Britain. Army Great Britain Colonies Coats Pants Felt hats  Insignia  South African War, 1899-1902 military uniforms
sgcool_label_text:
The British Army uniform, sometimes referred to as “redcoat”, has grown to become a symbol of the British Empire. Versions were widely worn within the colonies of the British Empire, by the British, Indians, and other Imperial soldiers. Today it is used as a ceremonial dress for the armies of many countries previously under British rule.
This particular uniform may have belonged to General A. W. Thorneycroft, known for his contributions to the Battle of Spion Kop during the Second Boer War.

title_text: Chinese and foreign merchants in Canton
creator_2: NA Paqua  *As mentioned in the stylistic significance field, this work has been attributed to Paqua.
physical_appearance: There are seven men depicted in this scene. On the left amidst the crowd of four, is a man in a tailcoat and top hat. He holds in his right hand a parchment, and a cane on his left. To his left is a moustached man in official robes. Standing to the back of these two men is a man in a colourful turban and Arabic shoes. The men in mandarin garb have long hair queues; in particular, one man in crimson has his neck chained and is being forcefully being taken away by a man in blue.
subject_terms_1: officials  arrests (legal events) cultural pluralism
subject_terms_2: Parsees Arrest China trade painting
sgcool_label_text: A Parsi merchant, with his colourful turban, European man in a tophat, and Chinese men with long hair queues participate in some as yet unknown activity. The Parsi community was present in Canton by the mid-18th century, helping to facilitate the British-dominated China trade by importing opium and cotton from India into China, while exporting tea and silk back to Europe and beyond. By the 19th century, there was a sizeable community of Europeans.

title_text: Friesland Wall Clock
physical_appearance: This is a wall clock and its body sits on four black rounded studs that rest on a wall bracket. Its overall decorative scheme includes paintings of vines, flowers, mermaids, as well as carved and gilded vases, cherub heads, and scrolling vines in open metal work. The clock's mechanisms can be seen via the glass panels on either side of the clock.
subject_terms_1: mermaids vine scrolls mechanical clocks  putti (motifs)
subject_terms_2: Mermaids  Scrolls (Decorative arts)  Malacca (Malacca, Malaysia)  Cherubs (Art)
sgcool_label_text:
Elaborately painted and gilded clocks like this, made in the northern province of Friesland in the Netherlands, were popular in Dutch colonial port cities. They appear frequently in inventories of the estates of residents of Batavia and Malacca.

The clock body itself sits within a large wall bracket with canopy. Because the wall bracket was thought to resemble a seat for the clock, the Dutch used the term “stoelklok” (stool clock) for them. 

They are also called “Friesian” or “Frisian” clocks, because of where they were made.

title_text: Painted fabric template
physical_appearance: This is a painted fabric template. It consists of four panels arranged in a horizontal row. Within each panel, there is an image of a bird surrounded by floral patterns. The coloured birds are drawn in a variety of positions with different uncoloured background motifs. The cloth is slightly stained.
subject_terms_1: textile art (visual works) birds (motifs) flower (motif) patterns (design elements)
subject_terms_2: Textile crafts Textile design Motifs
subject_terms_3: Textile art and design Vanishing trade
sgcool_label_text:
Fabric templates were used to guide the embroiderer. Drawn in a lively manner, each bird is surrounded by a dense square of ferns and flowers. These creatures are fantastical inventions, with peacock feathers for tails and bodies that are painted blue, green and yellow.

As pre-prepared template patterns were typically repetitive and conventional, this example stands out for the variety of animated postures and flora depicted. Pre-prepared patterns could be purchased and were popular because they could be used with beads, silk floss or a combination of different materials.

title_text: Drawn fabric template
physical_appearance: This is a drawn fabric template. It consists of a horizontal scrolling floral pattern on a long canvas. Along the central pattern is a repeating motif of a pair of birds flanking a singular lily stalk. The motif is set against a foliate background, with a row of flowers on either side of the pattern.
subject_terms_1: textile art (visual works) birds (motifs) flower (motif) patterns (design elements)
subject_terms_2: Textile crafts Textile design Motifs
subject_terms_3: Textile art and design Vanishing trade
sgcool_label_text:
Fabric templates were used to guide the embroiderer. Along the central border is a repeating motif of a pair of birds flanking a singular lily stalk, set against a foliate background. A row of flowers on both sides complete the pattern.

The small holes of double-thread Penelope canvas and other kinds of counted-thread canvases, made it possible to create out of beads designs which were originally used for silk embroidery. The fabric was cut diagonally so as to align beads in a vertical position.

title_text: Four boxes of beads
physical_appearance: This is a set of four boxes containing an extensive collection of beads of different types, fineness, colour and shade. Each group of beads are contained within a smaller cylindrical container. These containers are arranged into rows that have been segmented within each box. The top left box contain shades of green beads, and the bottom right box contain shades of blues. The other two boxes contain a variety of colours, including yellows, browns and purples.
subject_terms_1: Peranakan sewing tools tailors beadwork (visual works)
subject_terms_2: Beads Peranakan (Asian people) Sewing Equipment and supplies Tailors Clothing trade Bead embroidery
subject_terms_3: Vanishing trade Textile art and design
sgcool_label_text:
These four boxes contain a panoply of beads of different type, fineness, colour and shade. Colours range from deep indigo to pastel lavender, from dark green to pale yellow. Rocaille beads are rounded seed beads with no flat sides. Charlottes or cut beads, on the other hand, are glass seed beads with one or more flat sides. Both types are commonly found in Nyonya beadwork, often on the same object, and are known as manek potong.

European glass seed beads had been mass-produced since the late 15th century while smaller and more colourful beads were made possible by the technological advances in glassmaking in about 1760. Venice, Bohemia and Lyons were well known centres of bead production in early 20th century.

title_text: Sewing box with purl, sequins, beads
physical_appearance: This is a red sewing box that contains a set of six smaller boxes of purl thread, sequins, ribbons and beads and a small coil of wire. The sewing box is circular in shape, as are the smaller boxes containing the dewing materials. Five of the smaller boxes are of the same size, with the box in the middle being much smaller in size than the rest.
subject_terms_1: Peranakan sewing tools tailors beads (pierced objects) sequins (spangles) wire needlework (visual works)
subject_terms_2: Sewing Equipment and supplies Peranakan (Asian people) Beads Tailors Clothing trade Needlework
subject_terms_3: Vanishing trade Textile art and design
sgcool_label_text:
This red sewing box contains 6 smaller boxes of purl thread, sequins, ribbons and beads, and a small coil of wire. Purls, sequins, ribbons and beads were used in Nyonya needlework to achieve effects of colour, light and contrasting textures. Labels on some of the boxes remain intact. The label on the box which contains metal purl shows: ‘Made in France by Roland. Trademark Favier Brothers Lyons…’ , ‘Boite modele depose’, and ‘Pattern 2175 Frisée Brillante-Br.3’.

Purl thread was known as gim kasar and giem kembang, where gim means gold. Sequins are flat discs that were secured using beads or metal purl.

title_text: Two-piece wedding outfit
physical_appearance: This is a two-piece wedding outfit. It is a set consisting of a turquoise blue embroided jacket with matching skirt. The jacket is embroided with flowers such as chrysanthemum and the Buddha hand citron. The edges are decorated with an embroided scallop border. The buttons run down the left of the jacket. The pleated skirt is decorated with similar motifs, with a phoenix and a butterfly embroided in the center panel.
subject_terms_1: folk costume embroidery (visual works) ceremonial costume tops (garments, general) skirts (garments) flower (motif) phoenixes
subject_terms_2: Wedding costume Ethnic costume Embroidery Motifs Skirts Jackets
sgcool_label_text:
This is a two-piece wedding outfit worn by a Peranakan bride. The turquoise blue jacket is embroidered with a variety of auspicious flowers such as chrysanthemum and Buddha hand citron. An elaborate scalloped border adorns its edges. The matching skirt with pleats is similarly decorated with floral patterns. A phoenix is depicted in a landscape of peonies and butterflies on the central panel. The bride wore turquoise or green-coloured wedding robes on the twelfth and last day of wedding celebrations.

Peranakan wedding practices closely resembled old wedding customs in Fujian province, from which many Peranakans hail. For Peranakans living in Malacca and Singapore, wedding robes were often specially ordered from Shanghai or made by Shanghainese tailors living in Singapore.

title_text: Wedding robe with 2 hangings
physical_appearance: This is a silk wedding robe. It has a mandarin collar and side opening. The textile is embroidered with peonies and phoenixes, flying amongst cloud forms. The bottom hem of the robe features a triangular geometric pattern and layered clouds. There are two embroidered strips with beads hanging from v-shaped ends..
subject_terms_1: folk costume embroidery (visual works) ceremonial costume robes (main garments) flower (motif) phoenixes
subject_terms_2: Wedding costume Ethnic costume Embroidery Motifs Robes Rites and ceremonies
sgcool_label_text:
This is a wedding robe worn by a Peranakan bride. With a mandarin collar and side opening, the red robe is richly embroidered with peonies and phoenixes, symbols of prosperity and loyalty respectively.  Also included are two embroidered strips with strings of beads hanging from v-shaped ends. Four such hangings would have been attached to a cape placed over the wedding robe.

In Malacca, the garment was worn during the Chiu Thau ceremony which took place after the Chia Lang Kheh (Dinner for guests on wedding eve) and before the Chim Pang (Meeting of the Bride and Bridegroom).  Wedding robes were specially ordered from Shanghai or made by Shanghainese tailors living in Singapore.

title_text: Bamboo vest
physical_appearance: This is a set of two bamboo vests. It is made from strips of bamboo, strung together to create a lattice structure. A blue trim runs along the neckline of the vest as well as down the front and along the sleeveless arm holes.
subject_terms_1: ceremonial costume underwear
subject_terms_2: Vests Wedding costume Rites and ceremonies Underwear
sgcool_label_text: Bamboo vests were worn by both bride and bridegroom under their wedding garments. Strips of bamboo are strung to form a diamond-shaped mesh. A blue trim runs along the vest’s circular neckline, sleeveless arm holes and down the front. It is secured by frog fasteners at the neck and stomach. Bamboo vests were worn to allow for ventilation beneath the thick and heavily embroidered wedding garments. As wedding robes were often made from delicate silk, bamboo vests would have prevented sweat stains and fabric damage.

title_text: Batik Variant Truntum II
physical_appearance: This is a multicoloured painting of batik prints. Its composition comprises of repeated geometric patterns.
subject_terms_1: batik art  repeated motif  geometric patterns
subject_terms_2: Geometry in art Batik Reinterpreting history  Arts, Indonesian
sgcool_label_text: This work continues Apin’s investigations into the batik tradition in relation to its role in Indonesian art history.  This investigation started in the 1970s with his batik print works. The period also saw many modern Indonesian artists re-visiting traditional culture and mythology. Subsequently some would incorporate these elements into their visual language.

title_text: Chairil Anwar
physical_appearance: This is a portrait of a Chairil Anwar, one of Southeast Asia's most important poets. The figure's head angles away from the audience, and he is depicted to be wearing a blue shirt and is himself set against a colourful background. Yellow has been used to indicate the colour of the figure's skin. The artist's signature and date of work is found on the bottom left corner
subject_terms_1: figurative art  forms of expression (artistic concept)  identity
subject_terms_2: Figurative painting Figurative art Figurative expressionism  Identity  Anwar, Chairil, 1922-1949
sgcool_label_text: Executed after the Japanese Occupation, the work is a portrait of one of the most important poets in Southeast Asia. Here we can still observe Apin’s impressionist tendencies, similar to the works done during his  PERSAGI days. Together with Chairil Anwar, Apin was also part of the Gelanggang group of artists and writers. The group played an important role in the discourse of Indonesia’s cultural identity during the post-colonial period as outlined in the Gelanggang Manifesto of 1946.

title_text: Circle of Life
physical_appearance: This pastel drawing features characters from Javanese wayang and mythology.  The colours are vibrant, and the strokes are fine. A yellow wheel dominates the central composition, while geomtric patterns encircle it. Each mythological character is depicted in a different colour; three are in the foreground whilst two are in flight.
subject_terms_1: Wayang folklore religious characters
subject_terms_2: Mythology, Javanese Folklore Reinterpreting history  Arts, Indonesian
subject_terms_3: visual arts  Religious life and practices
sgcool_label_text: This work features characters from the Javanese wayang and other forms of Javanese mythology. Like Apins’s series of batik works, we can see his engagement with local folklore and traditions, even combining their visual language with his modernist tendencies. This synthesis represents Apin’s steadfast pursuit of new artistic languages without necessarily doing away with his traditions.

title_text: Batik Variant
physical_appearance: Split into three colours of blue, green, and red, the design of the background of thie print is filled with floral patterns. Printed atop, are geometric patterns that cover the entire composition. It is placed in a white frame.
subject_terms_1: batik art  repeated motif  geometric patterns  flower patterns
subject_terms_2: Geometry in art Batik Reinterpreting history  Arts, Indonesian
sgcool_label_text:
Apin did numerous works tackling the batik medium. Most of these works were titled Batik Variant with some having more than a few editions. From these series of works we can see his attempts at inserting the vernacular or ‘tradition’ into his practice which is known more for its progressiveness and universality ie. abstraction.

This work is culturally significant, especially since Indonesia has a well established history in the production of batik textiles. It was for this very reason that Apin’s interpretation of this entrenched tradition provides an interesting study of the medium in relation to the art and craft discourse. The 1970s period also saw many modern Indonesian artists re-visiting traditional culture and mythology. Subsequently some would incorporate these elements into their visual language.

title_text: Menenun (Weaving)
physical_appearance: The image captures a girl seated with her right leg folded and right leg outstretched. Not donning any clothes, she wears her long hair down and kept behind her shoulders.
subject_terms_1: nudes (representations)  abstraction graphic arts batik art
subject_terms_2: Batik  Arts, Indonesian  Abstraction  Graphic arts Female nude in art
sgcool_label_text: This work continues Apin’s exploration in the print technique. However beyond the print medium, there are also photographic and abstraction elements, combined with his lifelong study of the nude body. Hence this is a strong, confident work of an artist who is at the peak of his practice. To add to the multi-layered aspect of this work, the title Menenun which translates to Weaving also touches on the long-standing textile tradition in Indonesian besides of course, summarizing the technique of this work.

title_text: Linoleographs- Baharoedin & Mochtar Apin Box containing Linoleographs- Baharoedin & Mochtar Apin
physical_appearance: This is a black box within which the folder that holds the prints are placed.
subject_terms_1: independence  identity  propaganda
subject_terms_2: Merdeka  Independence Prints, Indonesian  Propaganda
context_1: First anniversary of Indonesia's Declaration of Independence
sgcool_label_text: This folio of 19 prints is a historically significant body of work relating to Indonesia’s Declaration of Independence in 1945. Commissioned by the Indonesia Bureau of Youth Affairs to celebrate the first anniversary of Indonesia’s independence, Baharoedin was informed that the government was interested in producing some propaganda materials. Consisting of 10 prints by Baharoedin and 9 prints by Apin, the works depict various images associated with the nation’s struggle towards Independence. 36 of these folios were then printed and distributed to various countries who had recognized Indonesia’s independence during that period.

title_text: The First Signpost Pantjangan Pertama \Folio of linocut prints titled \"\"Pantjangan Pertama\"\"\""
physical_appearance: \This is a folio of linocut prints and it is titled \"\"Pantjangan Pertama\"\" (The First Signpost). \""
subject_terms_1: social realism  genre (visual works)
subject_terms_2: Prints, Indonesian  Apin, Mochtar Social realism  Artists' books Genre prints  Indonesians
sgcool_label_text:
Pantjangan Pertama is another folio of linocut prints following Apin’s collaboration with Baharoedin in 1946. Funded by the Gelanggang collective this time round, it consists of 12 works on paper. Featuring a collection of images of objects and people going about their daily activities, they represent the ‘daily realities’ of the different societies within the Indonesian community.

During the post-WW II period, the print medium was generally associated with the Social Realist art movements, looking at the few examples in Southeast Asia. Apin’s prints works, though maintaining the socialist bent is as much, if not more, about the print medium itself as a possible new direction in modern Indonesian art. Culturally dominated by paintings, Apin’s folio of prints and the activities of the Gelanggang collective are testament towards this push.

title_text: The First Signpost Pantjangan Pertama
physical_appearance: \This is a folio of linocut prints and it is titled \"\"Pantjangan Pertama\"\" (The First Signpost). \""
