Pantjangan Pertama is another folio of linocut prints following Apin’s collaboration with Baharoedin in 1946. Funded by the Gelanggang collective this time round, it consists of 12 works on paper. Featuring a collection of images of objects and people going about their daily activities, they represent the ‘daily realities’ of the different societies within the Indonesian community.

During the post-WW II period, the print medium was generally associated with the Social Realist art movements, looking at the few examples in Southeast Asia. Apin’s prints works, though maintaining the socialist bent is as much, if not more, about the print medium itself as a possible new direction in modern Indonesian art. Culturally dominated by paintings, Apin’s folio of prints and the activities of the Gelanggang collective are testament towards this push.

title_text: The First Signpost Pantjangan Pertama Orang Tidur
physical_appearance: This linocut print depicts a person lying on his/her side and is sleeping.
subject_terms_1: social realism  figurative art  sleeping
subject_terms_2: Prints, Indonesian  Social realism  Figurative art  Sleeping  Apin, Mochtar  Indonesians

sgcool_label_text: Published in 1967, Liberte/ Merdeka is a folio of prints produced by artists associated with the Bandung Technological Institute (ITB). This interesting set of prints was essentially the artists’ interpretation of noted Surrealist poet, Paul Eluard’s poem Liberte. Consisting of the ‘who’s who’ of the ‘Bandung School’ of artists, this folio of prints can be seen both as an experimental publication in terms of the art-literary collaboration, and also the promotion of the print-making medium within the Indonesian context.

sgcool_label_text: Published in 1967, Liberte/ Merdeka is a folio of prints produced by artists associated with the Bandung Technological Institute (ITB). This interesting set of prints was essentially the artists’ interpretation of noted Surrealist poet, Paul Eluard’s poem Liberte. Consisting of the ‘who’s who’ of the ‘Bandung School’ of artists, this folio of prints can be seen both as an experimental publication in terms of the art-literary collaboration, and also the promotion of the print-making medium within the Indonesian context.

title_text: Bloodline of Peace
physical_appearance: This installation depicts a large collection of lenses joined together by metal pins to create a large quilt-like piece. Within each lens, there is a single drop of blood. The work is hung up by three points along the center. The use of fresnel lens create a reflective effect.
subject_terms_1: commissions (orders for works) peace symbolism (artistic concept) patriotism
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Art commissions Peace Patriotism
sgcool_label_text:
Commissioned for Singapore’s Jubilee Year celebrations, Bloodline of Peace was created in response to ‘Peace’, one of the country’s five founding values enshrined in the national flag. Expansive in scope and in spirit, Bloodline of Peace brings together a diverse range of Singaporeans who are conjoined through the shared act of giving life’s most precious fluid: blood. Unfolding like a monumental quilt, the work comprises over 11,500 units created from more than 34,500 prismatic Fresnel lenses, a material that Victor first used in 1997. Now, in Bloodline of Peace, each segment holds and magnifies in its ‘heart’ a single drop of blood contributed by individuals representing Singapore’s key communities such as the armed forces, medicine, civil defence, the arts, and the pioneer generation.

Blood is life, and when drawn by force, it implies brutality, pain, and death. Yet, when donated voluntarily, it is an act that saves the lives of loved ones – and strangers – during medical emergencies. Ultimately, the symbolically rich gift of blood signifies the utmost sacrifice for a fellow human being and for nation, and poignantly, peace – that most fragile of conditions – can oftentimes only be attained, upheld and protected through a willingness to make this highest sacrifice. In the artist’s words: “A transient state, ‘Peace’ is defined by absence – that of war and bloodshed. To be sustainable, commitment and preservation are  necessary processes undertaken by civilians while armed and medical personnel are at the frontiers”.

title_text: Bryde’s Fountain (After Marcel Duchamp)
materials_name: fibreglass stainless steel ceramic (material) cement (construction material) mixed media
physical_appearance: The installation art depicts a sculpture that is positioned on the floor. The base of the sculpture is that of a whale. Its tail and its left flipper can be seen. The whale is sculpted in a curved shape, with its mouth and tail curling upwards. Attached to its blowhole is a sculpture of a fountain. It has an oval basin and five tiers, and water can be seen to be released at the top
subject_terms_1: sculpture (visual works) whales fountains adaptations (derivative objects)
subject_terms_2: Kinetic sculpture Installations (Art) Bryde whale Fountains Art Adaptations
sgcool_label_text: Especially commissioned by SAM for the Exhibition Imaginarium: Over the Ocean, Under the Sea, Bryde’s Fountain is an adaptation of Krit Ngamsom’s earlier work R. Mutt’s Fountain from his widely praised series of works from his solo exhibition Already Mades (2011). The working fountain, now placed above a stainless steel representation of a Bryde’s whale, playfully evokes a whale’s blowhole. The whale, also known as the Buddha’s whale, resides in the Gulf of Thailand and is an auspicious sight. In presenting the work to audiences, he hopes that good fortunes will smile down upon them.

title_text: Damien, I’m Famished (After Damien Hirst)
physical_appearance: The installation art is set in a space that has blue walls and floors, albeit of different hues. To the left, a shark with its head and teeth exposed protrudes from a transparent tank. The shark is positioned, with its gaping mouth, in the direction of a school of fish. The fish have orange tips on their caudal fins and they are all of different sizes. They are made to look like they are swimming, with the help of vertical rods that extend from the ground.
subject_terms_1: sculpture (visual works) adaptations (derivative objects) Selachii (order) fish (animals) symbolism (artistic concept)
subject_terms_2: Kinetic sculpture Installations (Art) Art Adaptations Sharks Fishes Symbolism
sgcool_label_text: Krit Ngamsom’s kinetic sculptures are tongue-in-cheek references to iconic artworks that have changed definitions and assumptions about art. Damien, I’m Famished is a playful reinterpretation of Damien Hirst’s iconic work, The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living. Featuring the shark bursting from its tank to go after a tasty snack of fish, Ngamsom’s reinterpretation of the work draws its inspiration from notions of Thai-ness – and in this case, the Buddhist practice of Life Release.

title_text: Like Someone in Love #10
physical_appearance: The image displays three paintings that are attached side by side to the same overhead wooden board. The paintings are rectangular in shape and they are translucent. The painting on the left hand side has an orange border surrounding a centre that is painted purple. The middle one has a red centre and its border is black in colour. The one on the right has yellow centre and its perimeter is a purple border.
subject_terms_1: acrylic paintings (visual works) allegory (artistic device)
subject_terms_2: Paintings Triptychs Allegories
sgcool_label_text: chi too (b.1981) is a Sino-Malaysian artist currently based in Kuala Lumpur. (His name is rendered entirely in small letters.) He is a multidisciplinary artist whose practice “vacillates between the high-minded and the frivolous, the social and the personal, the transparent and the esoteric”, in the artist’s own words. He was also a member of the disbanded art collective The Best Art Show in the Universe. Since then, he has participated in various exhibitions and performance events in Malaysia and abroad, and was a Nippon Foundation Asian Public Intellectual (API) fellow in 2011. He has held four solo exhibitions to date, Longing (2011) at Blackbox MAP, Publika, Malaysia; State of Doubt (2012) at Akiba Art Lab, Tokyo Japan; and The Artist chi too Looks at Artworks As He Contemplates The State of the Nation’s Institutions a.k.a. How Can You Be Sure (2013) at Art Row, Publika, Malaysia, and most recently at the independent art space, Lostgens, at which he showed the Like Someone in Love series, of which the present work is a part.  Like Someone in Love #10 is a triptych of bubble-wrap paintings – sheets of that ubiquitous packing material, the individual bubbles of which have been painstakingly filled with acrylic paint via a syringe. The art historian Simon Soon penned an essay for the exhibition of the works at Lostgens, which encapsulates the conceptual framework of the series: “In a sense, chi too’s present exploration of painterly process casts a critical eye on two dominant tendencies in contemporary Malaysian painting. In both trends, painting is either regarded as either a self-evident channel for allegory or a transparent expression of emotive gesture. These are approaches to painting that Like Someone In Love as a series is evidently not. In terms of his painting method, chi too begins by choosing a sheet of bubble wrap as the painting support. The process is methodical and follows a pre-determined set of procedure. It requires him to painstakingly inject a small amount of paint into each bubble air pocket with a syringe. The neatly lined rows and columns of the bubble wrap provides chi too with a compositional grid. Based on this gridded matrix, he would explore a number of configurations that take us through a rudimentary lesson on colour theory.”

column52: Unreadable Wall

column54: quite literally

A small minority of educated individuals may be able to read between the lines"

title_text: Vortex 2015 – The Letter of Albert Einstein
physical_appearance: This installation is made of a hanging chandelier that is created using hundreds of individual glass alphabets. Collectively, the alphabets cast shadows on the surrounding ceiling, walls and floor, spelling out a letter.
subject_terms_1: chandeliers (hanging lights) political art letters (correspondence) nuclear power
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Glass chandeliers Art Political aspects Einstein, Albert, 1879-1955 Letters Nuclear energy
sgcool_label_text: Vortex 2015 comprises a chandelier made up of hundreds of individual glass alphabets, collectively spelling out a letter written by Albert Einstein to Franklin D Roosevelt in 1939, urging the American President to consider developing nuclear power as a means to balance out what was then perceived as Nazi Germany’s ambitions in this arena. As history would have it, Germany’s nuclear programme was never fully realized. America, on the other hand, went on to develop the atomic bomb, which was deployed with devastating consequences during the Second World War, in Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Decades later, the nuclear accident in Fukushima reminded the world of the perils of nuclear power, even as it left yet another scar on the psyche of the Japanese people. At first glance a visually seductive and scintillating work, Vortex 2015 reveals its dark heart, for its core is formed in the shape of a nuclear reactor. The message contained within its pieces of glass can only be read as shadows cast on the floor and surrounding walls – a comment perhaps, on how seduced we are by the promise of nuclear power that we choose to disregard or turn away from direct confrontation with its dangers. The choice of glass as a medium for this work has an additional layer of significance, beyond its immediate formal associations with the reflective crystalline components of chandeliers, for glass is also a medium to deactivate nuclear waste. A companion piece installed on the surrounding walls, The Dead Line, spells out in barely visible text, the names and dates of other nuclear disasters throughout history. These are incidents that many have chosen not to remember, but they are irrevocably etched into our shared history and psyche – warnings that we choose to ignore at our own peril.

title_text: Jangan Tipu 1
physical_appearance: This is a charcoal drawing of a street scene capturing a Bersih rally. In the cneter of the drawing, there is a woman gazing forwards. She is holding a bouquet of chrysanthemums in her right hand. She is wearing a tshirt with the face of a man, along with a rally badge and holding a 'Bersih' bag. She is standing in the middle of a crowd who are wearing similar t-shirts and holding up 'Bersih' posters.
subject_terms_1: rallies political art mixed media
subject_terms_2: Charcoal drawing Demonstrations Art Political aspects Bersih 2.0 (Organization) Mixed media (Art) Art, Malaysian
sgcool_label_text: Minstrel Kuik is a Sino-Malaysian artist born in Pantai Remis, Perak, in 1976. She received her tertiary education in Taiwan and France. While trained primarily in painting and philosophy, her practice today is centered on the mediums of photography and drawing, with elements of installation also present. The experience of growing up a Chinese woman in a social polity that privileges male, Malay-Muslim identity is foregrounded in Kuik’s work, where photography, for one, serves as the medium for her to explore social distances and attachments for its documentary and narrative quality. With the two Jangan Tipu (“Don’t Lie”) drawings, the artist notes that: “In analog photography, the negative is a latent image that unfolds the image/reality to the future – a prophetic object embedded with an oracle/truth. From the photographs taken by myself during the previous Bersih rallies 2.0 and 3.0 in 2011 and 2012, I have chosen 2 images, each with a dominant feminine figure at the center of the composition, looking out quietly yet in confidence at the audience. By using the concept of Madonna depicted in the classical Western painting, I would like to emphasize the role of females and their participation in the public and political sphere. With the help of grids, I measured each persons and objects in the composition by endless back and forth verifications, with the hope to anchor my subject matter to the space of action– the street, where the Bersih rallies took place. Spending day and night on the drawing has thus become a ritual for me to linger longer at the moment where the image was being taken, to become aware of the making of history. In Jangan Tipu 1, Teoh Lee Lan, the sister of Teoh Beng Hock, held in her right hand a bouquet of chrysanthemums in token of her brother’s tragic death when being interrogated by the MACC (Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission) in 2009.”

title_text: Domesticated Politics
materials_name: ink polyester (fiber) butyl acrylate cloth nylon
physical_appearance: This is a set of photographs. They depict different shots of a woman working with an iron and the Malaysian flag folded into small triangles. She is shown folding, ironing and assembling the triangle flags on the floor. There are no inscriptions seen.
subject_terms_1: flags political art elections
subject_terms_2: Photographs Art Political aspects Flags Elections
sgcool_label_text: Minstrel Kuik is a Sino-Malaysian artist born in Pantai Remis, Perak, in 1976. She received her tertiary education in Taiwan and France. While trained primarily in painting and philosophy, her practice today is centered on the mediums of photography and drawing, with elements of installation also present. The experience of growing up a Chinese woman in a social polity that privileges male, Malay-Muslim identity is foregrounded in Kuik’s work, where photography, for one, serves as the medium for her to explore social distances and attachments for its documentary and narrative quality. Domesticated Politics emerged from her current series of works that are constituted by the material remnants of the Malaysian 13th General Election that occurred in May 2013. In Kuik’s hands, the paraphernalia, banners and flags from the various parties, advertisements and much more examine the meaning of a today’s national state in contrast to something which should be very familiar to everybody called globalization. In these works, Kuik explores the dynamics between the personal and the political, and how such relations influence a person’s worldview. Her personal identity as Sino- Malaysian, female artist has led her to experiment – in Domesticated Politics – with the concept of domestication: to feminize, to soften the once exuberant, masculine and heroic objects, to make these flags immobile and impotent.”  She is seen folding, ironing, and assembling the triangle flags on the floor. By following the proportion of the national flag of Malaysia, these DIY flags are made smaller in the form of pillowcases. At the front of the flags, the movement of the working hands serves as a motif running through the sequence of nine images recomposed according to their visual rhythm. At the back of each flag is a fabric of a colorful pattern, used to suggest the people who are wearing it – the anonymous voters like herself, gives the front image – the necessary solidarity.

title_text: Flirting with the Moon
physical_appearance: The installation art depicts 12 identical frames that are evenly spread out in a four by 3 rectangular orientation. The frames are rectangular, wooden, and brown in colour Within each frame, a green flag of the Malaysian Islamic Party (PAS) are folded and placed in it. The flags are folded in such a way to create folds and pockets. There are several different items that are either placed just slightly into the pockets of the flags to leave them a little exposed, or placed beside the flags together in the frames. These items are blue and white in colour. A couple of them are in the shape of an open palm while others are cloths and a string.
subject_terms_1: political art flags dissident art repeated motif cresents (motifs)
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Parti Islam Semalaysia (LC) Dissident art
sgcool_label_text: Minstrel Kuik is a Sino-Malaysian artist born in Pantai Remis, Perak, in 1976. She received her tertiary education in Taiwan and France. While trained primarily in painting and philosophy, her practice today is centered on the mediums of photography and drawing, with elements of installation also present. The experience of growing up a Chinese woman in a social polity that privileges male, Malay-Muslim identity is foregrounded in Kuik’s work, where photography, for one, serves as the medium for her to explore social distances and attachments for its documentary and narrative quality. The title of Flirting with the Moon references the song made famous by Teresa Teng, “The Moon Represents My Heart”. The moon is also a sign of God, according to the Quran. In Flirting with the Moon, Kuik utilized PAS flags (i.e. the opposition Parti Islam Se-Malaysia, the flags of which feature a lunar motif), to create folds and pockets. Into these pockets she inserted various paraphernalia collected from the 13th General elections held in 2013. The Islamist fundamentalism of PAS is, according to the artist, one of the least desirable alternatives for Malaysia’s political scene, especially viewed from her standpoint as a female, non-Muslim Sino-Malaysian. In Kuik’s hands, political paraphernalia examines the meaning of a today’s national state in contrast to something which should be very familiar to everybody called globalization. In these works, she explores the dynamics between the personal and the political.

The title of Flirting with the Moon references the song made famous by Teresa Teng, “The Moon Represents My Heart”. The moon is also a sign of God, according to the Quran. In Flirting with the Moon, Kuik utilized PAS flags (i.e. the opposition Parti Islam Se-Malaysia, the flags of which feature a lunar motif), to create folds and pockets. Into these pockets she inserted various paraphernalia collected from the 13th General elections held in 2013. The Islamist fundamentalism of PAS is, according to the artist, one of the least desirable alternatives for Malaysia’s political scene, especially viewed from her standpoint as a female, non-Muslim Sino-Malaysian. In Kuik’s hands, political paraphernalia examines the meaning of a today’s national state in contrast to something which should be very familiar to everybody called globalization. In these works, she explores the dynamics between the personal and the political.

sgcool_label_text: This handmade lace sample is from the collection of Sylvia Kho who was a prominent bridal couturier in Singapore from the 1950s to 1990s. Sylvia Kho designed and custom-made wedding gowns using elaborate laces imported from Europe.  She travelled extensively to France and USA to learn how wedding gowns were designed and made. She also became one of the greatest buyers of wedding gown lace in France. This exquisite lace sample still has its original label from the maker, a certain A.Naef.co which is no longer in existence.

sgcool_label_text:
These lace sample come from the collection of Sylvia Kho who was a prominent bridal couturier in Singapore from the 1950s to 1990s. She designed and custom-made wedding gowns using elaborate laces imported from Europe.  She travelled extensively to France and USA to learn how wedding gowns were designed and made. She also became one of the greatest buyers of wedding gown laces in France. This lace sample would have been offered to her clients who comprised not only of brides but also mothers, aunts and sisters of the brides. 
This particular type of hand-made cotton lace were particularly popular with the mothers of brides.  Made by hand, such fine quality of lace are no longer produced by millinery houses in Europe.

sgcool_label_text: This diploma was awarded to Mrs Florence Chong (nee Wong Chit Moy) on 14 September 1954 by the Academy of Beauty Culture Ltd at New Bond Street, London. Mrs Florence Chong was the seventh sister of prominent local bridal designer Mrs Sylvia Kho (nee Wong Sien Moy). She received training in make-up and hairstyling in London and provided her services to brides in Singapore as early as the 1950s.

title_text: Zouk Velvet Underground Signage
physical_appearance: This is the signage for Zouk's Velvet Underground nightclub. The background of the signage is black while the fonts and images are in bright pink. Attached to the signage at the bottom is a white note that states 'Lot No 307'. An outline of a heart-shaped design is drawn on top of the letter 'V' in 'Velvet'. The signage does not look to be chipped or have any cracks on it.
subject_terms_1: nighclubs entertainment centers (inhabited places) Signs and signboards Logos (Symbols) discotheques
subject_terms_2: Singapore Nightclubs
context_20: Zouk nightclub operated out of three first restored godowns at Jiak Kim Street when it first opened to the public in March 1991.
sgcool_label_text:
Zouk nightclub operated out of three first restored godowns at Jiak Kim Street when it first opened to the public in March 1991. This was Zouk’s home for 25 years until its relocation to Clarke Quay’s Cannery Block at the end of 2016. 

Zouk at Jiak Kim Street had four signature zones which played different music to cater to different tastes: Zouk, Phuture, Velvet Underground and the Wine Bar. Velvet Underground opened in July 1994 after the restaurant space was converted into an exclusive enclave for members, making it Singapore’s first dance membership club then. Velvet Underground had its own private entrance and was known for its thick velvet-covered walls and iconic artwork. It catered to older Zouk patrons with a more relaxed lounge space that played house and soul music.

context_3: Together Again: (wood:cut) Part III Material exhibition at Royal Botanic Gardens, Edinburgh
context_9: Lucy Davis and the Migrant Ecologies Project team
column52:
Artist, educator and writer Lucy Davis’s interdisciplinary practice is informed by a longstanding interest in animal studies, natural histories, science and indigenous knowledge, materiality and memory in Southeast Asia, and the evocations of nature in art and visual culture. This work by Lucy Davis is part of the series titled ‘Together Again (Wood:Cut) Part lll: Material’, the third iteration of the eponymous research project, which the artist has been developing since 2008. The third iteration is focused on the questions of material, and is an artistic and part-scientific inquiry into our material world, and how everyday objects are reflective of the histories, migratory lives and sources of knowledge across Southeast Asia. Specifically, this body of work takes a 1950s teak bed as both starting and departure point for artistic, ecological and social inquiry all in an attempt to trace its historic, genetic and poetic life. 

The project put in motion when, in 2010, the Migrant Ecologies Project (founded by Davis) was awarded a Singapore Ministry of Education Tier 1 grant to extract DNA from a selected teak bed, and to travel to wherever the DNA suggested the timbre originated. This was carried out in collaboration with Double Helix Tracking Technologies, which used DNA technologies that traced the original location of the rainforest product to Sulawesi. Together with a team of scientists and a photographer, Davis visited a century year old teak plantation on Muna Island in South Sulawesi where she met with the villagers of Muna. The components that comprise ‘Together Again (Wood:Cut) Part lll: Material’ are a meditation on the experience of visiting Muna, and of the competing systems of knowledge the team encountered, between the shamanistic insights of the villagers in Sulawesi and the scientific inquiry of DNA technology. More than a simple forensic ‘search for origins’ of a particular rainforest product, the project opens on to a world in which the forces of magic has a deep significance to a community largely dependent on wood, and becomes embroiled in the contestation between what kinds of knowledge are allowed to make claims over the understanding of reality.

context_1: Together Again: (wood:cut) Part III Material exhibition at Royal Botanic Gardens, Edinburgh
context_7: Lucy Davis and the Migrant Ecologies Project team
sgcool_label_text:
Artist, educator and writer Lucy Davis’s interdisciplinary practice is informed by a longstanding interest in animal studies, natural histories, science and indigenous knowledge, materiality and memory in Southeast Asia, and the evocations of nature in art and visual culture. This work by Lucy Davis is part of the series titled ‘Together Again (Wood:Cut) Part lll: Material’, the third iteration of the eponymous research project, which the artist has been developing since 2008. The third iteration is focused on the questions of material, and is an artistic and part-scientific inquiry into our material world, and how everyday objects are reflective of the histories, migratory lives and sources of knowledge across Southeast Asia. Specifically, this body of work takes a 1950s teak bed as both starting and departure point for artistic, ecological and social inquiry all in an attempt to trace its historic, genetic and poetic life. 

The project put in motion when, in 2010, the Migrant Ecologies Project (founded by Davis) was awarded a Singapore Ministry of Education Tier 1 grant to extract DNA from a selected teak bed, and to travel to wherever the DNA suggested the timbre originated. This was carried out in collaboration with Double Helix Tracking Technologies, which used DNA technologies that traced the original location of the rainforest product to Sulawesi. Together with a team of scientists and a photographer, Davis visited a century year old teak plantation on Muna Island in South Sulawesi where she met with the villagers of Muna. The components that comprise ‘Together Again (Wood:Cut) Part lll: Material’ are a meditation on the experience of visiting Muna, and of the competing systems of knowledge the team encountered, between the shamanistic insights of the villagers in Sulawesi and the scientific inquiry of DNA technology. More than a simple forensic ‘search for origins’ of a particular rainforest product, the project opens on to a world in which the forces of magic has a deep significance to a community largely dependent on wood, and becomes embroiled in the contestation between what kinds of knowledge are allowed to make claims over the understanding of reality.

title_text: \West Point training map titled \"\"The War with Japan: Invasion of Burma (January-May 1942)\"\"\""
physical_appearance: This topographical map is rectangular in shape and its perimeter is marked by a pair of black lines. The training map is not crumpled and the ink is not smudged. Apart from being predominantly beige, lines, notes, and drawings in both red and blue are featured as well. The map depicts the territory of French Indochina when it was invaded by Japan during WWII.
subject_terms_1: world wars cartographic materials military centers military history
subject_terms_2: World War, 1939 - 1945 United States Military Academy Military maps Topographic Maps
sgcool_label_text: This is a topographical training map produced by West Point, the United States Military Academy, intended for use by its cadets. It documents the Japanese invasion of Burma from January to May 1942, with the movements of the Axis forces indicated in red and that of the Allied forces in blue.

title_text: Cycle of Old and New
physical_appearance: This is a printed photograph on canvas. The print depicts a textured painting that utilizes earthy colours of green and gray. The paint seems to be flowing downwards, seeping into the cracks of the medium, creating a vein-like pattern towards the bottom. There are no inscriptions seen on the print.
subject_terms_1: mixed media movement (compositional concept) painting abstraction Ice
subject_terms_2: Mixed media (Art) Photographs Impermanence (Buddhism) Prints Abstraction Ice
sgcool_label_text: When first viewed, the three works resemble surfaces of materials and matter that have been exposed to the elements and/or have experienced any number of photosynthetic processes; oxidation, corrosion, water streaks, algae blooms – Cycle of Old and New, Constant Flux and Natural Law by Cambodian artist, Loeum Lorn, seem to present the viewer with an intimate view of effects and reactions on our natural and built environments. It is only after gazing and scrutinizing the works for longer that one starts to recognise the marks of painterly strokes and it is with this observation that the viewer possibly admits an overly quick reading of the work; the works are surely paintings. But they are not. To describe them, as natural and built surfaces, captured in time, would not be incorrect nor is describing the works as paintings, for within this series one finds both; Cycles of Old and New, Constant Flux and Natural Law are paintings on ice blocks that have been captured on film and presented on canvas. Cycle of Old and New, Constant Flux and Natural Law were first shown at Lorn’s solo show, Yesterday, No More, held in 2012 at Java Arts in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. A show that was 6-years in the making, Yesterday, No More and Lorn’s continued experimentations with ice block painting and photography represents one of the more unique practices to hail from the Indochina area today. The practice of using blocks of ice as his canvas departs from Lorn’s experience as a child when he moved to the Thai border in the 1990s to escape the Khmer Rouge’s continuing terror. “Those nights were very cold,” he plainly states. With his art, he says, “I try to remind myself about all those memories.”   The painting featured here illustrates how Lorn felt during those nights. Lorn’s fascination with the forces of the cold temperatures that wrapped around and penetrated him are expressed in this painting and it is this proximity and intimicy that drew him to exploring ice blocks as a medium. The operation of moving quickly, and of working through the continual shifting and changing of the previous layers of paint against a melting canvas, forces Lorn to relinquish his sense of control over the medium he is attempting to wield and to give in and embrace the effects of the paints’ reaction against the melting ice; the motions of applying the paint are as much the artwork as the final photograph we see before us.  Containing notions of chance, transformation and impermenance, and with titles like, Cycle of Old and New, Constant Flux and Natural Law, Lorn’s works can be described as reflections of the life cycle and indeed the idea of transformation and impermenance as emphasised in the Buddhist reglion is something Lorn regards as a strong movement in his work: “My photographs are what’s left behind, like a memory,” he suggests, “and this I think is the connection between my work and the dharma”  which in Buddhism, refers to the law and order of the cosmos. Leoum Lorn (b. 1982, Cambodia) studied Visual Art at Phare Ponleu Selpak in Battambang, graduating in 2005. He works in photography, video and performance and has exhibited in Battambang and Phnom Penh, Cambodia and Paris, France. He currently runs a gallery in Battambang with his wife.

title_text: Constant flux
physical_appearance: This is a printed photograph on canvas. The print depicts a textured painting on ice that utilizes earthy colours of dark green and gray. There is a streak of dark green along the left, with a more concentrated paint streak on the right. The paint seems to adopt the uneven texture of the ice medium, seeping into cracks to create a vein-like pattern across the surface. There are no inscriptions seen on the print.

title_text: Every Point of View
physical_appearance: This is an installation piece that is site specific. It is composed of 400 PVC pipes attached to the ground upright. Text can be found on the pipes, and can only be read at a specific point; curated to be so by the artist who employed anamorphosis.
subject_terms_1: projections (visual works) site-specific works democracies  anamorphoses  commissions (orders for works)
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Demoracy  Art, Singaporean Anamorphoses  Art commissions
context_1: 5 Stars: Art Reflects on Peace, Justice, Equality, Democracy and Progress exhibition
sgcool_label_text:
Matthew Ngui’s use of the optical effect of anamorphosis is particularly apt in his engagement with the idea of Democracy. Dense with the vertical whiteness of over 400 PVC pipes, Every Point of View invokes the multi-pillared Parthenon in Athens, coincidentally the birthplace of democracy as an ideal and practice. 
Wandering amidst the forest of pipes, a viewer fleetingly encounters perspectives on the idea of ‘Democracy’. Ten representatives of particular demographics were invited to respond to two questions about ‘Democracy’, and the written responses were projected and traced onto the pipes. At specific points, the pipes become a continuous surface, where each statement is ‘jigsawed’ into coherence. Operating on the dynamics of anamorphic perception, only exact viewer positioning enables each statement to be read: the instant the viewer steps away from this tightly configured point, the perspective vanishes. These perspectives on democracy are experienced as moments of surveilled epiphany, as live camera feedback captures real-time footage at those points, which is projected in a separate space. A soundscape of murmurings of enunciations on democracy by elected office-bearers and public figures is also ‘piped’ through the installation, and viewers become listeners and speakers too – speaking into, or listening from openings on certain pipes. The artist sees the work as “analogous” to the democratic process: that democracy “is an understanding that different viewpoints exist and that it is within this acknowledgment that ways to co-exist are devised consensually and sometimes, not so.”
Matthew Ngui (born in 1962, Singapore) is a visual artist, trained in sculpture and now working in the areas of installation, video, performance, site-specific works and public art. He has exhibited locally and internationally in contemporary art museums and spaces in cities such as Berlin, Bordeaux, Copenhagen, Graz, Hong Kong, London, Manila and Vienna. Participating in the São Paulo (1996), Venice (2001) and Gwangju Biennales (2002) and the tenth Documenta in 1997, Ngui focuses on site-specific installations and performances that engage the locality and people of the city and space in which the work is exhibited. 

[Text by Susie Lingham]

title_text: Portrait of Robert Fullerton Robert Fullerton
physical_appearance: This is a oil portrait painting of Robert Fullerton. It features a man from waist-up, dressed in a brown coat with double-breasted buttons, and a white turtleneck top underneath. He is gazing towards the right, with his head tilted in the same direction. He is painted against a dark background. There is a signature and short description at the bottom-right of the painting.
subject_terms_1: governors
subject_terms_2: Painting Portraits Governors
sgcool_label_text: Robert Fullerton (1993-1831) was the governor of Penang from 1824 to 1826 and subsequently the first governor of the Straits Settlements upon its establishment in 1826, seving in that capacity until 1830. This portrait was most likely painted in Fullerton's younger days when he was an East India Company officer stationed in Madras. The painter of the portrait is almost certainly George Chinnery, a London born artist who painted in Madras from 1802 to 1807 before heading to Calcutta and later the China coast.

title_text: The Mystical Reality Reinvented ? Half-drunk Coca Cola Bottles
physical_appearance: This is an installation that consists of an abstract acrylic painting, a wooden shelf with two coca cola bottles with a printed quote beneath that spoke of abstract expressionism. These components are set against a purple-pink board.
subject_terms_1: abstraction group identity  drip painting  Abstract Expressionism Conceptual
subject_terms_2: Abstract expressionism Conceptual art Art, Abstract  Group identity  Installations (Arts)  Art, Malaysian
sgcool_label_text:
As graduates from the Hornsey College of Art in London (1962-1968), Sulaiman and fellow Malaysian art student Redza Piyadasa co-created a seminal artwork-cum-exhibition called “Towards a Mystical Reality: A Documentation of Jointly Initiated Experienced by Redza Piyadasa and Suleiman Esa” (TMR) at the Dewan Bahasa dan Pustaka (Institute of Language and Literature) in Kuala Lumpur from 2-7 August, 1974.  The exhibition showed an assortment of everyday objects and detritus but each indexing an event. In so doing, the artists presented a paradigm shift in how art was received and theorised in Malaysia at the time:  art became a means of critical enquiry and discussions about the definitions of art informed their enquiries and creations, where the art object was secondary to the ideas and experiences provoked by it.
  
For the inaugural exhibition of the Southeast Asia Gallery and to complement its archival display of the historic 1974 exhibition of TMR, the Gallery is commissioning the artist Sulaiman Esa (the surviving half of the duo) to produce a new work titled “A Mystical Reality Reinvented”, which looks back at TMR but interpreting this from the vantage point of today and also his own practice

title_text: The Mystical Reality Reinvented --Metamorphosis
physical_appearance: This work consists of three A3 sized photographic prints. The first of which shows a stained rain coat, the second captures a figure standing within an angular black perimeter with his/her head covered by a black conical hat, and the last being the same figure with his/her hands outstretched with his/her finger attached to some cords. The raincoat is also progressively stained over the course of the three images.

title_text: Figure of an immortal
physical_appearance: This is a sculpture of a man dressed in robes that cling to his body but flow with weight to his ankles. He stands atop a rock set amidst waves. He has his arms folded into his sleeves, and he dons a scholar's cap. His head tilts downwards to the left. A double gourd is seen to be fastened to his waist. Noticibly, there are small holes in the face of the figure.
subject_terms_1: gourd  Taoism deities
subject_terms_2: Gourds  Lü, Dongbin, 798-  Taoism  Ba Xian (Taoist mythology)  Deities
sgcool_label_text: This sculpture represents the continued interest and tradition in the production of bronzes in China, which had begun in the Shang dynasty (ca. 1600–1050 BCE). The figure exudes a sense of vitality through the billowing robes and the fluttering ribbons trailing from his cap. A double-gourd hangs from a cord fastened around the figure’s waist, which suggests that he is probably an immortal. The gourd was associated with longevity as well as protective and magical properties in Chinese culture. The figure may be Lü Dongbin, a Tang dynasty (618–907) poet and scholar who came to be venerated as one of the Eight Immortals in Daoism. Lü is regarded as the most influential of the Eight Immortals and is also revered as the Patriarch of the Daoist Quanzhen ?? (‘Complete Perfection’) Sect.

title_text: Jar with floral patterns
physical_appearance: The decorative scheme of this pale-slip jar is organized into three concentric circle with the central one being the largest. Both the top and bottom panels are filled with birds and floral sprays, while the middle panel consists of two large cartouches; one with a large blossom and the other with free-handed painted flowers and a butterfly. The base of the rim appears to either have discoloured or had not been fired properly.
subject_terms_1: lotus (motif)  birds (motifs)  flower (motif)  storage jars
subject_terms_2: Lotus in art  Birds in art Decorative arts Storage jars
sgcool_label_text: The decoration on this jar, which is executed in dark brown on a pale slip, consists of two large panels; one with a large lotus blossom and the other with freely-rendered flowers and a butterfly.

title_text: Carved Ebony and Ivory Box
physical_appearance: This is an ebony box with flower and scrolling leaf motifs carved all around. It is lidded and hinged, and has a key hole.
subject_terms_1: flower (motif)  scrolling foliage  jewelry boxes  exports
subject_terms_2: Ornamental boxes  Flowers in art floral decorations  Foliage plants  Colombo (Sri Lanka)
sgcool_label_text: This box of solid ebony is carved on all sides with bold flower and scrolling leaf designs which are known in Sri Lanka, Southern India and the Malay world as the floral pineapple motif.  The top is carved with a central sword-fruit flower motif.  Inside the box is a tray of lightly coloured wood with nine compartments, each with a lid inlaid with ebony and ivory which has been engraved with scrolling motifs and in-filled wtih black and red lac.  Boxes such as these were used in Sri Lanka by ladies to store jewellery and hair ornaments.  They were also produced for the colonial market.

title_text: Ancestor figure Hampatong
physical_appearance: This is a figural sculpture raised on a stump. The figure stands with his/her leg apart, and arms around the hips. The body is darkened brown, while the shoulder and head of the figure is of a lighter brown.

title_text: Deity Figure  Bulul
physical_appearance: This is a fetish figurine depicted to be in a squatting position with its hands folded in front.
subject_terms_1: indigenous people  magic  ancestor worship  sculpture
subject_terms_2: Fetishes (Ceremonial objects) Wood-carved figurines  Ifugao (Philippines people)  Ancestor worship  Protection magic  Figurative art Sculpture
sgcool_label_text: Bulul figures represent deified ancestors.  They were believed to be inhabited by living spirits which if properly looked after could keep away disease and misfortune. Bulul were often stored in rice granaries where they were believed to keep away marauding vermin and evil spirits alike. Figures carved in a squatting position are a widespread and archaic style common to many indigenous peoples around island Southeast Asia.

title_text: Ossuary figure
physical_appearance: This is a carved ossuary figure in a squatting position. Its palms are facing up and elbow resting on its kneecaps. The eye sockets are hollow and its teeth are bared.
subject_terms_1: indigenous people  magic  ancestor worship  ossuaries (funerary containers) sculpture
subject_terms_2: Fetishes (Ceremonial objects) Wood-carved figurines  Ossuaries  Ancestor worship  Protection magic  Figurative art Sculpture
sgcool_label_text: This figure would have originally adorned the end of a bone box or ossuary used to carefully store the remains of revered ancestors. It was found hidden deep inside a cave.  It is probably meant to represent an ancestor, a protecting spirit intended to frighten away thieves and evil spirits alike.  Ancestor figures carved in the form of a squatting man are found all over island Southeast Asia and are a common theme in the art of the Austronesian people.

sgcool_label_text: This is a half-portrait of Judge Hughes in three-quarter view, and set against a plain background.  It is not clear who Judge Hughes is although his choice of Chinese dress suggests his attempt at asserting his Chinese identity.  Coloured pigments were added directly onto this monochromatic photograph.  It is still mounted in its original frame.  Such portraits were hung in the halls of Peranakan homes to commemorate revered ancestors.  This bust portrait contains a signature of the sitter on the bottom right of the photograph.

title_text: Lamp
physical_appearance: This is a ceiling pendant lamp made up of three glass flower-shaped lamp shades with purple trimmings. It is supported and attached to the ceiling by a brass fixture.
subject_terms_1: Art Noveau  interior lighting  European
subject_terms_2: Art nouveau (Architecture)  Interior lighting
sgcool_label_text: This ceiling pendant lamp is comprised of three glass lamp shades with a floral pattern and purple trimmings.  It is supported by a brass fixture with curving decorative details that are reminiscent of the Art Nouveau style.  The Peranakans’ penchant for European-style furniture began from around the late 19th century.  English-styled teak furniture was displayed alongside Chinese blackwood furniture in Peranakan homes.  European designs were also adapted to suit Peranakan taste, such as the addition of Chinese motifs, gliding and mother-of-pearl inlays.  This fusion of influences and trends was also evident in Peranakan fashion and jewellery, and is one of the defining characteristics of Peranakan material culture.

title_text: Sarong Kecil
physical_appearance: This is a red on cream coloured sarong kecil. Flowering lotuses frame the central panel, where diagonal bands of blue, green, cream, and red filled with birds and flowering plants.
subject_terms_1: girls' wear  dyeworks lotus (motif) birds (motifs)  Peranakan
subject_terms_2: Floral decorations  Lotus in art  Birds in art Peranakan embroidery  Batik
sgcool_label_text: This piece is a sarong kecil, or a child’s tube-like skirt. Meant for a child’s body, it is significantly smaller than a normal sarong. The kepala (head) consists of multicoloured diagonal bands of blue, green, cream, and red, with a pattern of birds and flowering plants running through them. In the badan (body) section contains a large pattern of a lotus plant and birds.  When toddlers in a Peranakan household grew old enough, the girls would generally start wearing small sarongs, whereas the boys would move towards pantsuits. Sarong kecil are quite rare as most people did not want to devote such resources to clothing which would be quickly outgrown.

sgcool_label_text:
A practice she has been developing for five years, Melissa Tan’s initial investigations into landscapes included the examination of various fragments and varieties of rocks and rock formations with crystal clusters, whereby she began to observe and appreciate the complex structures of highly ordered crystal lattices as a metaphor for the process and production of contemporary art. 

Through experimentations with paper and metal, “If you can dream a better world you can make a better world or perhaps travel between them” features laborious and painstakingly hand-cut paper and laser-cut metal sculptures, which translate the continually expanding urban physical landscape and terrain of Singapore into abstract visual and sonic contemporary expressions.

title_text: Dollah Jawa
physical_appearance: There are four image clips taken from a video recording. On the most left, there is a portrait picture of a man. The second left-most photograph shows a family portrait of a couple and three children. The second right-most photo shows a royal man sitting on a throne chair and accompanied by three others. The right-most photograph shows a group of soldiers in uniform.
subject_terms_1: video recordings families (kinship groups) artists' films
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Video recordings Family recordings Malaya History Japanese occupation, 1942-1945 Video art
subject_terms_3: Installation art Films Family history 1942-1945 Japanese occupation
sgcool_label_text: Faizal Hamdan is a Bruneian artist born in Tutong, and raised in Bandar Seri Begawan. His practice is centered on the mediums of painting, sculpture and installation, and is often concerned with issues of materiality and tactility.  Commissioned for the 2016 Singapore Biennale (“An Atlas of Mirrors”), Faizal’s installation, Dollah Jawa, proffers the intersection of dual histories, macro and micro. In the telling of two intertwined tales, it engages on one hand with the neglected history of forced migration in Southeast Asia during the Second World War, and, on the other with the artist’s personal family history, which was the result of broader developments in the trajectory of the region’s past. Faizal’s grandfather, who hailed from West Java, was one of many Javanese who were forcefully expatriated to Brunei by the Japanese Army to serve the imperial troops during the war. He stayed on after the occupation ended, marrying a local woman and raising a family there. Those convergent historical vectors are materialised here in the form of visual images. Like dimly remembered figures from the past, or hazy memories of events occluded by dominant historical accounts, these images are cast as blurry projections on either side of a screen of fabric, the lack of pictorial definition seeming almost to serve as a metaphor for the erosive work of the passage of time. On one side of the screen, old photographs featuring Faizal’s grandfather – official portraits, sepia-tinged family snapshots – suggest familial ties, with some featuring fragments of scribbled notes on the back. On the other side are archival images from the Japanese Occupation in Brunei, which occurred from 1941 to 1945: these include, among others, the photograph of the arrival of Japanese troops in the sultanate, the then Sultan Ahmad Tajuddin with members of the occupying forces, an example of the ‘banana’ currency used during the occupation, and the Japanese surrender to the Australians at the end of the war.

title_text: The Wait Without Waiting
physical_appearance: There are two image clips taken from a video recording. In both clips, there is a still image of a road with a petrol kiosk in the background on the left. The image on the right has a yellow taxi on the road. The image on the right shows a small white lorry on the road. There are no people seen in either images.
subject_terms_1: streets taxicabs waiting video recordings
subject_terms_2: Video recordings Streets Taxicabs Waiting (Philosophy) Video Art
sgcool_label_text: Compositionally, The Wait without Waiting calls to mind the works Nighthawks (1942) and Twentysix Gasoline Stations (1963) and Standard Station, Amarillo Texas (1964) by American Realist painters, Edward Hopper and Ed Ruscha respectively. Sensationally too, The Wait draws the viewer to reflect on notions of identity, isolation and loneliness, echoing the impressions presented in Hopper and Ruscha’s renowned works. Stylistically, The Wait’s painterly quality arises out of the various ‘lines’ that cross the screen: the harsh horizontal and vertical lines marked out by the petrol station’s stationary silhouette along with the ‘green’ and ‘red’ taxis that brush past the screen work together to create a dynamic landscape that evokes both a sense of ‘stability’ and ‘instability’ that hangs in a fine balance. Through carefully crafted edits, that result in one footage presenting only available taxis and the other featuring only unavailable taxis, The Wait plays on the familiar emotions of satisfaction and frustration witnessed by individuals who attempt to hail taxis; “I edited the video separating the available and unavailable taxis, thereby also removing the actual waiting time of six hours. Then I stitched them all together into two separate channels, the taxis emerging continuously, seamlessly without wait,” explained the artist.

title_text: Rubbish
physical_appearance: The family image shows four pieces of paper products that have been designed to resemble pieces of rubbish, scattered on the ground. On the foreground there is a cigarette case. Above it, there is a flattered Mcdonalds cup. Beside the cup, there is a Snickers bar wrapper. Behind it, there is another wrapper.
subject_terms_1: waste replication (image-making processes) refuse disposal
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Litter (Trash) Consumption (Economics)
sgcool_label_text: Working with a strict methodology and set of criteria, Kentaro Hiroki handpicks everyday objects discarded on the streets to form the basis for his works. The things he chooses are intended to be reflective of time and space: unique to the localities in which he finds them, each object has its own story to tell of the communities it was found in. Once the artist has painstakingly replicated each found article into a detailed paper reproduction of the original items, the original value of these items in the economic context is replaced with an art object, its uselessness imbued with renewed meaningfulness. Each piece takes up to 4 four days to create, and Hiroki’s execution is simultaneously and exercise in translation and self-reflection.

title_text: History
physical_appearance: The images present a series of five rectangular textile artworks, placed side by side. They are mounted on a wall. All of the artworks have a similar border comprising of a black motif with red dots in the triangular, heart, and clubbed shape designs. The background of the artworks are yellow in colour. Each artwork depicts the outlines of two people standing side by side. They are holding hands and facing the viewer. All of them are barefoot. They are represented with ethnic costumes and headgears. Lao script has been embroidered on all five of the textile artworks.
subject_terms_1: motifs symbolism (artistic concept) depictions (visual works) ethnic groups folk costume genealogies (histories)
subject_terms_2: Motifs Symbolism Hmong (Asian people) Ethnic costume Family histories Appliqué Embroidery, Hmong
subject_terms_3: Ethnic costume Textile art and design Genealogy
sgcool_label_text: Phasao Lao’s History series is a rudimentary chronicle of his Hmong clan and its familial provenance. Each panel includes a black border of motifs that symbolise ‘spirits’, and an outline of different ancestors or leaders in red, the colour of strength and courage. But whereas oral and pictorial histories are more commonplace in Hmong culture, Lao has embroidered Lao script onto the fabric, placing significance on the posterity of both his artwork and his Hmong clan.

title_text: Tree Spirit Tree Spirit Tapestry
physical_appearance: This is a hanging tapestry. It has a white background, with repeated multicolored motifs. In the middle, there is a tall blue stick figure with circular patterns along its body. There are two other long black stick figures on either side. The tapestry is decorated with other figures and motifs of birds perched on hanging leaves. The tapestry is bordered by a repeated triangular scroll pattern.
subject_terms_1: birds (motifs) symbolism representation (forms of expression) embroidery (visual works) Hmong (culture or style)
subject_terms_2: Tapestry Motifs Symbolism Embroidery, Hmong
sgcool_label_text: Phasao Lao and Tcheu Siong are a Laotian husband and wife couple of Hmong ethnicity, who produce textile artworks that speak about the universal concepts of genealogy, movement and migration, and symbolism and representation. For the Singapore Biennale 2016, draped down one of the highest continuous walls in SAM are three tapestries of brilliant colour and design: Tree Spirit, Spirit of Sky and Earth 3 and Spirit of Sky and Earth 4 by Tcheu Siong. They bring a vivid array of curious and intriguing depictions into the tall gallery space. Hanging on the opposite wall, Phasao Lao’s History – a series of five fabric appliqué panels – traces the ancestral journey of the Hmong from Mongolia through the highlands of Lao to Luang Prabang, where his clan now resides. The couple’s partnership extends beyond that of marital ‘vows’. Though each of them has their own distinctive aesthetic and is an individual artist, both play a pivotal role in the other’s practice. Siong assists her husband by performing practical tasks in sewing and composition and Lao, as the village shaman, performs the more divinatory role of interpreter of her dreams. His interpretation of the creatures and abstract characters ‘witnessed’ in Siong’s dreams are then embodied in her large-scale textile art. Hmong textile and embroidery production is a traditional practice that is still used today as a marker of clan identity and cultural value, and features on clothing and accessories, in needlework traditions and ‘story clothes’ (pictorial embroidery). However, the works by Lao and Siong blend Hmong customs and culture through the use of textile motifs with figures and compositions that are uniquely their own. In her three works, Siong utilises a variety of design motifs that are typical of Hmong embroidery and story clothes: for example, the triangles that border her panels symbolise mountains, while the cluster of five circles with a dot in each symbolises a peacock ocellus. Particular to Siong’s repertoire of textile artworks are the lanky creatures that feature prominently on each panel. In the context of the animistic beliefs of the Hmong people, they represent ‘shadows’, ‘spirits’ or ‘souls’, which Lao as shaman distinguishes and names. To describe these panels – with their whimsical colours and seemingly childlike simplicity – as art brut, folk or naïve art would not be incorrect. But critical to their reception is also the recognition that these artworks reflect on the language of ‘self and society’ and the ‘spiritual and physical’ realms as perceived and experienced within the traditions and belief systems of contemporary Laos.

title_text: The Journey of Panji
materials_name: Ink canvas (textile material) acrylic paint wood (plant material)
physical_appearance: This installation depicts the collection of stories, the Wangbang Wideya, written by S.O. Robson, as a physical artwork. There is a large sculpture of the book on the ground, with letters spilling out from its sides. Behind the book, the letters lead up to a screen. On the screen are illustrated images of human figures in various scenes.
subject_terms_1: symbolism folk tales cartography (discipline) depictions (visual works) alphabets (symbols)
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Symbolism Panji Melayu Folk tales Cartography Prints Robson, S. O. (Stuart O.), 1941- Alphabets
sgcool_label_text: The Panji cycle is a collection of stories revolving around the legendary Prince Panji, which originated in Java around the 14th century and spread to what is now modern-day Malaysia, Cambodia, Myanmar, the Philippines and Thailand. It was only in the last century that these stories were gathered into a single volume, the Wangbang Wideya, by S.O. Robson.    The images in this artwork are taken from reliefs illustrating episodes from the Panji cycle. Their outlines are rendered in scripts, starting first with Javanese script, then flowing out into scripts reflecting the various regions and localities that this narrative has travelled to: a calligraphic cartography charting the movement of the Panji cycle throughout Southeast Asia. Even as the work reminds us of Southeast Asia’s shared cultural histories, the letters spilling out from the compendium of Panji stories suggest the impossibility of ‘containing’ Southeast Asia and the limits of any attempt to unify its histories or to conceive of the region as a singular entity.

title_text: Asking for Nothingness
materials_name: glass (material)  cork (bark)  wood (plant material)  photographic paper
physical_appearance: This is an installation comprising of multiple wooden open-shelf columns with glass bottles that have been filled with black and white photographs. The height of the columns tower over the average person, and the arrangement allows for the visitor to walk into and around the installation.
subject_terms_1: cultural heritage  elderly  group identity  memory
subject_terms_2: Heritage  Older people  Group identity  Collective memory  Installations (Arts)
sgcool_label_text: Asking for Nothingness is the largest work from Thai artist Navin Rawanchaikul’s series of bottle installations from the 1990s and rounds off a style that marked the artist’s early period of experimentation and social engagement, which included segues into assemblages and performances with intravenous injection bottles and bottled water. The bottle series started with a performance-installation titled Fon Pan-ya and Dee U-raporn in 1993, where the artist invited a pair of elderly villagers, one 72-year-old male and one 64-year-old female, in rural Chiang Mai to sit within two large vitrines holding two book covers embossed with details such as name, age and address, in order to highlight the disappearance of traditional values and modern society’s neglect of the elderly and illiterate.  This gradually morphed into black and white photographs of Thai villagers inserted into old medicine bottles and then displayed in wooden cabinets, buried into mud-filled wooden troughs or on tiered open-shelf columns – the last being the work There is No Voice (1993) which was also shown at the seminal exhibition “Traditions/Tensions” in New York. Asking for Nothingness expands on the presentation of There is No Voice, making it into a large-scale immersive room installation where the visitor meanders through the columns confronting or contemplating the myriad faces of the villagers.  Rawanchaikul’s message-in-a-bottle photographic archive of Chiang Mai's marginalised aged reaffirms the educational, historic, and cultural significance our seniors can imbue, if we take the time to preserve.

title_text: Untitled 2014 (curry for the soul of the forgotten)
physical_appearance: This is an installation that includes a bronze brazier placed in front of a video that shows the artist cooking with a brazier. This contextualizes the use of the object in an environment where the activity itself could not be replicated.
subject_terms_1: genre (visual works)  performance art cooking and heating devices
subject_terms_2: Art genres  Performance art Cooking, Thai Installations (Art)
sgcool_label_text:
Rirkrit Tiravanija was born in 1961 in Buenos Aires, Argentina and lives and works in Chiang Mai, Berlin and New York. He studied at the Ontario College of Art, Toronto, the Banff Center School of Fine Arts, Canada, the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, and the Whitney Independent Study Program, New York. Tiravanija’s invitation of audience participation through staging social events not usually undertaken within a gallery context informed the influential concept of ‘relational aesthetics’, coined by French curator Nicolas Bourriaud, which had a major impact on contemporary art in the 1990s. 

untitled 2014 (curry for the soul of the forgotten) is a development of Tiravanija’s renowned cooking performances, which he began in 1990. It features a bronze cookpot, evocative of ancient sculpture, which has been used to cook Thai curry near Tiravanija’s home in Chiang Mai. The accompanying video projection depicts the curry being cooked in the pot, as ‘documentation’ of the action. While the curry is cooking, the pot mysteriously moves across the platform, creating a sense of anticipation that is not entirely resolved. We don’t participate in, or even see, the eating of the meal; only the evidence of its production through the video and the blackened cookpot. Many of Tiravanija’s installations form the stage for events to take place, involving the viewer as part of the work. In this case, the artist creates a distance between the meal and the audience, who can only experience the work as evidence of an event that happened in the past.

This stand accompanies a lantern said to have been given to the Marquess and Marchioness Dalhousie by the merchants of Singapore during their visit to Singapore in 1850. 

The carved openwork panels depict animals, human figures, and floral patterns. The base features ferocious heads at the corners. Emerging from the mouth of each beast is a claw clutching a ball, a typical motif seen in Chinese furniture of the period.

title_text: Other Map Series Sri Lanka Map Series
materials_name: paper (fiber product) canvas (textile material) ink acrylic paint
physical_appearance: This is a set of five drawn maps of Sri Lanka. The five maps are of varied sizes. Each map is a multi-layered illustration, created by combining layers of maps, images of figures, colours and patterns. The artist retains some inscriptions from the official maps, but adds his own in various places. A few maps include a signature near the bottom.
subject_terms_1: cartography (discipline) representation (form of expression) interpretation colonialism
subject_terms_2: Maps Cartography Sri Lanka History colonies Imperialism Sri Lanka Maps
sgcool_label_text: Cartography is an act of history-making; history is created and interpreted by the act of mapping. Is it possible for an artist to look beyond officially constructed maps, and imagine a different past or an alternate future? Pothupitiye attempts to do so in this series, where he re-crafts the official version of maps to tell a different story. The maps he constructs are like palimpsests where he overlays, juxtaposes and transforms portraits of voyages, landscapes, mythical figures and other maps to re-inscribe stories of Sri Lanka’s past and present, interspersed with his own personal history. The maps he refers to range from Ptolemy’s maps of Ceylon to current maps of Sri Lanka. His atlas of maps tells many different stories simultaneously: of the deep scars of colonialism, the civil unrest and religious extremism of recent years, and also the lyrical beauty of a country that was once called Ceylon. (Text by Suman Gopinath, Singapore Biennale 2016 Assoc. curator, and curator of the artwork) Pala Pothupitiye (b. 1972, Deniyaya, Sri Lanka) obtained his BFA at the University of the Visual and Performing Arts in Colombo, Sri Lanka. Born into a traditional southern Sri Lankan caste of craft artists and ritualists, he incorporates and reinterprets the material and philosophical content of traditional art, to confront issues such as colonialism, nationalism, religious extremism and militarism, and extends his inquiry to questions of caste, the distinction between art and craft, tradition and modernity, as well as a critique of Eurocentrism. In 2005, he participated in the Fukuoka Asian Art Triennial and in 2010, he received the Sovereign Asian Art Prize. Pothupitiye is a founding member of the Theertha International Artists Collective.

title_text: Karagatan (The Breadth of Oceans)
materials_name: mother of pearl oil paint (paint) pearl (animal material)
physical_appearance: This installation art piece depicts 50 painted pearl pieces arranged in a line on the wall. On each of the pearl pieces, the artist has painted the image of an eye. The pearl pieces are of varies shapes and sizes.
subject_terms_1: symbolism eyes (motifs) allegory (artistic device) indigenous people
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Symbolism Eye Allegory (Art) Archipelagoes Philippines Indigenous people Filipinos
sgcool_label_text: Echoing the mystery of the mirror, this evocative installation does a poetic turn: in looking at the work, the work unnervingly looks back at you. Karagatan portrays the eyes of residents in coastal villages across the Philippines, ranging from fishermen to pearl divers, a master boat-builder to shell traders and others. The results of the artist’s research are delicate paintings that capture the tiny, distinctive characteristics of each subject’s eye: lines, curves and contours, which transform into unusual and unexpected portraits. As miniatures, the works draw upon a hallowed tradition associated with the royal courts, yet here, these tiny portraits map a community of coastal people who labour to harvest the bounty of the ocean but rarely reap its wealth. Halili pays homage to people whose fates and fortunes are bound to the ocean, limning their likeness on precious mother-of-pearl gleaned from the deep. Gregory Halili (b. 1975, Manila, the Philippines) carves and paints mother-of-pearl shells, creating memento moris. He received his BFA from the University of the Arts in Philadelphia and spent 25 years in the USA before returning to the Philippines. His work focuses on the art of miniatures, and he is interested in notions of memory, life, death and cycles. His work has appeared in numerous exhibitions and shows, including the Hammond Museum and Sculpture Garden (Salem, New York, 2001), Butler Institute of American Art (Youngstown, Ohio, USA, 2002), John Michael Kohler Arts Center (Sheboygan, Wisconsin, USA, 2003–2004), Nancy Hoffman Gallery (New York, 2014) and Silverlens Gallery (Singapore, 2015), and in the Philippines at the Ayala Museum (Makati City, 2005), Jorge B. Vargas Museum (University of the Philippines in Quezon City, 2006), West Gallery (Quezon City, 2011) and Silverlens Gallery (Makati City, 2014). He lives and works in Cavite, the Philippines.

title_text: The Most Mild Mannered Men
physical_appearance: This installation depicts two plinths, one supporting the bust of Sir Stamford Raffles, and the other left empty. The empty plinth has the name of Sultan Hussein Shah engraved upon a plaque. Both sculptures are white, and are positioned facing each other on opposite ends of the room.
subject_terms_1: busts (figures) allegory (artistic device) historical figures founders (originators)
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Busts Allegory (Art) Raffles, Thomas Stamford, Sir, 1781-1826
subject_terms_3: Installation art Raffles, Thomas Stamford Hussein Shah, Sultan 1819-1826 Founding and early years
sgcool_label_text: Driven by his concern about a growing historical amnesia, Fyerool Darma departs from his characteristic painting practice to present marble busts of two key figures in Singapore history: an appropriated bust of Sir Stamford Raffles by Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey, and a bustless pedestal inscribed with the name, birth and death dates of Sultan Hussein Mua’zzam Shah. Both Raffles and Sultan Hussein played pivotal roles in the signing of two treaties that resulted in the founding of modern Singapore, and this artwork seeks to uncover the relationships between them. The way these men are represented symbolises the partisanship of various narratives about them in historical discourse, reiterating the sentiment that history is often written by the dominant – in this case, the British – the very writing of which occludes other accounts and perspectives.

title_text: Monkeys in the House
materials_name: wood (plant material) paper (fiber product) clay paint (coating)
physical_appearance: This installation depicts three monkeys in a room with a cabinet and a desk with books. One monkey is on the ground on the left. Another is perched on top of the cabinet in the middle. The third is sitting on top of the desk on the right, with its hand on an open book. Beside the monkey, there is a stack of books. Some books have fallen on the floor by the desk.
subject_terms_1: monkeys (animals) symbolism chaos analogy sculpture (visual works) social issues
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Monkeys Symbolism Analogy Sculpture
sgcool_label_text: Living and working in an area with a high monkey population, Sakarin Krue-on inadvertently finds himself with, quite literally, Monkeys in the House on a number of occasions. Drawing on these personal experiences, the work which features 3 hand-sculpted monkeys invading a home-space is intended by the artist to portray the undesired disturbances which proliferate though multiple aspects of our everyday life – be it in within the private sphere, public spheres, or political spheres. The presence of the monkeys juxtaposes the otherwise neat and ordered space – and because within the same space, the civilised and the uncivilised are brought together to make clear that the “primitive” is not one of another time, but exists in simultaneity with the modern. While the monkeys have been portrayed as being relatively tame at the point in time when they are spotted, with destruction of the space still limited to some displaced books and partially torn page, the sense of impending chaos looms heavily on the scene – lest negotiations/actions take place promptly to circumvent the expected consequence.  It is in this regard that Monkeys in the House do not merely serve as a visual analogy for the range of similar situations which seemingly proliferate our lives, but a parable on arresting these problems before situations worsen or they get completely out of hand.

title_text: Rat House
physical_appearance: This installation depicts a rat house. The house stands on four wooden pillars. The body of the house has a layered exterior, with numerous holes and windows. The face of the house is decorated with vibrant colours and patterns. In each window, there is an image of a person.
subject_terms_1: mixed media allegory (artistic device) interactive art symbolism social issues dwellings gambling
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Mixed media (Art) Allegory (Art) Interactive art Symbolism Dwellings Gambling
sgcool_label_text: Inspired by a gambling game popular among Thai-Chinese people in the past, Sakarin Krue-on’s contemporary re-interpretation of the traditional rat house retains its associations with the human tendency of gambling and risk taking, yet in incorporating a video element to the work, Rat House, 2014 extends its critique beyond these human impulses alone to include a critique of the post-modern living condition in relation to our intrinsic nature as well. Furthermore, the structure of Rat House, 2014 in being seemingly comprised by a multitude of smaller houses stands as a mirroring of contemporary living conditions in which people living in cities with high population densities often find themselves accommodated in shoebox apartments as they live out their lives in a perpetual “rat-race”.  In resurrecting a contemporary iteration of the tradition rat house, Sakarin’s use of tempera paints for the designs and motifs of the house pays homage to century old traditions of Thai art-making practices, effectively re-introducing to audiences an age old artefact re-inscribed with issues of the contemporary.

title_text: Talapa Chetti Melaka or Headgear
physical_appearance: This is a talapa or headgear. It is made from batik fabric, with multicolored batik patterns and colours. There is a small triangle in the middle of the headgear.
subject_terms_1: cultural diffusion folk costume
subject_terms_2: Headgear Culture diffusion Batik ethnic costume
sgcool_label_text: The Peranakan Indians (also known as Chetti Melaka) have a 500 year history in the region. Historically, south Indian traders who operated in the Malacca straits intermattied with Chinese and Malay women giving birth to a hhybrid community with an eclectic culture. The culture of Peranakan Indian community is a reflection of their multi-ethnic origins; their language,dress, cuisine and lifestyle are a combination of Indian, Malay and Chinese components. Gajah Berang in Malacca is uniquely Chetti Melaka settlement that Peranakan Indians in Malaysia and Singapore trace their oirgins to. The Peranakan Indians also remain staucnh Hindus celebrating Hindu festivals. This is a traditional talapa or headgear worn by the Peranakan Indian men. Made from batik fabric, the name talapa is a Tamil word; this headgear is but one aspect of the community's hybrid culture.

title_text: Kebaya
physical_appearance: This is a white kebaya voile with machine embroidered flower designs along its hem and edges. It has a tapered end, and is a piece that is worn in a loose, open jacket fashion.
subject_terms_1: flower (motif)  foliage (motif)  womenswear  Sino-Japanese War, 1937-1945 folk costume
subject_terms_2: Straits Settlements  Floral decorations  Foliation (Architecture and design)  Peranakan embroidery  Sino-Japanese War, 1937-1945 Ethnic costume
subject_terms_3: Textile art and design  1942-1945 Japanese occupation Peranakan costumes
sgcool_label_text: This white kebaya has a faint white pattern of flowers and foliage on the cloth, and a white machine-made embroidered flower motif around its borders. The kebaya is a loose open jacket usually worn by Peranakan women of the Straits Settlements, Indonesia and Indo-European women of the late 19th to 20th century. It has embroidered edges that imitate the look of lace, which became popular during the mid-twentieth century and replaced lace as the decoration of choice along the border of the blouses. Its tapered ends was also popular during this time period. This kebaya belonged to a Chinese woman who was living in Java during the Japanese Occupation. She took on Peranakan dress and identity to adopt as low a profile  as possible in order not to attract attention

title_text: Kebaya
physical_appearance: This is a red on white kebaya voile with floral motifs lining its hems, sleeves, and edges. The material is sheer, and is worn as an open jacket.

sgcool_label_text: This pink and white kebaya has a check pattern running throughout the cloth, with embroidered flowers around the border. The kebaya is a loose open jacket usually worn by Peranakan women of the Straits Settlements, Indonesia and Indo-European women of the late 19th to 20th century. It has embroidered edges that imitate the look of lace, which became popular during the mid-twentieth century and replaced lace as the decoration of choice along the border of the blouses. Its tapered ends was also popular during this time period. Coloured pieces also became popular over white kebayas during this era. This kebaya belonged to a Chinese woman who was living in Java during the Japanese Occupation. She took on Peranakan dress and identity to adopt as low a profile  as possible in order not to attract attention.
