title_text: Wooden carriage
materials_name: wood (plant material)  metal  glass (material)  gilding (material)  lacquer (material)
physical_appearance: This is a wooden carriage whose body has been intricately carved, gilded, and lacquered with scenes of Chinese mythical animals and scrolling foliage. Two lamps are attached to the front of the vehicle, and the roof of the carriage is supported by four pillars.  Yellow tussles dangle from along the perimeter of this roof.
subject_terms_1: qilin phoenixes  scrolling foliage  ceremonial objects Peranakan
subject_terms_2: Qilin Phoenix  Foliation (Architecture and design)  Ceremonial objects Peranakan (Asian people)
sgcool_label_text: This rare wooden carriage was likely used as part a Chinese Peranakan ceremony known as Tedun in Central Java.  Its shape is reminiscent of European horse-drawn carriages.  It has a top that is supported by four tubular pillars.  Its surface is carved, gilded and lacquered with motifs inspired by Javanese and Chinese cultures.  These include Javanese-style scrolling foliage, and Chinese mythical animals, qilin and phoenix.  Tedun is an important ceremony that marks either the child’s first year or when the child begins to walk.  During the ceremony, the child will be seated in this carriage and taken around a chicken cage three times.  The child then selects object(s) from the cage that symbolically represent(s), and pre-dict(s) his/her personality and interests.

title_text: Handkerchief
physical_appearance: This is a multicoloured batik with three drawn-thread  panels of geoemtric patterns running along the perimeter of its borders. Interspersed, are various animals that also appear throughout the cloth. Central to this piece is a medallion consisting of scrolling foliage and animals, and is in itself, surrounded by other birds.
subject_terms_1: geometric motifs  scrolling foliage  birds (motifs)  batik art  Peranakan
subject_terms_2: Geometry in art Foliation (Architecture and design)  Birds in art Batik Indonesia  Peranakan (Asian people)
sgcool_label_text: This handkerchief is made from a single silk batik base, with a circular central medallion pattern consisting of plants and birds, surrounded by more birds circling around it. It has three drawn-thread patterns around the border, consisting of both geometrice patterns and animals. Judging by the hole in the centre, this cloth was possibly used as a handkerchief pinched between the fingers, or with a bunch of keys tied to the centre. This piece is particularly rare due to the embroidery technique - the drawn-thread pattern is usually only done once around the border. Thread-drawn embroidery is not unique to Peranakan culture, and was practiced by other ethnic groups in Java and Sumatra in the early 20th century. However, the combination of the embroidery and Chinese motifs make it highly likely that this piece is from the Chinese-Peranakan community.

physical_appearance: The is an abstract painting comprising of overlapping strokes of paint. Most of the strokes are congregated in the center of the composition, where horizontal strokes break into the swirl of overlapping colours.
subject_terms_1: abstraction
subject_terms_2: Art, Abstract Ink painting, Chinese
sgcool_label_text: Zao Wou-ki (1920 - 2013) is a Chinese-French artist who was recognised internationally as a significant figure in the modernist movement of Post-World War II. He was also regarded as a leading master in the context of the modern Asian art, and was widely considered to be one of the most successful living Chinese artists. 3.5.62 is a good example of Zao's early abstract imagery. As shown in this example, Zao's abstract schema is often framed within stable and simplified structures sectioned by horizontal segments. In the middle of the composition, forces and tensions are generated by layered interweaving colours and brushstrokes, which echo atmospheric energy and natural momentum. The imagery denotes the spiritual essence of the landscape-and-mountain painting in the tradition of Chinese art.

title_text: Cu?i Cùng (The End)
physical_appearance: This is a semi-abstract painting in an off-white colour. A black stroke runs horizontally  across the upper half of the canvas, and in it lies a skeleton. A pair of wooden Vietnamese shoes have been painted to be neatly placed facing the corpse in the bottom left corner.
subject_terms_1: abstraction deaths  life
subject_terms_2: Art, Abstract Life Death
sgcool_label_text: Artist Nguy?n Lâm’s work is a strong representation of the cosmopolitan tendencies of the art world of Saigon (now known as Ho Chi Minh City) in the 1960s. Born in Can Tho in Vietnam’s south in 1941, Nguy?n Lâm came to prominence at an early age. He was a member of the Saigon Young Artist’s Association, a dynamic group of artists who strove to bring greater innovation to the art scene in Saigon. He was selected for representation in many international platforms in the period, including the Paris biennales of 1961 and 1963, and the Sao Paulo biennale of 1967. He was also one of the youngest Vietnamese artists to be represented at Saigon’s First International Art Exhibition of 1962. This artwork is a semi-abstract composition imbued with symbolic references. It represents a textured, off-white field of colour, traversed by a dark channel. Figured subtly within the central channel of paint is the image of a corpse, while a pair of traditional Vietnamese wooden shoes interrupt the composition in the bottom right corner. The work is a mediation on life and death, and the traces of life remaining after death.

title_text: 1941 RAF map of the Malay Peninsular
physical_appearance: This is an annotated map of the Malay Peninsular. The map is printed in multiple colours including black, beige and red. There are several penned annotations, marking out places and interest, written in blue ink. The map is quite worn, with the fold lines stained and the edges creased and slightly torn.
subject_terms_1: prisoners of war world wars military officers
subject_terms_2: Maps Great Britain, Royal Air Force Prisoner of war World War, 1939-1945 Malay Peninsula
subject_terms_3: 1942-1945 Japanese occupation Great Britain, Royal Air Force
sgcool_label_text: This map belonged to George Dudley Binsted, a former Changi POW. This map of the Malay Peninsular was issued by the Royal Air Force (RAF), which Binsted had kept throughout his years of captivity and after. The map contains hand markings, which were believed to be the escape route he had planned. Binsted joined the Royal Air Force in 1941 and had flown Spitfires over France before being posted to Java. After the fall of Singapore in February 1942, Binsted along with four others, were captured by the Japanese. They were transported by ship to Singapore, where they spent the next three and a half years as POWs in Changi Prison.

The letters 'RAF' are embroided in the middle, with a wreath bordering it. The wings are embroided with two shades of beige thread, on a black base.

sgcool_label_text: This embroidered set of RAF wings belonged to George Dudley Binsted, who joined the Royal Air Force (RAF) in 1941 and had flown Spitfires over France before being posted to Java. After the fall of Singapore in February 1942, Binsted along with four others, were captured by the Japanese. They were transported by ship to Singapore, where they spent the next three and a half years as POWs in Changi Prison. While in captivity, Binsted created this set of RAF wings from scratch, using scraps of thread he could find in prison.

title_text: Mian Pratap Chand of Lambagraon hunting with the minister Shiva
physical_appearance: Bordering the main image are gold and white floral arabesques. Central to the scene are three white horses, upon which sits a man each. They are depicted to be bent over with a sword in their right hand; in the act of slashing their preys. Pratap Chand hunted a gazelle, whilst his other two companions brought down a boar and a young pig. In the distance to the right, two deers have been depicted to be hurrying off into the confines of the bushes.

title_text: Carved Wooden Pawukon Calendar with Lime Highlights
physical_appearance: This is a wood carving of a Balinese calendar. It is carved with a loop on an elongated neck on the left. Along the bottom, there is a single row of drilled holes. The face of the plank is engraved with 210 squares. The squares are marked with a series of crosses and circles, with some marked with a small stud. The edges of the engraving are whitened and highlighted. The calendar looks slightly worn out.
subject_terms_1: Balinese ways of life customs (social concepts)
subject_terms_2: Wood-carving Calendars Balinese (Indonesian people) Lifestyles Manners and customs
sgcool_label_text:
Calendars were used on Bali and Lombok to determine the correct time for festivals, rituals associated with rice planting, and horoscopes. Calendars were either painted on cotton cloth, or carved from wooden boards as with the example here. 
The front of this board is entirely engraved with 210 squares (seven days by thirty weeks - this being a full year in the Balinese Pawukon calendar of 210 days) and these are marked with a series of crosses and circles. Some of the squares are also marked with small metal studs. The reverse is engraved with 35 squares (seven days by five weeks for the Balinese/Lombok month of 35 days). The engraving is highlighted with lime powder which has been rubbed into the depressions.

title_text: Carved Wooden Calendar with Lime Highlights
physical_appearance: This is a wood carving of a Lombok calendar. It is carved with a stylised bird on the right with a leafy border. The face of the calender shows 35 squares that are engraved with a series of crosses, lines, circles and other markings. It is bordered by another leafy edge on the left. The edges of the engraving are highlighted with white and faded edges.
subject_terms_1: ways of life birds (motifs) Balinese customs (social concepts)
subject_terms_2: Wood-carving Calendars Lombok (Indonesia) Lifestyles Motifs Manners and customs

title_text: Rampant Series
materials_name: gelatin  paper (fiber product)  silver sulfide  baryta paper
techniques_name: gelatin silver process photographic printing techniques black-and-white photography
physical_appearance: This is a series of 7 black-and-white photographs focusing on natural landscapes that include bamboo, bananas, camphor laurels, and sugar can groves. Lungis and sarongs were hung and/or dressed on these plants. All prints have been framed with a black frame.
subject_terms_1: nature photography  sarongs bamboo (plant)  Cinnamomum camphora (species)  Saccharum (genus)
subject_terms_2: Nature photography  Photography, Artistic Bamboo Camphor tree Sugarcane New South Wales
sgcool_label_text: In Rampant, Simryn Gill photographed bamboo, bananas, camphor laurels and sugar cane groves in northern New South Wales, Australia. The plants are dressed with lungis and sarongs—garments from South and Southeast Asia, where many of these plants originated. Over time, these plants, once only found in South and Southeast Asia, became part of the Australian landscape. Some even came to be regarded as weeds that threaten the native flora, a point to which the title of the work alludes

title_text: Hotel Le Royal
physical_appearance: This painting depicts a scene in the dining room of the Hotel Le Royal. Comprised of vibrant colours, there are a multitude of figures that pepper the scene. To the right is a long table filled with Asian officials in suit and tie. A feast lays before them. To the left, are diners seated in separate tables. It is peculiar that these guests are not depicted with feet. In the top left corner, several individuals are identified as chefs for they are in aprons and a chef hat.  A clock sits above the main door, which is flanked by two images of dancers in traditional costume.
subject_terms_1: figurative art  hotels (public accomodations)  genre (visual works)  dining halls  social classes  naïve art  social status
subject_terms_2: Phnom Penh (Cambodia)  Genre painting Arts, Cambodian Outsider art Dining rooms  Cambodians  Social classes  Social status
context_20: Hotel Le Royal (now Raffles Hotel Le Royal)
context_21: 92 Kukhak Vithei Daun Penh, Sangkat Wat Phnom, Phnom Penh, Cambodia
sgcool_label_text: Svay Ken (1933-2008) is a significant figure in the emergence of contemporary art practice in Cambodia. Beginning to paint in the early 1990s, his work turned away from creating picturesque images of Cambodia, instead creating autobiographical or narrative images in a naïve style, connecting the grand narratives of Cambodian history and culture to the intimacy of daily life. The painting Hotel Le Royal documents the scene of the dining room in the hotel where Svay Ken worked for many years of his life. Painted in his characteristic, brightly-coloured naïve style, the work is rich with visually-engaging anecdotal observations of life in Cambodia in the 1990s. On the left-hand side of the work, a gathering of Asian officials attend a formal banquet.Elsewhere in the dining room, foreign, Western couples dine in luxury. Cambodian figures are present in the image only as workers: serving diners in the hall, or in the upper right section devoted to the chefs. The work therefore represents the social divide in Cambodia between wealthy foreign visitors and local Cambodians, as Cambodia was newly emerging from the privations of decades of civil war and the trauma of the Khmer Rouge period.

subject_terms_2: Lithography Orientalism  Opium abuse Exoticism in art  Singapore  Drawing  Colour prints
sgcool_label_text: This is a print from Hugo V Pedersen's book, Door den Oost-Indischen Archipel, which charted his travels in the East Indian Archipelago. The print was based on an actual sketch of a Chinese opium den in Singapore, which is presented as a dark, mystical place. Pedersen was a Danish artist who travelled to the Far East, including Singapore, in 1895.

context_1: The Duke and Duchess of Connaught's visit to Singapore
sgcool_label_text: This is a montage of scenes related to the visit of the Duke and Duchess of Connaught to Singapore in 1890. Connaught Drive, a new road at the Esplanade along the reclaimed sea front was named in honour of their visit, with the Duke and Duchess being the first users of the road upon their arrival in Singapore on 25 March 1890.

column52: which describes the scene depicted at 5 am
column53: with searchlights being flashed upon the liner and a torpedo-boat destroyer approaching to identify the ship. The scene of the passagers on board the liner

title_text: Rubbing of the stele commemorating Christianity in China
physical_appearance: These are three rectangular ink on paper rubbings; the largest of which commemorates the propagation of the religion from Da Qin in China. At the top of 001 is a Nestorian cross set amidst lotus blossoms. The inscriptions are in standard chinese and Syriac script; all written in a vertical fashion and read from top-down, right to left.
subject_terms_1: lotus (motif)  Nestorian (Christian sect)  stelae crosses (motifs)  inscriptions Syriac scripts Chinese scripts  Christianity
subject_terms_2: Lotus in art Church of the East Stele (Archaeology)  Nestorian tablet of Sian-fu Syriac language  Inscriptions Chinese language  Christianity
sgcool_label_text:
This rubbing reproduces the text on a stone stele erected in Xi’an in 781. At the very top is a cross set into a lotus blossom. The title reads: “Monument commemorating the propagation in China of the luminous religion from Da Qin” ?????????. 

The text in Chinese and Syriac (a dialect of Aramaic) describes the arrival of the Christian Church of the East in China in the 7th century. In 635, the Taizong Emperor issued an edict of tolerance for the religion. The Church of the East claimed to have Roman (Da Qin) origins to avoid association with Persia and Zoroastrianism. 

The stele was buried in 845 because of the persecution of foreign religions, and only rediscovered in 1625. It soon came to the attention of Jesuit missionaries in China, who were excited to find evidence of early Christianity in China.

title_text: Tea jar
physical_appearance: This is squared tea jar with panels on each side. Each panel is depicts a dragon chasing after a pearl.
subject_terms_1: tea (beverage)  storage vessels  dragons
subject_terms_2: Dragons in art Tea containers  Zhongguo wen hua xi lie  Pottery, Chinese
sgcool_label_text:
This squared tea jar is decorated on each side with panels showing two dragons chasing a pearl amongst the clouds. The model is probably inspired by Dutch pewter examples of tea jars. Similar shaped tea jars are also commonly produced in blue and white porcelain during the 18th century. The warm brown tone is the result of the low sand content of the clay, which comes from Yixing in Jiangsu province, eastern China. 

The Yixing kilns are known to have produced high quality ceramics, particularly teapots, from as early as the 16th century. The tea jars are not usually glazed, but burnished and fired. Yixing wares are popular domestically and abroad.

title_text: Complimentary admission passes to Singapore History Museum
physical_appearance: \This is a complimentary pass ticket for entry into the Singapore History Museum. The ticket has perforations that separates the ticket into three stubs; the first indicates that it is an SHM Complimentary Pass with the ticket number 202739
subject_terms_1: the second and third are identical and both indicate that it is valid for single visits only
subject_terms_2: and carries the National Heritage Board logo. An image of a pair of sanndals
subject_terms_3: and the word \"\"Complimentary Pass\"\" runs vertically down the side of the two latter stubs. \""
context_1: Singapore. National Heritage Board  Singapore History Museum  Museum tickets  national museums (institutions)
context_2: Singapore History Museum  Singapore. National Heritage Board  Museums  National Museum (Singapore)
column53: This complimentary one-time admission pass allowed entrance for a maximum of 4 people to the Singapore History Museum and its regular exhibitions. In 1993, the National Museum became part of the National Heritage Board (NHB) and the national collection of paintings, archaeological wares, ethnographical and historic material were then split into three different museums. The Singapore History Museum was housed in the museum’s original premises at Stamford Road. Following the museum’s redevelopment in 2006, the institution was renamed as the National Museum of Singapore.

title_text: Samuel Withers Safe used by Ministry of Law
physical_appearance: This is a black metal safe. It is rectangular cuboid in shape, with a door that swings outwards on the front. The front has a silver metal handle attached to it in the center, beside a turn combination lock. Above it, is a trademark inscription of the company. The door has a thin red border.
subject_terms_1: government employees government records
subject_terms_2: Safes Singapore. Ministry of Law Ho, Peng Kee Barker, Eddie, 1920-2001 Public records
subject_terms_3: Singapore. Ministry of Law Indranee Rajah Ho, Peng Kee Barker, E. W.
sgcool_label_text: This Samuel Withers safe was used by three political office holders at the Ministry of Law: Ms Indranee Rajah, Associate Professor Ho Peng Kee and Mr Edmund William Barker. E.W Barker was a first-generation minister in Singapore’s post-independence cabinet who served as Minister of Law from 1964 to 1988. He was responsible for drafting Singapore’s separation documents in 1965 – an agreement to separate, an amendment to the Malayan Constitution to allow Singapore to separate and the Proclamation of Singapore’s independence.

title_text: Photographs of Dr Joseph M Carrier 1962-1973
physical_appearance: This is a black-and-white print of a bowl of flower petals (?). The image is placed within a white frame.
subject_terms_1: black-and-white prints (prints on paper)  histories (literature genre)  flower pieces? travel photography
subject_terms_2: Black & White Pictures  Carrier, Joseph M.  Genre prints  Travel photography  Flowers
sgcool_label_text: Born in Vietnam in 1975 and brought up in Denmark, Danh Vo’s conceptual artworks and installations often draw upon elements of personal lived experience (his own, the lives of his parents and other family members) to explore broader historical, social or political themes, particularly those relating to the history of Vietnam at the close of the twentieth century. The photos were taken by Joseph Carrier, an American working in Vietnam. Like the objects owned by McNamara and JFK in Danh’s Mother Tongue show, or Martin Wong’s possessions in IMU UR2, the acquisition and appropriation of the photos become part of the work. That is, the history of the object matters. Here, meaning slides between US involvement in Vietnam, Carrier’s history and Danh’s own history.

title_text: Red House
physical_appearance: This photo installation depicts three red cloth-house sculptures, photographed against a backdrop of rural Laotian landscape. The three red houses are positioned in the center, surrounded by a large field. There are three farmers seen in the photograph beside one of the houses.
subject_terms_1: mixed media allegory (artistic device) symbolism communism photographs
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Mixed media (Art) Allegory (Art) Symbolism Laos History Communism Photographs China Southeast Asia
sgcool_label_text: The works by Bounpaul Phothyzan go against the typical grain of contemporary thought and art production in Laos. ‘Red House’ is a photo installation that comprises 5-framed photographs and a red cloth-house sculpture. Three red cloth wrapped house-structures are photographed against a backdrop of rural Laotian landscape. Used to symbolize the three red ‘houses’ of communism in the region – China, Vietnam and Laos, this work casually accesses the influence of China and Vietnam in Laos through the documenting of its changing scenery. In one image, we can imagine ourselves bearing witness to the crude unfurling of sky rise buildings that Chinese investment companies have been backing in under-tapped Laos. The bizarreness of sky scrapers as they abruptly punctuate the horizon line are significant as a demonstration of how China is attempting to gain a footing into Southeast Asia: swiftly and crudely. The polished and poetic capturing of ‘Red House’ belies the expansive socio- and geo-political influences China and Vietnam have on Laos.

title_text: Rajun Gardener (“New Migrants” series)
physical_appearance: This is a portrait of a moustached man. The background is composed of a composition of shapes, and the man has been depicted to be gazing directly at the viewer. The work is framed and a tag with the man's details is found beneath the image of the man.
subject_terms_1: migrant workers  blue collar workers
subject_terms_2: Portrait  Serigraphy  Dhaka (Bangladesh)  Malaysia  Immigrants  Migrant workers  Art, Malaysian
context_1: \This portrait was third in the series of \"\"New Migrant\"\" portraits shown in \"\"Of Migrants and Rubber Trees\"\" exhibition \""
sgcool_label_text: Rajun, Gardener is third in the series of “New Migrant” portraits, which was first shown in “Of Migrants and Rubber Trees”, a seminal exhibition by Malaysian artist Wong Hoy Cheong, held at the National Art Gallery in Kuala Lumpur, in August 1996. (The exhibition was curated by Malaysian gallerist Valentine Willie.) To date, Wong’s oeuvre had largely comprised brightly-coloured oil paintings reminiscent of Gauguin, but in the mid-1990s his practice took a turn: while still critically engaged with the historical and socio-political landscape of Malaysia, his works began to embrace contemporary forms like performance, installation and new media. The work emerged from a significant period in Wong’s artistic practice. The period of Wong’s artistic career from the mid-1990s to the early 2000s, in fact, coincided with a transitional moment in Malaysia’s politics (with the latter informing and inspiring the former). Wong was deeply engaged with the issues and concerns that reflect the trajectories of his country’s post-war development – an era that saw the emergence of Malaysia as one of the leading economies of SE Asia, but one that also witnessed the rise of racialism and race-based politics. In the late 1990s, the Reformasi movement arose from the very visible fallout that occurred in the wake of Anwar Ibrahim’s deposition by then-PM Mahathir: an active citizenry was mobilized to call for deep, structural reforms in the nation’s notoriously corruption-laden political culture, and Wong found himself caught up – both personally and artistically – in the tumult. The “New Migrants” series was first show in the aforementioned exhibition, which also included the “Migrants” series (which consisted of five large drawings detailing the history of Wong’s own Sino-Malaysian family), “History of Rubber and Labour” (an installation documenting the rubber trade in Malaysia and the migrant labour that sustained it). “New Migrants” was a series of ten, large-scale portraits – of, literally recent immigrants to Malaysia, generally of the blue-collar variety and hailing from poorer countries in Asia – rendered in charcoal, on paper.

title_text: Endless Hours at Sea
physical_appearance: This installation depicts the movement of water through mixed medium. There is a projection of light that reflects on the water on a screen. Beneath the screen, there is a large case with a video projection of the ocean.
subject_terms_1: projections (visual works) seas mixed media seascapes videography marine (of the ocean)
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Projection art Seas Mixed media (Art) Video recording Multimedia (Art)
sgcool_label_text:
Endless Hours at Sea is an exploration of the tempestuous emotional and psychological relationship humankind has with water. Seas and oceans have often been regarded as territories to be charted and conquered. Yet to actually voyage on watery expanses is to exist in a liminal space: always a ‘somewhere’ between leaving and arriving, and a ‘nowhere’ forever surrounded by ever-changing wind and weather conditions. This multimedia installation brings together material Atienza recorded from four oceanic journeys on cargo ships, and immerses the viewer in the constant state of flux that characterises life on board these vessels. As more than 400,000 Filipinos work ‘overseas’, this is an artistic journey that also finds echoes in the experiences of many of her countrymen. Endless is ultimately a work that reverberates close to home for Atienza – almost all her family is involved in the maritime industry, including her grandfather who was a lighthouse keeper.

The work of Martha Atienza (b. 1981, Manila, the Philippines) is sociological in nature, reflecting a keen observation of her immediate environment. She understands her surroundings as a landscape of people, first and foremost, and is currently investigating the usage of art as a tool for effecting social change and development. Atienza received her BFA from the AKI Academy of Art and Design in Enschede, the Netherlands and has participated in the art programme at the Kuvataideakatemia of the University of the Arts Helsinki, Finland. In 2015, she received the Thirteen Artists Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines, and in 2012, she received the Ateneo Arts Award, with residency grants in Liverpool, Melbourne, New York and Singapore. In 2016, she was the recipient of the first Mercedes Zobel/Outset residency at the gallery Gasworks in London. She lives and works in Bantayan Island, the Philippines and Rotterdam, the Netherlands.

object_work_type: shaped canvases (paintings by form) canvas paintings
title_text: Cicadas #2
physical_appearance: This is a shaped canvas painting. There are lines of red that course through the work.
subject_terms_1: screen prints  Cicadidae (family) wings (animal components) abstraction
subject_terms_2: Shaped canvas  Acrylic painting  Cicadas in art  Wings  Abstraction Art, Singaporean
sgcool_label_text:
Cicadas #2 brings together two interests that have coursed through Genevieve Chua’s practice: nature and the wild, as well as the intertwining relationship between sound and image. Part of Chua’s ‘Unnatural History Drawings’, the shaped canvas takes as its starting point, the extensive collection of natural history drawings that were commissioned by William Farquhar in the early 19th century. With an abiding interest to explore abstraction in painting, the work also incorporates the ultrasound image as a means to probe the relationship between sound and vision, and how sensorial experiences can translate across one other. Chua’s use of the ultrasound gestures towards the realm of possibility of what lies beyond the range of human sensory detection, as made realisable by science and technology. 

Cicada #2 evokes the shape of the insect delicately unfolding its damp wings after its period of dormancy, a phase and life ‘lived’ buried underground for 17 years for some species of cicadas. Waking as a thunderous force after dormancy, the cicadas collectively produce a deafening song during the mating season, only to die shortly after. Sex and impending demise are conjoined in the cicada song, a sonic cry that finds translation into the visual realm through the ultrasound pattern on the painting’s surface that is rendered based on the cicadas’ mating call. 

Genevieve Chua (b. 1984, Singapore) is a visual artist who works primarily through abstraction. Selected solo exhibitions include “Rehearsals for the Wilful” (Manila, 2016); “Parabola” (Singapore, 2014); and “Cicadas Cicadas” (Los Angeles, 2014). She has also participated in the Singapore Biennale (2011), and was the Young Artist Award in 2012 conferred by the National Arts Council, Singapore.

physical_appearance: This is a shaped canvas painting. There are splashes of white across the canvas comprising of a series of dots.

subject_terms_2: Shaped canvas  Acrylic painting  Moths in art Orchids in art  Abstraction Prints  Art, Singaporean
sgcool_label_text:
Moth #5 brings together two interests that have coursed through Genevieve Chua’s practice: nature and the wild, as well as the intertwining relationship between sound and image. Part of Chua’s ‘Unnatural History Drawings’, the shaped canvas takes as its starting point, the extensive collection of natural history drawings that were commissioned by William Farquhar in the early 19th century. With an abiding interest to explore abstraction in painting, the work also incorporates the ultrasound image as a means to probe the relationship between sound and vision, and how sensorial experiences can translate across one other. Chua’s use of the ultrasound gestures towards the realm of possibility of what lies beyond the range of human sensory detection, as made realisable by science and technology. 

The Moth series, the second of the arcs, draws upon Darwinian hypothesis that living creatures’ characteristics or forms evolve to over time, through a process of beneficial mutations. In this instance, the paintings revolve around a moth with an unusually long proboscis that enables it to pollinate a species of orchid with a highly elongated nectary. Evolution of the moth and orchid have thus unfolded in tandem, a progression in parallel. The symmetrical shape of Moth #5 calls to mind the insect’s form at rest, and the ultrasound patterns which were derived from the vibratory patterns of the walls or ground on which the moths were perched.

Genevieve Chua (b. 1984, Singapore) is a visual artist who works primarily through abstraction. Chua pursues an unfurling narrative that is informed by natural history and linguistics. Selected solo exhibitions include “Rehearsals for the Wilful” (Manila, 2016); “Parabola” (Singapore, 2014); “Cicadas Cicadas” (Los Angeles, 2014) and “Birthing Ground not a Sound” (Singapore, 2012). She has alos participated in the Singapore Biennale (2011), and was a recipient of the NAC Georgette Chen Scholarship in 2003/4 and the Young Artist Award in 2012 conferred by the National Arts Council, Singapore.

title_text: Royal Malaysia Police
physical_appearance: This is a collection of passport-sized photographs that have been re-photographed and presented. Most of the photographs are faded and unclear, or partially destroyed.
subject_terms_1: portraits symbolism political art police officers metaphor criticism politics governments (administrative bodies)
subject_terms_2: Photographs Portraits Symbolism Malaysia. Jabatan Polis Diraja Art Political aspects Metaphor Criticism Art, Malaysian Political science Government accountability
sgcool_label_text: Coming across an abandoned police station in Malaysia, artist Eiffel Chong discovered a number of passport-sized photographs of police officers and booking photographs of criminals. Some had been partially destroyed by dust and the elements, resulting in a mottled appearance blighted by dirt, insects and even mould. After collecting all the images, he re-photographed each one in the studio, treating them as dimensional objects marked by the detritus of time. For the artist, these found photographs came to be a metaphor for the corruptibility of ideals and order as embodied in the law. Preventive laws promulgated into the constitution, which give the police the power to detain suspects without presenting any evidence of wrongdoing before a court of law, is a prerogative that has historically been used to suppress political opposition and civil activism in many countries. Thus, in addition to their law enforcement functions, the police also play a large part in national security, and such power without accountability can, and does lead to the tendency to abuse that very power. In Malaysia, the annual Bersih (the Coalition for Clean and Fair Elections) rallies have been the site of alleged use of excessive force by the police, leading to criticism and probes by independent advisory panels. In Royal Malaysia Police, what is put under investigation is the reliance on the photograph’s power to verify identity – both for the police and the criminal. The artist’s documentary processes testify to the neutrality and material susceptibility of the photograph as witness, evidence and reference.

subject_terms_1: symbolism human hair disease flower (motif)
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Symbolism Cancer Hair in art Motifs
sgcool_label_text: Imhathai is a forerunner in the use of human hair in the making of works. Conceptualised for the Hair for Hope exhibition in support of cancer victims and survivors, the strands of hair which constitute the hand woven flowers in The Flower Bed originate from cancer victims, chemotherapy patients, cancer survivors, and donors to the program. The thousands of hand-woven flowers representative of Elysium, consoling cancer victims and relations of the pain they are currently undergoing, while reminding them of a better place that is to come. Marveling at the degree of detail in each piece, a viewer is also reminded of the necessary perseverance to overcome times of challenge. With this particular work, Imhathai Suwatthanasilp reaffirms her position as one of the top contemporary artists pushing the boundaries of the textile medium.

title_text: Soap Blocked
physical_appearance: This installation depicts a collection of carved soap blocks. The soap blocks are arranged on the floor in the shape of the map of Myanmar. Behind the soap sculpture, there is a poster on the wall. The poster shows an image of one of the artist's carved soap sculpture, with a short description.
subject_terms_1: symbolism political art prisons (institutions)
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Symbolism Art Political aspects Prisons Political prisoners Military government Burma
sgcool_label_text: he practice of Burmese artist Htein Lin spans the gamut from painting to installation to performance. He spent almost seven years in jail (1998–2004) for political reasons; during this time he developed his artistic practice by using bowls and cigarette lighters, in the absence of brushes, to make paintings and monoprints on prison uniforms. After his release, he moved to London in 2006, but returned to Myanmar in 2013. Soap Blocked was one of two Burmese projects included in the 2016 Singapore Biennale (“An Atlas of Mirrors”). It comprises a map of Myanmar, painstakingly constructed of a thousand squares of sculpted Shwe Wah soap, and stands as testament to the vicissitudes of Htein Lin’s tumultuous life. Having participated in the failed uprising of 1988 – an event commemorated today as a milestone in the country’s march towards the establishment of a democratic polity – he was forced to flee underground, spending several years in refugee camps on the border. He escaped and returned to Yangon in the early 1990s, but was again arrested and jailed on charges of opposition activity; he subsequently spent almost seven years behind bars and was released only in 2004. During this time he turned to art. In the absence of proper art-making tools, he used what meagre materials were made available to him to produce works on scraps of fabric, on prison uniforms – and in soap. One of the works that emerged from this period was a little carving of a captive human figure, hunched over and trapped within the claustrophobic confines of four walls, sculpted from a bar of Shwe Wah soap. The carving was smuggled out by a Red Cross representative after a prison visit in 1999, as a means of conveying to the rest of the world the deplorable state of the country’s prisons. Soap Blocked returns to the original moment of the artist’s desperate, clandestine plea. The installation maps and reflects the experience of thousands of political prisoners in Myanmar in recent decades, including the artist’s own incarceration. The work amplifies autobiographical resonance into a starkly visceral monument to the collective helplessness that the people of the country often faced during the years of socialist military rule.

sgcool_label_text: The long jacket was considered the appropriate formal wear for men during the early Republican period in China and Hong Kong. There was an interest in Western fashion after the collapse of the Qing dynasty. This Western style long jacket belonged to Mr Kaan Tat Choi, who was a successful businessman in the bullion business in Hong Kong. Mr Kaan expanded his business to Malaya in the 1920s, acquiring several rubber plantations along the east coast of Malaya. He also opened a bullion trading company called “Yee Shing” at 20 Canal Road in Singapore in the 1930s.

The long robe (known as ‘changshan’??in Southern China and Hong Kong and ‘changpao’ ?? in Northern China) was the standard informal garment worn by men during the early Republican period in China and Hong Kong. It is a one-piece long robe that can be worn alone or under a short jacket known as a ‘magua’ ??. This robe was tailored at a certain tailor shop by the name of Lu Xin Long ???  in Hong Kong.

This exquisite robe belonged to Mr Kaan Tat Choi, who was a successful businessman in the bullion business in Hong Kong. Mr Kaan expanded his business to Malaya in the 1920s, acquiring several rubber plantations along the east coast of Malaya. He also opened a bullion trading company called “Yee Shing” at 20 Canal Road in Singapore in the 1930s.

Black gummed silk (known as xiangyunsha??? or heijiaochou???  in Chinese) was a popular material used in the tailoring of summer clothing in Beijing, Shanghai and Hong Kong in the 1920s to 1930s. It has a distinctive black shiny surface which is waterproof and a matt brown underside which reveals an underlying weave of varying patterns. It originates in the district of Shunde in Guangdong province and is still being made there today.

This jacket belonged to Mr Kaan Tat Choi, who was a successful businessman in the bullion business. title_text: Origin
physical_appearance: This is a Chinese calligraphic ink work. It is composed of thick, vigorous and swift brush strokes that cover the entire paper. It is framed by a brown frame. The artist's seal can be found at the top left corner.
subject_terms_1: negative space
subject_terms_2: Ink painting, Chinese Emptiness
sgcool_label_text:
Zhuang Shengtao ??? (b. 1944, Guandong province, China) is a noted Chinese ink and calligraphy artist who has been affiliated with contemporary Chinese ink development in Singapore. Currently residing in Suzhou China, he had a history of studying and exhibiting in Singapore. He studied art at the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts, Singapore and was tutored by the Singapore ink master Shi Xiang Tuo. A Nanyang University graduate, he pursued further studies at the University of Nice, France and the Monterey Institute of International Studies, California USA in the 1980s. He also studied printmaking at the Cornish College of Arts, Seattle in 1988 and obtained his Masters of Fine Art at the University of Washington in 1990.
This monumental ink work exemplifies Zhuang’s distillation of calligraphic and ink brush work and the aesthetic sensibilities of American Expressionism. In particular, Zhuang found affinity with the practice of Jackson Pollock, whose works he encountered directly and closely at the museums with his move to the USA in 1987. Through this interface, Zhuang explored compositions that were bolder in scale and more complex in composition – producing depth and nuances in tonal values.  
 
The vigour and improvisational quality of Zhuang’s brushwork belies the discipline and compositional decisions determining the balance between ink and void. The notion of ‘Origin’ also captures the theme of Zhuang’s artistic preoccupations in probing both Chinese and western canons of art-making. Trained and mentored by Shi Xiang Tuo, Zhuang had risen to attention through his calligraphy and the principles of the calligraphic brush work have permeated his ink paintings.

title_text: Untitled
physical_appearance: This is a Chinese ink painting done in a hanging scroll format. A scripted verse can be found on the left; framed by the lighter ink used to paint this amorphous form. 2 single brush strokes; one of a lighter hue than the other punctuate the lower half of the scroll.
subject_terms_1: calligraphy (visual works)  poems  xieyi  abstraction
subject_terms_2: Ink painting, Chinese Calligraphy, Chinese Chinese poetry  Art, Abstract
sgcool_label_text:
Wong Keen (b. 1942) is regarded as a leading painter whose practice is often framed as the outcome of distilling and re-enervating eastern and western art genres. His oil paintings are marked by gestural and expressive brushwork, reinforcing affiliations with American abstract expressionism that shaped his formative years in New York; his paint handling also acknowledges debt to his grounding and fervor for calligraphy and Chinese ink particularly of the xieyi school.  
Wong had been tutored by Liu Kang and mentored intensively by Chen Wen Hsi. He participated in local exhibitions from 1956, with a solo exhibition at the National Library in 1961 before leaving for the USA, enrolling at the Art Students League of New York (1961-65) and later St Martin’s School of Art London (entered in 1966). He excelled in school and actively exhibited, receiving the Ford Foundation tuition grant in 1964 and the Edward G. McDowell Travelling Scholarship the following year that enabled him to tour Europe and the UK. He took on art related jobs including as an art instructor and art director in New York and continued to paint - winning the Consul-Gen of Japan Award in 1967, In the late 1970s he established a frame shop Keen’s Gallery and eventually an art gallery for emerging artists. He returned to art professionally and began to exhibit in Singapore. 

While this work was produced during Wong’s student years, it is important to note that Wong was actively exhibiting and excelling during these ‘school years’. He was the recipient of the Ford Foundation tuition scholarship just a year earlier, in 1964; and the year this work was made was the year he won the Edward G. McDowell Travelling Scholarship – marking the first for a Singaporean recipient. The latter scholarship allowed Wong to travel to Europe and London.  
During this time, he met up with his mentor Chen Wen Hsi who was in Europe at this time for his own exhibitions. Chen apparently brought along some Chinese art materials with which Wong used to produce several works. It has been noted in several texts that Wong has a strong link with calligraphy even from early years, formatively shaped by his mother, the late calligrapher Chu Hen-Ai. This painting bears a scripted verse alongside a more amorphous, ambivalent form and two slim brush strokes, rendered strategically. It is unclear whether this work should be read with the other work (forming a pair) or whether they could also be treated as independently.

title_text: Self-portrait
physical_appearance: This is a portrait of a man; he wears a collared shirt, and faces the audience. Noticibly, he dons half of a spectacle where the only remaining lens is cracked. In the background to the right is a painting on an easel.
subject_terms_1: Surrealist  self-expression
subject_terms_2: Painting  Self-portraits  Surrealism  Expression (Philosophy)
sgcool_label_text:
Lim Mu Hue ??? (sometimes Ling Mu Hua) [1936-2008] is reputed as one of Singapore’s leading printmakers, in particular in the woodcut and woodblock printmaking techniques. A respected art educator and alumnus of the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts (graduating in 1955), his oeuvre was far more extensive that popularly assumed. Lim was also highly proficient in pastel and charcoal drawing, Chinese ink and Western painting, exploring figuration, landscapes and still-life. He taught at NAFA from 1960-69 before leaving to work at the Nanyang Siang Pau (a Chinese newspaper), becoming its Art Editor from 1969-1975. He later set up his own printing company but continued to be active in various art capacities throughout his life. He was honorary advisor to the Lee Kong Chian Art Museum from 1970 to 1980); and Senior Researcher for the Xu Bei Hong Memorial Hall in Nanjing in 2001 and Visiting Professor at the Inner Mongolian Eastern Cultural Museum, China in 2002. Lim’s monumental public art mural for the Esplanade SMRT station was completed in the year of his passing.  

The interest in Lim’s woodcut prowess has often eclipsed his proficient and interesting painting portfolio. He has been celebrated largely for his detailed woodcutting imagery derived from street theatre and puppetry as well as distinctly local and regional activities such as fishing or gathering toddy.  

This self portrait painting presents another facet of Lim’s practice that merits more attention. This is a self-portrait of the artist when he was 27 years old. It is an intriguing phase not only within Lim’s oeuvre but also in the larger discussion of Surrealist and Symbolist influences or their variants in Singapore art development. That this was executed in 1963 throws light and insight on this area of research at this particular juncture of art history here and in the region. During this period, Lim was teaching art at NAFA; he was also producing woodcuts, drawings and cartoons.  
In this unusually small portrait, Lim’s self-depiction is dense with details that are open to interpretative possibilities. He dons spectacles but his eye-glasses appear snapped off so that only 1 side of the framed lens is left. The reflection appears to capture images of abstract paintings, possibly of those surrounding him in the studio or space he is in. The green tinge in this work is characteristic of surrealist-influenced works. This work also adds to the area of artist’s self-representations – an area of interest for museum curators and historians.

Prof. Chong Pai Mu  (b. 1911 – date of death not confirmed) (sometimes Zhong Baimu or Chung Pak Mook) is regarded as one of the early artists and educators in Western art in Penang and Singapore. He studied at the Xinhua Art Academy, Shanghai, later at the Nanjing Central University, under Xu Beihong as well as at the Beiping Central Academy. He was involved in filmmaking in the film community of Nanjing.  
He was one of the founding members of the Penang Chinese Art Club (or Yin Yin Art Society) in 1935, along with Kuo Ju Ping as well as Yong Mun Sen. At the onset of the 2nd Sino-Japanese war in 1937, he returned to Perak and was persuaded to teach art by Kuo in Penang. He relocated to Singapore, becoming an early teacher of Western Art at the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts in 1940, where he also took up the appointment of Head of Guidance Counselling. He left after a year and later set up the Hai Xia Art Supplies Company (Straits Commercial Art Co.) with former NAFA alumnus Tay Long that provided advertising signages as well as sold paintings alongside supplies in its early years. The partnership ended a few years later and Chong left Singapore. His practice is sometimes framed with Chen Jen Hao, Huang Baofang and Tchang Ju Chi. He eventually resettled in Hong Kong.  

The art work features a young girl in pig-tails, her tanned complexion a stark contrast to her light pastel-hued ribbons and dress. A 1996 auction in Taipei had in fact titled the work a Portrait of a Malay Girl in light of her complexion. (Ref: Fine Modern Chinese Oil Paintings, Drawings & Watercolours Auction, Taipei, 14 April 1996, Lot 58).  The work is signed and dated 1945 on the left lower of the canvas - executed when the artist was in his mid-30s, a few years after he had left the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts as lecturer of Western Art.

title_text: Sikh man
physical_appearance: This is, as the title suggest, the portrait of  a Sikh man. He dons a white turban, and has a beard. Decked in a greeen coat with a white shirt within, the colours are visually contrasting with the bright red background he has been set against. The artist's signature can be found on the bottom right.
subject_terms_1: Sikhism  turbans  single-sitter portraits
subject_terms_2: Sikhism  Turbans  Painting
sgcool_label_text:
Sikh Man, painted in 1960 when she was simultaneously working with the Bank of China, could arguably be read as marking an earlier juncture in Chen’s development just prior to the start of her excursions with the Ten Men Art Group from December 1960.  
 At this point, she was signing off her canvases as “Tan Seah Boey” (this was later shortened to a single character) and engaging colour forcefully and strategically. The only area of ‘modelling’ to create shadows and volume are on the Sikh man’s face; the rest of the painting adopts very little modulation of color. The outlines of his turban, his green jacket and scarlet background are rendered as segments of unmodulated and sometimes striking colour, evidencing the influence of Fauvist ways of rendering flat areas of pure, vivid colour.

title_text: Angkor Wat
physical_appearance: This portrait depicts two figures clad in a loin cloth whilst carrying an animal on a pole on their shoulders. The colours are of an earthy tone.
subject_terms_1: Angkor Vat hunter-gatherer (early  cultures)
subject_terms_2: Angkor Wat (Angkor)  Painting  Early civilizations?
sgcool_label_text:
Tan Seah Boey (b. 1927) or Chen Chengmei as she is better known (or Wang-Chen Chengmei), has experienced renewed interest and revisiting of her position and role in Singapore’s art history in the last decade. Several contexts may be forged in assessing her work – as the rare female presence in the male-dominated art scene of the 1960s and 70s that could be framed comparatively with Lai Foong Moi (1931-1994) and Sunyee (1919-2009); as a practitioner of faux naïve painting and printmaking; as a founding member of the seminal Ten Men Art Group (later the SEAsian Art Association) and her relationships with a notable network of artists that included her brother, the artist Tan Teo Kwang.  
 
Chen was trained at the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts (1950-54), where she studied under Cheong Soo Pieng and Lim Hak Tai as well as calligraphy under Chui Ta Tee. Her classmates included Lim Yew Kuan and Choo Keng Kwang. She was fluent in Chinese, English and French – working as the Bank of China’s interpreter for 20 years. Her ‘signature style’ is marked by flat, rudimentary rendering and a marked simplicity in form and colour. This faux naïve sensibility seemed particularly suited for her subjects that included folk communities and cultures in the region. Notable exhibitions include her solo exhibitions at the Museo de Arte Contemporanio de Oaxaca (1980, Mexico), Lasting Impressions, Printmaking (2006, Singapore) and Joie de Vivre: Chen Cheng Mei (2014, NAFA Galleries, Singapore).

This painting may be read in the context of Chen’s art expeditions with the Ten Men Art Group - a casual group that was formalized as the Southeast Asian Art Association by the time this work was produced in 1973.

title_text: Mother and Child
physical_appearance: This painting depicts a lady holding on to a child. She wears her hair in a bun, and holds her son in her left hand. Her head faces away from the viewer. The background is depicted to be flat and in two colours; a quarter of it green, the other of a yellowish-orange.
subject_terms_1: mothers children (people by age group)  families (kinship groups)
subject_terms_2: Mother and child  Families Painting
sgcool_label_text:
Yong Mun Sen (1896-1962) is often referred to as the Father of Malaysian painting, particularly in the genre of watercolour. Born Yong Yen Lang in Kuching, Sarawak Malaysia and was formally trained in calligraphy and Chinese ink painting in Guan-dong, China. In 1918, he worked in a bookstore in Singapore and in 1922 was transferred to the Penang branch of this store. He adopted this artist name of Mun Sen this same year and established his well-known art studios for art, sculpture and photography – the Tai Woon/Wei Guan Art Studio (renamed Mun Sen Studio in 1930). The studio was to become a meeting point for other leading artists of the time.  
 
He was one of the rallying forces behind the formation of key art societies including the Penang Chinese Art Club and Singapore Chinese Art Club, both formed in 1935. At his height Yong actively exhibited in America, UK, Malaysia and Singapore. He held exhibitions in Singapore from 1947 to 1953 at the Victoria Memorial Hall, Robinsons & Co. and John Littles, many of which were fundraisers for various causes including University Endowments, discharged prisoners, nurses’ welfare and campaigns against tuberculosis. 

While Yong is principally known for his naturalistic, expressive renditions of landscapes and landmarks in watercolour, he was also an accomplished oil painter who found an affinity with Paul Gauguin and his depictions of native subjects in Tahiti.  
 
The influence of Gauguin is discernible in Yong’s studies and rendering of regional subjects when he was travelling extensively throughout Malaya particularly in the 1940s and early 50s. This may be seen in the treatment of this subject as well as in a work already in the NGS Collection (Ref: Relaxing, c 1940s).  
 
The female subject in a sarong, is depicted in a pose that would be familiar to many in the region. Her arms are wrapped around her child who is hoisted to her side or hip, as is a common sight in many kampong dwellings. Both are rendered as being dark complexioned, their forms seamlessly melding one to the other - suggesting the strong bond between mother and child. This painting was featured in the exhibition Pioneers (2007, Valentine Willie Fine Art, KL) and dated 1940 during that exhibition.

title_text: Untitled
physical_appearance: This is a Chinese ink painting done in a hanging scroll format. An amorphous form of two colour hues occupy the top half of the scroll, while the bottom half has two singular diagonal strokes in opposing directions; one red and the other in black ink.
subject_terms_1: xieyi  abstraction
subject_terms_2: Art, Abstract  Ink painting, Chinese
sgcool_label_text:
Wong Keen (b. 1942) is regarded as a leading painter whose practice is often framed as the outcome of distilling and re-enervating eastern and western art genres. His oil paintings are marked by gestural and expressive brushwork, reinforcing affiliations with American abstract expressionism that shaped his formative years in New York; his paint handling also acknowledges debt to his grounding and fervor for calligraphy and Chinese ink particularly of the xieyi school.  

While this work was produced during Wong’s student years, it is important to note that Wong was actively exhibiting and excelling during these ‘school years’. He was the recipient of the Ford Foundation tuition scholarship just a year earlier, in 1964; and the year this work was made was the year he won the Edward G. McDowell Travelling Scholarship – marking the first for a Singaporean recipient. The latter scholarship allowed Wong to travel to Europe and London.  
 Wong had been tutored by Liu Kang and mentored intensively by Chen Wen Hsi. He participated in local exhibitions from 1956, with a solo exhibition at the National Library in 1961 before leaving for the USA, enrolling at the Art Students League of New York (1961-65) and later St Martin’s School of Art London (entered in 1966). He excelled in school and actively exhibited, receiving the Ford Foundation tuition grant in 1964 and the Edward G. McDowell Travelling Scholarship the following year that enabled him to tour Europe and the UK. He took on art related jobs including as an art instructor and art director in New York and continued to paint - winning the Consul-Gen of Japan Award in 1967, In the late 1970s he established a frame shop Keen’s Gallery and eventually an art gallery for emerging artists. He returned to art professionally and began to exhibit in Singapore.

title_text: Knitting The Future
physical_appearance: This is a performance item. The artist sits on the chair and knits a garment out of leek.
subject_terms_1: ethnicity identity  CD-Rs video recordings sound recordings
subject_terms_2: Performance art  Knitting  Leek  Blu-ray discs  CD-Rs Ethnicity  Identity  Video recording  Sound recordings  Teochew (Chinese people)
context_1: Singapore Biennale 2016, An Atlas of Mirriors
sgcool_label_text: Chuyia Chia is a Sino-Malaysian artist who works primarily in performance. Raised in Klang, Malaysia, and having attended art school in Singapore, she is today based in Gothenburg, Sweden. Knitting the Future was first staged in Venice in 2015, and was included in the 2016 Singapore Biennale (“An Atlas of Mirrors”), where it was one of several performative pieces. For a period of five weeks, for six days a week and six hours a day, Chia engaged in a marathon knitting session – except that her material of choice is not yarn, but the leek. Clad in a long black dress, sitting in the middle of a gallery space likewise fitted out in black, her ultimate goal is the completion of a full-length garment – or “body armour”, as she dubs it – woven entirely from thousands of skeins of leek. Chia  is of Teochew stock, the descendant of Chinese immigrants to Malaysia. While based in Sweden, her ethnic and cultural identity is integral to her artistic practice, especially at a stage in her life that has seen her displaced from Southeast Asia. The piece is informed by her Teochew roots, but Chia is also concerned about environmental issues. It occupies a central place in the culinary and cultural consciousness of the Teochew people of the Chaoshan region in southern China. It – or its close relatives, the scallion or garlic green – is a staple at the family meal during the annual reunion feast on the eve of the Lunar New Year. The generic Mandarin term for allium vegetables, suan (?), is a homophone with the verb ‘to count’ (?), and an old adage goes, ‘If one ate leek, there would be money to keep’.

techniques_name: sandblasting  glazing (coating process)  throwing (pottery techniques)  molding (forming)  firing (technique)

sgcool_label_text: This candle holder is one of the five porcelain wares from the award-winning “Spotted Nyonya” series by Singaporean designer, Hans Tan.  This series is a contemporary take on traditional Peranakan porcelain or nyonyaware.  Hans Tan was inspired by batik, particularly the resist-dyeing technique, to transform the surface of these wares.  Original glazed portions are preserved in the form of a new dotted pattern while the white porcelain body is revealed after sandblasting away and erasing the original glaze on these pieces.  The combination of green and pink polychrome colours or dots on the original decoration of these pieces are typical of nyonyaware.  Motifs commonly found on nyonyaware would include realistically depicted birds and insects amongst floral sprays.

title_text: Model of a Monkey Group
techniques_name: enameling overglazing  throwing (pottery techniques)  molding (forming)  firing (technique)  porcelain painting (image-making) freehand drawing (technique)
physical_appearance: This porcelain work shows a seated monkey holding onto a younger, smaller monkey on its back. The adult monkey is painted brown, whilst the smaller one is grey. Their faces and ears however, are painted in light brown. The monkeys are raised on a painted blue rock with peach and leaves.
subject_terms_1: monkeys (animals)  animal art  plant-derived motif
subject_terms_2: Figurative art Monkeys  Peach in art  Leaves in art  Pottery, Chinese
sgcool_label_text:
This model shows a figure of a seated monkey holding a younger monkey on its back. The group is painted in polychrome enamels and gold.  To create a distinction, the young monkey is painted in dark grey and the adult monkey is unevenly painted in shades of brown with fine parallel lines to simulate its body hair. Its abdomen is paler in colour, and its ears and face are painted in light brown. The sensitive treatment on the application of polychrome enamels by differentiating the use of lines and colour shades gives it a naturalistic appeal.

It marks a high point of Chinese porcelain depicting animal forms. It is realistically modelled and it shows why Chinese porcelain figures were so highly sought after in Europe. In the 16th – 18th centuries, Chinese porcelain became fashionable in the West, and were primarily exported as luxury goods.

title_text: Ivory Figurine of a Sri Lankan Nobleman
physical_appearance: This is an ivory figuring of a Sri Lankan Nobleman. He is depicted standing on a small octagonal platform, positioned upright and facing forwards, with his arms by his side. The figurine is shown wearing an outfit with a double-layered collar, a tunic with long sleeves, and pants. The figure is wearing a three necklaces, each with a floral pendant, and a tall headdress.
subject_terms_1: Sri Lankan nobles (aristocrats) folk costume commissions (orders for works)
subject_terms_2: Figurines Ivory carving Sri Lankans Aristocracy (Social class) Ethnic costume
sgcool_label_text:
The active Sinhalese arts and crafts in the last independent ‘mountain kingdom’ of Kandy included the wide use of ivory, which was a favourite medium for sculptures. The royal palace was a centre that attracted the most skilled craftsmen, an artistic elite, who formed a guild called ‘Pattal Hatara’. Members included painters, jewellers, gold and silversmiths and ivory workers. These same skilled workers were also involved in building and decorating the temples found throughout Kandy. They enjoyed the King’s protection and received royal donations. Their presence attracted other artists such as dancers and musicians to the court and the Kings of Kandy became famed for their patronage of the arts. 

This ivory figurine is a depiction of a Sri Lankan nobleman or dignitary standing on a small pedestal. The artist has engraved vertical lines into the figurine’s wide, double-layered collar that covers his shoulders, and also on his trousers and shirt cuffs. Wavy, horizontal lines have also been carved into his sleeves. He wears a long tunic (bo-hettya) which has five hanging pendants; four rest upon the front and back of his thighs while a larger one hangs upon his back underneath the layers of his collar. The figurine is adorned with three long necklaces with flower shaped pendants and he wears a flower shaped ring on each hand. He has a rotund, rather elaborate hat on his head and his hair is carefully parted and tied in a knot. He wears a benevolent expression, with closed eyes and boasts a magnificent handlebar moustache. His facial expression denotes a devout aspect. The figurine is exquisitely finished on the back, where the careful detailing and depth in carving continues. The relatively small size of the figure emphasizes the artist’s masterful skill in carving. 

Statuettes of kings, other royalty and the nobility – as well as ordinary men and women – are common in ivory dating from this period. They are particularly useful as records of costume of the royalty and nobility. The model for this piece might have been a member of the royal family, perhaps a prince or king. Such portraits are rare and would have probably been commissioned and produced as diplomatic gifts.

title_text: Powder Flask
materials_name: wood (plant material) mother of pearl ivory (material)
physical_appearance: This is a powder flask. The top of the flask, as well as the side, is inlaid with mother of pearl decoration against a dark brown background. The pattern features alternating geometric shapes. There is a finial on the top of the flask with vertical engraving. An orange, black, yellow and red string is attached to the finial. The flask is in the shape of a shell, with a curved bottom.
subject_terms_1: gunpowder geometric motifs containers (receptacles)
subject_terms_2: Powder flasks Gunpowder Motifs Containers
sgcool_label_text:
Gunpowder was the primary form of ammunition prior to the introduction of bullets. Gunpowder had to be loaded into the barrel of the gun, stored in a flask the gunpowder could be emptied into the barrel with ease. Indian ivory carving and mother of pearl decorative work was much sought after in the European market during  the colonial period. Ranging from everyday objects, armoury, gaming pieces to furniture were crafted in workshops around India for the colonial market. Mother of pearl workshops in Gujarat and Rajasthan produced furniture and other decorative objects for the luxury European market. 

The powder flask is made from wood in the form of a mollusc or a nautilus shell. The top of the object has been inlaid with mother of pearl against a dark brown ground. The pattern features alternating geometric shapes; on the very top, there are angular undulating lines decorated with eye-like circles, below (and around the body of the flask) a leaf-like pendant and circular dots are arranged in the shape of a cross. The ivory finial on the top of the flask is pumpkin-shaped with vertical engraving. An orange, black, yellow and red string is attached to the finial. The artist has made incisions that follow the natural curvature of the shell-shape. Powder flasks were used in order to store and carry while protecting gun powder from the damp. Indian powder flasks are often elegant, exhibiting intricate carving and precious inlaid decoration, and are sometimes covered with leather or fabric. 

Such flasks were produced by craftsmen of the Khatri caste in the Kotah state of the 19th centuryt. Such objects were popular after their inclusion in exhibitions such as the Colonial and Indian exhibition held in London in 1886, in much demand there after.

title_text: WWII Japanese Map of Southeast Asia and Northern Australia
physical_appearance: This is a World War II map of Southeast Asia and Northern Australia. It is an overview of the Southern Co-Prosperity Sphere. It was issued by the Japanese Intelligency agency.
subject_terms_1: cartography (discipline)
subject_terms_2: Maps  Greater East Asia Co-prosperity Sphere  Southeast Asia  Australia, Northern  World War, 1939-1945 Cartography
sgcool_label_text: This map provides an overview of the Southern Co-Prosperity Sphere, of northern Australia and Southeast Asia. Issued by the Japanese intelligence agency, there is also an inset map in the lower left corner that depicts Australia and Southeast Asia in the larger region.

title_text: Home, and a Home
physical_appearance: This is an installation piece comprised of welded steel bars and concrete. It has the structural form of a shophouse front. There are also rust-transferred drawings.
subject_terms_1: home (concept)  storefronts migrant workers  cross-sections  architectural drawings (visual works) architectural elements commissions (orders for works)
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art)  Shophouses Immigrants Home  Singapore  Displacement (Psychology)  Bangladeshis Architectural drawing  Art commissions
sgcool_label_text:
This work is in continuation with Barman’s earlier practice, where he investigates ‘landscape’ as an idea– not just the physicality of its presence, but the space that it occupies in the mind and in the memory, and the new meanings of ‘home’ for displaced Bangladeshi migrants in Kolkata. For this work, Barman spent time in Singapore chronicling the conversations and poetry of Bangladeshi migrant labourers,and translated them into skeletal-sculptures referencing pre-war Singapore shophouse fronts and rust-transferred drawings. These works evoke images of homes left behind, aspirations towards future homes and  the present feeling of homelessness. In the artist’s words, “transferring rust impressions onto paper, casting abandoned domestic objects in concrete and welding re-used construction iron bars in realising skeletal definitions of homes are more like sculpting from memory – reconstructions rusted in time”. (Text by Suman Gopinath, Singapore Biennale 2016 Assoc. curator, and curator of the artwork)

The recent art practice of Rathin Barman (b. 1981, Tripura, India) focuses on urban architecture and architectural forms. He has documented different layers of architectural progress that unveil the structural evolution of the contemporary urban landscape, while at the same time commenting on sociopolitical issues. His recent solo exhibition ‘No … I Remember It Well’ at Experimenter (Kolkata, 2015) emerged from the idea of ‘home’ shaped by conversations with and amidst people displaced since 1947 from East Pakistan (now Bangladesh). He transformed their memories into sculptural forms and, in the process, recreated remembered homes and landscapes. Barman has previously had two solo exhibitions and exhibited widely in India and around the world. He is involved in the public art project Edge Effect, curated by Kanchi Mehta, a Kochi-Muziris Biennale project (Kochi, India, 2014). He lives and works in Kolkata, India.

title_text: Again and Again We Are Somewhere
physical_appearance: This image depicts a hastily drawn amorphous figure. In the background are roughly sketched grass/waves and a mountain.
subject_terms_1: amorphous  fear anthropomorphic
subject_terms_2: Fear Drawing  Loss (Psychology)  Anthropomorphism in art  Art, Thai  Dreams
sgcool_label_text:
In Again and again we are somewhere, Dusadee Huntrakul renders in a seemingly automatic fashion a visage from a nightmare he experienced, hastily sketched in a bid to capture the memory of a fading dream. A fear stemming from confusion and feelings of being lost is the predominant theme of the work – and in this particular nightmare, the artist’s loss of his brother has manifested in his subconscious now as disorientation in an unfamiliar environment. 

An amorphous figure dominates the drawing, standing in the foreground of a crudely executed landscape featuring an unknown mountain (or is it a pyramid?), and as in the other pieces, waves. The identity of the figure is terrifying, but unknown – and from a psychoanalytic viewpoint can be seen as symbolic of the artist’s fear and dread manifest in an anthropomorphic form.

title_text: Gosh, We Are Fucked
physical_appearance: This image depicts a sea of waves represented by the overlapping curvy lines. A small boat is seen to be caught in these tumultous waters on the left hand side.
subject_terms_1: fear memory  dreams  waves (natural events)  surfing
subject_terms_2: Drawing  Loss (Psychology)  Fear Memories  Dreams  Waves  Art, Thai  Phuket (Thailand) Surfing
context_1: Dusadee + Dusit + Lovers + Dead Ones exhibition
context_21: 7th Floor, Center of Academic Resources, Chulalongkorn University, Phyathai Road, Pathum Wan, Bangkok 10330, Thailand.
sgcool_label_text: Gosh, we are fucked is one from a number of graphite on paper drawings that were featured in the Lovers + Dead Ones exhibition held at the Chulalongkorn University gallery in 2016. Rendered in an almost automatic fashion, the hastily drawn images exemplify art as a means of cathartic release. The images portrayed stem from the recurring dreams Dusadee has of his deceased brother, whose passing has affected Dusadee deeply. The personal story behind this work is also the impetus for the making of the sculptural piece He was out there all alone riding the monsoon waves like a champ later on – revolving around a holiday surfing trip to Phuket during the monsoon season.

title_text: He Was Out There All Alone Riding The Monsoon Waves Like A Champ
physical_appearance: This sculpture is composed of black cylindrical rods that have been stuck onto each other. Notably, a white (limp) phallus has been attaced to the central rod of the sculpture.
subject_terms_1: fear memory  waves (natural events)  phalluses  symbolism (artistic concept)
subject_terms_2: Sculpture  Loss (Psychology)  Fear Memories  Waves  Phuket (Thailand)  Penis  Symbolism  Art, Thai
sgcool_label_text: He was out there all alone riding the monsoon waves like a champ harkens back to a time when the artist’s brother was still alive – during a holiday to Phuket. The wave is a recurring motif that features in numerous of Dusadee’s sculptures and drawings. Stemming from how this memorable visit was during the monsoon season, the choppy conditions of the sea left a deep impression on Dusadee. Furthermore, since the primary purpose of the visit to Phuket was for surfing, Dusadee had watched his brother conquer these towering waves with both trepidation and pride – the flaccid penis affixed to the sculpture sheds light on the fear that the artist experienced as he watched his brother.

title_text: Untitled
physical_appearance: This sculpture is composed of  cylindrical rods that have been moulded, a porcelain rope that hangs off it, two eggs, and a wave-like sculptural motif.
subject_terms_1: fear memory  waves (natural events)  symbolism (artistic concept)
subject_terms_2: Sculpture  Loss (Psychology)  Fear Memories  Waves  Symbolism  Art, Thai
sgcool_label_text: Untitled incorporates numerous elements characteristic of Dusadee Huntrakul’s ceramic practice. While appearing unassuming, the sculpture’s curved contortions highlight the artist’s technical finesse with the medium. The porcelain rope seemingly defiant to the attraction of gravity lends the work a certain élan vital, and the work exudes an energy seemingly further amplified by two small egg-shaped pieces that rest upon the sculpture. What these “eggs” are are open to interpretation, and placement as well – and draw comparisons to a primordial cosmic egg, or when placed side-by-side, testicles as well. The wave motif present in other works from Dusadee also makes an appearance here. Now, in conjunction with the spheres, the waves seem to suggest the primordial nature of water, and it as a life force in itself.

sgcool_label_text: The personal story behind this work, like in Gosh, we are fucked, revolves around a holiday surfing trip to Phuket during the monsoon season. The repetition of the wave motif, even more evident and chaotic in this piece, obscures the image beneath it, and therefore suggests of an even greater nightmarish as the artist has recurring dreams revolving around the same event. The surrealist imagery and title of the work point out the bizarre amalgamation of fact and fantasy that constitute dreams. waves like a champ later on – revolving around a holiday surfing trip to Phuket during the monsoon season.

sgcool_label_text: Johnny Manahan’s Choose (1982) is probably the earliest surviving video artwork from the Philippines and the last artwork made Manahan made before completely devoting himself to his work in television. The video is historically and culturally significant for Philippine art and is probably among the earliest video works in Southeast Asia. The video is a self-reflexive commentary on the medium of video and television.

sgcool_label_text:
See Cheen Tee (1928 - 1996) was born in Terengganu, Malaysia. He came to Singapore in 1947 to pursue a formal Chinese education and completed his secondary education at the Catholic High School in 1948. He then joined NAFA in 1950 and was taught by the pioneer artists which include Cheong Soo Pieng, Chen Wen Hsi, Chen Chong Swee and Lim Hak Tai.

See Cheen Tee was adept at various mediums which include oil painting, watercolour, and sculpture but he was most known for his woodcuts. He started producing black-and-white woodcuts in the mid-1950s where his depictions of the social realities of life in Malaya back then, were amongst the finest he produced. Subsequently he started producing coloured woodblock prints from the mid-1960s. The latter were generally more decorative but his draftsmanship and illustrations continued to be of the highest quality, if not, more refined.
