title_text: Drown My Soul at Chico River (Bury My Soul in Chico River)
materials_name: perlite wood (plant material) aluminium (metal)  welded wire fabric acrylic paint
physical_appearance: This is a multicoloured mixed media work that foregrounds a group of individuals half dressed and armed with spears. They have been depicted in side profile; this group includes three men in loin cloths and two women clad in a longer cloth garment wrapped around their waist. The lady on the right has her fists punched into the hair, and she carries a baby on her back with a sarong.  The elderly man is the only figure who has his body and head (with eyes shut) facing the audience. The scene is set in a hilly landscape filled with vegetation. Punctuating the scene is a window frame-like object that disrupts the serenity of the green.
subject_terms_1: identity  figurative art rural communities indigenous people protests
subject_terms_2: Figurative painting Figurative art Figurative expressionism  Identity  Rural  Indigenous people  Protests (Negotiable instruments) Kalinga (Philippine people)
subject_terms_3: visual arts  Mixed media artists Heritage and Culture
context_1: This work is a response to the protests of the Kalinga people who wanted to stop the development of the Chico River dam project. Despite the martial law in place, they were successful in halting the project.
sgcool_label_text:
Born in Baguio in the Cordillera region of the Philippines, artist Santiago Bose (1949-2002), also known as “Santi” or “Santibose”, was a co-founder of the Baguio Arts Guild and a leader of the Baguio art scene. He is known for his innovations in medium and was concerned with developing more indigenous materials for art as well cultivating ties with respective local communities. Both form and content then were important to him in developing a national art. This consciousness probably arose from when he was still a student in the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts. In particular, Bose recalled when his teacher, the abstractionist Constancio Bernardo, suggested he use “imported colours” to improve the colouring of his works. Santi is then quoted in one article in 1981 as saying “Our models in art are Western. Maybe, it’s time for us to make our own models. To be international is to be Filipino first. We have a broken tradition… and I’m going to try to mend in my own way.” 

“Drown My Soul in Chico River” (1981), also known as “Bury My Soul in Chico River,” is a work made by Santiago Bose in response to the protest of the Kalinga people, part of the ethnic group known as Igorots, to stop the Chico River dam project. The dam project would have permanently flooded their ancestral lands and despite being under the rule of Martial Law, the Kalinga people managed to successfully stop the project. It is an important subject matter reflecting the artist’s concerns on the issues of the local tribes/people from the Cordillera region where he was born. The title of the work comes partly from a book written in 1970, “Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee: An Indian History of the American West.” Bose, who spent time in the US, was influenced by the increased activism of minority groups there such as the American Indians.

Bose received the Thirteen Artists award in 1976 and his works are in the collections of Cultural Center of the Philippines, Queensland Art Gallery (Brisbane), Museum of Contemporary Art (Sydney), Western Front (Vancouver), Centro Wilfredo Lam (Havana) among others.

column52: This coranto is possibly the earliest surviving broadshaeet reporting on events in the East Indies. Written to the British East India Company, it reports on the Dutch East India Company's capture of the Banda islands of Lantore (Great Banda) and Polaroone (Pulo Run) from the British in 1621. The report focused on the purported sacking and violence commited by the Dutch, and the forcible removal of the Banda inhabitants to Batavia.

title_text: Majie’s mandarin-collar top
physical_appearance: This is a mandarin-collar top. It is white in colour. The buttons run from the collar and sideways, towards the left. The sleeves are mid-length. The hem of the top flares outwards slightly. The fabric features subtle repeated pineapple motifs. There are no tears seen on this garment.
subject_terms_1: tops (garments, general) maids (servants) pineapple (motif)
subject_terms_2: Ethnic costume Household employees Motifs
sgcool_label_text: This cream coloured mandarin-collar top with pineapple motifs belonged to a majie, a Cantonese female domestic helper. Majie is derived from a Shun Tak term (ma cheh) which means mother and sister. As this group of women had taken a vow never to marry, the term Majie alludes to their spinsterhood and refers to their work taking care of children. Majies typically wore a samfoo uniform consisting of a white mandarin-collar top and black trousers.

sgcool_label_text: This State of Singapore passport belonged to a Cantonese female domestic helper, Ms Leong Kun Toh. The passport is dated to 17 July 1963, 2 months before the merger of Singapore and Malaya and the formation of Malaysia. The passport features the owner’s personal particulars, with her profession labelled peculiarly: “Servant,” and her place of birth: “China”. The password was subsequently renewed in 1964 as a Malaysian passport, with recorded immigration stamps to Hong Kong and Malaysia.

title_text: Majie’s Comb
physical_appearance: This is a ceremonial comb. The comb has fine teeth on either side. The two sides are joint in the center by a dark brown block. Along the block, there is an inscription in gold. The ends of the teeth are rounded by a white plastic.
subject_terms_1: maids (servants) ceremonial objects customs (social concepts) cultural ceremonies
subject_terms_2: Household employees Combs Ceremonial objects Rites and ceremonies
sgcool_label_text: This comb belonged to a majie, a Cantonese female domestic helper. In adherence to tradition, majies underwent a sor hei (combing up) ceremony where they took an oath before a statuette of Guan Yin (Goddess of Mercy) to remain unmarried and celibate. Sor hei, in literal terms, means to “comb up” the hair into a bun or plait. Many majies chose to undergo sor hei as a socially accepted form of singlehood, choosing sworn sisterhood as an alternative to the institution of marriage.

sgcool_label_text:
This black ribbon belonged to a majie, a Cantonese female domestic helper. In adherence to tradition, majies underwent a sor hei (combing up) ceremony where they took an oath before a statuette of Guan Yin (Goddess of Mercy) to remain unmarried and celibate. Sor hei, in literal terms, means to “comb up” the hair into a bun or plait. 

While some majies wore their hair in a plait, some also clipped their hair in a bun, using a hairclip as shown. The choice of an unassuming colour like black for the ribbon blends in with black hair, which also ties in with the majie’s fidelity to their vow of modesty and humility.

This graduation gown belonged to Dr Earl Lu (1925-2005), one of Singapore’s most prominent art patrons and philanthropists.  Lu graduated with a Bachelor of Medicine and Surgery degree from the University of Sydney in Australia.  

The gown has a label from Australian upmarket department store David Jones. Founded in 1838, David Jones is currently the oldest departmental store in the world that had been operating under the same name.

title_text: Re:Looking 2002-2003 (With A Simplified Installation In Collaboration With National Gallery Singapore)
physical_appearance: This installation is comprised of a room structure, lamps, photographs, furniture, and a television that plays a fictional documentary.
subject_terms_1: black-and-white photographs  video art  colonialism  local histories  architectural elements migrant workers
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Photographs  Video art  Imperialism  Local history  Migrant workers
context_9: The architectural elements of the exhibition were salvaged from the former Supreme Court and City Hall buildings
sgcool_label_text: What if Malaysia had colonised Austria? Re:Looking is an invitation to imagine an alternate version of reality where Austria is experiencing post-colonial predicaments as its citizens seek out better lives in Malaysia, its former colonial master. Located in a cosy living room, the work is rooted in deliberate misinformation. Is everything you see on television real? Wong uses the documentary form, which seemingly presents objective, factual accounts of history, to question the role of the mass media in conveying “truth.” Faced with solemn recollections by Austrians and Malaysians about a shared history that never existed, the line between history as we know it and this alternative construct begins to blur. For this new installation of Re:Looking, Wong used salvaged architectural fixtures from the colonial-era former Supreme Court and City Hall buildings.

title_text: Shi Hou Guanyin
physical_appearance:
This is a figurine of the Simhanada Avalokitesvara. S/he sits on a resting lion, in a position of royal ease (maharajalilasana) . S/he dons a five-pointed crown, and is adorned with jewellery. The garment clings onto his/her bodice and is seen reaching the shin of the bodhisattva. Amitabha seats in the center of the crown. The bodhisattva and lion rests atop a lotus pedestal of fleshy leaves.  For more on the Simhanada Avalokitesvara:

Himalayanart. (n.d.). Simhanada (Lion's Roar). Retrieved March 1, 2018, from https://www.himalayanart.org/items/519 Leidy, Denise Patry, and Donna Strahan. (2012). Wisdom Embodied: Chinese Buddhist and Daoist Sculpture in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.  New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 156
subject_terms_1: bodhisattvas  sculpture (visual works)  Buddhism
subject_terms_2: Sculpture  Avalokitesvara (Buddhist deity)  Bodhisattvas  Buddhism
sgcool_label_text:
The bodhisattva is seated in a posture of royal ease on a recumbent lion. The androgynous figure is adorned with elaborate, royal jewellery, and with a tiny figure of Amitabha Buddha seated in the headdress.
The presence of Amitabha Buddha identities the figure as Guanyin or Avalokiteshvara. The presence of the lion refers to its roar, “Simhanada”, symbolising the force of Enlightenment. Depictions of Simhanada Avalokiteshvara developed in India around the eleventh or twelfth century, and appeared as Shi Hou Guanyin in China during the twelfth century.

subject_terms_1: epitaphs  burials  exhumation
subject_terms_2: Gravestones  Epitaphs  Burial  Exhumation
context_20:
Bukit Brown Cemetery  citation: 

Singapore Infopedia. (2010). Khoo Seok Wan ???. In Singapore Infopedia. Retrieved February 26, 2018, from http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_1652_2010-03-02.html
sgcool_label_text:
This is a tombstone of Khoo Seok Wan (1874-1941), a renowned scholar of poetry and literature. Born in Haicheng county in Fujian province, settled in Singapore when he was eight and held the title of Ju Ren as he passed the Imperial examinations at the provincial level. He was also the founder of the first progressive Chinese newspaper in Singapore (Thien Nan Shin Po) and championed the cause of women’s education. He donated $3,000 towards the fund of setting up Singapore Chinese Girls’ School in 1899. He was also a fervent supporter of the Reformist Movement in China and invited key reformist Kang Yu Wei to take refuge in Singapore, paying for all his expenses. 

Unfortunately, Khoo was not adept at managing his fortune and he was declared a bankrupt at age 34. He then earned a living working as an editor for various newspapers such as Cheng Nam Jit Poh, Nan Feng Ri Bao, Jue Hua Zhou Bao and Sin Chew Jit Poh. He was also the chief editor of Sin Chew Jit Poh’s literary supplement, Fan Xin. 

Khoo passed away on 1 December 1941 and was buried at Bukit Brown Cemetary.

title_text: Covered Bowl
techniques_name: throwing (pottery techniques)  molding (forming)  firing (technique)  porcelain painting (image-making) underglazing
physical_appearance: This is a covered bowl in underglaze blue, iron red, and gold. Within the cartouches, are decorations of flowering plants, and a carp with its head and tail above the waves. Interspersing the cartouches are scroll motifs and florets. Standing at the top of the lid is a figure of a rooster.
subject_terms_1: flower (motif)  carp scrolls (motifs) roosters (birds) exports  tableware
subject_terms_2: Imari porcelain Flowers in art  Leaves in art Exports  Roosters in art  Fishes in art  Tableware
sgcool_label_text: This covered bowl with under-glaze blue, iron red, and gold decoration was made at kilns in Arita, Japan. Porcelain with this combination of colours has come to be called “Imari ware” (after the Japanese port city from which it was exported). These wares became popular in Europe in the late 17th century, via the trade of the Dutch East India Company. They brought in Japanese ceramics when Chinese production fell because of political instability.

title_text: Re/Cover no. 4, Re/Cover no. 5, Re/Cover no. 7, Re/Cover no. 8 Re/Cover
physical_appearance: This set is a collection of four photographs. These photographs are of scenes in homes. In each photograph, there are individuals seated position in the middle. A thin, transparent fabric is thrown over them in the scene.
subject_terms_1: mixed media photographs ethnicity world wars symbolism social issues
subject_terms_2: Mixed media (Art) Photographs Racially mixed people World War Two Vietnam History Symbolism Social history
sgcool_label_text:
‘Re/Cover’ is Phan Quang’s ongoing project that delves into one micronarrative to have taken root after Japan’s invasion and eventual repatriation after World War Two: the ‘marriage’ of Southeast Asian women to Japanese soldiers and the children, produced through this union, who continue to live in Southeast Asia today. 

The Vietnam chapter of this project took nearly two years (between 2011 and 2013) to produce and involved his travelling the length of Vietnam to understand the personal stories of the Vietnamese women and the half Vietnamese, half Japanese children that were ‘left behind’ by their Japanese military husbands or fathers. The numerous stories expressed and collected filled Phan Quang with a deluge of historical and intimate facts that interlaced with the weight of emotion carried on the shoulders of these women throughout the 70 years since the end of World War Two. In his series, Phan Quang utilises the thin, light and transparent materiality of the chiffon fabric that he sourced from a factory in Kyoto, Japan, (whilst on residency in the country) as a tool to ‘carve’ out a space for these previously concealed relationships to ‘breathe’; in covering these singular Vietnamese women or the half Vietnamese, half Japanese families with the chiffon, Phan Quang attempts to recover a microhistory of Vietnam.

title_text: All Lines Flow Out
physical_appearance: This installation depicts two large hanging drainage socks in the middle of the room. Each drainage sock contains a large amount of detritus.
subject_terms_1: mixed media video recordings drains metaphor
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Mixed media (Art) Video recording Drainage Singapore Metaphor
sgcool_label_text:
All Lines Flow Out takes the viewer through the monsoon drains of Singapore, drawing attention to the vast network of longkangs (the local term for the massive monsoon drains) which form an unintended map of the country. It is a journey that ends when the rainwater meet and merge with the sea between Singapore and Malaysia. Unfolding along a loose narrative, various individuals are met along the way, each of them has a singular – though not-always pleasant – encounter with the waters. History and personal memory are summoned too, through a brief voice-over from the last inhabitant of Singapore’s final remaining house by the sea.

Informed by Lim’s own experience as a former national sailor, the work is shaped by what the artist perceives as a paradoxical relationship that Singaporeans often have towards water and the sea. Growing up in a densely populated and highly urbanised environment, few residents on the island show a natural affinity for the very thing that circumscribes its shores. Nonetheless, water sits high on the national consciousness: regarded as a critical resource to ensure national security and survival, it is vigilantly managed and ordered. Yet at times, the human desire for order is upturned when Nature returns with fury in torrential downpours that have caused flash floods in the very heart of the city.

title_text: Act 4 Scene 2 (Episode 1 Finale): The Mistakes I Made While Building The Joe Schooling Swimming School Diorama
materials_name: resin (organic material) clay paint (coating) paper (fiber product) acrylic paint wood (plant material)
physical_appearance: This installation depicts a diorama of a swimming complex. The miniature swimming pool is encased in a wooden box and presented on top of a wooden stool. In the pool, there are eight demarcated lanes. There are several human figurines in the swimming pool. Some are fully submerged while others are submerged midway.
subject_terms_1: dioramas swimming swimming pools
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Schooling, Joseph, 1995- Yip, Pin Xiu, 1992- Diorama Swimming Swimming pools
subject_terms_3: Installation art Schooling, Joseph Isaac Yip, Pin Xiu Swimming
sgcool_label_text:
Act 4 Scene 2 (Episode 1 Finale): The Mistakes I Made While Building The Joe Schooling Swimming School Diorama was first shown at FOST Gallery in “Solid Prayers”, Chun Kai Qun’s first significant solo exhibition in Singapore. Chun (b. 1982), who by his own admission is “the quintessential object maker”, is interested in the study of what he terms “object biographies”, as a means of better understanding how everyday objects function as a reflection of personal tastes, attributes, moral principles and social ideals. This research drives his artistic practice and materialises mainly in the form of sculptures and installations. Chun received his MFA from the Glasgow School of Art, and is the co-founder of the curatorial collective LATENT SPACES, which reinvents idle spaces in Singapore as platforms for experimental art. In 2015, he was conferred the Young Artist Award, Singapore’s highest recognition for young art practitioners.
In the words of curator Michelle Ho, who penned an accompanying essay for the exhibition, Chun’s works “have been conceived with an awareness of the improbability of their realisations, and a sense of the futility of their endeavours …… what is noteworthy is the artist’s outright disclosure of his failure.” Of the present work, she writes: “The Mistakes I’ve Made While Building The Joe Olympic Swimming School Diorama started as his intent to make a diorama, based on his reflections of the journeys of Olympic champion Joseph Schooling and Paralympian Yip Pin Xiu, and how their stories provided alternative accounts regarding the ease of achieving one’s dreams. In the process of making the work, he noted some less than satisfactory results – defects that occurred - and Chun turned them into the basis of the artwork. The work became an artwork about itself, with the confessions of an artist detailing his imperfect skills. More critically, Chun also deals with the perception of failure, and its relativity …… By embarking on the futile endeavours that he insists on pursuing, and navigating through unfavourable conditions that he has chosen to situate his works within, Chun turns failure into productive engagements …… Such is the nature of Chun’s works which operate in the realm between heroic aspiration and absurdity, using humour and failure to play off the futility of ambition against the ideal of excellence, and through such an artistic determination, bring about new possibilities for expanding the purpose of art.” (Ho, “Flawed Miracles – The Art of Chun Kai Qun”, 2016.) 
What is particularly striking about Mistakes, then, is the salient disjuncture between its ostensible theme, success, and its material being, its status as a failed experiment. Joseph Schooling, of course, stands as the epitome of success, being the first Singaporean to win a gold medal at the summer Olympics; in that regard, he also serves as an encapsulation of the Singapore Story, with its emplotted trajectory of overcoming almost insurmountable hurdles, and moving from a third world outpost to a flourishing first world economy. Joseph Schooling, is success incarnate, the Singapore Story made flesh. Juxtaposed against this shining beacon is the abject condition of the object, an attempt gone awry in the studio: “Chun features small figures who gamely swim or sink within a swimming pool of solidified resin, disingenuously admitting to several minute “errors” (“I glued down number 2 crooked”)—which naturally triggers compulsory inspection of the work.” (from a review of the show on Art Asia Pacific’s online edition, by Marybeth Stock). In purporting to depict a success story, what Chun has done instead is to present a failure as a finished product, to expand the conceptual notions of object-making.

title_text: Boundary Fluidity
physical_appearance: This is a multimedia work that is comprised of acrylic painted tarpaulins and the screening of a single channel video.
subject_terms_1: acrylic paintings (visual works)  historical maps  identity  boundaries
subject_terms_2: Multimedia (Art) Tarpaulins  Video recordings  Acrylic painting  Maps  Identity  Boundaries  Art, Malaysian
sgcool_label_text:
Sino-Malaysian artist Chong Kim Chiew (b. 1975) graduated from the Guangzhou Academy of Fine Art in Guangzhou, China, majoring in oil painting. His practice encompasses both the two- and three-dimensional, with the latter most often assuming the form of site-responsive installations, which are critical engagements with the social and political connotations of the site of display, and the relation of the object to the space and architecture. Chong’s preferred mediums in the two-dimensional include painting and drawing, as well as new media formats such as video. 

In the Boundary Fluidity series, Chong has produced a series of maps rendered on large pieces of tarpaulin, with an accompanying video. In a recent solo exhibition at Wei-Ling Gallery in Kuala Lumpur, these maps were hung from the ceiling, consecutively installed in one line, with others lying supine and spread out on the floor, or rolled-up and leaning against the wall. These maps, comprised of crimson, black, white, grey and bluish acrylic encrustations and criss-crossing webs of lines, cracks, tears and cuts, are palimpsestic renderings of historical maps of Malaya and the South China Sea region, from the colonial period and right up to the era of nation-building in the 1950s and ‘60s. Barely glimpsed the thick impasto are place names such as Gemas, Malinan, Malacca or Singapur - the old colonial Malaysia stated additionally in the words “Malaya Britanica”, separated or connected through a number of fine or bold lines. Though globalization suggests a de-territorialised world, borders are omnipresent and a sociological and political fact – controlling the movement and flow of communities and capital across the globe. As Chong himself observes, boundaries are fluid. They keep on transforming endlessly – a characteristic that also marks personal identity. According to Stewart Hall, identities are never completed, and, in fact, they are always in motion. They are the originary point of history; history and its changes are nothing but a mirror of the unstable human identities. From this perspective, the Boundary Fluidity series seems to transform the awareness of frontiers and borders as places of conflict into places of great potential. The many intertwined lines can be read as a grid system, a net holding together all the different spaces, places and identities; they even can suggest the growth of identities like rhizomes, into more complex and layered identities, suggesting pluralism or hybridity as our natural state of being.

Most pua sungkit have a red ground colour but this one is dyed indigo blue, making it one of the rarest Iban cloths produced.

physical_appearance: The image displays three paintings that are mounted alongside one another on the walls of a building. subject_terms_1: batik art paintings (visual works) Orchidaceae (family)
subject_terms_2: Paintings Triptychs Batik Cattleyas Art, Abstract
sgcool_label_text: In Istana Garden, Sarkasi Said has composed a symphony of vibrant colours inspired by the lush flora of the Istana garden. Conducted with energy and vigour, the colours harmonise, expressing the vitality of the tropical island of Singapore. Drawing his inspiration from the verdant flora in the Istana garden, the artist proposed an abstract rendering of the Cattleya orchid – the largest hybridised Orchid to be found in Singapore – on the batik medium. Sarkasi’s views the various varieties of plant-life are symbols of warmth and harmony; the vigorous growth of tropical flora an intimation of communal comity. Furthermore, the orchid serves as a symbol of an extension of friendship between countries in the Singaporean diplomatic context.

title_text: ? Tolong ?,? Tolong ?
physical_appearance: This painting is composed of two panels with similar iconography. At the top of the panel, is a row of Chinese coins with the character ? peppered in its midst. In the upper centre, is the word ? (greed). Prominent on each panel is a circular composition of repeated figure heads with the word ? (human) on its snout and a dollar sign alternating between the heads. The words ?? and ?? can be found on the middle of the left and right panel respectively. In the bottom center, is a figure head where the left side is grey with eye closed and the right black with eye opened. The figure wears a yellow hat in the shape of an ingot with two choppers on each side. They are tied together to a Chinese coin which is topped by a bowl with the word ? (eat).
subject_terms_1: Chinese scripts logograms (scripts) approximate symmetry
subject_terms_2: Acrylic painting  Chinese characters  Logography  Art, Malaysian  Symmetry (Art)
context_1: Painted Words and Written Paintings: For the Refined and for the Masses- A solo exhibition by Liew Kwai Fei
sgcool_label_text:
Liew Kwai Fei is a Sino-Malaysian artist whose primary medium is paint. Having graduated from the Malaysian Institute of Art (MIA), Liew got his start as an artist with the Ruman Air Panas collective (alongside such figures as Yap Sau Bin, Chong Kim Chiew, Phuan Thai Meng et al). The work produced in the early part of his career were non-figurative canvases in the lineage of mid-century abstraction, and its sub-categories of geometric abstraction, colour field painting, hard-edge painting and minimalism. Beginning in 2011 and 2012, however, Liew’s practice took a radically different tack. At a solo exhibition in 2012 at Valentine Willie Fine Art (where he had previously been employed as an gallery assistant), entitled “????, ????– Painted Words and Written Paintings: For the Refined and For the Masses”, he presented a series of compositions that included a grotesque, surreal iconography drawn from a personal and private visual language, with generous helpings of textual elements based on Chinese characters, sayings and cross-cultural punning. 

The present work, ? Tolong ?,? Tolong ?, was first shown in the VWFA solo exhibition. Being a former employee at the gallery, Liew was exposed to a kaleidoscopic range of artistic styles and a relatively liberal artistic atmosphere, which represented a liberation for him, but also accentuated his discomfort with that particular social milieu, which was English-speaking, westernized and globalized. Hailing from a Chinese-speaking, working-class background, Liew spent 3 years at MIA, specializing in traditional Chinese ink painting and calligraphy – a considerably brief education for an artistic beginner whose childhood and teenage years were defined by cultural signposts such as Japanese manga, Cantonese TVB dramas and popular cinema from Hong Kong, and local vernacular culture. In other words, Liew’s socio-economic class and attendant education marked out his outlook and cultural worldview as an artist, and the shift in his aesthetic language stemmed from a growing desire to reflect that background and the social divide he experienced; the resurgence of figurative forms in his formerly abstract compositions alludes to the tenets of both Marxism and modernism. (At the same time, Malaysian society – including both its middle and working classes – was going through a significant change, due largely to a popular social movement, Bersih, agitating against blatant corruption in the highest levels of the Najib administration.) From an abstract idiom devoid of narrative, Liew tried to develop a visual language that could speak to a local audience unfamiliar with the concerns and aesthetics of contemporary art in a globalized vein. 

Here, Liew also introduced calligraphy into his pictorial compositions, with handwritten Mandarin and Malay words in thick acrylic paints, creating readable logograms enfolded into his visual iconography. Beginning in 2011, the Chinese character ?(person, human) has appeared frequently in Liew’s works; it also figured in into other related words that share the same radical, such as in ?(greed). In ? Tolong ??? Tolong ?, the logogram of ?was embedded in the motif of cash coins; it has been multiplied and painted as the orange eyebrows or the black mustache, personifying both the official (?) and the businessman (?). Other elements issued from different registers of vernacular culture, ranging from amateurish mural painting in Chinese temples to the unrefined visuals of comic books from both Hong Kong and Japan, laid out in symmetric composition that recalls the tao-tie of ancient Chinese bronzes, and orchestrated like a chorus composed of axioms, myths and tricksters, depicting an absurd scene extracted from a national saga. The painting shows us an enclosed man-made system that looks like a pair of contaminated lungs in the process of an alchemic transmutation fueled by a permanent restructuring of power due to the unapologetic practice of *nepotism and *cronyism in the country.

sgcool_label_text: This is a photograph of Oei Tiong Ham, a wealthy businessman and Majoor (major) of the Chinese community in Semarang.  Seated on a chair, he is dressed in a suit, and was reportedly the first Chinese man in Semarang to adopt Western clothing, given its political significance. Oei Tiong Ham made his fortune in sugar production and opium trading and was known as the “Sugar King” of Indonesia, He donated land  for the construction of the Tao Nan School building (now  Peranakan Museum) in 1910. The rise in the number of photography studios in the 1850s led to the circulation of nineteenth-century European-styled portraits in the Straits Settlements and Dutch East Indies.

sgcool_label_text: The violin and the Malay drum (rebana) are two of the principal musical instruments used in Dondang Sayang, an exchange of songs, which made use of the pantun (a Malay poetic form). These instruments belonged to Koh Hoon Teck, who founded the Gunong Sayang Association in 1910, one of the first Peranakan theatre associations in Singapore, which is still active today. Koh excelled at the violin and also mentored prominent singers such as his nephew Gwee Peng Kwee. Koh’s company (founded in 1905), Koh and Company, published five volumes of Malay poems for Dondang Sayang which were compiled by Koh and his father.

sgcool_label_text: This photograph shows Tan Beng Wan (1851-1891) wearing traditional Han Chinese dress of a jacket (magua) and long robe (changpao). He poses in what is likely to be a photographic studio, leaning against a draped balustrade. Tan Beng Wan was the eldest son of Tan Kim Tian, with whom he founded Tan Kim Tian and Son Steamship Company in 1871. The firm was one of the first in Singapore to buy and build ships. He also served as Municipal Commissioner from 1888 until his death. This photograph came from the collection of Botan House, the ancestral home built by Tan Kim Tian.

sgcool_label_text: Tan Cheng Siang(1885-1977) looks out confidently at the viewer in this studio photograph. Wearing a double breasted suit, complete with a boutonniere and pocket watch, he sits before a plain backdrop with a panama hat by his side. The shop mark ‘Koon Sun Photographer, Singapore’ can be seen on the photograph. Koon Sun Photo Studio was located along South Bridge Road in Singapore’s city centre. It was one of the two photographic studios established by Lee Tat Loon and Lee Tit Loon, whose son went on to found Lee Brothers Studio. This photograph came from the collection of Botan House, the ancestral home built by Tan Kim Tian.

title_text: Portrait of Tan Kim Tian Tan Kim Tian
physical_appearance: This is a drawn portrait of Tan Kim Tian. He is depicted seated. There is an ornate table on the let, with a vase of flowers on it. He is dressed in a black jacket over a blue silk robe, and is holding a fan in his right hand. The face of the fan depicts a Chinese landscape painting. The drawing is largely creased and faded on some areas.

sgcool_label_text: In this portrait, Tan Kim Tian (1832-1882) is depicted seated by an ornate table, accompanied by objects that point to his learning, taste and wealth. Dressed in a black jacket (magua) over a blue silk robe (changpao), he holds a fan, on which a Chinese landscape painting is visible. The portrait is signed, ‘Drawn by Ong Kwee Huang, Coleman Street No. 22, Singapore, AD 1887.’ Together with his son Tan Beng Wan, Tan Kim Tian founded Tan Kim Tian and Son Steamship Company in 1871, which was one of the first in Singapore to buy and build ships. He was also the first president of the Tan clan temple. Botan House was built by Tan Kim Tian in 1883 at the corner of Neil Road and Craig Road (since demolished).

title_text: Mirror
physical_appearance: This is a mirror. It is framed by wooden beams with engraved incised designs. The top of the mirror is decorated with a balustrade of small spindles. The top of the mirror features carved flowers and vines against a speckled background in a triangular shape. There are small carvings along the left and right side of the mirror frame as well.
subject_terms_1: carvings (visual works) Peranakan cultural diffusion furniture
subject_terms_2: Mirrors Culture diffusion Peranakan (Asian people) Furniture
sgcool_label_text: This mirror is framed by beams with incised designs, including a balustrade formed by finely carved spindles. This is crowned by a gable filled with carvings of flowers and vines against a speckled background. With its features inspired by European architecture, this mirror is a modest example of Peranakan hybrid tastes. Teak furniture whose designs were inspired by English styles was popular among Peranakans since the late 19th century. This mirror came from the collection of Botan House, the ancestral home built by Tan Kim Tian in 1883 at the corner of Neil Road and Craig Road (since demolished).

title_text: Gold buckle with silver belt
materials_name: gold (metal)  silver (metal) * I put this because the belt is actually silver
physical_appearance: This is a silver belt fastened with a gold buckle. The buckle has lobed edges, an escutcheon in the center, surrounded by birds and foliage in open metal work. The belt is made of links and three rows of florets.
subject_terms_1: belt buckles  florets (tools)  coats of arms  foliage (motif)  birds (motif)
subject_terms_2: Belts (Clothing)  Escutcheons (Heraldry) Birds in art  Flowers in art Leaves in art
sgcool_label_text: This gold buckle with lobed edges has at its centre an escutcheon flanked by two birds with their wings outstretched as if in flight.  The composition resembles a coat of arms and is seamlessly woven into the background of rich foliage, all cast in delicate openwork. The shape of the buckle is a variation of the ogive which was popular among the Malays and Peranakan Chinese. Nyonyas often wore buckles with metal belts. The owner wore this buckle with a silver belt, made up of links and three rows of florets.

title_text: Gold buckle and belt
physical_appearance: This is a gold belt with a gold buckle. The overall decorative scheme is an interplay of stylised ribbons where some strands have been chased to give an added texture to the item.
subject_terms_1: belt buckles  stylization
subject_terms_2: Belts (Clothing)  Straits Settlements  Palembang (Indonesia)
sgcool_label_text: The buckle of the gold belt features a dynamic interplay of stylised ribbons, some of which are lightly chased to give the effect of depth and texture. This Art Deco pattern is repeated in the smaller plaques of pierced gold. Several markings can be found on the back : Dun jing (?? or pound gold), ??, ??, and ‘HP’. While belts with multiple panels were popular in the Straits Settlements at the beginning of the 20th century, the style could be traced to the courts of Palembang.

title_text: Painted Chinese Silk Gown For The European Market  Robe a la francaise
physical_appearance: This is a silk robe a la francaise with an open front. It is decorated with flowers that were hand-painted.
subject_terms_1: womenswear flower (motif)  imports  cultural diffusion  hand-painted
subject_terms_2: Dressmaking  Dresses Women's clothing  Silk  Flowers in art  Imports  Culture diffusion
sgcool_label_text:
This gown made of imported Chinese hand-painted silk reflects how Europe acquired luxurious Chinese export textiles to be tailored by French dressmakers into fashionable Western silhouettes. This sack-back gown style (robe a la francaise) with open front showing a decorative petticoat, and fabric at the back arranged in large flat pleats from the shoulder to the floor opening into a full skirt, was popular in 18th-century Europe. The featured flowers are quite distinctively British, such as roses, carnations (pinks) and lilac. 

Chinese export silks and wallpapers were probably hand-painted in the same workshops in Guangzhou, and appreciated extensively by wealthy Europeans in their dress and home furnishings since the 18th century. In technique and design, such silk textiles also suggest a Chinese market response to the European fascination in Indian painted cottons.

title_text: Standing Buddha
physical_appearance: This is an ivory figure of a standing buddha. His right hand is raised in the vitarka mudra, whist his left hand is placed by his side. The identifiable physical attributes (lakshana) are the flaming ushnisha, the snail-shell coils as his hair, the elongated ear lobes, and the lotus flower upon which he stands. His eyes are closed, and the monastic robe clings onto his body and reaches down to his ankles.
subject_terms_1: Buddhism  vitarka mudra  sculpture
subject_terms_2: Buddha  Buddhism  Figurines Sculpture
sgcool_label_text:
The Buddha has the deeply folded robes, and an erect posture, which are prevalent in this period in Sri Lanka. The end of his robe is placed over his left shoulder, with his left arm by his side. The right hand forms a gesture of teaching. He stands on a delicately articulated lotus base. The flame usnisha, also a distinctive feature of Sri Lanka Buddha figures, is separately carved. 

The Buddhist faith witnessed a revival during the 18th century in Sri Lanka under the reign of Kirti Sri Rajasimha (1747-1782). Ivory for Buddhist imagery was used more frequently from then onwards. The refinement in the art of ivory carving achieved by artists can be seen in this piece.

title_text: View of the East India Company Factory At Cossimbazar From The Other Of The Hooghly River
physical_appearance: This is a watercolour painting of a landscape scenery. The East India Company factory is seen in the background, and the Union Jack can be found flying high on the right. A river separates the foreground from the background; on it several boats are cruising.
subject_terms_1: factories (organizations) boats  landscapes (representations)
subject_terms_2: Painting East India Company  Cossimbazar (India) Factories  Boats  Landscapes Hugli River (India)
context_1:
The Allure of India: Company School Painting from Murshidabad & Patna 1795-1830 exhibition For more see: 
Francesca Galloway. (2017). The Allure of India Company School Painting from Murshidabad & Patna 1795-1830. Retrieved February 7, 2018, from https://www.francescagalloway.com/usr/documents/exhibitions/list_of_works_url/30/the-allure-of-india-may-exhibition-francesca-galloway.pdf
sgcool_label_text:
This painting comes under the broad category known as “Company paintings” – referring to a variety of Indo-European styles that were so called because many of their patrons worked for the European East India Companies (EICs). Local artists realised that patronage was shifting from the old Indian aristocracy to the new European traders and military officers in the suburbs and began to adapt to their new patrons’ tastes.

The main body of Company painting in Eastern and Upper India developed in the late 18th century in Murshidabad, West Bengal where contact with the Europeans were particularly strong as the Portuguese, British, Dutch and French EICs all maintained factories at Cossimbazar, an important trading centre. This painting was most likely commissioned by a British patron as evident by the factory’s architecture and the depiction of the Union Jack flag proudly flown in front of the building.

title_text: The Taj Mahal From Across the River (Tadjemehall sur la Jamna )
physical_appearance: This is a watercolour painting of a scenic landscape. Running across the center horizon of the painting is the Taj Mahal. Separating that from the foreground is a calm river with a single boat. The still water is implied by the reflection of the Taj Mahal; as seen in the water. In the foreground, the land is bare except for several standing individuals.
subject_terms_1: landscapes (representations)
subject_terms_2: Painting Taj Mahal (Agra, India)  Murshidabad (India) Landscapes Yamuna River (India)
context_1:
The Allure of India: Company School Painting from Murshidabad & Patna 1795-1830 exhibition For more see: 
Francesca Galloway. (2017). The Allure of India Company School Painting from Murshidabad & Patna 1795-1830. Retrieved February 7, 2018, from https://www.francescagalloway.com/usr/documents/exhibitions/list_of_works_url/30/the-allure-of-india-may-exhibition-francesca-galloway.pdf
sgcool_label_text:
This painting comes under the broad category known as “Company paintings” – referring to a variety of Indo-European styles that were so called because many of their patrons worked for the European East India Companies. These paintings were often commissioned as souvenirs of the European patrons’ sojourns in Asia. Styles or schools were typically associated with places of artistic production. 

Unusually, this view of the Taj Mahal from across the Yamuna river in the city of Agra was painted over a thousand kilometres away by a Murshidabad artist. The lack of detail on the Taj Mahal buildings and the naturalistic watercolour style suggests the possibility that the artist may not have seen the Taj Mahal and modelled this painting on sketches or paintings by visiting European artists. By comparison, Agra artists tended to use draughtsman techniques to produce paintings or drawings of the Taj Mahal as meticulously detailed, architectural renderings.

title_text: A Muslim Wedding Ceremony
physical_appearance: This painting depicts the scene of a Muslim wedding ceremony taking place under a red canopy. Women are seated around the perimeter of the canopy. In the center, the bride and groom are separated by a piece of cloth held up by two ladies. The groom is seated on a low chair to the left, while the bridge stands on the right.
subject_terms_1: genre (visual works) weddings (ceremonies) folk costume customs (social concepts)
subject_terms_2: Painting Ethnic costume  Weddings Islamic marriage customs and rites
subject_terms_3: Watercolour painting Ethnic costumes Marriage customs
context_1:
The Allure of India: Company School Painting from Murshidabad & Patna 1795-1830 exhibition For more see: 
Francesca Galloway. (2017). The Allure of India Company School Painting from Murshidabad & Patna 1795-1830. Retrieved February 7, 2018, from https://www.francescagalloway.com/usr/documents/exhibitions/list_of_works_url/30/the-allure-of-india-may-exhibition-francesca-galloway.pdf
sgcool_label_text:
This painting comes under the broad category known as “Company paintings” – referring to a variety of Indo-European styles that were so called because many of their patrons worked for the European East India Companies. The primary motivation of these patrons for collecting such paintings was purportedly documentary hence Company paintings generally depict scenes of daily life, occupations, festivals, architecture, local flora and fauna. This painting belongs to the Patna school, considered to be one of the most prolific centres as Patna rose in prominence and prosperity under British administration, prompting artists to move from Murshidabad. This painting appears to reflect the style of Sewak Ram, one of the more renowned painter who had migrated to Patna from Murshidabad in 1790.There is no evidence however to suggest that Sewak Ram was indeed the artist of this piece.

This vibrant painting offers a glimpse into the myriad rituals that constitute traditional Muslim wedding customs in India. Although only the nikah (solemnisation ceremony) and a feast (walima) are required to conduct a wedding according to Islamic orthodoxy, additional local traditions may be incorporated. The scene most likely corresponds to the sharbat pilai ceremony that takes place immediately after the nikah ceremony, where the bridegroom is taken into the bride’s house among the company of womenfolk from the couple’s families, to drink the sharbat, a sweet syrup.

title_text: Reliquary crucifix
physical_appearance: This is a reliquary crucifix. On one side  of the object, is a three dimensional figure of Christ Crucified. Above him, is a plaque with the words INRI, and beneath his feet is the image of a skull. The sides of the cross are decorated with scrolling foliage motifs and symbols of the Passion of Christ. A figure of the Virgin Mary praying with her hands clasped is found on the other side. There are knobs on the bottom and on the arms of the cross.
subject_terms_1: reliquaries  foliage (motif)  missionaries  Christianity Roman Catholicism
subject_terms_2: Reliquary crosses  Pendants (Jewelry) Jesus Christ  Christianity  Mary, Blessed Virgin, Saint.  Jesus Christ Passion Leaves in art  Missions  Catholic Church
sgcool_label_text:
This crucifix pendant is actually a reliquary. The knob at the bottom of the cross unscrews and panels on both sides open to reveal small compartments. Relics and other valuable items could be stored within. 

On one side, there is a figure of Christ Crucified. On the other side is a figure of the Virgin Mary. The blooms below her feet are unusual and quite interesting: they appear to be a chrysanthemums, a flower popular in Japanese decorative arts. This crucifix reliquary was, in fact, made in Japan, perhaps for Western Christian missionaries working there. The decoration was made with a technique called sawasa, which involves applying lacquer to a gilded metal surface, then both incising and adding raised relief decoration to create stunning contrasts in black and gold.

title_text: Three Horizons
physical_appearance: This is a colourful oil painting done on three boards. The central figure is a female nude, and her figure spreads across the boards with her head being in the right most panel. For the middle panel, the figure's torso appears to have been cut open; her internal organs are exposed, and a fluid seems to be gushing out. As for her legs, they have been executed in an abstract form that causes the figure to appear blended with the background.
subject_terms_1: nudes (representations)  abstraction  Surrealist
subject_terms_2: Art, Malaysian Triptychs  Art, Abstract Surrealism
context_7: Ministry of Culture, Youth, and Sports
sgcool_label_text:
Ismail Mustam was born in Sabak Bernam, Selangor in 1944. He attended the Malay School at Sungai Air Tawar (1950-53), and the Government English School in Sabak Bernam (1954-56). He studied at the Victoria Institution in Kuala Lumpur (1957-61). As an artist, Ismail is primarily self taught. He did, however, received the guidance of his art teacher, Patrick Ng, as a student at the Victoria Institution and a member of the Wednesday Art Group. Before turning twenty-five in 1969, he had been a temporary art teacher at the Government Secondary School in Sabak Bernam (1962), a book illustrator with Dewan Bahasa dan Pustaka (Language and Literature Agency) (1963-65), and a designer at the Handicraft Development Centre of the MARA Institute of Technology (UiTM) (1966-69). 

He clinched the first prize for his work, ‘Evolution’ (1968), in the batik category at Salon Malaysia in 1968. ‘Evolution’ was selected for Malaysia’s participation at the 10th Sao Paulo Biennial held in 1969. Another three of his batik paintings were also showcased at the Biennial. With a scholarship from UiTM, Ismail studied advertising design at the Art Centre College of Design in Los Angeles, USA between 1969 and 1971, graduating with a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree. He worked at Leo Burnett Advertising (1971-81) as its art director. He later joined Johan Design Associates (1981-82) as an associate creative director, and eventually set up his own agency, Ismail & Associates, in 1983 where he served as its managing creative director until 2009. Throughout his practice, the artist has produced works of diverse stylistic expression which may have been influenced by the training he received and his experiences in different artistic fields, namely illustration, textile design and graphic design. 

Through his work, Ismail has contributed to Malaysia’s nation-building projects locally and internationally. For instance, his mural design, which is discussed below, was used for the façade of a government building in the country’s capital. The painting proposed for this acquisition was produced in the 1960s, a critical time for a newly-independent nation during which the government sought ways – in this case, visual and artistic – to project national ideals to a wide audience. ‘Three Horizons’ was part of a travelling exhibition in Europe between 1965 and 1967. Sponsored by the Ministry of Culture, Youth and Sports, this exhibition showcased a selection of paintings and sculptures by contemporary Malaysian/Singaporean artists such as Latiff Mohidin, Chuah Thean Teng, Cheong Soo Pieng, Chen Wen Hsi, Hoessein Enas, Syed Ahmad Jamal and Khoo Sui Hoe. 

Ismail experienced early success in his late teens. When he was only seventeen years old and a pupil at the Victoria Institution, he was regarded as a prodigy after making an entry into the arena of public art when, in 1961, his first mural design won the grand prize in a nation-wide competition and was chosen to adorn the façade of Dewan Bahasa dan Pustaka (DBP). His design materialised into a 64 ¼ x 34 ¼ ft (approx. 20 x 10m) mosaic which was celebrated as “the largest in the country” in 1962 (“A Mighty Mural Gets Its Final Touches”, The Straits Times, 31 January 1962, p. 20). 

‘Three Horizons’ is a triptych – of semi-abstract paintings – which depicts a stylized, nude female figure lying on her side, with her head in the right-most panel, her torso in the middle and her lower body in the left-most one. Her long spiny fingers resemble claws, and her hands are tied loosely together with what looks like a red barbed wire. Parts of her stomach and legs appear as though the skin had been cut open, exposing her internal organs and muscles, and suggesting a surrealist touch to the painting. The painting also displays cubist elements as seen with the different angles by which the face and body were rendered. Done in a palette of reds, browns, oranges, yellows and blues, the female figure stands out against a dark, quiet background. A horizon runs across the three panels at the top of the work. A solitary moon is positioned at a distance in the middle panel. Despite standing out against the background, the figure appears to fuse with the background at some parts. The left-most panel, for instance, shows her lower body abstracted to look as though it is part of a mountainous landscape. 

Produced when Ismail was twenty-one years old and prior to the formal art training he underwent in the late 1960s, ‘Three Horizons’ bears a composition and stylistic approach that are arguably influenced by the work he had done for the mural designs in the early 1960s. Here he created an image of a stylized figure that is laid out across three segments of a pictorial space, with each segment focusing on different parts of the female figure.

title_text: The Grand Phantom Narrates
physical_appearance: This is an installation piece comprising of half a red picture frame hung on one side of the wall whilst the other -which is white- is affixed on the opposing side. A red carpet is also placed on either side of the wall.
subject_terms_1: politics  carpets  picture frames  power
subject_terms_2: Art, Malaysian  Installations (Art)  Autonomy  Picture frames and framing Carpets  Political power
sgcool_label_text: Yap Sau Bin was one of the founders of the Malaysian collective, Rumah Air Panas, He first showed, as a solo artist, in 2000 at Galerie Petronas, and – more significantly – he participated, the same year, in the Bakat Muda Sezaman (“Young Contemporaries”) competition organized by the National Visual Arts Gallery, with a work titled Youthful Contention not (  ) Parental Eclipse.  (The Young Contemporaries award was started by the NVAG in 1974.) He participated twice more, in 2002 and 2004, with … Who Gave Birth to the Great White One … and The Grand Phantom Narrates, respectively. Yap considers these early works a trilogy or series of sorts (post facto). They mark the beginning of his practice as a conceptually-driven artist; the Bakat Muda Sezaman (BSM) series is primarily concerned with the interrogation and deconstruction of social and institutional contexts, esp. those in which hierarchies of power are operative. He was particularly interested in looking critically at exhibitionary and museological contexts, or how such frameworks impart significance and determine meaning with regards to art objects. The Grand Phantom Narrates, the last in this loose trilogy, is more explicitly concerned with political power. The piece is Yap’s response to the momentous resignation of Mahathir as prime minister of Malaysia in 2003. (The latter is, perhaps, the Grand Phantom and narrator of the title, possessing the wherewithal to shape discourse.) The work is an installation, comprised of half a red picture frame hung on one side of a white wall, and, on the other, another half picture frame, this time in white; on the ground, under each half-frame, is a piece of red carpet, also looking like it was cut in half. Viewed from the side, the installation is meant to evoke the sight of a red canvas passing through a white wall, and emerging on the other side of the wall rendered white. The wall, of course, is a metonym for the institution (as it physically was, during the work’s initial display at the NVAG in 2004). The cultural institution is here conflated with political ones, and both stand as symbols of power, and the way that this institutional power – whether cultural, as with the museum, or political, as with the prime ministership – whitewashes and controls individual autonomy and subjectivity.

title_text: Rape and Pillage
physical_appearance: This is an installation work consisting of 39 Thai civil service uniforms, each with an embroidered portrait of a Thai politician. The uniforms hover above the ground.
subject_terms_1: politicians  embroidery (visual works)  uniforms  public services (organizations) social issues
subject_terms_2: Thailand  Politicians  Civil service  Uniforms  Installations (Art)  Embroidery
sgcool_label_text: Thai artist Jakkai Siributr is best known for his works in the textile medium. Featuring intricate embroidery and needlework, Jakkai confronts socio-political issues afflicting Thailand through the medium of fabric. In his numerous exploration of the turbulent Thai political scene, Jakkai hasn’t shied away from vocal critique. Immediately confrontational, Rape and Pillage features 39 white polyester jacket and trouser uniforms worn by the Thai civil service. Each uniform has been embroidered with the portrait of a Thai politician. Hovering off the ground, these uniforms strike the viewer as spectral representations of the politicians. Jakkai’s distrust of the state’s political leaders rings clear – the title of the work makes no attempt at concealing any disdain whatsoever. Yet, the work is also an invitation to viewers to cast their own judgement on these leaders themselves.In a time of political instability, the textile-based practice of Jakkai Siributr stands as a stark contrast to the state of affairs in the country today. The meticulously-crafted and labour-intensive hand-made pieces, all slow, skillful precision and carefully worked stitching, are in their sobriety and virtuosity in absolute opposition to the ethos of Thai public affairs today: fast, thoughtless, and random.

title_text: Certificate of Merit presented to Lim Chong Pang
physical_appearance: This is a certificate of merit presented to Lim Chong Pang by Kanichi Naito, Mayor of Syonan. Framing the words is a red floral border and a crest (stylised ?) at the top of the paper.
subject_terms_1: social recognition local histories
subject_terms_2: Local history  Compliments
subject_terms_3: 1942-1945 Japanese occupation History Lim, Chong Pang
sgcool_label_text:
Certificate of Merit presented to Lim Chong Pang by the Mayor of Syonan (1945)

This is a Certificate of Merit presented to Lim Chong Pang by the Mayor of Syonan, Kanichi Naito in 1945. 
Lim Chong Pang (1904 –1956) was the second son of Lim Nee Soon, the “Pineapple King” of Singapore. A prominent businessman, the range of Lim Chong Pang’s businesses included property and estate management, film production and movie theatres. He was also the director of the Overseas Assurance Corporation, a company his father co-founded.   
Like other prominent community leaders, Lim Chong Pang was imprisoned when the Japanese invaded Singapore in 1942 and was released on the condition that he will support the Japanese war effort by raising funds. He was made a council member of the Overseas Chinese Association (OCA) of Syonan and was the vice-chairman of the propaganda department. In 15 February 1945, he was one of thirty-eight local residents given a Certificate of Merit at the Dai Toa Gakjio (Greater East Asian Theatre) for their valuable services rendered to the Administration.

title_text: In Between Spaces
physical_appearance: This installation depicts a triptych of concrete panels. On each panel, there are narrow strips of photographic prints set in shallow trenches cut into the surface of the panels. The trench on the top panel is cut vertically, the second horizontally, while the third panel only has a short trench on the bottom left corner.
subject_terms_1: mixed media photographs symbolism urban development nature trails urban environments triptychs
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Mixed media (Art) Photography Symbolism Urbanisation Nature Triptychs
subject_terms_3: Installation art Photography Nature and Environment
sgcool_label_text: In Between Spaces is a collaboration between Singaporean artist Zen Teh and product designer, Sharifah Nasser. Teh (b. 1988) was educated at the School of Art, Design and Media of NTU, and has so far been included in numerous group shows locally, and abroad in Thailand, Taiwan and China; she enjoyed a solo presentation at 2902 Gallery in their former Waterloo space. Her practice is defined by her interest in the impact of human activity and urban expansion on the natural world, especially in Southeast Asia, and often assumes the mediums of photography, sculpture and installation, integrating photographic images in three-dimensional forms. The present work consists of a triptych of raw concrete panels, into which has been set – in shallow trenches cut into the surface of the panels – narrow strips of photographic prints on dibond. The images are of the Green Corridor, an uninterrupted stretch of natural greenery that runs the entire length of Singapore, from the old Tanjong Pagar Rail Station in the south to the border of Malaysia in the north; the stretch, of course, once marked the extent of the Malaysian KTM line that reached its southern terminus in Singapore. The material configurations of the piece are symbolic and immediately recognizable: the concrete suggests the rapid and large-scale urbanization of the island’s terrain, and the strips of images of vegetation evokes the corridor itself, a confined, circumscribed island of natural flora adrift in a sea of unchecked development – at the expense of the environment.

title_text: Tanah Impian (Dream Land) Exposition de Paris
physical_appearance: This is a silkscreen print depicting a scene outside of the exhibition compounds of the Exposition de Paris in 1900. The Indonesian flag is seen to be hanging on a pole that is attached to a roof on the top right corner.
subject_terms_1: identity  nationalism  world's fairs  posters ways of life  popular culture  appropriation (imagery) redesign
subject_terms_2: Serigraphy Art, Indonesian Nationalism Identity  Exposition universelle (1900: Paris, France) Posters Ways of life Popular culture  Appropriation (Art) Adaptations
subject_terms_3: Visual arts  Art exhibitions National identity  Poster art  Media and advertising  Popular culture
sgcool_label_text: Tanah Impian (Dream Land) is a series of prints based on images drawn from Indonesian popular culture, spanning 100 years. The project was conceived in 2014, the year of the elections in Indonesia when nationalist rhetoric dominated public consciousness, Artist collective Krack Studio sifted through a mass of research and archival material, eventually selecting 24 images that referenced the idea of the Indonesian Dream and / or told an interesting story about changing definitions of the ‘Nation’. Ranging from political posters to advertisements, comic strips, movie posters and magazines, these images, reconstructed and re-imagined by the artist collective, chronicle Indonesia’s evolving aspirations, desires and identity, as well as how Indonesia has been perceived and imaged for the ‘Western’ gaze.

sgcool_label_text: Tanah Impian (Dream Land) is a series of prints based on images drawn from Indonesian popular culture, spanning 100 years. The project was conceived in 2014, the year of the elections in Indonesia when nationalist rhetoric dominated public consciousness, Artist collective Krack Studio sifted through a mass of research and archival material, eventually selecting 24 images that referenced the idea of the Indonesian Dream and / or told an interesting story about changing definitions of the ‘Nation’. Ranging from political posters to advertisements, comic strips, movie posters and magazines, these images, reconstructed and re-imagined by the artist collective, chronicle Indonesia’s evolving aspirations, desires and identity, as well as how Indonesia has been perceived and imaged for the ‘Western’ gaze.

title_text: Mavis
physical_appearance: This is a sculpture of a lady. She has short hair, and sharp features. Her head turns away from the viewer, and her collar bones are defined. The sculpture is realistic in its style.
subject_terms_1: realism (artistic form of expression)
subject_terms_2: Portrait sculpture  Realism in art  Eurasians
sgcool_label_text: \Annaratnam Gunaratnam was a women who has sustained her practice through commissions. She was an important artist in the genre of portrait sculpture. She produced portrait sculptures of many dignitaries like Mahatma Gandhi
column51: and Swami Vivekananda
column52: were presented to the Ramakrishna Mission Bartley Road Singapore. She was also important in the field of art education. She taught art at the Methodist Girls' School
column53: Kuala Lumpur
column54: and then as head of the art department at the Raffles Girls' Secondary School from 1948 to 1968 in Singapore. She also taught art to boys at the Beatty Secondary School before her early retirement.

accession_no_csv: This sculpture shows strong technical ability in casting
Image: capturing the flowing lines of her clothes and detailed features of her facial expression. Her commitment to realism is shown in her focus on details and her representation of women not as \"\"idealised types\"\" but as an individual with her own subjectivity"

title_text: Saeta 44
materials_name: oil paint (paint)  canvas (textile material)  canvas board
physical_appearance: This is a semi-abstract oil painting executed in rapid strokes of colour in various directions against a predominantly black and dark brown colour field.
subject_terms_1: abstraction  modern (generic time frame)
subject_terms_2: Art, Abstract Art, Philippine Modernism (aesthetic) Postwar reconstruction  Painting
sgcool_label_text:
Fernando Zóbel (1924-1984) was a self-taught artist who was a central figure in the development of postwar modern art in the Philippines in the 1950s. He, like other Philippine artists at that time, were experimenting with semi-abstract forms and Zóbel initially drew particular inspiration from Philippine folk art, even authoring the book Philippine Colonial Sculpture (1958) due to his interests. He, and the circle of artists he found camaraderie with, frequented and exhibited at the Philippine Art Gallery, a small gallery dedicated to modern art which gave young artists an opportunity to exhibit their works. These artists were often viewed in opposition to the conservative group, who made figurative and idealized images after the works of established artist Fernando Amorsolo. Artists like Zóbel felt what was important was the quality of painting, rather than the modern vs conservative debate.  While he was a leading figure in Philippine abstraction, Zóbel also remarked, “The whole abstract versus figurative bores me; I find it beside the point.” 

Zóbel initially struggled with abstraction but found the language he was seeking in his Saeta series. The Saetas, in their inspiration in the numerous scaffoldings Zóbel was exposed to in his family business, also reflect the rapid urbanization and reconstruction of Manila after the devastation of World War II. The architect Leandro Locsin, who Zóbel often worked with and whose modernist structures were congruent with Zóbel’s tastes, recounted that Zóbel had told him, “My God, look at all these scaffoldings, they’re beautiful! There are so many ugly buildings around that many times, the scaffoldings are even more beautiful than the buildings.”

In terms of technique, Zóbel had initially struggled with creating thin, controllable lines with oil paint, eventually arriving at using a glass hypodermic syringe with its needle removed. The solution came to him upon seeing a cook writing “Happy Birthday” in icing on a cake.

“Saeta 44” is a strong example which demonstrates Zóbel’s innovative technique and which also carries the narrative of Philippine postwar modernism, especially in how it was fostered after the war’s destruction and how Zóbel was one of the earliest artists in the Philippines to paint in abstraction. Lines of white and yellow paint splay out in numerous directions, forming several junctures and giving the impression of rapid movement. They particularly stand out over the layers of black and brown underpaint. While it seems like the work was made spontaneously, Zóbel often made several preparatory studies before painting and was a consummate drawer. He had even suggested that, “You might define the Saetas as drawing in thin lines against a field of color.”

sgcool_label_text: The Rafflesia patma is a parasitic plant species from the genus Rafflesia, named after Sir Stamford Raffles. In an expedition in Sumatra in 1821, Raffles together with the botanist Joseph came across the flower now known as the Rafflesia arnoldii. This coloured print of the Rafflesia patma was reproduced in horticultural journal Flore des serres et des Jardins de l'Europe, founded by the Belgian horticulturalist Louis Benoit van Houtte.

sgcool_label_text: This is a hardbound compilation of piano sheet music bearing the armorial booklate of Sir Thomas Stamford Raffles. Contained within is a page bearing his wife Sophia's handwritten playlist, possibly of her favourite songs. Lady Sophia Raffles, who married Sir Stamford Raffles in 1817, was an accomplished pianist.

title_text: Ceremonial Robe
physical_appearance:
This is an embroidered ceremonial robe that opens on the front. It has floral and vegetative motifs interspersed with images of anchors and ships' wheel.  A blue and silver star shaped insignia is found attached to the left breast of the robe.  For more on the artefact's history, please refer to: 

1. Brennan, Julia M. and Yaowalak Bunnag. (2014, March). Thai Official Rank Robes (Sua Khrui): History, Fabrication, and the Conservation of Admiral de Richelieu's 19th Century Robe. Arts of Asia. Retrieved March 13, 2018, from http://www.caringfortextiles.com/site3/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/Arts-of-Asia-March-2014.pdf 2. Thailand Tatler. (2015, December). The Royal Robes. Thailand Tatler. Retrieved March 13, 2018, from http://www.caringfortextiles.com/site3/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/RoyalRobesThaiTatler.pdf
subject_terms_1: insignias (devices)  cultural diffusion Flower (motif)  diplomacy
subject_terms_2: Regalia (Insignia) Robes  Ceremonial objects  Richelieu, Andreas du Plessis de, 1852-1932 Culture diffusion Flowers in art  Embroidery  Diplomacy
subject_terms_3: Textile art and design  Decorative arts
context_1: Bestowing of title and rank of The Most Illustrious Order of Chula Chom Klao by King Rama V to Danish Admiral Andreas du Plessis de Richelieu.
sgcool_label_text:
This traditional Thai ceremonial robe known as a sua kluah was presented to Admiral Andreas du Plessis de Richelieu by King Chulalongkorn in 1902. Richelieu, a Danish naval officer, rose to the rank of vice admiral of the Thai Navy. 

This type of robe was originally based on Persian or Moghul forms. By the 19th century, these types of robes had begun to incorporate design techniques of a European nature. The gold metallic embellishments probably come from France, with the decoration being similar to that of royal and military garments. This particular robe also has its own idiosyncratic hybrid aspects: its decoration includes images of anchors, whales, and ship’s wheels integrated into the floral patterns.

sgcool_label_text:
Rong Wong-Savun (b. 1932, d. 2009) first encountered photography at the age of 16-17, and taught himself to read the Kodak manual using a Thai-English dictionary. He developed photos until his fingernails were dyed black with darkroom chemicals. When he was twenty, he showed his photos to Mom Rajawongse Kukrit Pramoj, who admired his skills and bought the photos for his magazine. Having developed a rapport with M.R. Kukrit, ‘Rong eventually became a permanent employee at the Siam Rath Weekly Review. 

Echoing his early photographic subjects, his later literary pursuits reflected the world of the common, often underprivileged, people who were neglected and dismissed by society at large. 

Named a National Artist in the field of Literature in 1995, Rong is remembered as a pivotal and prolific writer who transformed the landscape of Thai literature through the topicality of his work and the originality of his language.

Named a National Artist in the field of Literature in 1995, Rong is remembered as a pivotal and prolific writer who transformed the landscape of Thai literature through the topicality of his work and the originality of his language.

sgcool_label_text:
Rong Wong-Savun (b. 1932, d. 2009) first encountered photography at the age of 16-17, and taught himself to read the Kodak manual using a Thai-English dictionary. He developed photos until his fingernails were dyed black with darkroom chemicals. When he was twenty, he showed his photos to Mom Rajawongse Kukrit Pramoj, who admired his skills and bought the photos for his magazine. Having developed a rapport with M.R. Kukrit, ‘Rong eventually became a permanent employee at the Siam Rath Weekly Review. 

Echoing his early photographic subjects, his later literary pursuits reflected the world of the common, often underprivileged, people who were neglected and dismissed by society at large. 

Named a National Artist in the field of Literature in 1995, Rong is remembered as a pivotal and prolific writer who transformed the landscape of Thai literature through the topicality of his work and the originality of his language.

title_text: Cadastre
materials_name: Vietnamese natural lacquer (so?n ta) on iron (75 individual tiles; 2.5kg each), wooden plinth painted with concrete.
physical_appearance: This is a floor sculpture composed of 75 lacquer tiles, each with a central floral design.
subject_terms_1: floor tile  flower (motif)  urban planning  Toxicodendron succedaneun (species) lands (general areas)
subject_terms_2: Tiles  Art, Vietnamese  Sculpture  Flower in art  Lacquer and lacquering  Cadastres City planning
sgcool_label_text:
As a term, ‘cadastre’ refers to an official register of land ownership comprising surveys that often include detailed investigations into the history of land use, and other legal accounts of title deeds. As an artwork, ‘Cadastre’ physically comprises 75 hand-produced, French colonial-era floral-designed lacquer tiles positioned on a raised platform. Contextually, ‘Cadastre’ refers to the collective sub-consciousness of the Vietnamese people, particularly those based in Hanoi, which is rooted in Vietnam’s history. Together, the 75 tiles amount to an area of 3 square meters – the precise area that each person in Hanoi was afforded during the country’s period of land reforms. One was confined to this area to live in, having to incorporate kitchen, toilet, and living area into this restrictive space.

Cadastre’ is a way for the artist to discover, discuss, show, the prevalent attitude towards land and ownership and show the material size and weight and conceptual “value” of land.

title_text: Untitled (MT_116)
physical_appearance: This is an acrylic on canvas painting in black. Brick lines are drawn in uniform grids. It is monumental in size.
subject_terms_1: monochrome Minimal  repetition (artistic concept)
subject_terms_2: Minimal art  Acrylic painting  Repetition (Aesthetics)
sgcool_label_text:
Like monochromatic monoliths, Maria Taniguchi’s ‘Brick’ paintings occupy a silent but palpable presence in space. Each painting in this body of works is covered by a uniform grid of brick lines pencil-drawn onto the surface, and the brick lines perform simultaneously as a formal, visual schema and conceptual device that conjoins each painting to the next – and all other ‘Brick’ pieces – in this decade-long series. An impeccable surface underscores the work’s quality as a two-dimensional painting, yet the work’s objecthood is emphasized by how each ‘Brick’ is often installed leaning against the wall rather than hanging off it, such that the work oscillates between abstract painting and/or minimalist sculpture. And despite appearing like a wall against a wall, each ‘Brick’ is, in actuality, an environment or world unto itself: it does not represent anything other than itself. Each stands rather, as a record of time and pain-staking labour for Taniguchi paints each brick individually – an exercise of repetition that transforms the paintings into temporal registers of artistic process. 

Taniguchi is best known for her large-scaled ‘Bricks’ which make their most impactful statements  – not merely in terms of physical presence, but more significantly, as visual documents to the passage of time – and MT_116 stands as one of her rare, few works that approaches such a monumental scale. 

Maria Taniguchi (b. 1981, Dumaguete City, Philippines, in 1981) won the Hugo Boss Asia Art Award in 2015 and was a LUX Associate Artist in 2009. Recent exhibitions include History of a vanishing present: A prologue, the Mistake Room, Los Angeles (2016); Afterwork, Para Site, Hong Kong (2016); Globale: New sensorium, ZKM Centre for Art and Media, Karlsruhe, Germany (2016); The vexed contemporary, Museum of Contemporary Art and Design, Manila (2015); and the 8th Asia Pacific Triennial of Contemporary Art, QAGOMA, Brisbane (2015). Her work is held in a number of collections including the M+ Museum, Hong Kong; the Burger Collection, Hong Kong; Kadist Art Foundation, San Francisco; QAGOMA, Brisbane; and the K11 Art Foundation, Shanghai.

title_text: Two-part panoramic view of Telok Ayer Bay from Mount Erskine
physical_appearance: This is a panaromic black-and-white photograph of Telok Ayer Bay from Mount Erskine. It features an elevated view down a street on the left, with numerous roofed buildings. There is a view of the bay on the right, with several ships scattered out at sea. The photograph is slightly faded, and has several stain marks along the top. There is a vertical line across the center, where photographs were stitched together. There is a title at the bottom of the photograph.

sgcool_label_text: This is a view from Mount Erskine, looking down Amoy Street. The roof of the Chinese temple, Thian Hock Keng, features in the foreground, while St Andrew's Cathedral, the Court House and the Empress Place Building are faintly visible in the background. Telok Ayer Bay is shown on the right of the image, with the old Telok Ayer market along the coast, and a scattering of ships further out at sea.

sgcool_label_text: This is a memoir of Henry Vacher, who departed from Southampton to work for the Peninsula & Oriental (P&O) shipping company in Calcutta in 1866. Privately printed and compiled by his son Francis, this memoir charts Vacher's life in India and Malaya, including a vacation he took to Singapore in 1873.

title_text: Photograph album presented to George Lowe as a souvenir of his visit to Singapore
physical_appearance: This is a photograph album. The album is covered in red cloth, with decorative gold gilt. There is a coat of arms of the City of Singapore in the center. Underneath it, there is a text inscription. The edges of the photograph album is slighty worn out.
