subject_terms_2: Photograph albums Photographs Albums (Books) Souvenir Lowe, George, 1924-2013 Hillary, Edmund, 1919-2008
sgcool_label_text: George Lowe was a member of the British Expedition that saw Sir Edmund Hillary scale Mount Everest on 29 May 1953. In September that year, Lowe accompanied Hillary on a visit to Singapore to deliver their first Everest lecture outside of New Zealand at the Odeon Theatre to an audience of 1,620 schoolchildren. This photograph album, with the coat of arms of the City of Singapore in gilt on the cover, was presented to Lowe as a souvenir of his visit.

title_text: Music Box series
materials_name: paper (fiber product)  graphite (mineral)  cotton (textile)  enamel paint
physical_appearance: This series of works comprise of a both mixed media and graphite pencil works. They are abstract constructions; the composition is reduced to lines and colours.
subject_terms_1: abstraction  lines (artistic concept)
subject_terms_2: Art, Singaporean  Art, Abstract  Lines
sgcool_label_text:
Mak Kum Siew’s artistic practice represents those from the second generation of Singapore artists trained overseas in Europe and America, with peers including Thomas Yeo, Choy Weng Yang, Teo Eng Seng, Ng Eng Teng, Tan Teo Kwang, Wong Keen and Goh Beng Kwan. A striking difference between Mak and his peers was his early success in London, which led to his decision to remain away from home to live and work in U.K. as a professional artist. 

Born in 1940 when Singapore was still a British colony, Mak grew up amidst the bustling Joo Chiat district, where his parents ran a laundry business that serviced the British, which later changed to an izakaya (Japanese-style pub) during the Japanese Occupation. Being the youngest of nine siblings, Mak first studied in Yangzheng Primary ???? before enrolling to Chinese High School ????. While the former allowed Mak to cultivate grounds in Chinese calligraphy, it was at the latter that his budding art practice and passion shone. His talent was spotted by Tay Ann Long, Chen Wen Hsi and Cheong Soo Pieng. Amongst his peers, Mak was known as Cheong’s favourite pupil, as he was given private lessons afterschool at NAFA, and both went to London together in 1961 for their individual pursuit of artistic excellence.

In London, Mak Kum Siew first studied at Central Saint Martin's School of Art (1961-1964), followed by gaining acceptance to the Painting programme at the Royal College of Art (1964-1967) through the open-application channel. Here, he formed a lasting relation with teacher Peter de Francia (1921 – 2012), who became a confidant to Mak. London was also where Mak became acquainted with Fang Shaoling ??? (1914 – 2006). The two was introduced by Cheong Soo Pieng in the early 1960s and quickly formed a relationship akin to familial members. 

Mak exhibited widely in U.K. with solo exhibitions at Arnolfini (1967), RCA London (1969), Commonwealth Institute (1970); and in group exhibitions at Whitechapel (1964), ICA London (1967), Royal Academy of Arts' Summer Show (1968-1981), National Portrait Gallery (2000), to highlight a few. Between 1968 and 1988, Mak took up teaching positions at a number of art colleges and schools in England and Wales as well.

With a firm grounding in art established in Singapore, and a blossoming phase in U.K., Mak reached a critical point at the end of the 1980s. He found himself tired of the seemingly repetitive art making process of his well-received abstraction pieces, and overtly occupied with his responsibilities in the art schools. 

This artwork belongs to the last series of works by Mak that captures his fixation and experimentation with the basic formality of abstract art, deduced to lines and colours. For Mak, as he shared during the interview / studio visit in February 2017, he wanted to see how far or how much he could alter one’s optical perspective on these 2-dimensional paintings by varying their tone, colour, and undulation, through everyday ordinary materials.

With a firm grounding in art established in Singapore, and a blossoming phase in U.K., Mak reached a critical point at the end of the 1980s. He found himself tired of the seemingly repetitive art making process of his well-received abstraction pieces, and overtly occupied with his responsibilities in the art schools. 

This artwork belongs to the last series of works by Mak that captures his fixation and experimentation with the basic formality of abstract art, deduced to lines and colours. For Mak, as he shared during the interview / studio visit in February 2017, he wanted to see how far or how much he could alter one’s optical perspective on these 2-dimensional paintings by varying their tone, colour, and undulation, through everyday ordinary materials.

title_text: Kebaya
physical_appearance: This is a kebaya top. It is made of sheer white cotton textile, and opens by the front. The hem along the front, collar, and ends of the sleeves are decorated with multicolored floral embroidery intertwined with tennis racket patterns.
subject_terms_1: folk costume flowers (motifs) Peranakan tops (garments, general) blouses (main garments)
subject_terms_2: Ethnic costume Motifs Peranakan (Asian people) Blouses
sgcool_label_text:
This white kebaya has embroidered tennis rackets decorating its borders and cuffs, an unusual motif in kebayas as sports were considered male activities until the late 19th century. This view began changing as shifting ideas gender roles and female emancipation became more widespread; and by the 1930’s, sports such as tennis, badminton, and volleyball were popular amongst young women. 

Kebaya was the Peranakan women’s garment of choice in the early to mid-20th century, although it was also worn by non-Peranakan women. This piece was donated by a Chinese-Vietnamese lady who bought them in Singapore shops and wore them in the 1980’s and 1990’s in London.

title_text: View Of The Bund With A Regatta In Progress, Shanghai, 1849–51
physical_appearance: This is an oil on canvas panoramic painting of the view of the Bund in Shanghai. A row of Western architecture buildings (including a Chinese-roofed building) line the river bank, and a regatta is depicted in the foreground.
subject_terms_1: mercantile buildings  regattas
subject_terms_2: China trade painting  Panoramas  Shanghai (China) Jardine, Matheson & Co.  Commercial buildings  Russell & Co. Regattas
subject_terms_3: Oil painting  Visual Arts Rowing  Commercial buildings
sgcool_label_text:
This panoramic painting is one of the earliest views of the Shanghai Bund. From the buildings visible, it has been dated to between 1849 and 1851. The artist included several landmarks, among them the first European-style buildings in the settlement and the Chinese Custom House. In the foreground, boats take part in a regatta.  

As Shanghai grew in stature as a British and European settlement, paintings like this were important records of the development of the port and the increasing volume of international ships in the harbour. The city became a gateway for interactions between East and West.

title_text: Mother and Child
physical_appearance: \This is a bronze sculpture with two figures mounted on a base. The curvilinear form of the \"\"mother\"\" figure has her legs melded together. A child rests on her right; supported by two hands. \""
subject_terms_1: mothers  children (people by age group)
subject_terms_2: Bronze sculpture  Mother and child  Ng, Eng Teng, 1934-2001  Art, Singaporean
sgcool_label_text:
One of the most prolific modern sculptors in Singapore, Ng Eng Teng (1934 – 2001) produced numerous innovative works over a span of four decades. These include large-scale public sculptures, which are displayed throughout Singapore, to life-sized and smaller ones. After undergoing his formal training at the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts (NAFA) where he built a strong foundation in drawing and painting, Ng went on to study ceramics in the United Kingdom in the early 1960s. Upon graduation, he worked as an industrial pottery designer in Ireland for two years before returning to Singapore in 1966. These various stints equipped him with, not only the creative and conceptual approaches, but also the necessary technical vocabulary to deal with the three-dimensional form and with different materials.

This bronze sculpture belongs to the iconic “Mother and Child” series created by the artist. Ng Eng Teng, whose oeuvre dealt primarily with the figure and the human condition, believed that humanity began with the family where children would learn values through the dynamic relationships with their parents. The artist has articulated the supportive role that a mother plays in her offspring’s life through various compositions, making the mother and child a recurring motif in his body of works. Some sculptures, for instance, poignantly portray the child sitting restfully on the mother’s lap or in her embracing arms. In this particular work, the mother’s large hands protectively press her child close to her side. 

A sculpture that was cast in Taiwan, “Mother and Child” was left behind in the late artist’s studio for several years. It has been temporarily sited at Tampines Central Park and will be moved to National Gallery Singapore where it will be installed on the existing pavement structure in front of the Gallery, becoming part of the its façade that faces the Padang. It is also the last monumental work produced by the artist. Another work, which was produced in 1980 and also entitled “Mother and Child”, is located at Orchard Parade Hotel.

title_text: Lectern With The Jesuit Monogram
materials_name: wood (plant material) mother of pearl lacquer (material) metal
physical_appearance: This is a lacquered lectern with inlaid mother-of-pearl. The central medallion shows a sunburst, within which is the word IHS with three nails; the symbol of the Society of Jesus. Surrounding the central sunburst medallion are vegetative motifs in gold. The back panel shares a similar aesthetic scheme but with the addition of a pair of birds in flight.
subject_terms_1: missal stands plant-derived motifs  Christianity  Roman Catholicism monograms
subject_terms_2: Catholic Church  Christianity  Leaves in art Flowers in art Birds in art  Furniture  Jesuits  Monograms
sgcool_label_text:
All surfaces of this wooden book stand are coated with lacquer, and enhanced with gold and mother-of-pearl designs. The Jesuit emblem is prominent in the decoration. An elaborate lectern of this type, emblazoned with the symbol of a religious order, was likely meant to support a missal, the book of texts and instructions used to celebrate the Catholic Mass.

The object was probably made in one of the port cities of Southeast Asia or China, imitating similar Japanese objects, which were in high demand at this time.

title_text: Violin from the collection of Mrs Marimuthu Gopalakrishnan Violin And Case
physical_appearance: This is a violin with its case and accessories. The case is black, and has a red inner cushioning. It has two clasps at each end, and a handle in the middle for easy carrying.
subject_terms_1: violin cases  rosin bows (chordophone components) stringed instruments (musical instruments)  music (performing arts)
subject_terms_2: Violin Violin cases Gums and resins Violin bows Stringed instruments  Music  Performing arts
sgcool_label_text: Mr. S Gopalakrishnan (b. in 1920 in Tanjavur) was a prominent violinist, and Carnatic singer. He arrived in Singapore in 1939 and actively participated in the Indian classical music scene here. Mr Gopalakrishnan performed alongside veterans of classical performers such as Pandit M Ramalingam and MV Gurusamy at temple and other music festivals. He also taught violin lessons at the Singapore Malayalee Association from the 1970s to 2000s. He was a member of the Tamils Reform Association and performed his wedding according to the principles of the Self-Respect Movement. He was also employed as a compositor at the Far East Air Force from 1954 to 1970.

title_text: Beggars in the Mist (Gadawpalin Temple, Pagan)
physical_appearance: This is an oil on canvas painting of a scene where a group of beggars are gathered around a fire that had been set up in front of the Gadawpalin Temple, Pagan. The palette is dull, and stands in contrast to the bright orange-red of the fire. A road leads to the temple, and several figures are depicted to be trekking that path. This painting is framed by a dark brown frame. The artist's signature can be found on the bottom left corner.
subject_terms_1: beggars temples (buildings) pagodas (buildings)
subject_terms_2: Pagan (Burma)  Art, Burmese Buddhist temples  Beggars Painting  Pagodas
sgcool_label_text: Kyaw Hlaing (1914-1996) was born in Bogalay, Myanmar. He first studied under U That Don-Kyaik Latt and became a close pupil of Ba Nyan. Upon Ba Nyan’s recommendation, he was appointed as an art instructor at the State School of Fine Arts in Yangon, a position he held for ten years. The name 'Bogalay' was often used by him to highlight the importance of his birthplace. Proficient in both oils and watercolour, he is most known for landscapes with his characteristic use of cerulean blue and night scenes.

title_text: Necktie belonging to Justice Choor Singh
creator_1: Sidhu, Choor Singh Sidhu, Choor Singh (TTE)
physical_appearance: This necktie belonging to Justice Choor Singh is navy blue in colour. The older version of the embelm of Federated Malay States, in the colours red and yellow can be seen throughout the tie in a diagonal fashion. Diagonal twin lines in red and yellow also appear after every row of diagonal embelm symbols.

sgcool_label_text: This navy blue necktie is woven with an older version of the emblem of the Federated Malay States. It would have been worn for official purposes by Justice Choor Singh. Choor Singh was the first Indian to hold the position of Magistrate in Colonial Malaya, and was appointed as a judge of the Supreme Court of Singapore in 1963. Apart from an illustrious legal career, he made significant contributions to the Sikh community in Singapore. He was one of the founders of the Singapore Khalsa Association, and advocated the teaching of Punjabi in Singapore as the Chairman of the Sikh Advisory Board. He also authored several books on the Sikh religion and the Sikh community in Singapore.

title_text:
TRANCE 
Part 1: WARPAPER
Part 2: Video Installation (Year Zero; For What It’s Worth; Are We All Just Dust?; Thousand Hills) 
Part 3: Metamorphosis  TRANCE
physical_appearance: This installation art is created by a combination of audio and visual works. There is a foldable rusted chair occupying a central position in a space. In front of the chair, there is a projection on a wall. The projection features a multicolored soundwave pattern.
subject_terms_1: multimedia works political art video recordings propaganda sound art interactive art
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Video recordings Multimedia (Art) Propaganda Sound art Trance Interactive art Politics in art
sgcool_label_text: TRANCE was produced in collaboration between two of Thailand’s most promising young artists Arnont Nongyao and Piyarat Piyapongwiwat. Emerging from both artists’ interests in music, vibration and acoustics, as well as linguistic theory, TRANCE was produced as an examination of contemporary political issues through the propaganda music that inspired people from diverse cultures and backgrounds into committing some of the worst human atrocities in history. Comprising of 3 parts, the works bring to the forefront, for examination, the trance-inducing properties of propaganda tunes, and that in spite of their happy melodies and feel-good effects, the atrocities these compositions have inspired people to commit.

title_text: The Game 24 Channel video work
physical_appearance: This is an image of twenty-four still rectangular frames from within a video clip. All of the still frames are in colour. Each of the frames displays a different image from the others. A number of these frames show two men who are decked in a green military outfit. They can be seen holding rifles which are green in colour. Images of people riding motorcylces, in groups or individually, are common as well. There are images of buildings as well, one of which seems to be constructed with bricks while the other is concrete. At least three of the frames show the presence of a red cloth that the men in uniformsare holding, or are being wrapped up in.
subject_terms_1: video recordings film (performing arts) military uniforms historical regions historic buildings rural areas cultural landscape motorcyclists local histories culture
subject_terms_2: Video recordings Motion pictures Military uniforms Historic buildings Cultural landscapes Motorcyclists local histories Culture Hue (Vietnam)
subject_terms_3: Films National identity Historic buildings Historic districts Historic sites
sgcool_label_text:
‘The Game’ by the Le Brothers follows on from their three-channel video, ‘Into the Sea’ which saw the brothers grapple with notions of self and society, land and sea, city and country, and the precariousness that surrounded each. In this one-hour long, 24-channelled video artwork, the brothers explore in greater detail the lay of the land around their adoptive city, Hue, which was the ancient capital and former imperial seat of Vietnam, and also the region in which the Vietnamese Demilitarised Zone (DMZ) between North and South Vietnam resides. 

Ranging from the sandy coast of Bai Bien Thuan Hai, to the forested banks of the Perfume River and along the way stopping at burial sites such as the Tomb of Khai Dinh, and a traditional brick factory, ‘The Game’ spans the length and breadth of the city and was described by the brothers as a way “for them to get to know their city better”. As in their earlier videos, ‘The Game’ sees the brothers play the role of protagonists. Activating their proximity as identical twin brothers, they navigated across the land and sea of Hue and found themselves performing the role of mediators between the histories of tension, civil unrest, war, and eventual reunification of their country. In the video, the brothers – doned in military uniforms – incorporate props such as wooden carved guns with roses sticking out of each barrel, colourful netting, and porcelain plates amongst others, in an attempt to reveal the naïve, complex, and often delicate relationship the Vietnamese have with their country and its history.

title_text: Falim House: Observations 10-channel video projection with sound
physical_appearance: This is an image of ten still rectangular frames from ten different videos. All of the still rames are in colour. Each of the frames displays a different image from the others. A number of these frames show the interior structure of a building, displaying items, furnitures, doors, and windows. One of the frame is a shot of the exterior of a mansion. Another frame is a close-up of a page within a document, but the writing on it is illegible.
subject_terms_1: video recordings film (performing arts) interior spaces (spaces by location) exterior views mansions abandoned buildings abandoned dwellings furniture documents (object genre)
subject_terms_2: Video recordings Motion pictures Mansions Abandoned houses Furniture
sgcool_label_text: The ten video channels that comprise Hayati Mokhtar’s Falim House: Observations seem suspended between the silence and stasis of the still image, and a series of ever-so-slight stirs and shifts that suggest to the viewer that these tableaus are, in fact, animated. One witnesses, in the far distance beyond a deserted vestibule, the movement of a human silhouette; little happens on the lawn outside a partially open window, except when a small herd of farm animals darts by; the sound of a whistling voice is heard echoing through the empty hallways of an derelict structure. These forlorn fragments document the interior and surroundings of the titular mansion, located in Ipoh. Falim House was built by Foo Nyit Tse, one of the wealthiest tin tycoons in Malaya in the early twentieth century. Today, it lies in a state of suggestive ruin, the Foo family having left most of their belongings behind, including furniture, antiques and personal letters. The artist remarks: “Imagine these sequences as photographs that teeter on the cusp of becoming the moving image; stills that, at certain points, suddenly flow into a depiction of a whole series of events: small actions that, seen collectively, build up into a narrative – a film, even, of sorts.”

title_text: Invisible Force
materials_name: photographic paper steel (alloy) magnets mixed media
techniques_name: creating (artistic activity) photographic processes metalworking forming (physical activity)
physical_appearance: The image shows an installation. It is rectangular in shape. The background of the installation is black in colour. There are numerous bright specks scattered throughout the entire installation. The installation resembles stars in a dark sky.
subject_terms_1: sky stars (extraterrestial bodies) celestial space (astronomical concept) force (mechanical concept) mixed media works
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Constellations Stars Force and energy Derivative works
sgcool_label_text: Invisible Force reproduces part of the starry sky as photographed by NASA, strictly in accordance with the location and the size of the stars, by using nearly 30,000 industrial magnets that weigh almost two tonnes. Through the use of magnets, the work ingeniously represents the invisible gravitational forces between the celestial bodies.

title_text: Dust (Singapore Galaxy)
physical_appearance: This installation is created in a landscape fashion. This work is composed on a black and grey background where white dots are interspaced throughout the entire piece of art.
subject_terms_1: sky stars (extraterrestial bodies) space (astronomical concept) galaxies mixed media works symbolism (artistic concept)
subject_terms_2: Sky Stars Installations (Art) Galaxies Derivative works Outer space Symbolism
sgcool_label_text: Dust (Singapore Galaxy) is based on a photograph of the night sky around Singapore. The seemingly random scattering of chalk dust is in fact a precise placement charting stellar distributions as depicted in the original astronomical photograph. In Chinese, the characters for ‘dust’ also refer to those who are socially underprivileged, and carry the additional meanings of the ordinary and mundane. Here, dust is vested with solemnity and divinity in its transformation into the limitless universe, mapping the infinitesimal traces of human existence onto the infinite.

title_text: The Thin Black Line
materials_name: wood (plant material) metal plastic (organic material) wire mixed media
physical_appearance: The image shows an installation. The left side of the image features a close-up view of a grey speaker and a phonograph horn that is yellow in colour. Both of these items are hung up on a wooden pillar. A black wire conects this pair of items to a similar pair, seen at the right hand side of the image. The setting of this installation piece is in the interior of a building. There is a transparent window in the background, showing trees on the other side.
subject_terms_1: mixed media works multimedia works musical compositions symbolism (artistic concept) local histories
subject_terms_2: Multimedia Installations (Art) Music Symbolism local histories
sgcool_label_text:
The visitor experiences ‘The Thin Black Line’ by Vietnamese American artist, Richard Streitmatter-Tran, audibly before they do visually. Ambient music that occasionally includes recognisable transmissions of the carefree laughter of cherubic children pulses through the space, throwing the visitor into a an eerie sense of being hurtled into an era past. ‘The Thin Black Line’ comprises four pairs of speakerphones and phonograph horns attached to wooden pillars. Black wiring, that stretches across the gallery space – piping music to each of the speakers – allows for a conversation to take place between elements of the artwork. 

‘The Thin Black Line’ pairs two styles of speakerphones, visually bringing together two eras of Vietnamese history: the colonial era under the French, and the post-war and present era, whilst the juxtaposition of the speakerphones and the experimental music it emits crafts a conversation around past memories, present experiences, and future thoughts of Vietnam as being intertwined to the point of inseparable.

title_text: EARTH
physical_appearance: This is an image of a rectangular still from within a video clip. It features a large number of people. None of them are standing up, but lying down or leaning against fragments of pallets and cardboard boxes. Most of the males are bare-chested. There are wreckage and items such as tires and wires, mainly at the foreground of the image.  A washing machine can be seen at the left hand side of the still. The background of the still is dark, and some greenery can be seen. The centre of the still seems to be more brightly lit than the other areas.
subject_terms_1: video recordings film (performing arts) apocalyptic art groups of people derivative works appropriation (imagery)
subject_terms_2: Video recordings Motion pictures Apocalyptic films People Derivative works Appropriation (Art)
sgcool_label_text: EARTH presents a vision of a post-apocalyptic world, where a sprawl of human bodies is arranged across a bleak landscape of detritus. The lighting, composition and tableau of the work are steeped in references to canonical works of Western art which depict the extremities of the human spirit, in suffering, heroism and hubris. As the light and camera pan over sections of this unearthly sprawl, the human figures stir, rising and then falling back into slumber once again. The rhythms and cadences of these movements evoke that of an organism silently breathing, as the light alternately picks out individual bodies and merges them into one massive entity.

The building of Boustead Institute was located between Anson Road and Tanjong Pagar Road. It was used by seamen of the Tanjong Pagar Dock Company as a residence when they were transiting through Singapore. The building was named after Edward Boustead, founder of the Tanjong Pagar Dock Company, the Chamber of Commerce, and The Singapore Free Press.

This photograph shows Government House (the Istana) nestled among the trees. A lone figure in the foreground looks in its direction. ‘20209. P. Z. – Singapore. Government House’ is printed at the bottom edge of the photograph. 
 
Government House was built in 1869 for the first governor of the colony of Singapore. It was renamed the Istana when the Yang di-Pertuan Negara Yusof bin Ishak took residence. Today, it is the official residence of the President of the Republic of Singapore.

This hand-coloured photograph shows a women with a baby on her lap. Inscribed on the photograph is the studio mark ‘The Eastern Studio Singapore’. 

Eastern Studio was set up by the early 1920s by Lee King Yan, who was also the founder of Lee Brothers Studio. A well-respected photographer in Singapore, newspapers lauded him as ‘one of the pioneers of photography’ in Singapore and the ‘Colony’s Grand Old Man of Photography’ at the time of his passing.

sgcool_label_text:
Written in Dutch, ‘How to make a Good Photo: a book for the amateur photographer’ was published by the Eastman Kodak Company in Batavia. 

The Eastman Kodak Company was established in 1892, and succeeded the company George Eastman first founded when he started producing dry plates for sale in Rochester, New York in 1880. The introduction of the Kodak camera in 1888 marked a milestone in the history of photography for it made photography accessible and affordable to millions of amateurs who were not professionally trained.

In Indonesia, photography studios were established by the Chinese as early as the last decade of the 19th century. Many of these were established by recent immigrants from China and came to rival the European-owned studios which dominated the market.

Cartes de visite are small portraits mounted on boards measuring about 6.35 x 10 cm. They were sometimes collected and displayed in specially-designed albums with slots on each page for individual cartes. This type of photographs was very popular in the second half of the 19th century. 

The cartes de visite found in this album were produced by several photography studios, one of which was Alfred Ellis. The studio was located at Upper Baker Street, London from 1884 to 1898.

This photograph shows a group of girls from Singapore Chinese Girls School and older women, who may possibly be school teachers. 

Singapore Chinese Girls’ School was established on Hill Street in July 1899. Starting with a class of just seven students, the school did not initially enjoy the support of senior members of the Peranakan community who did not believe in female education. Led by Lim Boon Keng and Song Ong Siang, the group of younger Peranakans were determined to establish a school for girls which offered a modern curriculum based on Confucian values.

The Tiong Hwa Hwe Koan was founded in 1900 by a group of Chinese businessmen and journalists and aimed to promote the customs and language among the Indies Chinese. The first Tiong Hwa Hwe Koan Chinese school was established a year later.

subject_terms_3: Decorative arts Peranakan clans and associations Tan, Jiak Kim Ong, Ewe Hai Anderson, John, Sir (Colonial administrator)
sgcool_label_text:
Around the body of this chalice, iris and tall grass are cast in high relief against a subtly dappled background. A pair of fishes swims among this watery terrain. The inscription on the foot reads: Presented to Tan Swat Neo by his Excellency the Governor & the Singapore Members of the Legislative Council on the occasion of her marriage 3rd November 1905. 

Tan Swat Neo (1884-1909) was the daughter of Tan Jiak Kim (1859-1917), a prominent Peranakan businessman who served on the Straits Legislative Council from 1889 to 1915. The chalice was a gift from James Anderson, Governor of Singapore, to commemorate the occasion of Tan Swat Neo’s marriage to Ong Hood Hin (1882-1957), grandson of Ong Ewe Hai (1830-1889). The donor is the granddaughter of Tan Swat Neo.

title_text:
Dutch manuscript with colour drawings of 201 maritime flags of the world
C1740
physical_appearance: These are two volumes of Dutch manuscript with colour drawings of 201 maritime flags of the world. Both of the volumes, bound by a brown hardcover, are encased in a black case. Both the volumes look worn out and discoloured while the black case does not seem to have undergone as much wear and tear.

subject_terms_4:

 France (nation) East Indies (general region)
sgcool_label_text:
This is a c1740 Dutch manuscript with illustrations of maritime flags from across western and eastern world. The 201 colour drawings come with Dutch titles identifying each of them. Included are those from the British Isles, the Dutch Republic, Spain, France and the East Indies. 
The profusion of flag types and their diverse regional identities illustrates the complexity of the 18th century marine world which accommodated various competing naval forces with differing political reigns and ambitions.

title_text:
List of unrecorded medicines issued by Dutch East India Company (VOC) and Dutch West India Company (WIC).for their overseas garrisons.
1742
physical_appearance: This is a list of unrecorded medicines issued by Dutch East India Company (VOC) and Dutch West India Company (WIC) for their overseas garrisons. This list contains lines of text in Latin, referring to medicines and their ingredients. The pages are slightly browned and soiled near the edges. Otherwise the list remains wholly untrimmed and generally in good condition.
subject_terms_1: medicines (material)
subject_terms_2: Lists
sgcool_label_text: This is a list of simple and compound medicine issued by the Dutch government for use by the Dutch East India Company (VOC) and Dutch West India Company (WIC), who had troops stationed abroad. They could be used in the hospitals of Dutch garrisons with fewer than 3000 men. The medicines could be prepared on site following the The Hague pharmacopoeia of 1738 – which was a Latin text that was the official source for the municipality of the Hague in the Netherlands.

context_22:
The handwritten document illustrates at a very fundamental level the colonial practice of administration of the Dutch VOC. The manuscript in Dutch reveals various aspects including 
protocols, procedures, finances and administrative paperwork for VOC officers arriving in Batavia and the Cape of Good Hope. Among other instructions to be found is information on the cost of purchasing a black slave boy in Batavia and the expense of his upkeep.

title_text:
Dutch book of sermons in VOC binding
4th edition
physical_appearance: This is a fourth edition Dutch book of sermons in a black VOC binding. This book has a distinct monogram of the Dutch East India Company, also known as the VOC, on the binding. The monogram is encased by patterns in the shape of rectangular frames. The book has two gold clasps, one at the top right and the bottom right of the binding.
subject_terms_1: rare books Dutch Colonial  ships  seamen missionaries sermons
subject_terms_2: Rare books Ships Sailors Missionaries Sermons Monograms Nederlandsche Oost-Indische Compagnie
sgcool_label_text: This rare Dutch book of sermons with the distinct VOC monogram was intended primarily for the use of the Dutch sailors and missionaries and shows the importance of religion in the everyday operations of the VOC.  Although the name on the title page attributes the book to one to a minister of the name Justus Bulaeus (1580-1611), it is believed that the author was his son, Johannes Bulaeus (1595-1650/1). This edition was revised and enlarged by Viglius Cornelius Dominus, whose name is not mentioned except for his initials on the title-page. He added summaries and references to Bible verses and prayers to the original text.

title_text: Head of Buddha
physical_appearance: This is a stone sculpture of a head of Buddha. It is gray in colour. The Buddha's head is decorated with large, soft curls around the crown. The face of the sculpture shows a serene facial expression, with the Buddha's eyes facing downwards in meditation. The Buddha's ears are elongated.
subject_terms_1: Buddhas (visual works) Buddhism
subject_terms_2: Sculptures Buddhas Buddhism Sculpture, Javanese
sgcool_label_text:
The head has soft, delicate features, showing a serenity, with the eyes gently looking down in meditation, and large curls rise to form the usnisha. The earlobes are elongated, indicating the heavy earrings once worn by Prince Siddhartha, who renounced all wealth to follow the path to enlightenment and become the Buddha.
Southeast Asia was situated on the trade routes from the Indian subcontinent to China from ancient times. Buddhism arrived in Java along these trade routes, and subsequently missionaries followed. Javanese devotees travelled to Nalanda University in Bihar, Northern India, establishing strong connections with Indian Buddhist centres.

title_text: ??????? (Lay down your weapon, follow me)
materials_name: mixed media brass foam (material form) paper (fiber product)
physical_appearance: This installation art comprises of a series of photographs on a wall, and a structure in the center of the space. The structure is composed of twenty-eight black pecis, perched on metal bars on a stand. Each of them have pinholes pierced in the center. Behind the structure on the wall, there are two rows of photographs presented within wooden frames against yellow background paper. The photographs are printed film negatives.
subject_terms_1: political art photographs pinhole photography symbolism (artistic concept) speeches (compositions) nationalism
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Photographs Symbolism Politics in art Photography, Pinhole Soekarno, 1901-1970 Speeches Nationalism
subject_terms_3: Installation art Photography Sukarno Politics and Government
sgcool_label_text:
Boedi Widjaja left his hometown of Solo for Singapore at the age of 9, due to ethnic tensions. Throughout the 28 years away from his homeland, or tanah air, he attempted to come to terms with his identity and to understand what was happening in Indonesia, largely through mass media where the disseminated image occupies a pivotal role. In the words of the artist, “(t)he indexicality of photos - their authoritative testimonies of what-has-happened - and their transparency* proved problematic in my attempt to come to terms with my absence from Indonesia…The country’s archival press photos, specifically those images that perform national identity through the visual documentations of iconic politicians and historical milestones, often led me to imagine that I was (or could be) a part of this shared identity despite my physical disconnection from Tanah Air while at the same time reminding me why I was never part of it…I wanted to address memories where the personal and political intertwined. I want to relook at these familiar yet disembodied images, reconstruct them in a new place of beginnings and infinitely defer their meanings. If optical memory was all that I could ever have of this history then let that be my entry point and process for re-narration.”

In his installation “Lay down your weapon, follow me”, an installation of 28 pecis-- one for each year of the artist’s absence from Indonesia -- occupies centrestage. The peci is a black felt hat popularized by Indonesia’s first President Sukarno as a nationalistic symbol. Boedi modified these hats into pinhole cameras, to produce 28 negative prints of various images of Sukarno delivering speeches at various occasions. The distanciation of the final image from its source through the processes of its reproduction parallels the emotional and cultural detachment experienced keenly by the artist, from the politics and narratives attached to these images. At the same time, Boedi’s processes reveal a poignant attempt to grasp at some understanding of these histories, albeit one filtered through lenses of his own construction.

*Kendall Walton used the term ‘transparent pictures’ to describe the photograph’s make-believe ability, its function as a lens through which the viewer sees something other than the photo itself.

title_text: Space Probe
physical_appearance: The image shows a painting. It is rectangular in shape. The background is predominantly yellow in colour. At the bottom of the painting, the image of a dome can be seen. The dome is transparent, revealing a green region that is demarcated by wavy lines. At the centre of the painting, there is a circular relief that seems ot be projecting from the surface of the painting.
subject_terms_1: abstraction symbolism (artistic concept) cosmos
subject_terms_2: Mixed media painting Paintings Abstraction Symbolism Motifs
sgcool_label_text:
Born in Penang in 1939, Teh Tien Chong was a notable sculptor, painter and educator in Singapore. Prior to moving to Singapore, he held several teaching appointments in Malaysia and London. Teh relocated to Singapore in 1974 to teach at the United World College of Southeast Asia (UWC), where he was in-charge of the 3D Art Department. At the school, he actively organised and participated in several editions of the UWC Arts Festival together Teo Eng Seng and Gavin Waddell, from 1975 to 1979. Teh’s works were captured in several surveys of art and contemporary sculpture in Singapore around the 1970s, including ‘Colour’ at the National Museum Art Gallery (NMAG) in 1977,  ‘Contemporary Singapore Sculpture’ at NMAG in 1978, and the annual display of the permanent collection at NMAG from 1976 to 1979. Teh was also invited to lead several sculpture workshops at the NMAG from 1976 to 1979. 

A sculptor by training and temperament, Teh received considerable albeit short-lived acclaim for what he called his “sculptural reliefs”. He sought to expand the possibilities for both sculpture and painting, and created works using stacked, shaped canvases and reliefs, not unlike the artist Anthony Poon, who created his relief paintings around the same time. This work is representative of Teh’s use of the cosmos as a recurrent motif, informed by the artist’s interest in both the science fiction of HG Wells and his observations of technological advancements of the time.

title_text: Children of the Sun
physical_appearance: This is a large multicolored painting. It is in the shape of a square. It depicts seven figurative figures in various positions, using bright colours and defined shapes. There is a bright, circular shape at the top-center of the painting, with yellow and white wavey lines portruding from it. In from of the circular shape, there is a figure painted in shades of green, with an arm stretched upwards. At the bottom of the painting, one figure is resting on an open stylised plant with outstretched leaves. There are no signatures seen.
subject_terms_1: commissions (orders for works) natural element motifs figurative art
subject_terms_2: Painting Oil on canvas Figurative art Art commissions
subject_terms_3: Khoo, Sui Hoe Oil painting Lim, Chong Keat Singapore Conference Hall
context_1: Opening of the Singapore Conference Hall
sgcool_label_text: Children of the Sun is one of the few works undertaken by the artist on such a monumental scale. It could be considered an early work, but is deeply intertwined with the artists’ interest in the figurative form. The history of the painting intertwines deeply with the national development of Singapore. The Children of the Sun was first commissioned for the opening of the Singapore Conference Hall (currently a National Monument). The painting was then kept on display in the lounge of the conference hall. Painted in 1965 at Datuk Seri Lim’s Pasir Panjang seaside cottage, the Children of the Sun was the first major large painting by Khoo Sui Hoe.

sgcool_label_text:
This photograph was taken by Singaporean photographer Tan Lip Seng. Tan is arguably the most important photographer in the region developing colour derivative and photo montage techniques. His works in the 1960s were a result of various experiments meticulously combining multiple colour transparencies into one to achieve the desired montage within one frame.

Tan spent 42 years as a medical photographer at the National University of Singapore. Many of his works have won numerous awards internationally and show a strong graphic and stylistic sensibility.

sgcool_label_text:
This photograph was taken by Singaporean photographer Tan Lip Seng. Tan is arguably the most important photographer in the region developing colour derivative and photo montage techniques. His works in the 1960s were a result of various experiments meticulously combining multiple colour transparencies into one to achieve the desired montage within one frame.

Tan spent 42 years as a medical photographer at the National University of Singapore. Many of his works have won numerous awards internationally and show a strong graphic and stylistic sensibility. Tan is also the first Singaporean to be awarded a fellowship by the Royal Photographic Society of the United Kingdom in 1970. Conferred the Cultural Medallion in 1985, Tan recently published a retrospective of his works, ‘Light & Shadow: Tan Lip Seng’s 50 Years of Photography’ in 2009.

subject_terms_3: Photography National Iron and Steel Mills Limited Industrial buildings
sgcool_label_text:
This photo was taken at the National Steel Mill and was one of Tan Lip Seng's submissions to the Royal Photographic Society (UK) for his ARPS application in 1964.

A self-taught photographer, Tan Lip Seng went on to become one of the world’s top photographers working in colour derivative photo montage technique. He was the first Singaporean to be listed as The World’s Top Ten Colour Slide Exhibitors by the Photographic Society of America in 1969 and was also the first Singaporean to be awarded a fellowship by the Royal Photographic Society of the United Kingdom in 1970. Conferred the Cultural Medallion in 1985, Tan recently published a retrospective of his works, ‘Light & Shadow: Tan Lip Seng’s 50 Years of Photography’ in 2009. An exhibition was held concurrently to mark the book’s launch.

sgcool_label_text:
This photograph was taken by Singaporean photographer Tan Lip Seng. His works in the 1960s were a result of various experiments meticulously combining multiple colour transparencies into one to achieve the desired montage within one frame.

Tan Lip Seng started his career as a medical photographer at the National University of Singapore. He is famous worldwide for his innovative colour derivative photo montage technique as well as his travel photography.

subject_terms_1: Equus caballus (species) women (female humans) polo clubs (built complexes)
subject_terms_2: Digitally printed materials Colour prints Polo ponies Women Polo
sgcool_label_text:
The Frame (1974) is an example of one of Tan Lip Seng's many experiments with colour photography. This photograph was taken at the Singapore Polo Club (next to the old Police Academy along) and the silhouetted frame in the foreground of the photograph was produced from laying a wire mesh over the transparency slide. 

Tan spent 42 years as a medical photographer at the National University of Singapore. Many of his works have won numerous awards internationally and show a strong graphic and stylistic sensibility. Tan is also the first Singaporean to be awarded a fellowship by the Royal Photographic Society of the United Kingdom in 1970. Conferred the Cultural Medallion in 1985, Tan recently published a retrospective of his works, ‘Light & Shadow: Tan Lip Seng’s 50 Years of Photography’ in 2009.

sgcool_label_text:
This photograph by Singaporean photographer Tan Lip Seng was submitted to the Royal Photographic Society (UK) for his Fellowship application. This work is one of the examples of Tan's innovative colour technique, in which he creates a high contrast backdrop in order to bring out details of his subject matter. 

Tan Lip Seng started his career as a medical photographer at the National University of Singapore. He was the first Singaporean to be awarded a fellowship by the Royal Photographic Society of the United Kingdom in 1970.

title_text: At Singapore, a watercolour painting by William Godfrey Rayson Masters
physical_appearance: \The image shows a painting. The painting has a grey border and it is envlosed within a black frame. The image depicted on the painting shows a body of water and land. The background shows the sky as well as several houses. Tall poles can be seen erected on the sands as well. The foreground shows a number of boats on water. Two people can be seen walking on the sands
subject_terms_1: as well as another two on the boats. All of them are wearing brown hats. \"\"At Singapore\"\" is stated at the bottom left hand corner. \"\"WGR. Masters\"\" is stated at the bottom right hand corner. \""
subject_terms_2: boats bodies of water (natural) rivers dwellings cultural landscapes
subject_terms_3: Watercolour painting Singapore Boats and boating Bodies of water Rivers Dwellings Landscapes
column51:
This charming vignette belongs to a tradition of images that were produced by itinerant artists who travelled through Singapore in the 19th century. This was painted by Captain William Godfrey Rayson Masters while on his expedition to China in 1859-1860 - thus providing us with a specific historical context for the painting. 

Masters served as a Captain of the Royal Marine Light infantry under the command of Rear-Admiral Hope in 1859-60. He was seriously wounded during the attempt to storm the forts at the entrance to the Pei-Ho river in June 1859. The forts were eventually taken in 1860 and the combined English and French forces entered Tientsin

title_text: View of the Amsterdam Harbour from the Sea
creator_2: Hendrik de Leth Johannes Covens and Cornelis Mortier
techniques_name: papermaking copper engraving (printing process) hand coloring
physical_appearance: This print shows the view of the Amsterdam Harbour from the sea. There are two lines of text centralised at the top of the print. The legend, comprising five lines of text in Dutch and numbered one to twenty-seven on both halves of the print, can also be seen at the bottom of the print. The legend provides details of the important buildings portrayed in the print.
subject_terms_1: harbours merchant vessels
subject_terms_2: Engravings Harbours
sgcool_label_text: This is a view of the Amsterdam harbour from the inlet known as the IJ. The harbour is depicted as bustling with activities with a variety of shipping vessels dominated by a large mewrchant vessel in the foreground. The profile of the city is visible in the background, with a detailed legend below identifying major buildings. The print was produced by Hendrik de Leth, and published by Johannes Covens and Cornelis Mortier.

title_text: Jan Jansson's 1632 Map of Asia
techniques_name: papermaking copper engraving (printing process) hand coloring
physical_appearance: This multicoloured map is Jan Jansson's map of Asia in 1632. All four sides of the map is covered by vignettes of the detailed maps of Dutch trading ports and the aps of Goa, Calcutta, Kandy (Ceylon), Bantam, Gammalamme (Moluccas) and Macao. There are also many lines of text in Dutch throughout the map specifying the names of places and communities in Asia in the 18th century.
subject_terms_1: cartography (discipline) vignettes (visual works) trade (general function) ports (settlements)  indigenous people
subject_terms_2: Maps Cartography Vignettes Commerce Harbours Nederlandsche Oost-Indische Compagnie Linschoten, Jan Huygen van, 1563-1611
subject_terms_4:
Macao (inhabited place) Goa (state) Calcutta (inhabited place)
 Kandy (former nation/state/empire) Banten (former nation/state/empire) Moluccas (island group)
sgcool_label_text: This richly illustrated map of Asia was published in 1632 by the Dutch cartographer and map publisher Jan Jansson. It features vignettes of the various Dutch ports in Asia and corresponding depictions of local peoples in their respective costumes.

title_text: Van Keulen's Map of Java
techniques_name: papermaking copper engraving (printing process) hand coloring
physical_appearance: This is a multicoloured map of Java which was created by Gerard Van Keulen. This map, divided into western and eastern parts, has an inset map and view of Batavia.There are many lines of text in Dutch throughout the map specifying the names of places in Dutch-colonised Java in the 18th century.
subject_terms_1: seas cartography (discipline) topography (attribute) hydrography
subject_terms_2: Pictorial maps Navigation Seas Cartography Hydrography
subject_terms_4: Nederlandsche Oost-Indische Compagnie Jakarta (inhabited place) East Indies (general region) Java (island)
sgcool_label_text: This two-part map of Java was produced by Gerard van Keulen, an engraver, mathematician and hydrographer for the Dutch East India Company. It was published later by his son Johannes van Keulen II in Part VI of his collection of sea charts, the Zee Fakkel, in 1653. Apart from the main map which shows both West and East Java, the insets provide a map and view of Batavia.

title_text: Engraving of a Dutch man-of-war
techniques_name: papermaking copper engraving (printing process) hand coloring
physical_appearance: This is a multicoloured engraving of a Dutch man-of-war. The top portion of the print is richly illustrated and contains textual information, in German,on the schematics of a fully-rigged three-masted Dutch man-of-war with 96 guns. The bottom portion of the print holds information about the hierarchy of the crew on board, from the highest officer to the lowest servant.
subject_terms_1: warships  navigational instruments
subject_terms_2: Engravings Warships Navigation Man o’ war
sgcool_label_text: This print of a fully-rigged three-masted Dutch man-of-war provides a schematic of its exterior and interior, including a view of its cross-section as well as illustrations of typical navigational instruments used, accompanied by descriptions of their use. In addition, a full listing of the typical hierarchy of the crew on board is provided.

title_text: Visscher's Map of Southeast Asia published by Pieter Schenk
creator_2: Nicolas Visscher I Pieter Schenk Jr
scale_type: The scale of the map is in miles.
techniques_name: papermaking copper engraving (printing process) hand coloring
physical_appearance: This is a multicoloured map of Southeast Asia, created by Nicolas Visscher I and published by Pieter Schenk Jr. There are many words at the top of the map, highlighting the names of places in Southeast Asia where the Dutch East India Company (VOC) extended their control over trade activities. The bottom of the map has lines of text that represent the title and scale of the map.
subject_terms_1: coastlines cartography (discipline)  trade (general function) cartouches (ornament)
subject_terms_2: Pictorial maps Coasts Cartography Nederlandsche Oost-Indische Compagnie East Indies Spice trade India Australia Southeast Asia Cartouches, Ornamental (Decorative arts)
subject_terms_4: Southeast Asia (general region) India (nation)  Australia (nation) East Indies (general region)
sgcool_label_text: This map of Southeast Asia by Nicolas Visscher was printed in the early 18th century by Pieter Schenk. It depicts the sphere of influence of the Dutch East India Company, spanning from India to the northern coastline of Australia. The focus, however, is that of the East Indies around which the spice trade was centred.

title_text: Matthaus Seutter's Flag Chart of the Seafaring Nations printed by Tobias Lotter
techniques_name: papermaking copper engraving (printing process) hand coloring
physical_appearance: This is a multicoloured flag chart of the seafaring nations created by Matthaus Seutter and printed by Tobias Lotter. The title of the chart can be seen in two lines of text in German at the top of the chart. A single line of text also appears on top of each of the 139 flags represented in the chart. There is also one line of text centralised at the bottom of the chart, beneath all the flags.
subject_terms_1: flags identifying artefacts
subject_terms_2: Flags Identification
sgcool_label_text: This 18th century flag chart illustrates the flags of 139 seafaring nations. It was published by Tobias Lotter, based on the work of his father-in-law Georg Matthaus Seutter.

title_text: Blaeu's Map of the Moluccas
scale_type: The scale is centralised at the bottom of the map.
techniques_name: papermaking copper engraving (printing process) hand coloring
physical_appearance: This is a multicoloured map of the Moluccas, created by Jodocus Hondius and published by Willem Blaeu. There are two cartographic cartouches at the top of the map. The cartouche on the top left shows early Dutch settlement on the island of Bachian while the cartouche on the top right shows the title of the map. An illustration on the lower right corner of the map shows a Moluccan couple in Europeanised native dress.There are many lines of text in Latin throughout the map specifying the title, scale and the names of all the spice islands represented in the map.
subject_terms_1: topographical views settlement (population activity) cartouches (ornament) indigenous people cartography (discipline) cartography (discipline)
subject_terms_2: Pictorial maps Cartouches, Ornamental (Decorative arts) Indigenous people Cartography Maluku (Indonesia) Linschoten, Jan Huygen van, 1563-1611 Nederlandsche Oost-Indische Compagnie
sgcool_label_text: This map of the Moluccas or Spice Islands was first produced by the map engraver Jodocus Hondius and subsequently bought over by cartographer and map publisher Willem Blaeu who published this map. As the first large scale map of the Moluccas, this map shows its various islands, along with pictorial depictions of the relief and settlements on the islands, including that of the early Dutch settlement on Bachian.

title_text: Surrender of Sultan Mahmud Badaruddin II after the Dutch expedition against Palembang
creator_2: H. P. Oosterhuis J. A. Lutz
physical_appearance: This is  a multicoloured aquatint depicting the surrender of Sultan Mahmud Badaruddin II after the Dutch expedition against Palembang in 1821. Most of aquatint is covered by Dutch vessels and flags. There are three lines of text in Dutch at the bottom of the aquatint specifying the title of this scene of surrender.
subject_terms_1: expeditions (journeys) schooners watercraft flags illustrations (layout features) proofs (prints by function)
subject_terms_2: Aquatint Schooners Boats and boating Flags Pictures Mahmud Badaruddin II, Sultan of Palembang, 1768-1852
sgcool_label_text: In 1821, the Dutch launched an expedition against Sultan Mahmud Badaruddin of Palembang, who had been hostile against Dutch. The expedition was successful, and the Sultan is depicted in this print being escorted to the Dutch vessel Joanna, later to be exiled to Ternate. This aquatint was produced by J. A. Lutz, after an original work by H. P. Oosterhuis.

G.R. Lambert and Co was a leading and the most enduring of the European photography studios in Singapore. This carte de visite shows a  studio photograph of two children posing with a porcelain drum stool, before a painted backdrop of a landscape with houses. This photograph was probably taken by Pun Lun photography studio at High Street in Singapore. 

Pun Lun (1864 – c.1900) was a Chinese photographer, with a successful studio in Hong Kong and branches in Foochow (Fuzhou), Saigon and Singapore.

Studios were already established across the Strait Settlements and the Dutch East Indies by the 1840s and became increasingly prevalent in the 1850s. During the 1920s, Chinese-owned studios dominated the studio photography trade in Southeast Asia.

title_text: Photographs of a Dutch-Indonesian banknote
physical_appearance: The image shows two black-and-white photographs. They feature the front and back copy of a banknote, respectively. They are rectangular the banknote in the photograph at the top contains a signature. There is a line of Dutch in bold, in the photograph at the bottom. subject_terms_1: paper money
subject_terms_2: Black-and-white photography Bank notes
sgcool_label_text:
These photographs show a Dutch-Indonesian banknote.

King William I of the Netherlands granted the right to create a bank in the Indies in 1826, De Javasche Bank (DJB) opened in Batavia in 1828, and had exclusive rights to issue paper bank notes for 10 years. The bank’s rights were renewed periodically until 1922.

In 1839 the French government made public technical information about the production of photographs, prompting a fervour for photographic technology which quickly spread from Europe to Southeast Asia. The first photography studios in the Dutch East Indies and the Straits Settlements were established in the first decades of the 1840s.

sgcool_label_text: These ten photographs are portraits of Herbert Lim Eng Kwan (1927-2002),  Chairman of Singapore Tourist Association from 1967 to 1970, and founder and managing director of Jackie's Bowl for over 20 years. ‘Herbie’ was the son of the Peranakan businessman Lim Chong Pang (1904 – 1956) and grandson of the pineapple and rubber planter and prominent philanthropist Lim Nee Soon (1879 – 1936).

title_text: Affectionately Yours No. 1
physical_appearance: The image depicts a painting. The portrait of a lady is the subject. She is depicted to be smiling and she adorns a blouse that is patterned with colourful flowers. Her facial features and hair are drawn with a pencil. The background of the painting contains images of stalks and flowers. These flowers are in red, yellow, and blue.
subject_terms_1: portraits women (female humans)
subject_terms_2: Portrait painitng Women
sgcool_label_text:
This work depicts Elizabeth Lee, mother of the artist Dick Lee, against a colourful background of flowers in full bloom. 

Popularly known as Dick Lee, Richard Lee Peng Boon was born in 1956. He is a prolific singer and songwriter. He has also written many well known musicals including Beauty World (1988), Fried Rice Paradise (1991) and Forbidden City (2003). He was awarded the Singapore Cultural Medallion in 2005 for his achievements in music.

title_text: Photograph of Lee Chin Koon
physical_appearance: The image shows a black-and-white photograph. It is rectangular and it features an elderly man. He is sitting down and looking towards the direction where the photograph was captured. He adorns a long-sleeved shirt that has flowery patterns all over.

subject_terms_3: Portrait photography Lee, Chin Koon Lawyers
sgcool_label_text: This photograph shows Lee Chin Koon (1903-1997), father of Lee Kuan Yew (1923-2015) who was the first Prime Minster of Singapore. Born in Indonesia, he was the attorney to the Sugar King Oei Tiong Ham, and the first honorary secretary of the Chinese Swimming Club.

title_text: Photograph of Ong Tiang Wee
physical_appearance: The image shows a colour photograph. It is rectangular and it features an elderly man. He is dressed in a suit and tie. He is sitting on a chair and both of his hands are placed on his lap. He is looking towards the direction where the photograph was captured. The background shows a piano and a painting.
subject_terms_1: portraits men (male humans) businessmen
subject_terms_2: Colour photography Portrait photography Men Businessmen
sgcool_label_text: This photograph shows Ong Tiang Wee (T W Ong) posing seated before a painting. The son of Ong Boon Tat, a prominent Peranakan businessman and owner of New World Park, T W Ong was a barrister and partner of the law firm, Laycock and Ong at Malacca Street (1941-1986); Member of Singapore Municipal Commission (1934-1948); President of Anglo-Chinese School Old Boys' Association (1946-1947); President of Straits Chinese British Association and The Peranakan Association, Singapore (1948-1992); and Member of Board of Directors of Overseas Assurance Corporation Limited or OAC (1937-1996).

Studios were already established across the Strait Settlements and the Dutch East Indies by the 1840s and became increasingly prevalent in the 1850s. During the 1920s, Chinese-owned studios dominated the studio photography trade in Southeast Asia.

title_text: Photograph of Rabindranath Tagore and members of the Theosophic Society
physical_appearance: The image shows a black-and-white photograph. It is rectangular and it features a group of people. Most of them are sitting down while a few are standing at the back. subject_terms_1: group portraits poets societies religious orders
subject_terms_2: Black-and-white photography Portrait photography Portraits, Group Theosophical Society (Chennai, India) Tagore, Rabindranath, 1861-1941 Social groups Religious institutions
sgcool_label_text:
This photograph shows Rabindranath Tagore surrounded by members of the Theosophic Society in Singapore.

Rabindranath Tagore (1861 - 1941), Bengali writer, poet, composer, and painter and winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1913, visited Singapore in 1927. While in Singapore, he attended a reception given by the Straits Chinese at the Garden Club at Raffles Square, attended by prominent Peranakans including Dr Lim Boon Keng.

title_text: Album leaf with nine photographs
physical_appearance: The image shows nine black-and-white photographs. All of them are rectangular and seven of them are in landscape orientation while the other two are in portrait orientation. The photograph at the bottom right shows a person dressed in formal attire and holding a magician's hat and wand. Another photograph at the left hand side shows a woman reading and in the interior of a building. The settings of the other photographs are in this same room as well. An individual wearing a suit and tie, with a hat, is present in most of these photographs.

sgcool_label_text:
Pasted on the same album page, these nine photographs show various recurring figures in two rooms. 

With continuous improvement of camera technology, it became possible to take photographs outside a studio in the first decades of the 20th century. Many middle-class families collected photographs in albums as a way of documenting family life, or documentasi keluarga.

title_text: Misty Morning
physical_appearance: \The image shows a colour transparency. \"\"Kodachrome Transparency Processed by Kodak\"\" is stated at the top and inverted at the bottom. The trunk of two trees can be seen in the foreground of the image. \""

sgcool_label_text:
This kodachrome colour transparency shows a view of the Fullerton building taken from across the bay, framed by two trees. Inscribed on the verso are ‘Dr Cheah Seng Kee’, ‘99’ and ‘Misty Morning’.   
Kodachrome was a colour film introduced by the Eastman Kodak company in 1935. Its manufacture was discontinued in 2009, and processing ended in 2010.

In 1839 the French government made public technical information about the production of photographs, prompting a fervour for photographic technology which quickly spread from Europe to Southeast Asia. The first photography studios in the Dutch East Indies and the Straits Settlements were established in the first decades of the 1840s.

title_text: Pomegranate (A Blessing for Many Children) ???
physical_appearance: The image shows a painting. The painting is rectangular in shape and it is enclosed within a brown frame. There is a white border between the painting and the brown frame. The painting depicts pomegranate fruits hanging from branches, together with several pink flowers. There is a seal and signature at the lower left hand side of the painting. To the right, there is a vertical line of Chinese characters. There are two more seals alongside the vertical line of Chinese characters.
subject_terms_1: symbolism (artistic concept) pomegranate (fruit) fertility
subject_terms_2: Paintings Symbolism Pomegranate Fertility
sgcool_label_text:
Tan Keng Cheow (b.1907 – d.1972) was a widely known as a reputable calligrapher and founder of Bai Hong Lou Collection. He graduated from Jinan University and studied under artists Xie Gongzhan, Ye Gongchou, and Huang Binhong there. Thanks to his close friendship with his teacher Huang Binhong, Tan was able to amass a substantial collection of his works and thus naming it “Bai Hong Lou”, indicating it contains over 100 works by Huang Binhong. 

Tan arrived in Singapore in 1949, where he went on to serve as the principal of Tuan Mong High School and Chung Cheng High School. With his interest in Chinese ink paintings and calligraphy, Tan actively promoted the two, in particularly the latter. In memory of his tireless contribution, the Chinese Calligraphy Society of Singapore established the Tan Keng Cheow Calligraphy Fund in 1991 to award distinguished local calligraphers. 

Pomegranate (A Blessing for Many Children) was clearly a gift for the eldest son of a friend who is older than Tan, as we understands from the accompanying inscriptions. While one reading suggests that this friend may be Tan’s elder sister, it is quite common during that time to address someone who is familiar to you as a sibling. Based on the inscription, we know that this friend is named Pei Ying, while her son is named Rui Qing. 

The content of the painting suggests that it was a gift for Rui Qing’s wedding, as the fruit pomegranate is often used in Chinese ink paintings as a blessed symbol of having many children. This reason lies in the homophonic relation between the Chinese character for children or particularly refers to sons and seeds. Pomegranate is a fruit that has numerous seeds, and hence, became an auspicious symbol ‘to bear many children/sons’.

title_text: Pumpkin ???
physical_appearance: The images show a painting. The image on the right contains a close-up of the painting in question, while the image on the left hand side shows the same painting, with its frames and white border visible. Images of pumpkins, with leaves and thin branches, are depicted in the painting. There are two vertical lines of Chinese characters on the left hand side of the painting.
subject_terms_1: symbolism (artistic concept) squash (gourd)
subject_terms_2: Paintings Symbolism Motifs Squashes
sgcool_label_text:
Pumpkin is an exemplary work by Wu Tsai Yen that demonstrates his skilled execution and mastery of the finger-painting technique, which traces its practice to the Tang Dynasty. At the same time, this particular painting acts as a record of a visit Wu had. Shown in the inscription, on a day during the start of the winter season in 1964, Jiong Xi brought along some refined objects, most likely antiques or curiosities of some sort, during his meeting with Wu. It was an enjoyable time. 

While it is not known to us who Jiong Xi might be, the choice of material and motif of this painting emblems the precious moment of friendship and in the changing season. The orange colour of the pumpkin and its swaying leaves gives off a translucent gleamy effect on the paper, which carries specks of white, silver, and gold.

title_text: Endemic
physical_appearance: This installation art comprises of twelve mechanised copies of rare orchids. The orchids are yellow and red in colour, with green stems and leaves. The flowers are scattered and presented on a wooden table, with each flower mechanised to open and close.
subject_terms_1: symbolism (artistic concept) Orchis (genus) mechanization natural sciences cultural diffusion
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Symbolism Politics in art Orchis Mechanization Nature cultural diffusion
subject_terms_3: Installation art Nature and Environment Plants
sgcool_label_text: Endemic is an installation of twelve mechanised copies of rare orchids endemic to Mount Kinabalu in Sabah. Each orchid is constructed using materials common to silk/artificial flower fabrication, with petals mechanised to open and close slowly. As the artist puts it: “The re-creation of these endemic orchids into their synthetic twin allows for these endemic species to exist elsewhere, however unnatural it may be. They will be forced to become un-native; a forced migration, an especially apt metaphor as it relates to the indigenous communities within the region and the fluid presence of regional migrants. As each race grows generation by generation regardless of nationality, one’s own stake on ownership and native rights become blurred, and the idea of belonging to one group or one culture conversely becomes ever more crucial.” The botanical subject matter of Endemic – while demonstrating the artist’s interest in the history of natural science – also suggests broader thematics of colonialism, migration, authenticity, and the native and the indigenous. These concerns provide the critical contexts within which Chong’s intensive research and fieldwork in the area of Mt. Kinabalu’s endemic flora, and the history of Sabah’s indigenous communities which have long lived with these plants, are framed. This trajectory of Chong’s practice is further demonstration of not only a vitally important strand of art-making in the region – one that is engaged with cultural worlds and registers of knowledge removed from the metropolitan centres – but also one that is responsive to critical issues still impacting the cultural lifeworlds of Southeast Asia today.

title_text: Il Fait Bleu
physical_appearance: This is an image of a rectangular still from within a video clip. It features a sky that is filled with clouds. The clouds look to be overcast and there are different hues of dark blue as a result. There is a smattering of white patches that can be seen on the image still as well.
subject_terms_1: video recordings sky metaphor symbolism (artistic concept)
subject_terms_2: Video recordings Video art Sky Metaphor in art Symbolism La Rochelle (France)
sgcool_label_text:
Muhammad Akbar embarked on the Il Fait Bleu series while on residency at La Rochelle, France. The artist was struck by the shade of blue of the evening sky in France – a shade not altogether alien to him, given his background in video production. A blue field or screen suggests the backdrop against which all manner of special effects can be created; it is also what one sees when there is a lack of a signal. This ‘blank slate’ and suggested disconnection is an apt metaphor for the artist’s experience of being in a foreign locale. 

Il Fait Bleu is a video capturing the changing sky, from sunrise to sunset. It is a meditative piece, almost as if the artist was trying to clear his mind of preconceptions so as to fully immerse himself in his new environment. Hints of La Rochelle’s historic and classical architecture frame the patch of sky, giving the viewer the impression of standing in an enclosed courtyard while looking up at the heavens. Projected onto the ceiling, the work also calls to mind the tradition of European fresco painting.

title_text: Il Fait Bleu (Bandung Series)
physical_appearance: This installation depicts a large collection of images that are captured on paper. Each image on a piece of paper is a silhouette. The silhouettes of street lights, buildings, and signs can be discerned. The installation is illuminated by blue light. The images on paper are placed on three sides of the wall, surrounding a table and chair in the middle.
subject_terms_1: buildings (structures) cityscapes (representations) landscapes (representations) silhouettes
subject_terms_2: Installations (Art) Buildings Cityscapes Landscapes Silhouettes Bandung (Indonesia)
sgcool_label_text:
Muhammad Akbar embarked on the Il Fait Bleu series while on residency at La Rochelle, France. The artist was struck by the shade of blue of the evening sky in France – a shade not altogether alien to him, given his background in video production. A blue field or screen suggests the backdrop against which all manner of special effects can be created; it is also what one sees when there is a lack of a signal. This ‘blank slate’ and suggested disconnection is an apt metaphor for the artist’s experience of being in a foreign locale. 

Il Fait Bleu (Bandung Series) is a suite of works capturing the silhouettes of various buildings and landscapes in Bandung. It continues the series of the same name initiated in La Rochelle, where Akbar delighted in observing and documenting the forms of French classical architecture intermingled with newer, urban forms – a unique sight for the artist, more accustomed to seeing dilapidated or poorly maintained historic buildings in his hometown. With the Bandung series, Akbar comments on how Bandung (dubbed ‘The Paris of Java’) attempts to emulate an European ideal, in its architecture as well as culture, but falls short in several instances. The work captures a sense of the cityscape in Akbar’s hometown, suffused with a sense of homely familiarity as well as nostalgia.

physical_appearance: The image shows an armband. It is tubular in shape and floral designs in the form of gems line the surface of the ornament. subject_terms_1: goldwork (visual works) jewellery ornaments (object genre) allover patterns foliage (motif) flower (motif)
subject_terms_2: Armbands Gold jewellery Goldwork Motifs
sgcool_label_text:
The bazuband, the Persian name for an upper armband, is a classic form of Mughal jewellery worn by both men and women. Mounted in gold, this bazuband is set with white sapphires and enamelled on the reverse with polychrome floral designs. 

The gems are set on a blue ground in the kundan technique. The kundan-set is one of the oldest forms of jewel-making in India and involves layering narrow strips of gold (kundan) to form a solid wedge around the gemstone. Mughal jewellery was often a unique combination of kundan-set gems and enamelling. Traditional mughal jewellery is still made in this manner today.

These gemstones are silver in colour.
subject_terms_1: goldwork (visual works) jewellery ornaments (object genre) flower (motif) worn costume accessories
subject_terms_2: Buttons Gold jewellery Goldwork Motifs Dress accessories
sgcool_label_text:
This set of buttons are mounted in gold and set with flat-cut diamonds on a blue ground. The reverse sides are enamelled with polychrome floral designs. Blue buds with green leaves support several five-petalled, red flowers. 

The buttons were intended to be attached to front of a sherwani, a knee length coat commonly worn in India in the late 1800s. A western adaptation, the sherwani became associated with the image of an elite and educated Indian man. Decorated sherwanis would have gem-studded buttons like these attached to them.

sgcool_label_text:
Lim Cheng Hoe is attributed as a pioneering artists who specialized in the medium of watercolour. He was a founding member of Singapore Watercolour Society since its inauguration in 1969.

Lim Cheng Hoe regarded himself as a self-taught artist as his only exposure to art education was when he received art instruction from Richard Walker as a student at Raflles Institution. Nonetheless, he was respected by his peers and juniors for his mastery of the watercolour medium. Notable artists such as Ong Kim Seng and Gog Sing Hooi highly regarded him as their mentor.

While he exhibited in shows organised and/or facilitated by the Singapore Art Society, YMCA Art Club and Singapore Watercolour society, Lim never had a solo exhibition during his lifetime. His first solo exhibition was presented by the Singapore Watercolour Society in 1980 following his demise in 1979.

His paintings can be found in the collections of the National Heritage Board, Monetary Authority of Singapore, Balai Seni Visual Negara and other private organisations and individuals.

sgcool_label_text:
Tan Choon Ghee was born in Penang in 1930. He travelled to Singapore in the late 1940s to enrol at the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts (NAFA), graduating in 1951. He went on to further his studies at the Slade School of Fine Art in London from 1957-1959. He was subsequently awarded a scholarship from the German government to study art in Germany. During this time, he travelled extensively in Europe before returning to Penang to settle in 1969.

Tan is noted as being influenced by fellow Penang-based artist Kuo Ju Ping (1908-1966), who had graduated from NAFA earlier in 1940, as well as other masters of his favoured medium of watercolour, such as Yong Mun Sen (1896-1962) and Abdullah Ariff (1904-1962).

As a key second generation artist working primarily in the medium of watercolour, Tan is known for his deft application of ink and colour on paper. During his frequest visits to Singapore, he was drawn towards depicting the bustling activity of the Singapore port and the workmen and everyday characters that populated his scenes.

As a key second generation artist working primarily in the medium of watercolour, Tan is known for his deft application of ink and colour on paper. He is particularly known for his renderings of everyday scenes of Penang - capturing the bustling activity on the streets set against the distinctive architectural features of the many Chinese temples and shophouses that comprise Penang's landscape.
