Tan Choon Ghee was born in Penang in 1930. He travelled to Singapore in the late 1940s to enrol at the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts (NAFA), graduating in 1951. He went on to further his studies at the Slade School of Fine Art in London from 1957-1959. He was subsequently awarded a scholarship from the German government to study art in Germany. During this time, he travelled extensively in Europe before returning to Penang to settle in 1969.

Tan is noted as being influenced by fellow Penang-based artist Kuo Ju Ping (1908-1966), who had graduated from NAFA earlier in 1940, and masters of his favoured medium of watercolour, such as Yong Mun Sen (1896-1962) and Abdullah Ariff (1904-1962).

As a key second generation artist working primarily in the medium of watercolour, Tan is known for his deft application of watercolour and ink on paper. He painted a large number of works during his time spent in Europe, and was particularly inspired by the distinctive architectural features of Venice set against its iconic waterways that Tan would seek to capture repeatedly in his art.

title_text: Type 0 Civilization
materials_name: oil paint (paint) alkyd paint varnish aluminium alloy
physical_appearance: This is a painting. It is portrait in orientation. The painting is an abstract piece, featuring multicoloured, strong brushstrokes. There are no signatures seen on the painting.
subject_terms_1: abstract (general art genre) symbolism (artistic concept) energy
subject_terms_2: Rubens, Peter Paul, 1577-1640 Symbolism Humanity Apocalypse in art Energy
sgcool_label_text:
Working with the medium of painting for more than a decade now, Ruben Pang is a young Singaporean artist who has gained significant recognition for his abstract works. Paintings from Pang possess an almost musical quality – through his brushstrokes and erasure of the paint that has been applied, the colours presented upon his wood, canvas, or aluminum panels reflect the musical qualities of counterpoint and harmony, even as he delves into themes of apocalypse and chaos. 

Type 0 Civilisation is a work inspired from Pang’s travels to Europe where he encountered works of western masters, such as, John Martin, Gerhard Richter, and Peter Paul Rubens.  Especially drawn to apocalyptic scenes, Type 0 Civilisation is Ruben Pang’s re-capturing of Peter Paul Rubens’ iconic work, The Fall of The Damned. Executing the work intuitively, Pang sought to extract the essence of the work from classical painterly principles of light and shadow. Contrasting the deliberate and planned methodologies utilized by Rubens, Type 0 Civilisation, like numerous of Pang’s other works was executed in a style that can be best described as a stream of consciousness. With no pre-determined goal in mind, Pang’s brushstrokes are led by intuition, reflex, and accident. 

The work’s title references the expanded Kardashev scale, a system of measuring a civilization’s technical advancement based on its ability to harness and store energy. The original Kardashev scale ranges Type I, Type II, and Type III, each corresponding to planetary, stellar, and galactic civilisations; the expanded scale’s inclusion of a Type 0 references our planet’s current state of advancement. In this regard, one may perhaps draw a mirroring between the Archangel Michael’s casting of the fallen angels from the heavens and humanity’s current desire for technological advancement – where the unfettered thirst for power are paths leading to potential ruin.

column72:
Known for his watercolour landscapes and street scenes, Idris Mohamed Ali’s works reveal a strong understanding of colour, depth and realism. His paintings of old Singapore are especially important as they serve as a visual documentation of our national heritage. 
Started painting at 10 and not being able to afford formal art training, Idris learnt from books, observation, practice and a brief tutelage under pioneer Malay artist, S. Mahdar. In 1962, at the age of 18, this self-taught artist had his first group exhibition at the Singapore Victoria Memoral Hall.

title_text: Kampong Pasir Panjang
physical_appearance: This is a watercolour painting. It is landscape in orientation. It features a scene of Kampong Pasir Panjang. There is a roofed house on stilts in the center of the painting. It is surrounded by trees and vegetation. On the left, there is a rough silhoutte of a person at the front of the house. There is a signature in black on the bottom left, with a year indicated.

title_text: Large ewer and salver
physical_appearance: This is a set comprising of a large ewer and its accompanying salver. The ewer is of a globular form, sitting on a foot, with a thin neck rising towards a wide spout with straight edges. The slaver has raised edges. Both the ewer and the salver has engravings throughout the body, with a detailed foliate ground comprising of mythical beasts and animal motifs. There is an inscriptive band on the neck and rim of the ewer.
subject_terms_1: birds (motifs) scrolls (motifs) khamsa inscriptions Qur'ans
subject_terms_2: Ewers Salvers Motifs Islamic inscriptions
sgcool_label_text: Exquisite metalwork represents one of the more significant artistic traditions of the Muslim sultanates along the Deccan plateau in southern India, that emerged at the end of the 15th century. Owing to either descent from Persian adncestors or belief in the Shi’i faith, the Deccani courts showed an affinity with Persian artistic traditions and influences. The animal decorations on both the ewer and the salver allude to this Persian reference with the inclusion of mythical beasts such as senmurv, yali and dragons, with other animals such as elephants and hares. These motifs are set against a detailed foliate ground on the ewer. A hamsa, an aquatic bird with symbolic meaning derived from the Hindu tradition, is depicted on the centre of the salverr. The presence of Hindu and Persian elements reaffirms the association with the Deccani sultanates while the inscription bands in Arabic script bear verses from the Quran, surat al-Baqarah (Chapter 2: ‘The Heifer’) found mainly on the neck and rims of the ewer underscore the Muslim context.
